GIULIANI DISCOUNTS COLOR AS AN ISSUE
LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani, in an appeal largely directed at white New Yorkers, declared yesterday that yearnings for racial peace should not become the deciding factor in his campaign against David N. Dinkins, the city's first black major-party candidate for mayor.

Prison Accounts for Inmates
LEAD: Prison officials said today that they had accounted for all inmates at the riot-torn state prison here and attributed an earlier report that five prisoners were missing to paperwork errors.
Hundreds of inmates who slept outdoors for three days were returned to cells at the prison near Harrisburg, where scores of people were injured and half the buildings gutted or damaged by fires set Wednesday and Thursday in rioting that stemmed in part from overcrowding.


Earthquake Survivor's Car Is Lifted From Rubble of California Highway


Pork Bellies Rise the Limit As Export Optimism Grows
LEAD: Prices of pork belly futures soared the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday.
Analysts said the rise reflected anticipation of further export sales of the meat, which normally attracts little interest overseas.

A Low Bid By Fujitsu Stirs Protest
LEAD: Facing a rare Government rebuke and an official investigation, Japan's largest computer company, Fujitsu Ltd., said today that it would give up a contract to design a large computer system.


Japanese Are Concerned About Rockefeller Deal
LEAD: A Japanese developer's purchase of the majority interest in Rockefeller Center and other mid-Manhattan properties stirred concern today in business and political circles that were already apprehensive about the recent negative publicity over Japanese acquisitions in the United States.


U.N. Chief Favors Norwegian in Refugee Post
LEAD: The United Nations Secretary General has told representatives of member nations that he is ready to nominate a former Norwegian official as the next United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

Savings Institution Milked By Its Chief, Regulators Say
LEAD: A California savings and loan executive paid himself and family members $34 million from the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association in the three and a half years before its demise, Federal regulators told Congress today.


Vikings' Vaunted Defense Bows to Giants
LEAD: In his pregame speech to the Giants on Monday night, Coach Bill Parcells was a prophet.


Foes and Backers Begin Ads on Charter Revision
LEAD: A graphic television commercial showing several dozen worms crawling out of a can - and urging New Yorkers to prevent the can from being opened by voting against the proposed city charter - is to be broadcast beginning today by a coalition opposed to the revised charter.


Reebok Introduces Inflatable Shoe
LEAD: Reebok International Ltd. introduced a $170 pair of inflatable basketball shoes called the Pump and said it would spend $15 million on its advertising campaign, which it believes is the largest product introduction in the history of the footwear industry.
Reebok's chairman, Paul Fireman, said Reebok expects to begin shipping the model to retailers on Nov.


Prices of Farm Products Increase Slightly in Month
LEAD: The prices that farmers received for raw products rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in October from September levels, leaving the monthly index seven-tenths of 1 percent higher than in October 1988.

Stock Trading Rules to Be Studied
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange plans to re-examine its rules for coordinated halts in trading in the market, known as circuit breakers, John J. Phelan Jr., its chairman, said yesterday.


Plan Canceled For New Courts In Manhattan
LEAD: After three years of feuding, New York State and New York City have given up on plans to convert a state-owned building in lower Manhattan to new court space, city and state officials said today.


Warner Brothers Plans To Distribute 'Roger'
LEAD: ''Roger and Me,'' the darkly comic documentary film about unemployment in Flint, Mich., will be commercially distributed by Warner Brothers, the film company said Monday.


67 Arrested In Rampages On Halloween
LEAD: More than 100 youths moving in packs rampaged through parts of Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday, attacking pedestrians, robbing stores, and slashing one man with a knife, the police said.

Cleaning the Soil After a Gasoline Leak
LEAD: There are an estimated two million underground gasoline tanks in this country, at service stations and industrial plants, and at least a quarter of them are thought to be leaking.
Owners of these sites are obliged to clean up contaminated soil to prevent gasoline from fouling supplies of drinking water.


Utility in Florida Pleads Guilty in Political Contributions
LEAD: The Gulf Power Company, the major supplier of electricity in northwestern Florida, pleaded guilty today to conspiring to make secret illegal campaign contributions to political candidates.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about drug education programs misstated the amount spent by New York City annually on drug education.
It is $34.5 million, not $34.5 billion.

LEAD: For 10 years, Boston's dining scene has been stirring to life.
The city's Yankee clubs and old-style French restaurants got a wake-up call from nouvelle cuisine when L'Espalier opened in 1979.

A West African Land's New Name Brings It Little Relief From Old Troubles
LEAD: The dust and the poverty in this West African nation are not much different from when the country was called Upper Volta, but the political climate is changing, growing more arbitrary, as Capt.
Blaise Compaore consolidates the power he seized with violence two years ago.

Review/Music; 2 Schools of Country, at Marlboro Festival
LEAD: The Marlboro Country Music Festival on Sunday night at Madison Square Garden offered two visions of country music.
The first, represented by Ricky Van Shelton, Merle Haggard and George Strait, is deep in the honky-tonk tradition, part of the new traditionalist movement that looks to the hard-rocking country stars of the past for their legitimacy.

LEAD: The Soviet violinist and conductor Vladimir Spivakov formed the Moscow Virtuosi in 1979, drawing on competition winners and first chair players from several Soviet orchestras to form an elite chamber orchestra.

Restraint From Calvin Klein, Youthful Chic From Ellis
LEAD: CALVIN KLEIN, who has been known for paring his clothes to the bare minimum, got to the roots this time.
Marc Jacobs, who has had a difficult time filling the shoes of the late Perry Ellis, has solved the problem by being himself.
Arnold Scaasi, who always claims he wants nothing more than to make pretty dresses, succeeded in doing just that.


Journalist's Role for Charity Questioned
LEAD: Albert R. Hunt, the Washington bureau chief of The Wall Street Journal, has come under criticism from members of his staff for his role in a recent charity fund-raising event that included soliciting Washington lobbyists to buy tickets.


Findings Suggest Jet's Flaw Was Visible Before Crash
LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board released metallurgical findings today that raise the possibility a small crack that led to the United Airlines DC-10 crash here in July may have been detectable before the accident.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Oct. 21 about the Polish government in exile in London mistranslated a Latin inscription on a bust of Gen.
Jozef Pilsudski.
The inscription, ''Summus Polonorum Dux,'' means ''Supreme Leader of the Poles.''

K. E. Beer Dies at 80; International Publisher
LEAD: Kenneth E. Beer, founder in 1944 of the Manhattan Publishing Company, which specialized in publishing international documents, died of a stroke Monday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y.


Corrections

The programs listed will be shown on Channel 7 during those hours tonight.


House Would Extend Smoking Ban on U.S. Flights
LEAD: The House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a Senate-House conference agreement to ban smoking on all commercial airline flights within the continental United States and on most flights to Alaska and Hawaii.
Approval came on a voice vote.
The ban was part of a compromise measure that would provide $12 billion for transportation programs for the fiscal year that began Oct.


Negative Race Disgusts Many Voters in New Jersey
LEAD: The negative campaigning by the candidates for governor of New Jersey is troubling many people who are expected to vote on Nov. 7.


Pleats? Cuddly Cardigans? Brooks Brothers Unbuttons
LEAD: Brooks Brothers, the staid, sedate, venerable, buttoned-down and buttoned-up clothing retailer, is taking the first step toward loosening its rep tie and cruising into the 90's.
A $7 million facelift has added shiny escalators and bright lights to its flagship Madison Avenue store at 44th Street.


WINE TALK
LEAD: IN the dim recesses of the past I worked for a newspaper that prided itself on its ability to ''repackage the product.'' It worked something like this: a reporter covering some event would file a bulletin for the company's news service, then return to the office and write up the same event for the next day's paper.

The Only Reasonable Charter Choice
LEAD: New Yorkers will vote next Tuesday on a dramatic revision of their constitution, the City Charter.
It's a conscientious, reasonable proposal that deserves support.
Besides, there isn't much choice.


Fatal Heart Attack at Opera
LEAD: A 70-year-old man suffered a fatal heart attack last night at the Metropolitan Opera at Lincoln Center during a performance of Verdi's ''La Traviata,'' officials said.
The man, Samuel Weiss, of 351 East 84th Street, collapsed in his seat at 9:22 P.M.
Mr.
Weiss regained a pulse after several physicians in the audience administered cardio-pulmonary resuscitation for about 20 minutes, officials said, but was pronounced dead shortly after being taken to Roosevelt Hospital.

World Series Fails In ABC's Ratings
LEAD: Low ratings and few games combined to make the World Series, which ended with the fourth game on Saturday, a financial disappointment for ABC and a ratings boon for the competition.
The series had an average rating of 16.4 and about a third of the audience, far below last year's scores, when NBC's broadcasts of the games averaged a 23.9 rating and 39 percent of the audience.

Israel Spira, 99, Leader of Bluzhov Hasidim
LEAD: Rabbi Israel Spira, who as the Grand Rabbi of Bluzhov was the spiritual leader of a Hasidic branch in Brooklyn and Israel, died yesterday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn.
He was 99 years old and lived in Brooklyn's Borough Park section, where his synagogue was situated.


Injury Is Not Likely to Idle Simms
LEAD: Phil Simms was limping today and his sprained right ankle was swollen.
Coach Bill Parcells, however, gave his starting quarterback ''a pretty good chance to play'' Sunday against the Cardinals in Phoenix, although he said Simms would miss practice Wednesday.


Corrections
LEAD: Picture captions in some copies yesterday about Republican women who support abortion rights reversed the identities of the two women at the right.
At the top was Representative Olympia Snowe; at the bottom, Representative Claudine Schneider.

Hydrogen: Is It the Clean Fuel of the Future?
LEAD: When all the coal, natural gas and oil have been burned, or the world does not dare burn any more because of global warming, what will be used for fuel, especially for cars, trucks and buses?


Cubs' Zimmer Is Honored
LEAD: Don Zimmer, a manager of three other teams in the major leagues before winning his first title this season with the Chicago Cubs, was named National League manager of the year yesterday, collecting 23 of 24 first-place votes.


Needle Attacks Spreading Fear on West Side
LEAD: Many women on the Upper West Side said yesterday that they were staying home or asking friends to escort them on the street because of a recent series of attacks in which women were jabbed with needles or pins.

LEAD: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week ended yesterday.

LEAD: Criminal charges against a youth arrested in the beating and rape of a jogger in Central Park were dismissed yesterday, and a lawyer for the one of the six remaining defendants said he expected that the youth would become an important witness for the prosecution.

New Quake in Armenia
LEAD: An earthquake shook the southern Soviet republic of Armenia today, but no casualties or damage were reported, Tass said.
The press agency said the epicenter of the earthquake, which measured between 5 and 5.5 on the Soviet 12-point scale, was near the town of Gukasyan, in the same area hit by a catastrophic quake last Dec.

Ruling on Eastern
LEAD: An arbitrator ruled that Eastern Airlines must give its pilots a retroactive pay raise of 8 percent stemming from a dispute in 1986, said James L. Lindsey, a lawyer for the pilots' union.
Unless changed, the decision could cost Eastern about $65 million, which may not be paid until Eastern emerges from bankruptcy, said Robin M.


Lessons
LEAD: Prophets frequently go without honor in their own country.
So can educational innovators in their own school districts.

Pregnancy as Punishment
LEAD: Dan C. Rasmussen is a judge of the Pasco County Court in Florida.
But by his lights he is also a jurist whose judgment about reproductive freedom is superior to that of the United States Supreme Court, and an adoption counselor besides.


New Corporate Effort to Aid Innovative Schools
LEAD: Officials of RJR Nabisco Inc., the huge food and tobacco company, said yesterday that the company's foundation would spend $30 million to spur innovative and sometimes risky programs in schools throughout the United States.

Producer Seeks Control of Rally's
LEAD: A group of dissident directors led by Burt Sugarman, the Hollywood producer and takeover specialist, said it had formally begun a consent solicitation to gain control of the board of Rally's Inc., a fast food concern based in Louisville, Ky.
Mr.
Sugerman, who controls 45.2 percent of the company, has filed for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to raise his stake to more than 50 percent.

LEAD: When Katherine Preonas was a young girl shopping with her mother in downtown Albuquerque, she was often criticized for speaking bad Spanish.
In fact, she was speaking fluent Greek.

St. Albans Sees Itself As a Bastion For Dinkins
LEAD: In St.
Albans, tidy houses stand sedate on trim lawns under the leafy plane trees of the side streets.
Blocks away, or just around a corner, boarded-up stores and littered lots are scattered between thriving businesses.

LEAD: The dollar ended higher against leading currencies in quiet trading yesterday.


Iran-Contra Judge Planning to See If 2 Prosecutors Know Too Much
LEAD: The Federal district judge in the case of John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, today ordered an unusual hearing in which two prosecution lawyers are expected to testify about their knowledge of Mr.
Poindexter's testimony to the Iran-contra Congressional committees.


William W. Laird, a Financial Adviser, 79
LEAD: William Winder Laird, a financial adviser, philanthropist and a former director of E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company, died Oct. 20 at his home in Wilmington, Del.
He was 79 years old.

Leonard Cohen, Sports Reporter, 87
LEAD: Leonard Cohen, who worked for 48 years as a reporter, feature writer, columnist and sports editor for The New York Post, died on Monday of a heart attack in Lauderdale Lakes, Fla., where he had lived since his retirement in 1974.
He was 87 years old.


Run for the Money Doesn't Always Pay
LEAD: By finishing first in the Los Angeles Marathon seven months ago, Art Boileau of Canada and Zoya Ivanova of the Soviet Union each won $26,385 and a Mercedes-Benz worth more than $30,000.
Those same prizes are available to the first-place finishers Sunday in the New York City Marathon, and if Boileau and Ivanova are first again, they would qualify for a $300,000 bonus for winning both races.


Bausch &amp; Lomb At Sales Peak
LEAD: Bausch &amp; Lomb Inc. said it would give its employees a day off to celebrate passing the $1 billion sales level.
Dec. 22 will be a paid holiday for the eye and health care company's 12,400 employees worldwide.
The company achieved $1 billion in sales for 1989 for the first time in its history last week.


Thatcher Urged to Tie Pound to Other Currencies
LEAD: Nigel Lawson, who resigned as Chancellor of the Exchequer last week, challenged Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher openly today to swallow British national pride and let the pound be tied more closely to the other currencies of the European Community as soon as possible.


First Shipment of U.S. Aid Arrives in Poland


U.S. Issues Finish Little Changed
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were unchanged to slightly higher in seesaw trading yesterday as dealers sifted through conflicting reports on the economy.


Palestinian Suicide Bombing Wounds 3 on an Israeli Boat
LEAD: A Palestinian guerrilla blew up his booby-trapped fishing boat in a suicide attack on an Israeli patrol boat on Monday night, killing himself and wounding three Israeli soldiers, the Israeli military reported today.

LEAD: The number of baseball players earning $2 million or more continued to climb this year, to a record 20, but two even more intriguing economic developments involved the average team salaries of the Mets and the Yankees.

Bombing at Salvadoran Leftists' Office Kills Eight
LEAD: Eight people, including one of El Salvador's most outspoken leftist organizers, were killed today and 35 others injured when a bomb exploded in the headquarters of a labor confederation here.

Faulty Records Costing Dinkins Matching Funds
LEAD: David N. Dinkins's mayoral campaign yesterday was denied, at least temporarily, $95,142 in public funds by the city's Campaign Finance Board because of inadequate accounting of contributions.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: THE sweet-hot complexity of a well-made curry can be wonderfully invigorating.
The term curry is really a catchall Anglicism that means little to Indian cooks.
It is a word that British colonials applied to all the spice mixtures typically found in Indian cooking.
The equivalent would be calling all French sauces hollandaise.

Review/Television; Portrait of a Missouri Artist: 'Hard-Drinking Tough Guy'
LEAD: Critics may disagree on the value of Thomas Hart Benton's paintings, but Ken Burns's illuminating documentary about the Missouri artist leaves no doubt that his life is worth a look. ''Thomas Hart Benton,'' at 9 P.M. on Channel 13 and 10 P.M. on Channel 49, presents the muralist as a ''hard-drinking tough guy who happened to be an artist'' and ''a sophisticate who pretended to be simple.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the purchase of a controlling interest in the Sansui Electric Company by Polly Peck International P.L.C. referred to the deal incorrectly.
It was not the first foreign purchase of a Japanese company traded on the Tokyo Stock Exchange; in 1983 Merck &amp; Company acquired control of the Banyu Pharmaceutical Company.


Jesuits Discuss Future 'Age of Laity' at Their Colleges
LEAD: The presidents of the nation's 28 Jesuit colleges and universities met at Fordham University last week to discuss the future of their institutions in the face of a dramatic decline in the number of Jesuit priests.

Easter at the Music Hall
LEAD: For the first time in 11 years a live Easter show, featuring the Rockettes, is to be presented next year at Radio City Music Hall.
Beginning today, tickets are on sale for the show, called ''Easter Extravaganza,'' which is to run from April 11 to April 18.
Tickets are $27 and $30.
Information: 247-4777.


Charlotte Neuville Softens the Edges
LEAD:  CHARLOTTE NEUVILLE has pared down her act for spring but retained the essence of her style.
While the models look less androgynous - the oversize ''boyfriend'' jacket has been cut down to a woman's size - the tailoring is still impeccable.

Gen-Probe Agrees To Chugai Offer
LEAD: Gen-Probe Inc., a medical products company based in San Diego, agreed to be acquired by the Chugai Pharmaceutical Company of Japan for $6.25 a share, or about $100 million.
Gen-Probe's stock soared $2.75 a share today, to $6, in over-the-counter trading.
Its 84.6 percent rise was the best of the day.

LEAD: *
Seiniger Advertising, a Los Angeles-based motion picture agency acquired last month by the WPP Group, has established a New York office at the headquarters of Ogilvy &amp; Mather, another WPP holding.


METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD: RALPH W. FLAX of Southbury, Conn., wrote back to Northeast Utilities, his local energy supplier, that yes, he would be interested in learning more about a plan to lower hot-water rates.

Roy Shuts Out the Faltering Islanders
LEAD: If the Islanders' fans look hard enough, they might find a few positive points to stress about their team's 3-0 loss to the Montreal Canadiens tonight at the Nassau Coliseum.
For instance: The Islanders never stopped trying, skating hard toward the Montreal end until the final buzzer.

Judge Overturns Chicago Statute on Flag
LEAD: A Cook County Circuit Court judge ruled today that a Chicago ordinance banning flag desecration violates the free speech provisions of the Constitution and cannot be used to prosecute artists whose works make use of the flag.

Plan of Unocal And Venezuela
LEAD: The Unocal Corporation said it would spin off nearly all its operations in the Middle West, including an oil refinery and several hundred service stations, into a joint venture with the Venezuelan state oil company.


Who Makes What in the Major Leagues
LEAD: The 1989 baseball incomes for players who were on major league rosters or the disabled list Aug. 31.
The figures were obtained from management and player sources and include base salary, pro-rated share of signing bonus, other guaranteed money (such as payment for trades), bonuses earned during the season and all post-season awards except for most valuable player and Cy Young awards, which have not been determined.


Stadium Plan May Fall Victim to Quake
LEAD: An 85-year-old survivor of the 1906 earthquake is making an impassioned plea on the radio here that voters approve a ballot measure to allow construction of a new baseball stadium that would keep the Giants in San Francisco.

LEAD: Workers searching the wreckage of Interstate 880, where more than a mile of roadway collapsed in the earthquake two weeks ago, found the bodies of a woman and a man in separate vehicles, a police spokesman said today.

Accounting Rule Dispute
LEAD: Upset by a decision that would limit the jurisdiction of the Governmental Accounting Standards Board, nine organizations representing state and local government officials said yesterday that they would withdraw their financial support from the board and start their own rule-making body.


Keeping Tabs on the Mega-Shoppers
LEAD: Warren E. Norquist may not cut much of a figure at the local mall, but he was clearly born to shop.
As worldwide director of purchasing and materials management for the Polaroid Corporation here, he spends $900 million a year, nearly half the money taken in by the large camera, film and electronics company, with the energy and sophistication of a teen-ager buying clothes or videotapes.

Danville, Vt.
LEAD: WHEN is a cranberry not a cranberry?
When it is a high-bush cranberry (Vibernum trilobum), also known as the American cranberry bush.
Botanically speaking, it is not a cranberry at all but a member of the honeysuckle family.
But whatever botanists say, Christine Wakefield insists that the translucent scarlet berries she picks each fall make a jelly whose flavor is ''more cranberry than cranberries.

Florio, Acting Assured, Rehashes Old Themes
LEAD: Visiting with students and elderly voters today, Representative James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate for governor, sounded a reprise of some of the main themes of his campaign: the need to fight drugs and crime and to provide opportunity to all New Jerseyans.


In the Alphabet Soup of Life, Can an X, Y or Z Rise to the Top?
LEAD: IS alphabet destiny?
Are those of us who spent our youth languishing at the rear desks assigned to the W's, consorting with the V's and the XYZ's - the steerage of the address book - doomed to a life as also-rans?
Do Xaviers crave forever to be Atwaters, and Adamses never want to try the view from the Zabriskie heights at the back of the classroom?

Many Japanese Wary On Mitsubishi U.S. Deal
LEAD: During the last few years, as Japan's larger real estate companies poured billions of dollars into overseas investments, the prestigious Mitsubishi Estate Company stood apart, being content to collect rents from its vast holdings at home and to watch their value soar.


Robert Louis Hodapp, Bishop, 79
LEAD: Bishop Robert Louis Hodapp, a former bishop of Belize and a Roman Catholic missionary in that country for nearly 50 years, died on Thursday.
He was 79 years old.

LEAD: Wayne Gretzky scored three goals and had three assists in his first showdown of the season with Pittsburgh's slumping Mario Lemieux, and Bernie Nicholls had two goals and three assists tonight as the Los Angeles Kings beat the Penguins, 8-4.

Dutton's Adult Unit to Be Absorbed
LEAD: Citing ''several years of mounting losses,'' Penguin USA said yesterday that it would no longer operate as a separate unit the adult publishing division of E. P. Dutton, the 137-year-old publishing house that it acquired two years ago.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
American Express Travel Related Services Co. promoted Bonnie J. Stedt to executive vice president of human resources.


Seafaring Summitry's Lore
LEAD: Since the beginning of World War II, only one American President, Franklin D. Roosevelt, has held an international conference at sea, and Roosevelt held two of them.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Omnicom Earnings Up
LEAD: The Omnicom Group said its earnings rose by 54 percent, to $5.6 million, in the third quarter of this year, from $3.6 million in the period last year.
Its earnings per share jumped by 47 percent, to 22 cents a share, from 15 cents a share in 1988.
For the first nine months of 1989, Omnicom's net income grew by 26 percent, to $29.6 million, from $23.5 million.

LEAD: AS much as food is a part of life, in many cultures it is also essential to the rituals of death and mourning.

FOOD NOTES
LEAD:  Pre-Marathon Pasta On Saturday evening, more than 10,000 participants in the New York City Marathon are expected to do their carbo-loading at Tavern on the Green at the annual pasta party sponsored by Ronzoni Foods Corporation.
They will dine on three dishes selected from more than 60 recipes submitted by restaurants last week in three categories: traditional, cold salad and vegetarian.

A Director's Race With AIDS Ends Before His Movie Opens
LEAD: When the director Howard Brookner died of AIDS on April 27, he left two statements.
The first was 8,100 feet of celluloid called ''The Bloodhounds of Broadway,'' starring Madonna, Matt Dillon, Jennifer Grey and Randy Quaid.
The second, written in the sardonic manner in which he handled his illness, was taped to his refrigerator during the last year of his life: ''There's so much beauty in the world.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in SportsMonday this week about the Oakland Athletics' domination of the World Series gave incorrect run totals for 1928.
In that Series, the New York Yankees outscored the St.
Louis Cardinals in four games by 27-10, not 30-10.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of All Saints' Day, alternate-side parking rules are suspended today.
Other regulations remain in effect.

LEAD: Shandwick P.L.C. yesterday continued its policy of growth by acquisition, buying two agencies on opposite sides of the globe.

Armstrong Selling Carpet Business
LEAD: Armstrong World Industries agreed in principle to sell its carpet operations to Shaw Industries for an undisclosed amount of cash.
Armstrong said it was divesting the carpet business because the segment did not generate adequate returns.
In 1988, the business contributed $368.3 million to the company's worldwide sales of $2.68 billion.


Ford Completes Associates Deal
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company completed a $3.35 billion acquisition of the Associates First Capital Corporation from Paramount Communications Inc.
Ford said Dallas-based Associates, the nation's third-largest independent finance company based on total assets, would operate as an independent affiliate in the Ford Financial Services Group.


Whittaker Sells A Plastics Unit
LEAD: The Whittaker Corporation said it had sold its Duall/Wind plastic extrusion business to the American Filtrona Corporation, Richmond, for an undisclosed price.
The sale is part of a series of divestitures Whittaker has made under a plan made in response to an unwelcome takeover attempt.

Reviews/Theater; A New, Nonviolent Ending for 'Lisbon Traviata'
LEAD: With his new, nonviolent ending to ''The Lisbon Traviata,'' Terrence McNally recognizes that life is not grand opera.
In the final scene, Anthony Heald is called on to internalize his anguish over his lover's departure rather than to melodramatize it as he did in the earlier version of the play.
In the end, he is alone, without life support, a victim of self-abandonment.

Senna Fined $100,000
LEAD: Ayrton Senna, the defending world driving champion, was fined $100,000 yesterday by an auto racing tribunal, which rejected an appeal of the Brazilian's disqualification in the Japanese Grand Prix.
With only the Australian Grand Prix left on the 1989 schedule, the ruling assured that the Formula One driving title would go to Alain Prost of France, a teammate of Senna on the McLaren-Honda team.

Soviet Managers in U.S.
LEAD: Sixteen Soviet executives began learning capitalist skills this week at a management training program at Northeastern University.
During the three-and-a-half-month program, billed as the first of its kind, the 16 will be exposed to American business management methods in areas like international marketing, business strategy, the art of negotiation and management of executive stress.





Bridge
LEAD: This year, as usual, will be almost a year long.
The Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship will conclude the 1988-89 season tonight two weeks before the entries close for the new season.


Swedish Diary Is Reported to Link Gandhi Personally to Arms Graft
LEAD: Indian newspapers published excerpts today from a document that said Prime Minister Rajiv Ganhi had been personally involved in a billion dollar arms scandal.


A Reading for AIDS
LEAD: Colleen Dewhurst, Charles Busch, Brad Davis and D. W. Moffet will be featured in a special reading of Larry Kramer's play ''The Normal Heart'' on Nov. 13 at 7:30 P.M. at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place.
Proceeds will benefit the AIDS Treatment Registry, a service organization that provides information on experimental drugs.


'Interim' Sessions
LEAD: Saying he does not want to ''miss something'' in the rapidly shifting terrain of East-West relations, President Bush announced today that he would meet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in December for two days of unstructured talks.


Judson Branch, 82; Led Allstate
LEAD: Judson B. Branch, former chairman of the Allstate Insurance Companies, died Monday at Glenbrook Hospital in Glenview, Ill.
He was 82 years old and lived in Northfield, Ill.

Ellen L. Buell, 84, a Times Editor
LEAD: Ellen Lewis Buell Cash, former children's books editor of The New York Times Book Review, died yesterday in Chattanooga, Tenn.

9 Guards Plead Not Guilty In Assaults at Meadowlands
LEAD: Nine security guards at the Meadowlands Sports Complex were arraigned today on charges of assaulting people during and after Grateful Dead concerts two weeks ago.


Anne Frank Benefactor Hailed
LEAD: West Germany has awarded its highest civilian medal to a Dutch woman who hid Anne Frank from the Nazis, the West German Embassy said today.
The woman, Miep Gies, is being given the Federal Cross of Merit First Class for her ''crucial role'' in hiding Miss Frank and her family, the embassy said.

Thomas Will Try a Comeback
LEAD: Kurt Thomas, the United States' greatest male gymnast, who is nine years removed from his last competitive back handspring, is trying to make a comeback at the age of 33.
He wants to compete in the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, where he debuted his trademark ''flair'' move on the pommel horse 14 years ago.


About New York; A Fishy Epic: Not-So-Old Man Versus the Sea
LEAD: There was a point, late in his career, when people thought Hemingway might be slipping.
Then he wrote ''The Old Man and the Sea'' and won the Nobel Prize for literature.
The book's cover says the story of an elderly man's fight with a big fish has ''the simplicity of a fable, the significance of a parable and the drama of an epic.


A Stevenson Tale Of a Plotting Heiress Is Found and Printed
LEAD: One hundred years ago, Robert Louis Stevenson, the Scottish author of ''Treasure Island,'' ''Kidnapped'' and ''Dr.
Jekyll and Mr.
Hyde,'' sailed from Hawaii to Samoa, where he would spend the last five years of his life.
He was accompanied by his American wife, Fanny, and his stepson, Lloyd Osbourne.

Currents; At a San Antonio Theater, The Forecast Is Cloudy
LEAD: WHEN it opened its doors 60 years ago, the Majestic Theater in San Antonio was one of the theater architect John Eberson's most enthralling picture palaces.
Built in Moorish and Spanish Revival style, the theater epitomized Hollywood magic, with small twinkling bulbs for stars, lights that simulated sunrise and sunset, and a machine that wafted clouds across a Mediterranean-blue ceiling.

Tokyo Journal; Prime Minister's House: A Most Unstately Home
LEAD: The first crisis to face the new Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu last summer started in the hallway around the corner from his office here, in an aging, squat building near Parliament that one would pass by without noticing if it was not surrounded by guards.

STUDY CITES LACK IN PRENATAL CARE
LEAD: A newly released study of prenatal health care in the United States has found that from 1984 through 1986, 16 percent of American women who gave birth each year had inadequate prenatal care, either by starting care in the fifth month of pregnancy or later, or by making fewer than half the recommended number of visits to the doctor.


New Continental Head Will Not Shift Strategy
LEAD: Mickey P. Foret, the new president of Continental Airlines, has no plans to make any big changes at the airline, which has begun to show signs of turning around.

LEAD: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that it had been notified that Reliance Group Holdings Inc. would seek clearance from the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department to buy more than 15 percent of UAL's stock.

Asylum for Vietnamese Refugee
LEAD: A Vietnamese man who escaped his homeland by riding for two days on the rudder housing of a Cypriot tanker that docked here Monday has been granted temporary asylum in the United States.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in the Media Business pages on Friday about The New York Post's decision to drop its Sunday paper referred incorrectly to the resignation of Peter O. Price, who had been publisher.
His departure was not linked to problems with the Sunday paper and he was not removed from the job; he resigned in April to help start The National, a daily sports newspaper that is to begin publication soon.

LEAD: Seeking to regain a tactical advantage in his fight for a cut in the capital gains tax, President Bush is seriously considering proposals to make permanent the $16 billion in automatic spending cuts that took effect on Oct. 16, Republican Congressional leaders said today.

The move, when it is officially made, would idle Vandeweghe for a minimum of five games, until at least the Nov. 14 game against the Trail Blazers in Portland, Ore.


Rev. Francis Litz, 91; Led Canonizing Effort
LEAD: The Rev.
Francis J. Litz, whose efforts led to the canonization of St.
John Neumann, died Sunday, from complications of a stroke, at a health care center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.
He was 91 years old.
Father Litz took up the cause of St.
John Neumann, Philadelphia's fourth Roman Catholic bishop, in 1956 and served for more than 20 years as vice postulator for his canonization.

But until this week Shaun had a problem shared by thousands of other New York City pupils: no good school library in which to find his favorite books.

75 Flights Added By Eastern Air
LEAD: Eastern Airlines added 75 flights, increasing its schedule to 775 daily.
The company resumed service to five Caribbean destinations and added nonstop flights from Miami to Los Angeles, San Francisco, Toronto, Chicago, Newark and other cities.
Eastern added 29 daily departures from its Miami hub, giving it 65 flights from there.

Close to Home
LEAD: SEVERAL years ago a man was murdered out in Utah.
His demise occasioned two books and from them two television dramas.
It also sold a lot of paperbacks.
I read both books, saw both television dramas and from this total immersion in his life and death retain only one thing.
He loved meat loaf, ate it every day in fact.

Reviews/Music; Frankfurt Orchestra, Led by Eliahu Inbal
LEAD: In his 15 years as music director of the Frankfurt Radio Symphony Orchestra, the Israeli conductor Eliahu Inbal has made an extensive series of recordings that have brought his ensemble some international attention.

Reviews/Music; 'Babi Yar' Symphony in Its Directness and Simplicity
LEAD: Shostakovich's Symphony No. 13 (''Babi Yar'') is 17 years old, but it seems as fresh as today's front page.
The five-section work, less a symphony than a dramatic cantata or oratorio, foreshadowed with uncanny accuracy the changes that were about to shake Soviet society.
Listening to the Philadelphia Orchestra's performance at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, one was struck anew by the prophetic directness of the Yevgeny Yevtushenko texts and the bardic simplicity of the music that Shostakovich devised to illustrate them.


Review/Theater; Filling the Stage With a One-Man 'Tempest'

Curchack plays all the roles and assumes all directorial and scenic responsibility, opened Tuesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of the Next


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press in late editions on Saturday (reprinted in some copies on Sunday about a Vermont farm where marijuana was found growing last year misstated the number of plants involved. The state police found 12 plants, not 200, on the farm, owned by Robert Machin and Joann Liddell.

Home Improvement
LEAD: ALUMINUM combination storm windows, consisting of upper and lower glass panes and a screen, are ordinary features on many homes.
Installation is usually not too difficult.
To find the size you need, measure the length and width of the window frame on the outside.
If the window has blind stops - strips of molding around the perimeter that hold the upper sash in place - select storm windows that can be set into the opening and fastened to the stops.

LEAD: Senior officials of the United States Treasury Department and Japan's Finance Ministry will meet next Wednesday in Washington to discuss broad financial market issues, a ministry official said today.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Moldy Shingles  Q. The peaked roof of my country house is covered with asphalt shingles that have a sand finish.
On the shady side a gray-green mold or fungus is growing on the shingles.
I sprayed it with a fungicide that I use on my roses, but it did not seem to help.
Can this moss damage the roof, and how can I get rid of it?

Milan Huebl, 62, Head Of '68 Prague College
LEAD: Milan Huebl, who headed Czechoslovakia's Communist Party Academy in the 1968 reform period known as the Prague Spring and who later joined the independent human rights group Charter 77, was found dead in a Prague building on Saturday.
He was 62 years old.
The cause of his death was unknown.
Mr.
Huebl was a major ideologist behind the liberalization started by the Czechoslovak leader, Alexander Dubcek, before the Prague Spring was crushed by a Soviet-led invasion.

LEAD: Federal officials are investigating the manufacturer of a monitor intended to prevent crib deaths.

South Korea Surplus
LEAD: The Bank of Korea said Monday that September's current account, which covers trade in goods and services, produced a surplus of $714 million, the biggest monthly surplus in 1989, after a shortfall of $79 million in August.
The central bank said that according to provisional figures, exports grew 4.5 percent, to $44.5 billion, in the first nine months of this year from the corresponding 1988 period.

LEAD: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari said today that Mexico is still waiting for most of its commercial bank creditors to decide how they plan to carry out July's historic debt reduction agreement, and he also expressed concern that the Mexican economy may be overheating.

Critic's Notebook; The Basic Crookedness of Docudramas
LEAD: Let me make one thing perfectly clear: the only good docudrama is an unproduced docudrama - even if it's about Richard M. Nixon.
ABC's three-hour version of ''The Final Days,'' based on Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein's version of the collapse of the Nixon Administration, is but the latest appearance of a form that seems designed to do to television journalism what Hurricane Hugo did to South Carolina.

LEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., a unit of the American Express Company, has become the latest Wall Street firm to discontinue index arbitrage.

LEAD: Hundreds of East Germans swarmed to the West German Embassy here today just hours after East Germany lifted a travel ban, and the official East German press agency said as many as 8,000 had crossed into Czechoslovakia.


Currents; A Museum For Lovers Of Modern Furniture
LEAD: QUIETLY and without fanfare, the Swiss-born Rolf Fehlbaum, director of the Vitra furniture company in Basel, has spent six years amassing one of the premier collections of modern furniture in the world.
With Alexander von Vegesack (who sold large parts of his collection to Mr. Fehlbaum) as curator, the Vitra Design Foundation has acquired some 250 pieces from the estate of the late Charles Eames, the personal library of George Nelson and the private collection of the Danish designer Verner

LEAD: A major earthquake registering 7.1 on the Richter scale struck off Honshu Island early today, Japanese officials said.

Robinson Top Manager
LEAD: Frank Robinson, who guided the Baltimore Orioles to one of the greatest turnarounds in baseball history, was selected yesterday as the American League's manager of the year.


Savings Bond Sales Suspended by U.S.
LEAD: Sales of United States Savings Bonds were indefinitely suspended today because Congress failed to enact legislation raising the Federal debt limit.
Without the legislation, the Government's borrowing authority dropped from $2.87 trillion to $2.80 trillion at midnight Tuesday.


Brooklyn Youth Slain After Halloween Fight
LEAD: A Brooklyn youth was fatally shot outside a Bensonhurst church just before midnight on Halloween, two hours after he was embroiled in a donnybrook that started when a group of teen-agers threw eggs at a passing limousine, the police said.


Novelty Fades For Vodka Ad
LEAD: With great fanfare, Absolut Vodka has introduced its annual Christmas print advertisement, which it bills as the world's first talking ad for a consumer product.


People
LEAD: *
Diane G. Frank has been named marketing director, Paulette Keffas has been named advertising manager, and Sondra Gage has been named New York advertising manager of Child magazine.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about payments made by a Lincoln Savings and Loan executive to himself and his family misstated the participation of Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. in meetings on proposed disciplinary actions against Lincoln.
Senator Riegle attended the second of two meetings with the regulators; four other senators attended both meetings.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Brendle's Inc., Elkin, N.C., a discount retail chain, named Jim Eversole executive vice president of marketing.


Notes and Bonds Rise Modestly
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved modestly higher in moderate trading yesterday, as signs of continued softness in the economy persuaded some market participants to buy securities.


Campbell Soup Chief to Retire Early
LEAD: The chief executive of the Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that he would take early retirement.
His responsibilities were quickly divided between two top executives of the company, and its stock jumped on the news.

Soft Tech: The Feel of Things to Come
LEAD: BEFORE he was asked to design one, Christopher Alviar, a 27-year-old industrial designer in Beaverton, Ore., had not paid much attention to squeegees.
To him, a bathroom squeegee was akin to a toilet-bowl plunger, ''something that you wanted to keep out of sight,'' he said.


Relocation Plan By Comprehensive
LEAD: The Comprehensive Care Corporation said it planned to sell nine small California hospitals and move its headquarters from Irvine, Calif., to St.
Louis.
Last week, the company reported a $4.7 million loss and said its deal to be acquired by the First Hospital Corporation, Norfolk, Va., had collapsed.


Deadwood Journal; Gambling Returns To Town Of Legend
LEAD: This celebrated town of the Wild West welcomed its return to legalized gambling today at - when else? - high noon.

LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers signed Jim Burt, the former Giant nose tackle, yesterday to fill the void created when Michael Carter suffered a right foot injury in the 49ers' 23-10 victory over the Jets on Sunday.

Campaign Profile; Dinkins: Tenacity in a Deliberate Style
LEAD: His opponents say David N. Dinkins plays a steady game of tennis.
They say he never loses his temper, allowing himself at most an ''Oh, David'' when he double-faults or misses a return.
But mostly they remark on his reliable forehand and his punctilious observance of the courtesies of the game.


Fatal Slip Under a School Bus
LEAD: A 9-year-old girl was killed yesterday when she just missed her school bus, ran alongside it and slipped under the rear wheels, the police said.
The victim, Tiana Nelson of 788 East 21st Street, Brooklyn, was pronounced dead at Kings County Hospital shortly after the 8 A.M. accident at Ditmas and Flatbush Avenues, said a police spokesman, Sgt.


Dinkins and Giuliani Agree to a TV Debate
LEAD: The New York City mayoral campaign took another bitter turn yesterday.
David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed to two televised debates, but Mr.
Dinkins said last night that he might not take part in one after he was shown the text of a commercial released by the Giuliani campaign.
Mr.
Dinkins described the advertisement as scurrilous.


Brazil Inflation Rises
LEAD: Brazil's inflation rate for October rose to 37.6 percent, the second-highest monthly rate on record, the Government statistics office said this week.
The increase follows September's rate of 36 percent and was exceeded only by the 70.3 percent figure for January.
An official of the Government statistics office said consumer prices had risen 1,303.8 percent in the last 12 months.


Azima Considers Braniff Purchase
LEAD: Farhad Azima, founder of the defunct Global International Airways Corporation, said he was considering the possibility of buying Braniff Inc.
Mr.
Azima said that if he was successful, the airline could operate 60 to 80 flights a day from Kansas City, its main hub, to about 30 cities.


Despite New Twist, No Arrest in 6-Year-Old Murder on S.I.
LEAD: As twilight faded, Stanley Gardiner - a man known for his modesty, quick smile and conviviality - was seen driving into his Staten Island garage.


Corrections
LEAD: A brief article yesterday about the appointment of Sharon Percy Rockefeller as president and chief executive of WETA in Washington misstated the timing in some copies.
She was appointed on Monday, not yesterday.
Another brief report on the appointment, inadvertently published elsewhere in the paper, identified WETA incorrectly; it is a public television and radio station, not just television.


Help, at Last, for the Working Poor
LEAD: When President Bush vetoed a $4.55 an hour minimum wage bill in the spring he invited a legislative compromise: a smaller minimum wage increase combined with an expansion of tax credits for the working poor.
Fortunately, that compromise is about to become reality.

4 Vandals Ordered To Judaism Classes
LEAD: Four youths who admitted spraying swastikas and anti-Semitic slurs on a rabbi's house and other buildings owned by Jews must take lessons in Jewish culture and perform 50 hours of community service as punishment, a judge ruled on Tueday.


Vincent Appoints Greenberg as Deputy Commissioner
LEAD: Steve Greenberg, a player agent and the son of Hank Greenberg, was named deputy commissioner of baseball yesterday, effective Jan. 1.


INSIDE
LEAD:  New Move on Capital Gains


Computer-Trading Outcry Forcing Changes
LEAD: The outcry on Wall Street and Main Street over computerized stock trading, often blamed for accelerating the market crash of October 1987 and the recent share-price gyrations, has become so great that new market rules are being adopted and others appear imminent.
The rule changes come as even investment houses that once championed the practice are abandoning the business in droves.


No Bail for Jackson Relative
LEAD: Noah Robinson, the Rev.
Jesse Jackson's 47-year-old half brother, was denied bail on Monday after the Government had argued he might try to kill or intimidate witnesses against him.
Mr.
Robinson was indicted last week on charges of skimming profits from restaurants he owns and of hiring gang members to kill a man who uncovered the alleged scheme.

LEAD: The Amoco Corporation should pay about $100 million for damages incurred when its Amoco Cadiz tanker ran aground, spilling 68 million gallons of crude oil off the coast of France in 1978, the judge who presided over a lengthy trial has decided.

He was 63 years old.

The New Soviet Oppression: 15 Days in Jail
LEAD: The human rights watch in the Soviet Union has switched from celebrated cases of oppressed individuals to a myriad of disorderly conduct arrests of ordinary people testing the limits on free speech and assembly.


Anger With Ortega Unites Policy Makers in U.S.
LEAD: Bush Administration officials and members of Congress from both parties condemned President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua today for his decision to end a 19-month cease-fire with Nicaraguan guerrillas supported by the United States.


2 Administrators Removed to End School's Turmoil
LEAD: Seeking to ''bring quiet'' to a Brooklyn elementary school that has been in turmoil for more than a year, Schools Chancellor Bernard Mecklowitz yesterday approved the transfer of the principal and the assistant principal.


Only Brooklyn Has a Contest For Prosecutor
LEAD: When voters in New York City go to the polls on Tuesday they will be asked to elect district attorneys in three boroughs.
But in two - Manhattan and Queens - the incumbents are running unopposed and in the other, Brooklyn, where two candidates are on the ballot, the outcome is generally regarded as a foregone conclusion.


Review/Television; A&amp;E's Bow To Theater: A Series Of One-Acts
LEAD: Tonight at 9 o'clock, cable's Arts &amp; Entertainment Network begins making a monthly bow in the direction of live theater and, while modest, the effort is admirable. ''American Playwrights Theater: The One-Acts'' is getting under way with ''Third and Oak: The Pool Hall,'' written by Marsha Norman ('' 'Night, Mother'').


Pretoria Alerts Its Troops in Namibia in a 'False Alarm'
LEAD: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today that South Africa had alerted its forces after intercepting communications by United Nations monitors in Namibia saying that up to 600 rebels had infiltrated from Angola in the last week, but United Nations officials dismissed the messages as fraudulent.


California to Act on Temporary Tax for Quake Aid
LEAD: The California Legislature will meet Thursday in a special session to vote on a temporary increase in the state sales tax to raise $800 million for earthquake relief and repairs.


Congressional Panel Urges That Underground A-Tests Be Revealed
LEAD: The Federal Government should abandon its policy of keeping some underground nuclear explosions secret, a Congressional report said yesterday, because the practice needlessly raises public fears over the extent of radiation leaks into the atmosphere.

Death Toll in Blast Reaches 18
LEAD: The 18th person has died of injuries sustained in a series of explosions at a plastics plant last month.
Five people remained missing today.
A construction worker hospitalized since the Oct. 23 explosions and fire at the Phillips Petroleum Company plant died Tuesday, said Jere Smith, a Phillips spokesman.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  McEnroe Advances: Third-seeded John McEnroe struggled to a 6-3, 6-3 victory over Jonas Svensson of Sweden in the opening round of the Paris Open yesterday.
In second-round matches, Michael Chang routed Henri Leconte of France, 6-3, 6-2; Aaron Krickstein beat Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-3, 5-7, 6-4, and second-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden edged Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 6-4.


Israel to Stop Using Arab Reporter's List Of Contacts in Gaza
LEAD: A military investigator was ordered today to stop using telephone numbers in a personal phone book confiscated from a Palestinian journalist to round up the reporter's professional contacts for interrogation.


Tidewater Stake
LEAD: The Hong Kong investment arm of New Zealand investor Sir Ronald Brierley has lowered its stake in Tidewater Inc. to 9.6 percent, from 11.7 percent.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the concern, Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd., gave no reason for the sales.
Industrial Equity had requested a seat on the board of Tidewater, a New Orleans-based compressor and marine equipment concern.


Costa Rica Breaks the Mold
LEAD: Costa Rica has announced what could be a dramatic breakthrough in stalled efforts to reduce the bank debt of third world countries.
The plan could serve as a model for negotiations between creditor banks and other debtor nations.

Girl Is Wounded by Stray Bullet in Brooklyn
LEAD: A 15-year-old girl was shot in the neck outside her high school in Brooklyn yesterday, apparently by a stray bullet fired from a block away during a dispute between two groups of youths who fled, the police said.


Review/Circus; Big Apple's New Faces: Grandma And a Bison
LEAD: After last season's collaboration with the Nanjing Acrobatic Troupe, the Big Apple Circus has done an about-face.
Its new show, ''Grandma Goes West,'' is a rambunctious but not-so-wild version of a cowboy jamboree.
As usual, the entertainment (in a heated tent at Lincoln Center) is intimate and unpretentious.


Review/Dance; Maguy Marin Mocks the French Bicentennial Hoopla
LEAD: In a year that left France buried up to its cockades in celebrations of the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution, the choreographer Maguy Marin has come up with an anti-commemorative theater piece.


Special H.U.D. Prosecutor Is Requested by Democrats
LEAD: Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee today formally requested appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate allegations of political favoritism and perjury against the former Housing Secretary, Samuel R. Pierce Jr.
The request by 19 Democrats provoked a sharp response from Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who accused two leading Democrats on the Judiciary Committee of introducing ''partisan politics'' into Federal investigations of the Department of Housing and Urban


Japan Buys the Center of New York
LEAD: Japan's Sony Corporation bought Columbia Pictures last month.
Now Mitsubishi is paying $846 million for 51 percent of the Rockefeller Group, owner of Rockefeller Center, the vibrant Art Deco cluster of 19 buildings in the heart of New York City.
Is the transfer of American assets to Japanese ownership something to worry about?


Japan Trade Surplus Down
LEAD: Japan's current account surplus, which measures trade in both goods and services, fell in September for the seventh straight month, tumbling 22 percent from a year earlier, to $5.91 billion, the Finance Ministry said today.

Review/Art; An Art of Motion: Joan Mitchell's Abstract Expressionism
LEAD: The nine paintings in Joan Mitchell's first show at the Robert Miller Gallery are lucid and fresh.

LEAD:  HOCKEY  Sabres 4, Canadiens 3: Pierre Turgeon had a goal and two assists to lead Buffalo in Montreal.
Turgeon, who set up Mike Hartman's tie-breaking goal midway through the second period, jumped on a giveaway by Russ Courtnall and put a wrist shot past Patrick Roy 10 minutes 35 seconds into the third period to give the Sabres a 4-2 lead.

The principal setting is the London branch of an American bank named Whitney Paine, whose employees, needless to say, are all in emotional need.

LEAD: Handicappers who have been excavating piles of old race-result charts, trying to see which of the entrants in the Breeders' Cup races Saturday have run well at Gulfstream Park before, have probably been mining fool's gold.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the credit markets referred incorrectly to the saving to be realized by New York City in a debt reorganization that includes a new bond issue.
The saving, of $161 million in the 1990 fiscal year and $101 million in 1991, will result from lower payments of principal and interest, not just interest.

TV Weekend; Eternal Verities in Wilder's 'Our Town'
LEAD: The genius of Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town'' is in its simplicity.
Writing in 1938 about the way people are, ''in our living and our dying,'' the scholarly Wilder devised a play drawing on what philosophers call the eternal verities.
The townsfolk of his Grover's Corners in New Hampshire live within thoroughly familiar, unchanging cycles.

LEAD: Suedzucker A.G. of West Germany agreed to pay nearly $740 million for a Belgian sugar maker in a deal that puts it in contention to become Europe's biggest sugar producer.

Chemical Bank Certificates Are Priced to Yield 8.838%
LEAD: A $350 million offering of asset-backed certificates by Chemical Bank was priced yesterday through an underwriting group headed by Chemical Securities Inc.
The transaction is the first such asset-backed deal to be handled by an underwriting group comprising only banks.


3 Designers: Casual to Fanciful
LEAD: Louis Dell'Olio took a trip to Pompeii.
Bob Mackie recalled a visit to Las Vegas when he was very young and impressionable.
Mary McFadden was impressed by an exhibition of Surrealist paintings.
These are the sources credited yesterday by the three designers for their spring collections.
The result: disparate clothes, casual to fanciful.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press in some editions on Saturday about a farm where marijuana was found growing last year misstated an admission made by Robert Machin as part of a settlement to keep the farm.
He admitted he had grown the plants; he did not admit having done so to pay property taxes.

Strategies for Dining Cheaply and Well
LEAD: NEW YORK is one of the most expensive dining cities in the world; it is also one of the cheapest.
You can have a transcendent feast for $100 at the Quilted Giraffe, or a platter of lemon-grass chicken at Saigon in Chinatown for $5.95.
Finding the best dining bargains in town requires persistence and a resilient stomach, as I learned on a recent tour of about three dozen inexpensive restaurants in Manhattan.

LEAD:  Brunch at Metro


Savings Bond Rates Fall
LEAD: United States Savings Bonds will earn 6.98 percent interest in the next six months, down from the 7.81 percent rate of the last six months, the Treasury Department said Wednesday.
New sales have been suspended because Congress has not enacted legislation raising the Federal debt limit.
When sales resume, bonds issued in November will earn interest from the first of the month.


Piniella to Manage Reds, Newspaper Says
LEAD: Lou Piniella has agreed to a two-year contract to manage the Cincinnati Reds, according to a published report.


KLM-Northwest
LEAD: KLM Royal Dutch said it was reducing its stake in NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, to $150 million, from $300 million, in compliance with rules of the United States Department of Transportation.
KLM also said it had agreed to sell 75 percent of its wholly owned Golden Tulip Internatinal hotel group for an undisclosed sum to a group consisting of the Multi Development Corporation and Ravast Beheer N.V., both of the Netherlands, and Toga Hotels-Helfer Holding S.A.

Traffic Alert
LEAD: Because of the New York City Marathon, these streets will be closed to traffic in Manhattan for much of Sunday morning and afternoon: First Avenue from 59th Street to the Willis Avenue Bridge, Fifth Avenue from 136th Street to 102d Street and Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Broadway.
In addition, some traffic lanes on the Queensboro Bridge, the Willis Avenue Bridge, the Madison Avenue Bridge and the Verrazano Narrows Bridge will be closed.

LEAD: Christopher Hogwood will conduct the Academy of Ancient Music in an all-Beethoven program at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M.

Hondurans Reject Nicaragua Call for Talks on Rebels
LEAD: Asserting that existing peace accords are sufficient, the Honduran Government has bluntly rejected a Nicaraguan call for urgent new talks on demobilizing the rebel army.


Morris DeGroot, 58, A Statistics Professor
LEAD: Morris H. DeGroot, professor of statistics and industrial administration at Carnegie Mellon University, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Pittsburgh.
He was 58 years old.


Union Curbs an Agent
LEAD: Jerry Kapstein, one of baseball's earliest and wealthiest agents, yesterday became the first agent to be decertified by the Players Association.
The union took the action because of Kapstein's role in the effort to sell the San Diego Padres.
Joan Kroc, the Padres' owner, who is Kapstein's mother-in-law, has Kapstein as the sales agent for the club.


Bengals Hope Offense Is Rolling Once Again
LEAD: The Cincinnati Bengals had been scratching their heads and mulling over what plug had been pulled on their razzmatazz offense.
Cincinnati had lost 2 straight games at home, where they had won 12 straight.
In those losses the Bengals scored only 13 points against the vulnerable Miami Dolphins and only 12 against the Indianapolis Colts.


Plant Workers Rebuff Chrysler
LEAD: Hourly workers at the Chrysler Corporation mini-van plant in St.
Louis overwhelmingly rejected an unusual company-sponsored proposal for a four-day workweek intended to increase production by 20 percent.
The rejection is a blow to

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 476 money market mutual funds increased by $2.19 billion, to $359.71 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 143 institutional funds decreased by $6.7 million, to $84.82 billion.
The assets of the 236 general-purpose funds were up by $750.5 million, to $117.66 billion.


Review/Film; Grim Voices From Brazil
LEAD: The Public Theater's documentary series Brazil Why, focusing on that country's social conditions, begins today with Octavio Bezerra's horrifying, sincere and very slippery vision of life among the underclass. ''An Avenue Called Brazil'' might have been even more forceful if it had been a true documentary instead of an unlabeled mix of real-life scenes and re-enactments.


Tribute to Milton Goldman
LEAD: A memorial service for the theatrical agent Milton Goldman is to be held at noon on Monday at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street.
Among those expected to participate are the actors Douglas Fairbanks Jr., Helen Hayes, Jack Gilford, Irene Worth, Garson Kanin, Vanessa Redgrave and Geraldine Futzgerald.


'Sid Caesar' to Close
LEAD: ''Sid Caesar and Company: Does Anybody Know What I'm Talking About,'' a comedy revue with music, directed by Martin Charnin, will close after the Sunday matinee at the Golden Theater, 252 WEst 45th Street, The show will have run for five regular performances and six previews.


Ruth D. Coleman, Photographer, 85
LEAD: Ruth Doloboff Coleman, a photographer and former president of the Pictorial Photographers of America, died of cancer Wednesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx.
She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: In a deal that reflects the continuing consolidation of the world auto industry and the eagerness of big car makers to acquire prestigious brands, the Ford Motor Company announced today that it plans to buy Jaguar P.L.C. for a total of nearly $2.38 billion.


Ex-Nursing Home Aide Gets Life Term in 5 Patient Killings
LEAD: A former nursing home aide was sentenced to life in prison without parole today for smothering five patients in a lover's pact with another woman.

REPUBLICANS DROP EFFORT IN SENATE TO CUT GAINS TAX
LEAD: With the reluctant agreement of the Bush Administration, Senate Republicans today effectively abandoned their effort to win a cut in the capital gains tax this year.
They did so by giving up their plans to attach the measure to the three major spending bills under consideration.

2% Cut in Agencies' Budgets Is Ordered by Cuomo Administration
LEAD: The Cuomo administration ordered a 2 percent cut in the operating budgets of state agencies today, saying the reduction was needed because the state had overestimated tax revenue and faced a potential deficit of almost $300 million this year.


Soviet Miners' Strike Spreads, Testing Walkout Ban
LEAD: An illegal wildcat strike has spread to most of the coal mines in the Arctic city of Vorkuta, confronting Soviet authorities with their most serious test of a new law restricting labor walkouts.


Inmate Escapes From Hospital; Rapes Woman
LEAD: A Rikers Island prisoner being held on robbery charges escaped from a Brooklyn hospital yesterday and three hours later forced a woman into her apartment and raped her, the police said.

Totes to Acquire German Company
LEAD: Totes Inc., which makes and sells umbrellas, boots and other footwear, agreed to buy a West German company that distributes umbrellas.
Bradford E. Phillips, Totes's chief executive, signed the agreement in West Germany to buy Jagra-Haus G.m.b.H.
The German company will be renamed Totes Deutschland.


New Extension Of Telerate Bid
LEAD: Dow Jones &amp; Company said on Wednesday that it was extending until next Thursday its $576 million offer for the 33 percent of the electronic financial information company Telerate Inc. that it does not own.
It was the second extension in the $18-a-share offer in the last week.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  WHAT'S UP THERE, ANYWAY?


Risk Seen in Market Plan
LEAD: Sunshine and slower markets were proposed yesterday as the temporary cure for sharp downward moves in the stock market.
But while the changes may slow trading, they could also create confusion about market prices, perhaps helping to further alarm customers who are unable to sell when prices are falling.


Senate Shelves Effort to Disclose Mail Costs
LEAD: Members of the Senate made clear today that they want the House of Representatives to join them in disclosing the cost of Congressional mass mailings, but, to avoid scuttling an agreement to reduce the taxpayer-financed mailings by half, they declined to force the issue.


University Will Preserve Park That Was Scene of Protests
LEAD: The University of California at Berkeley, faced with community opposition to its plans to build student housing on a park near the campus, has announced that it will preserve the land as open space.

Economic Scene; The Rift in Britain On Joining Europe
LEAD: THE political crisis sweeping Britain, the most serious to hit Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher since she took office more than 10 years ago, has a fundamental economic issue at its roots: Should Britain become a full member of the European Monetary System as soon as possible or would it be dangerous for it to link the pound to the European currencies, especially the West German mark, at a time when the British inflation rate is high and the nation could be on the verge of recession as well?


Two at Knoll Sued Over Sale of Subsidiary
LEAD: The United Technologies Corporation and Gibbons Green van Amerongen, a New York investment firm, yesterday filed a lawsuit against two top executives of Knoll International Holdings Inc., the office products company, seeking damages of $173 million.


Bennet Korn, 75, TV Executive
LEAD: Bennet H. Korn, an executive with the Metromedia Corporation in the 1950's and 60's, died of a heart attack at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif., on Tuesday.
He was 75 years old and suffered from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease.


ABUSE CASE GOES TO CALIFORNIA JURY
LEAD: After more than two and half years and $15 million, the McMartin Preschool child-molesting trial, the nation's longest-running criminal proceeding, went to the jury today.

2 Companies Win Awards

Housing Plan Dominates Yonkers Race
LEAD: One year after Yonkers was almost bankrupted by contempt fines when four City Councilmen refused to comply with a housing desegregation plan, the entire seven-member Council is up for election in a vote widely seen as a referendum on the plan.


ACID RAIN MEASURE WOULD DIVIDE COST
LEAD: To break a deadlock that has stalled action on the Bush Administration's clean air bill, the chairman of the House Energy Committee today proposed a new way to finance the multibillion-dollar cleanup of the pollution that causes acid rain.


New Disney Attraction
LEAD: A new health and fitness pavilion opened this week at Disney World's Epcot Center, featuring a ''thrill ride'' through the human body and gadgets that tell visitors how healthy they are.
The $90 million ''Wonders of Life'' attraction is the ninth pavilion in the Future World section of Epcot Center.


Dollar Finishes Day Mixed As Traders Await Reports
LEAD: The dollar finished mixed in light trading yesterday as dealers awaited the release of new data on the nation's economy.


Sadie T. M. Alexander, 91, Dies; Lawyer and Civil Rights Advocate
LEAD: Sadie Tanner Mosell Alexander, a lawyer and civil rights advocate for 50 years who achieved a number of academic and professional distinctions as a black woman, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Cathedral Village, a retirement community, in Philadelphia.
She was 91 years old and had been hospitalized with Alzheimer's disease in Cathedral Village since 1983.


Judges Honor Kaufman's 40 Years on Bench
LEAD: Judge Irving R. Kaufman, a senior judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, who is recognized for his support of First Amendment rights, was honored Tuesday on his 40th anniversary on the Federal bench by a gathering of his fellow judges and former clerks.

LEAD: With its resident boys choir, fine organ, sure leadership and ample musical budget, St.
Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue continues to present some of the most appealing liturgical concerts in New York.
Tuesday night, the program was an all-French tribute to the bicentennial of the French Revolution, consisting of Poulenc's a cappella Mass in G (1937), his Concerto for organ, string orchestra and timpani (1938) and the 1893 version of Faure's


Cowles Sale Of 2 Papers
LEAD: The Cowles Media Company said today that it would sell The Rapid City Journal in South Dakota and The Great Falls Tribune in Montana and would offer to buy back up to 250,000 shares.


Penguin Names U.S. Chief
LEAD: The Penguin Group Inc. said yesterday that it had chosen Morton Mint to become chief executive officer of Penguin USA.
Mr.
Mint is currently the president and publisher of Penguin Canada.

LEAD: New York's mayoral campaign is sputtering to a messy finish.
Rudolph Giuliani and David Dinkins have finally agreed to two televised debates, exquisitely timed to get as little attention as possible.
And Mr.
Dinkins's campaign records are in such disarray that the Campaign Finance Board has withheld $95,000 in public matching funds.

LEAD: Richard Dent, the 6-foot-5-inch, 265-pound defensive end, yesterday signed what is believed to be one of the most lucrative contracts in Chicago Bears history.

Corrections
LEAD: The Washington Talk column on Thursday about California's place in the Presidential primaries referred incorrectly to California's allotment of delegates to Presidential nominating conventions.
While Republicans have apportioned them winner-take-all, the Democrats have split them among the candidates since 1976.

Braniff Announces Additional Layoffs
LEAD: Braniff Inc. cut about 100 jobs in a further effort to reduce costs as the carrier struggles to emerge from bankruptcy for a second time.

Albanian Unrest in Serbia
LEAD: Security forces clashed today with a crowd in Podujevo and moved to quell other protests by people of Albanian stock in this southern region, where at least three people died in unrest this week.

LEAD: Julio Cesar Chavez, the World Boxing Council superlightweight champion, will defend his title against Sammy Fuentes on Nov. 18 in Las Vegas, Nev.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about efforts to reduce the capital gains tax misidentified the three bills to which Senate Republicans had planned to attach the proposal.
As stated elsewhere in the article, they were a bill to raise the national debt ceiling, one to modify the Medicare catastrophic-coverage program and one to repeal tax rules against discrimination in employer-paid health insurance.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Wednesday about a dispute over charitable fund raising by The Wall Street Journal's Washington bureau chief referred incorrectly to Jerald F. terHorst of the Ford Motor Company.
He is director of national public affairs with responsibility for media relations and issue analysis, not a lobbyist.


Bird Scores 32 in Return
LEAD: Larry Bird scored Boston's first 6 points and had 32 over all last night as the Celtics beat the Milwaukee Bucks, 127-114, for their 11th consecutive opening victory at home.
Bird, who played six games before undergoing heel surgery last Nov. 19, got 13 of the Celtics' first 17 points and made his first 3-point attempt.


Auction as AIDS to Benefit
LEAD: An auction of paintings, clothing, furniture and other items will be held on Dec. 3 at 7 P.M. at the American Ballet Theater, 890 Broadway (19th Street).
The auction will benefit the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, a lobbying organization.
Items to be auctioned, which include works by David Hockney, Annie Leibovitz, Robert Rauschenberg, Andy Warhol and Francesco Scavullo, will be on view from noon to 3 P.M.

Review/Opera; A Parable, With Simple Ritual
LEAD: Benjamin Britten's church parables - short operas that drew their inspiration from Noh drama, medieval mystery plays and contemporary concerns - remain among his most telling creations.
They are not exactly upbeat, and in the wrong hands they can plod self-importantly.
But with their artfully innocent simplicity, sparse but telling daubs of instrumental color and refined intensity of expression, they count among the finest works of modern-day musical theater.

LEAD: With the holiday season approaching, competition in the desk-diary and pocket-calendar industry is intensifying, and now the consumer has more choices than ever.

Pace of New Jobs Calms Recession Fears
LEAD: The Labor Department reported today that the economy created new jobs at a brisk pace in October, calming fears that it might have begun to skid toward recession.

A Correction
LEAD: The omission of a word altered the meaning of a letter Oct. 21 by the Rev.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  McEnroe to Meet Becker: John McEnroe beat Michael Chang, 6-3, 3-6, 6-2, yesterday and Boris Becker was forced to a third-set tie breaker for the second consecutive day before defeating Wally Masur, 6-7, 6-4, 7-6, in the quarterfinals of the Paris Open.
McEnroe will play Becker in the semifinals.(AP)


Thousands in Bulgaria Rally
LEAD: Thousands of demonstrators in Bulgaria today mounted the first large pro-democracy rally in the country's postwar history, a diplomat said.
Estimates of the number taking part ranged from 4,000 and 9,000.
They were demonstrating on the last day of a 35-nation environmental conference in Sofia, the capital.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Nature's Black Gold
LEAD: Autumn's leaves should never be discarded.
Decomposed leaves and garden debris are nature's black gold, the crumbly stuff that improves soil and makes plants grow better.
And now that landfills are running out of space and burning leaves adds to air pollution, the best way to handle garden debris is to recycle it as compost.

Traffic Alert
LEAD: Because of the New York City Marathon, these streets will be closed to traffic in Manhattan for much of tomorrow morning and afternoon: First Avenue from 59th Street to the Willis Avenue Bridge, Fifth Avenue from 136th Street to 102d Street and Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Broadway.
In addition, some traffic lanes on the Queensboro Bridge, the Willis Avenue Bridge, the Madison Avenue Bridge and the Verrazano Narrows Bridge will be closed.

Breeding Success And Bettors
LEAD: It is called the Breeders' Cup because the $10 million being given away today in seven championship races at Gulfstream Park comes from the pockets of the nation's horse breeders.
The breeders, though, are just the most recent link in the great chain of racing money.


97 Missing in Capsizing
LEAD: An American-owned oil drilling ship with 97 people aboard capsized early today after a typhoon swept through the Gulf of Thailand with 100-mile-per-hour winds.
Barry Lane, a spokesman for the Los Angeles-based Unocal oil company, said six survivors had been rescued in heavy seas about 270 miles south of Bangkok, but that they were Thai fishermen, not crew from the capsized Seacrest drilling vessel.

LEAD: A Customs Service helicopter that was used to chase boats suspected of carrying drugs crashed in the Florida Keys while pursuing a speedboat Thursday night, and one of those aboard was still missing today.

LEAD: Colombian judges and court workers went on strike today, demanding greater protection against a surge of violence related to the drug trade.
President Virgilio Barco Vargas renewed his pledge to keep fighting the traffickers.
