Chicago School Control Shifts to Parent Councils
LEAD: More than 5,400 parents, community residents and teachers took an oath of office Thursday night, swearing to ''represent the interests of our children's education with respect and dignity'' in the most radical school decentralization plan ever attempted in the United States.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Pocket-Size Stereos
LEAD: It has been 10 years since the Sony Corporation introduced the Walkman, a pocket-sized tape cassette player without speakers, designed to provide high-quality sound through headphones.
Now, there are hundreds of such ''personal stereos'' on the market (nearly 50 from Sony alone), from dozens of manufacturers, at prices from under $40 to above $400.

A.T.&amp;T. Venture
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories and Hampshire Instruments said they plan to collaborate on several areas of X-ray lithography development, an advanced technique for manufacturing semiconductors.
Hampshire is a Marlborough, Mass., semiconductor equipment maker that is developing a new class of tools that use X-rays instead of light to etch ultra-fine circuits on semiconductor chips.

LEAD: The Mobil Oil Company announced plans to spend $468 million building a North Sea gas pipeline and onshore processing plant at St.
Fergus in northeast Scotland.

The processing plant will have a permanent work force of 80 when production begins in three years.

LEAD: An entry in the Calendar column of The Home Section on Thursday misstated the admission policy for ''Modernism: A Century of Style and Design,'' a show at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan next Thursday through Nov. 12.

For Supreme and Civil Court
LEAD: Tuesday's judicial contests in New York City serve notice again of the need to reform judicial selection, now largely controlled by party leaders who help determine which candidates get on the ballot.
The Democratic slates sure to win include high-caliber candidates but also a disappointing number of mediocre choices - underscoring the need for true merit selection.

LEAD: Turning aside the first major challenge to the settlement of the Government's racketeering suit against the teamsters' union, a Federal district judge in Manhattan yesterday backed the broad powers of court-appointed officers to discipline the union's officials.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation today announced the layoffs of 4,000 workers in a series of moves that ended production of two subcompact cars in Detroit, eliminated a shift at a car-making plant in St.
Louis and closed a supply plant in Wisconsin.

LEAD: Iran will mark the 10th anniversary of the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran with a large demonstration organized by one of country's most militant politicians.

LEAD: Senate leaders said today that they expected swift Congressional agreement on a deficit reduction plan that would restore $16.1 billion in spending that was eliminated when automatic budget cuts went into effect last month.

LEAD: Researchers at Genetics Institute Inc., a biotechnology concern in Cambridge, Mass., have obtained the world's first patent on genetically engineered interleukin 3, a protein that stimulates growth of human blood cells.

Merrill Rejoins Clippers
LEAD: Stump Merrill, who managed the Columbus Clippers to the International League pennant in 1984, will return to manage the Yankees' Class AAA farm club next season, a Columbus radio station, WBNS, reported yesterday.
Merrill, who also managed the Clippers in 1985, will replace Rick Down, who took over Columbus in August when Bucky Dent was named manager of the Yankees.

Review/Theater; Love and Loss and the Salve of Time
LEAD: In the final play of Reynolds Price's trilogy, ''New Music,'' a father reveals a closely guarded family secret to his son.
The moment is both intimate and wryly amusing - and it is followed by other personal intimations.
After almost six hours in the company of an extended family in a small North Carolina town, we come to recognize the characters as old friends and to feel the tautness of the bonds of blood, marriage and acquaintanceship.

He tells the U.N. he does.

Third world states, fearful that rivals may make chemical weapons, may want to make them, too.

His Honorarium
LEAD: After a dozen years of amateur philosophizing and scolding, Edward I. Koch has decided to turn pro.
The Mayor, whose offer to serve a fourth term was declined by New York voters, said last week that when he leaves office in January he will hit the lecture circuit and maybe even hire out to do a few product endorsements.

From an Empty Nest, the Voice of the Turtle
LEAD: HUMAN the hamster must have sensed his superfluity.
While we were agonizing over how to dispose of our unwanted pet, he bit my son, caught his cold and died.
It was all so convenient, we couldn't have planned things better.


In Quest of Turkey's Majestic Rugs
LEAD: EVEN when the Aegean sun is most intense, there's a freshness to the air behind the giant stone walls of the 17th-century caravansary in the center of Kusadasi, in southwestern Turkey.
This renovated Ottoman inn, known in its modern Turkish incarnation as the Kervansaray, has shady palms and flowering trees in the central court and cushioned chambers along the side and is an irresistible place to while way the hours admiring a vast array of brightly colored carpets.


Campus Life: Massachusetts; Where Students Live and Work As Firefighters
LEAD: A week before final exams last December, Christopher Hookway spent part of a Friday evening in an ambulance, trying to dress the wounds of a drunken student who had shattered a plate-glass dormitory window with his fist.

Feeling Like an Onlooker As a Baby Is Awaited
LEAD: OF all the landmarks in the unique relationship between mother and daughter - first day at school, first date, high school prom, wedding - the most meaningful and overwhelming is the time when a daughter becomes pregnant.


In Pisa, a Jewel of a Museum
LEAD: FREQUENTLY dusty, dim and grimy showcases, Italian museums have been much criticized of late.
They are often closed for sciopero (strike), restauro (restoration), and even, in the case of museums run by a religious order, for lutto (mourning) if one of the order's members has died.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. After a shower, water accumulated in the tub to a depth of seven inches.
After several hours, I removed the drain stopper and tried a 3-foot-long snake, but this did not help.
Drainage in the bathroom sink and basement sink seemed fine.
I started to scoop water out of the tub and pour a chemical drain cleaner into the toilet.


As Projects Crumble, Brazil Is Thinking Small
LEAD: After the state electric company here ran out of money this month, 3,300 workers walked off the construction site of Xingo dam, one of the country's largest public works projects.

LEAD: Your Oct. 15 article regarding Gildah, an Asian elephant  [ ''Anywhere She Wants,'' Long Island Journal ] , was rather misleading.


Reston, Retiring at 80, Still Looks Up the Road
LEAD: James Reston, who retired from The New York Times on Friday, his 80th birthday, said in a farewell interview that President Bush should do more, at this potentially pivotal moment, ''to help along'' the political and economic evolution in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: The protests of retail pharmacists have not slowed the rapid growth of prescriptions sold by mail - at least not yet.


In the Final Hours, Pete Rozelle Reflects
LEAD: The words still stick in Pete Rozelle's craw.
At a 1975 meeting of National Football League club owners, he sat there and listened as Carroll Rosenbloom challenged his reign as commissioner.
Several months earlier, Rosenbloom, then the owner of the Los Angeles Rams, had signed Ron Jessie, a wide receiver who was a free agent after having exercised the option clause of his contract with the Detroit Lions.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having recently returned from two weeks in Iceland, we enjoyed ''A Chunk of Lava in the Sea.'' However, we disagree with the description of the land: ''not a single plant among all the brave and graceful Icelandic grasses, mosses and wildflowers has yet been able to climb the volcano Eldfell for new life.

LEAD: Top-ranked Notre Dame tied a school record today with its 21st consecutive victory, beating Navy, 41-0.
The victory was also Notre Dame's first shutout in six years.

Admission is free; information, 945-0505.

Sterba specialized in the psychoanalytic study of artists, publishing biographies of Beethoven and Michelangelo.'' From that terse description one might not have gathered that this was the same Dr.

LEAD: I REMEMBER the night I first met David.
Sue had phoned me two days earlier. ''We've got a buddy for you.
When can you meet him?'' As soon as possible, I said.


Review/Music; String Quartets in Three Idioms
LEAD: At once compatible and contradictory were the first two items on Wednesday's program by the Tokyo String Quartet at the 92d Street Y. Mozart - whose Quartet in G (K. 387) began the evening - was perhaps the first of our confessional composers.
This confiding, commiserating tone established an intimacy between musician and listener that became the modus operandi of 19th-century music.


Officials See String of Navy Accidents as Random
LEAD: Current and former Navy officials insist that the succession of accidents this week was more a random illustration of the dangers of life at sea than a sign of deficiencies in training or maintenance.


More Than Just Another Dr. Kildare
LEAD: From Dr.
Ehrlich to Dr.
Kildare, from Paul Muni to Richard Chamberlain, from yellow fever to black lung, medicine and entertainment have long been bedfellows.
By now, the medical drama tends to run as predictable a course as the common cold.
The dedicated young doctor sets out on the road to the cure for something dire; he works hard, makes personal sacrifices, meets rebuffs, almost despairs - then succeeds.

LEAD: A PLAYWRIGHT (the real Arthur Kopit) sets out to write a play about the end of the world.
What he comes up with is a play about a playwright (the fictional Michael Trent) who is writing a play about the end of the world.

WHAT'S DOING IN: San Antonio
LEAD: The first thing you notice about San Antonio is that it's so old.
It was settled in 1718, and the buildings on the narrow streets seem to vibrate with history.

Question Of the Week; Are There Too Many Injuries in The N.F.L.?
LEAD: Absolutely.
The average career of an N.F.L. player is 3.8 years.
It is the only sport, including hockey and boxing, in which United Press International puts out a weekly injury list.
In other words, the N.F.L. is one day a week of playing and at least six days of recovering.


Defenses Are on the Blitz
LEAD: Whether it was the Eagle, the Spinner or the 46, National Football League teams in the first half of the season have created catchy monikers for their defenses with a primary goal in mind: line maneuvers up front that created havoc and provided pressure on quarterbacks.


FLASHCARD
LEAD: THREE-QUARTERS of the class of 1986 with bachelor's degrees had full-time jobs within a year of graduation.
An additional 11 percent were employed part time, and almost 3 in 10 had continued their education beyond a bachelor's degree.
Eighty-five percent of the 1986 degree recipients in business and management found full-time employment by 1987, the most likely field of study to do so.

Special Today
LEAD:  Education Life/Section 4A


FLASHCARD
LEAD: ALMOST all freshmen college students from Arizona remain in their home state.
Ninety-seven percent of Arizonans in college for the first time in 1986 enrolled in campuses within the state.
Close behind is California, with 95 percent of students registering at colleges in their native state.
Just over half of students from New Hampshire remain in the Granite State for their college education, which is the lowest proportion in the country.

Fred Mustard Stewart's enjoyable tale of a San Francisco family features an interesting cast of characters, a lively sense of humor and an impressive ability to blend historical fact and popular fiction.

In the Footsteps of a Marathon Veteran
LEAD: On the occasion of the 20th New York City Marathon, I think it's only fair that nouveau runners be told how it used to be in the old days when the race was confined to Central Park.
The tune from ''Rocky'' had not yet serenaded runners.
There were two Port-a-Johns and no waiting.
The rallying cry of the underdog, as reflected in the ''Rocky'' metaphor, has been the marathon's most compelling theme.

Test
LEAD: Are you average?
Find out using the Scholastic Aptitude Test, the college etrance exam.
These questions were answered correctly by the majority of average-scoring S.A.T. test-takers several years ago.
According to the Educational Testing Service, which writes the exam, the average adult or high school senior today should do equally well, since test scores have remained fairly stable in recent years.

Sick Schools
LEAD: PARENTS once worried about simple, traditional diseases in their children's school lives, like flu and measles.
Nowadays their concerns are about bugaboos with symptoms less visible and effects more threatening: asbestos fibers in the air, lead sipped at the drinking fountain and radon gas seeping through classroom floors.

In 1989, it has taken on a new meaning for the 70,000 residents of Middletown, where my colleagues and I are leading a fight against the power lines proposed by a public utility.

Elizabeth Cohen: Acoustical Engineer
LEAD: Shaping sound is both science and art.
For Elizabeth Cohen, 35 years old, becoming an acoustical engineer resolved a tough choice. ''I was torn between a career in music and one in science,'' said Ms.
Cohen, who has fine-tuned the basses, trebles and everything in between in concert halls, at outdoor performances, in recording studios and on film.

U.S. and Soviet Sisters Meet at Last
LEAD: Separated for decades by the Iron Curtain, daughters of an American tap dancer who found fame in the Soviet Union met today in a kitchen glowing with quiet laughter, hugs and happy exclamations.


FLASHCARD
LEAD: ONE in six public-school teachers works at an outside job for additional income during the school year.
Almost a fifth work outside the school system during the summer.
Of teachers who moonlight, just over a quarter do so only during the school year, 36 percent only during the summer recess and another 36 percent throughout the year.

California comes in second with 314 colleges and universities, followed by Texas with 171.

Review/Music; A Concert of New Music 'In Celebration of the Soloist
LEAD: One approaches a new music concert called ''A Celebration of the Soloist'' and containing a piece called ''Narcissus'' with some suspicion.
One of the minor illnesses of postwar composition has been the instrumental solo as scientific experiment, whereby acoustical and mechanical properties are stretched and music is lost in the performer's self-absorption.

THE REGION: A Governor for Harder Times; For New Jersey, Two Who Stress Differences
LEAD: THE next governor of New Jersey will inherit a state that has seen boom times but now faces harder days.
Presided over for eight years by Thomas H. Kean, a popular Republican who by law is barred from a third term, New Jersey's economy has expanded.
Now the state is facing a budget squeeze as it deals with some of the results of development like traffic and environmental problems while trying to eradicate the decay of Newark and Camden.

Swing for Dancing
LEAD: George Kelly's Jazz Sultans are to play swing music for dancing in a program presented by the New York Swing Society today at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090).

Modern Dances of Bones Rather Than Flesh
LEAD: The loneliness that wells up in Susanne Linke's extraordinary performance of Dore Hoyer's dances is so extreme that the pain distilled in these powerful solos seems hardly capable of healing.
Hoyer, an exponent of the German ''Expressive'' (Ausdruckstanz) dance before and after World War II, did, in fact, commit suicide in 1967.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. After a shower, water accumulated in the tub to a depth of seven inches.
After several hours, I removed the drain stopper and tried a 3-foot-long snake, but this did not help.
Drainage in the bathroom sink and basement sink seemed fine.
I started to scoop water out of the tub and pour a chemical drain cleaner into the toilet.


Review/Dance; BarriersIn Reveries Of Waiting
LEAD: These people might have been trapped indoors on a rainy Sunday.
From the looks of them, it was easy to believe they had been cooped up together for a whole month of rainy Sundays.
What was there for them to do?
Not much.
So they waited.
They twitched.
They bickered.
And calmed down.

LEAD: I once asked Carl Banks of the New York Giants why there were so many injuries.
Was it the Astroturf?
Equipment?
The training, or lack of it?
His answer was simply, ''Everybody is just too big!''


High Flyers
LEAD: INEXPENSIVE air charters for college students on holiday, begun in the 1960's in the spirit of backpacks and Europe-on-$5-a-day, have gone sharply upscale in recent years.
Today they are a profitable way for alumni associations to cultivate and maintain close ties to wealthy graduates.

LEAD: IN THE stereotypical world of high school athletics, good grades are harder to come by than good hands.
However, a national study of 14,000 high school athletes by a Buffalo researcher concludes that the image of the dull-witted athlete is a false one.

Arnold D. Panzer, dispensing prescriptions simply makes good business sense. ''I have a seven-day-a week, walk-in, primary care practice, so dispensing medicine is in line with the focus of my practice - convenience,'' he said. ''My patients don't have to schlep over to a pharmacy.''


How the Cocaine Is Coming In This Time
LEAD: AMERICA loves a showdown between good and evil, and when President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia launched a surprise attack on cocaine traffickers on Aug. 18, the United States stood up and cheered.

COLD FUSION CONFUSION
LEAD: Your authors contend that ''good'' scientists always try to ''kill the discovery.'' That is straight out of Karl Popper's philosophy of falsification, and it simply doesn't describe the behavior of real scientists.
No scientist kills his own discovery - you verify it to your own satisfaction, publish it and let the skeptics do their worst.


Prospects; An Even Slower Economy
LEAD: The economy grew by 2.5 percent in the third quarter, and the unemployment rate for October was virtually unchanged from the month before at 5.3 percent.
But employment did soften in the manufacturing sector as sales of American-made autos plummeted.
So where is the economy headed?
Four economists offer their views.


No More
LEAD: The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, once the largest afternoon newspaper in the country, died at home last week after a long illness.
It was 86 years old.
In its heyday, the newspaper had more than 700,000 readers and was known to keep a safe full of cash on the premises to finance the whims of the founder, William Randolph Hearst, or bail too-enterprising reporters out of jail.

Montauk
LEAD: To the Editor: The story about Montauk by David Laskin (''History at the Tip of Long Island,'' Travel, Aug. 27) raised fond memories dating back more than 50 years.
In those days Montauk was a landscape serene, beautiful and unspoiled by suburban sprawl.
And I recall that the Long Island Rail Road had a Fisherman's Special from Penn Station.

LEAD: THE restaurant is called Allisters, but its owners are Don and Robin McAllister.
Why the name change?

This Oakdale restaurant is the antithesis of a casual neighborhood bar.

FLASHCARD
LEAD: GROWING numbers of college students are balancing school and work.
Last year almost half the full-time college students between the ages of 16 and 24 were employed.
Half of these worked between 15 and 29 hours a week, and 10 percent were employed full time, working at least 35 hours a week.
Sixteen years ago only 37 percent of the full-time students in that age group were part of the labor force.

LEAD: Three motorists given speeding tickets each sent the St.
Clair Circuit Court clerk $50 in pennies to pay for the fines, and the clerk says he will not accept them.

I was sitting next to the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, who had been making a half-hearted attempt to read a book he had brought along, but who was looking out now at the fog, thinking things.

Tyson to Hit The Books
LEAD: For someone who has what amounts to a doctorate in the sweet science, Mike Tyson has some glaring gaps in his formal education.
He never completed junior high school.
Now the heavyweight champion has apparently decided to make up for lost time.
According to officials of Central State University in Wilberforce, Ohio, Tyson plans to fill in his gaps through a study program leading to a general equivalency degree, considered a substitute for a high school diploma.


LECH'S AMERICAN ANGEL
LEAD: David Margolick captured perfectly the contradictions in Basia Johnson's persona.
Her history is riddled with irony.
To wit, after nearly a decade fighting the Princeton Township tax assessor over the value of her estate, which she put at around $4 million (the litigation earned my former law firm several hundred thousand dollars for representing the township), and having finally settled the suit, your article now speaks of her ''$30 million mansion.

LEAD: Army investigators will decide this month whether to recommend the Medal of Honor for a Jewish veteran who is said to have killed more than 500 Japanese soldiers in a single furious encounter in World War II but to have been denied the nation's highest military decoration because of anti-Semitism.

WEEDS ARE US
LEAD: Ralph Waldo Emerson, who as a gardener really should have known better, once said that a weed is simply a plant whose virtues we haven't yet discovered. ''Weed,'' that is, is not a category of nature but a human construct, a defect of our perception.
This kind of attitude, which draws on an old American strain of romantic thinking about wild nature, can get you into trouble.

FLASHCARD
LEAD: DEFAULTS on guaranteed student loans are expected to cost the Federal Government about $2 billion in fiscal year 1990.
The 1987 default rate for federally guaranteed student loans was 17 percent, down from 21 percent the previous year. (The 1987 default rate was calculated using the percentage of borrowers who joined the repayment ranks in 1987 and then defaulted in fiscal years 1987 or 1988.) For-profit trade schools had the highest incidence of nonpayment, at 33 percent.

Pastimes: Gardening; High Praises for A Showy House Plant
LEAD: Clivias are almost too good to be true.
Just when everyone is deeply entrenched in wintertime doldrums, clivias gush forth with unabashed umbels of fiery flowers.
They are therapeutic plants.
Their blossoms come to the rescue just when you need color the most.
They brighten your life for a month or more during the darkest days of the year.

THE WORLD'S WARS
LEAD: This is a coffeetable volume of 75 war photographs, and since they depict the conflicts of the 1980's they are all in color; the mangled flesh is red and the flames are orange.
These are strong, evocative pictures reminding us that a guerrilla's vengeful rage or a child's poignant grief are just as affecting in little wars - Nicaragua, Northern Ireland, Lebanon and the like - as they were in earlier wars that slew millions.

Scientists In Waiting
LEAD: IN A LABORATORY at Trinity University in San Antonio, Luis Martinez Jr. works these days as part of a team of scientists trying to produce for the first time certain members of a class of molecules, called carbodications, whose structure has been described in theory but not observed.
It is among the most basic of inquiries, aimed at expanding the understanding of nature: the painstaking but riveting sort of hunt in which thousands of graduate students and their postdoctoral mentors engage every day.

LEAD: ''The Bear,'' as it might have been made by Touchstone Pictures: Bart, the 2,000-pound grizzly, would not star.

The British Columbian scenery, which was actually filmed in the Bavarian Alps, need not be quite as authentic; it could be augmented by studio-built sets.

FLASHCARD
LEAD: THE average school district in the United States contains five schools with a total of almost 150 teachers and just over 2,500 students.
There is considerable diversity in the actual size and range of American school districts.
The largest, in New York City, includes 993 schools employing more than 50,000 teachers and accommodating more than 900,000 students.

TRAVEL ADVISORY
LEAD:  Cosmonauts to Caviar in the Soviet Union


Rental Cars
LEAD: To the Editor: This summer I had an experience with a car rental agency that your readers should know about.
I rented a Chevrolet Corsica from Dollar Rent a Car in Orlando, Fla.
The car was stolen six days later in Miami.
Not only did Dollar refuse to provide me with another car, but they also informed me that I would be liable for the price of the car - even though I had paid extra for the collision damage waiver.


In Mediterranean Cooking, Olive Oil Is Even in Dessert
LEAD: MEDITERRANEAN cooking refers to the cuisines of Italy, Spain, southern France, Greece, Turkey, Israel and the North African countries that border the sea.
Their dependence on olive oil accounts in part for their current popularity.

New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: There are some people who have only to open their mouths to be real downers.
They are not insulting and they are not necessarily complainers about life, marriage, children or finances - they're not even negative in the traditional sense.
They merely bring out the not-so-nice characteristics in others, and one of those characteristics is an almost irresistible urge to give them a good swat.


Correction
LEAD: An article on Sept. 24 about the Vermont-Quebec border area referred incorrectly to three towns in the area.
They are North Hatley (not North Hately), Ayers Cliff (not Aye's Cliff) and Katevale (not Kateville).

POSTINGS: Words and Pictures; A TriBeCan History
LEAD: In a bid for support in its drive to have large tracts of TriBeCa landmarked, the public-interest group leading the fight has published a 64-page architectural history of the area of southwestern Manhattan titled ''The Texture of TriBeCa.'' The softcover book, with more than 75 pictures and drawings of structures in the neighborhood, was written by the architectural historian Andrew Scott Dolkart.

COLD FUSION CONFUSION
LEAD: The remarks of Robert P. Crease and N. P. Samios, in their article ''Cold Fusion Confusion'' (Sept. 24), add to a long history of scientific ''spin control'' - attempts by established science to protect its professional solidarity from outside threats, real or imagined.
Brookhaven National Laboratory is an important center of conventional fusion research.

I put the thing away.''

Plan to Halt Drugs on Roads
LEAD: THREE HUNDRED police officers from all of Westchester's 44 municipalities met in Valhalla last week to begin training in a special Highway Drug Interdiction Program.
The program is sponsored by the county and could double the number of drug-runners and drug-impaired drivers apprehended on county and local roads.


Employers in the Suburbs Try Commuter Management
LEAD: AS American urban centers continue to become decentralized, more and more workers find themselves commuting between suburbs instead of to jobs in the city.
The resulting suburban gridlock has produced loud complaints and little action.
Few local and county governments have the money or wherewithal to untangle the problem.

LEAD: Nestled in the wallets of an increasing number of Americans are plastic cards that require their owners to pay only a small fee of $1 to $5 for a prescription.
Without filling out any forms, their employers and insurers pick up the remaining cost.

Small Steps Toward Acceptance Renew Debate on Gay Marriage
LEAD: SINCE the early 1970's, when seven states, including New York, rejected the idea of allowing homosexual couples to marry, the issue has been all but dormant.
But recently the debate has been revived.
Among the most significant reasons for the renewed interest, gay-rights leaders say, is the AIDS epidemic, which has brought questions of inheritance and death benefits to many people's minds.

Scotland
LEAD: To the Editor: I was pleased to see the article on Scotland with the photo of Portpatrick Harbor (Travel, July 16).
Unfortunately, in reviewing places to stay in that quaint seacoast village, you left out the Carlton House, which was in the center of the photo.
This immaculate, pleasant guest hotel, which is run by Penny Harvie, is the place to stay if you want to relax with interesting guests while only spending about $28 a night for bed, breakfast and a scrumptuous dinner.


Will They Go For the Strong, Silent Type?
LEAD: Is this a time to keep silents?
Sensing a surge of interest among collectors, MGM/UA, Paramount, HBO and some other video distributors have been releasing large numbers of classic silent films.
Earlier this year, MGM/UA issued the first and silent ''Ben Hur'' and ''The Big Parade.'' Paramount released ''The Ten Commandments'' and several other titles.

Hers; All That Glitters Is the Tub
LEAD: THE MOMENT I hear that someone will be dropping by my apartment, I find myself draped over the side of the bathtub, a can of Ajax in one hand and a sponge in the other.
It doesn't matter who's coming, how long the person will stay or what I happen to be doing at the time.
I hang up the phone and head straight for the bathroom.

LEAD: In a city in which real estate projects tend toward the mammoth, one under way on the Upper East Side might easily qualify as the smallest of the year.
Developers have bought for $750,000 the shell of a 17-foot-wide house at 344 East 72d Street, near First Avenue, and are turning it into a single-family, four-story town house to be marketed for $2.5 million.

LEAD: To the Editor:


The Special Role Of Parochial Schools
LEAD: The article on parochial schools (''About New Jersey,'' Sept. 24) states well the need for concern over inadequacies in financing schools in New Jersey cities as opposed to their suburban counterparts.
It also highlights clearly the financial needs of the Catholic schools in the cities.
However, several generalizations about these schools need to be clarified.


The Museum That Theory Built
LEAD: A medium-sized museum in a medium-sized city that has been underwritten by a rich retailer and designed by an architect who has never before built a museum would seem like a prescription for total irrelevance.
And the fact that the museum will open without a single picture on its walls might seem to render it not only irrelevant but laughable.

LEAD: The United States and Australia urged Fiji today to find a solution to its political problems that would be acceptable to all ethnic groups in the South Pacific island chain.


Chemical Makers Are Cleared in Lawsuit by Textile Workers
LEAD: A Circuit Court jury has cleared three chemical manufacturers in a lawsuit brought by textile workers who claimed that exposure to a toxic material gave them a crippling lung disease.


Adventuring In the Cloud Forests Of Ecuador
LEAD: THE cloud forest of Ecuador sounded so gentle.
It is, after all, jungle, that is to say, rain forest, but at altitudes high enough to eliminate the sweltering heat, ants, mosquitoes, malaria and even poisonous snakes.
Its mountainous inclines make it perfect for trekking, more or less.

Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Savory Pork: Marinade Is the Trick
LEAD: It is not true that you must give up pork if you are on a low-fat diet.
Pork tenderloins are not only tender, they are also very low in fat.
It is easy to compensate for that lack of fat with a savory marinade, which adds immeasurably to the flavor of the meat.
The longer it is allowed to sit, the deeper it penetrates.

The Age Of Egalitarianism Takes a Toll
LEAD: THIS morning, my 8:20 commuter train to New York was canceled at the last minute.
There was an announcement that those of us waiting on the platform should walk to the New Haven side of the tracks, where a train would pick us up in 10 minutes.
Since I am seven months pregnant, the idea of folding up my newspaper, recapping my warm cup of decaffeinated coffee and walking up and down two sets of stairs with a heavy briefcase was somewhat daunting.

LEAD: Some of the oldest openings seem innocuous, but beware that impression - it may mean only that you are too young to have seen them in their heyday.
Then they were tested in battle after battle and analyzed to the hilt because they were once the cutting edge, the focus of the avant-garde ideas about strategy.


Record Milk Prices Are Expected to Rise Further
LEAD: The price of milk rose to a record 75 cents a quart in the New York metropolitan region in October and is likely to rise even more before the end of the year, New York State milk marketing experts said this week.


Voters to Make Choices Tuesday for Governor and Assembly
LEAD: AFTER watching a bitter campaign for governor between James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate, and Jim Courter, the Republican nominee, voters will have their say on Tuesday, when they will also decide party control of the 80-member State Assembly and the fate of five public questions that call for $590 million in proposed spending.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. After a shower, water accumulated in the tub to a depth of seven inches.
After several hours, I removed the drain stopper and tried a 3-foot-long snake, but this did not help.
Drainage in the bathroom sink and basement sink seemed fine.
I started to scoop water out of the tub and pour a chemical drain cleaner into the toilet.


Precautions With Wood Stoves
LEAD: IF you are planning to get a wood-burning stove, there are several things to consider before making a choice.
First check with your building inspector or fire marshal to find out whether installing a wood stove is permitted where you live and what restrictions and requirements apply.


THE GUIDE
LEAD:  WALKING TOUR


Review/Theater; Neil Simon's Dismal New York City
LEAD: To be sure, life in New York City has its drawbacks.
Crime is rampant, pollution is everywhere and nothing works: if the hospitals or the garbage men aren't on strike, the water is turned off.
But it could be worse.
You could have Mel Edison as a neighbor.


Editors' Note
LEAD: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today and the section's cover drawing, about the new production of ''The Threepenny Opera,'' depict Maureen McGovern in the role of Polly Peachum.
After the section went to press, it was announced that because of a vocal cord injury, Ms.
McGovern would not perform for several weeks.


Xavier Goes to Great Lengths to Play
LEAD: There has been no Metro Bowl, pitting the best teams from the Catholic High Schools Football League against the best from the Public Schools Athletic League, since 1986.
So Xavier and Fordham Prep had no reason to believe there would be added significance to their annual Thanksgiving Day clash this year, no worry that the winner would qualify to play the public school champion.

Texas Instruments Gets Personal
LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. last week added its name to the growing list of companies that are offering impressive portable computers and personal laser printers.
Well known as a maker of semiconductors, industrial automation and control systems, military electronics and powerful calculators, T.I. has in recent years offered few products that the average consumer of business computers might buy off the shelf.


Island Haven For Wildlife In Georgia
LEAD: GEORGIA'S last family-owned barrier island and a wilderness resort, Little St.
Simons, about halfway between Savannah and Jacksonville, Fla., is not to be confused with neighboring St.
Simons, a 15-minute boat ride away, which it caps like a beret.
St.
Simons has sleek golf and tennis resorts, condominium colonies and shopping malls.


Pastimes; Camera
LEAD: Remember Art Linkletter's comment that ''Kids say the darndest things?'' Well, readers of this column can say the darndest things, too.

LEAD:  ASHES OF IZALCO.
By Claribel Alegria and Darwin J. Flakoll.
Translated by Darwin J. Flakoll. (Curbstone Press/Talman, Cloth, $17.95; Paper, $9.95.) A political polemic presented in the form of a novel is a tricky hybrid.
To be persuasive while balancing the message with the medium is no mean feat.

LEAD: THE TEACHERS and administrators of William B. Travis High School in Austin, Tex., have a vision: they want to transform Travis into a world-class school with an emphasis on the study of global issues, using computers and other advanced technology.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation says it will purge its files of thousands of names of people and organizations collected during its controversial investigation of Americans who protested United States policy in Central America.

LEAD: Making sense of the weather is never easy, but at no time of the year is it trickier than now.
The lined trench coat is back from storage and ready for duty, and the muffler and gloves are standing by in the hall closet, along with the boots.
Unless someone has made a grievous error, this is November.

LEAD: Siran Stacy ran for 149 yards and Gary Hollingsworth passed for 151 today as Alabama defeated Mississippi State, 23-10, and moved closer to its first Southeastern Conference title since 1981.


Brazil's Atlantic Playground
LEAD: DWARFED by the transoceanic behemoths of Air France and Varig, a small blue-and-white propeller plane scoots every day past Recife's imposing international air terminal.
Once airborne, the plane leaves behind Brazil's northeastern bulge and heads out to sea, in the direction of Africa.


Nets Keep Calm To Edge the Magic
LEAD: There was nothing magical about the Nets' victory tonight.
They earned it.
The Nets won because they stood up to an emotional effort from the expansion Orlando Magic, which was making its National Basketball Association debut before a festive and vocal sellout crowd.

LEAD: Three months after President Bush's nominee for the nation's top civil rights enforcement job was rejected by the Senate Judiciary Committee, Bush Administration officials say it is unlikely that the Justice Department post will be filled before January.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; Where Even the Ivy Is Ivy-Covered
LEAD: The last stretch of road to Princeton University winds through trees, past tilled fields and over Lake Carnegie, a body of water perfectly shaped - by design - for the sport of rowing.
If, as on one Sunday in autumn, the lake is full of delicate boats powered by young people with considerable muscle definition, cheered on by banner-waving fans, the perfect collegiate moment may be experienced.

LEAD: ''The Venetians: Modern Glass 1919-90,'' the largest exhibition of post-World War I Venetian glass vessels ever mounted in New York, now fills the Muriel Karasik gallery, 1094 Madison Avenue, at 82d Street.
It will remain through Dec. 2.


Review/Pop; Some Good Dirty Fun
LEAD: In a series of mock violent skits by the group Gwar at the Rapp Arts Center on Monday night, heads rolled, blood spurted into the audience, a mutant animal wrestled with a Roman centurion and oversize sex organs appeared in various forms.


Female Rappers Strut Their Stuff In a Male Domain
LEAD: In most rap songs, there are only two kinds of women - those who say yes, to become pliant and ornamental sex objects, and those who say no, to be reviled as coldhearted money-grubbers.
That's because, well beyond its first decade, rap has been an almost exclusively male domain.
Although the first wave of rap records in the late 1970's included a female group, the Funky Four Plus One, among the hundreds of rappers making records during the 1980's, there have been barely enough female performers to be counted on both hands.


Shedding Light on Evil Men and a Sinister Time
LEAD: One of the more alarming chapters in recent American history is an often overlooked episode from the 1920's.
The wonder is that a time so filled with evil men and frightening doings has remained in obscurity; that it didn't scare Americans half to death.
And that such an episode has only now been given dramatic re-creation, in a two-part NBC mini-series, ''Cross of Fire.


PITCHING DOCTORS
LEAD: THE SUDDEN DEATH LAST JUNE OF JOHN Matuszak, once a defensive lineman for the Los Angeles (formerly Oakland) Raiders, was initially ascribed to cocaine, but later was declared by the Los Angeles County Coroner to be the result of an accidental overdose of a prescription drug.
Matuszak had been relieving chronic back pain with Darvocet, a form of propoxyphene.


Giuliani and Dinkins Income Reports Put Them in New York City's Top 2%
LEAD: While neither the Democratic nor the Republican candidate for mayor appears to enjoy a lavish style of living, their incomes put them comfortably in the top 2 percent of taxpayers in New York City.


Traffic Alert
LEAD: Because of the New York City Marathon, these streets will be closed to traffic in Manhattan for much of this morning and afternoon: First Avenue from 59th Street to the Willis Avenue Bridge, Fifth Avenue from 136th Street to 102d Street and Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Broadway.
In addition, some traffic lanes on the Queensboro Bridge, the Willis Avenue Bridge, the Madison Avenue Bridge and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge will be closed.


A Soviet Hoopster In the Promised Land
LEAD: Sarunas Marciulionis, the first Soviet ever signed to a National Basketball Association contract, is lying face down across a trainer's table in the basement of the New England College gym in Henniker, N.H.
It's late summer, the beginning of preseason rookie camp for Marciulionis's new team, the Golden State Warriors, and, after a workout, he is being treated for a strained lower back.

LEAD: Peggy Noonan paints a rather bleak picture of the pervasive White House milieu - one in which staff members are encouraged to be ''average'' and where, thanks to speechwriters, the Administration ''got invented every day.''

LEAD: MOST OF MY 240 graduate and undergraduate students at the Beijing Institute of Chemical Technology were witty, wise, sweet and highly intelligent - sometimes brilliant.
They were patriotic, with a deep-rooted love of their homeland, its ways and its people.

And with each loss, the load increases.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: When the 0-8 Dallas Cowboys take the field against the Washington Redskins today, the starting Dallas quarterback will be Steve Walsh, not his fellow rookie, Troy Aikman, according to Coach Jimmy Johnson, who said that Aikman had not made enough progress in recovering from a finger injury to reclaim the job.


Students Say Best Death Is a Late One
LEAD: ''LIVE HIGH, die young and leave behind a good-looking corpse,'' a slogan among college students of the 80's that was popularized by an article in Rolling Stone magazine, has met its own early demise.
Most students want to live long, prosper and die painlessly at an old age, according to a survey of more than 200 students at the Rochester Institute of Technology.


Pharmacies Fight Off New Competition
LEAD: There is a drug war in America today that has nothing to do with crack dens and money laundering.
Pharmacies are fighting to keep what was once their exclusive domain: the retail market for prescription drugs.
Since 1985, health maintenance organizations, doctors and mail-order houses have cornered a growing share of that business and last year sold 15 percent of the nation's $28 billion in prescription drugs.

LEAD: The Jets activated Pat Ryan yesterday, giving them a proven alternative to Ken O'Brien at quarterback for the first time this season.


Uprising Aggravates Israel's Economic Troubles
LEAD: As Israel enters its 11th month of deep recession and the unemployment rate moves toward 10 percent, political leaders are increasingly blaming the Palestinian uprising.

LEAD: It would doubtless overstate the case to call S. I. Newhouse the George Steinbrenner of publishing.

In 1986, William Shawn, the longtime editor of The New Yorker, got the unexpected ax.
Last year, it was Grace Mirabella, the editor of Vogue.

COLD FUSION CONFUSION
LEAD: I was amused, then not so amused by ''Symptom No. 2: The 'discoverers' are outsiders.'' The ridicule of outsiders in their quest for truth is the hallmark of orthodoxy.
The function of orthodoxy, however, is to preserve the status quo.
Creativity comes from outsiders, like two bicycle mechanics from Dayton, or a lonely patent clerk in Switzerland.

It now reads ''Welcome to Starrett at Spring Creek.''

No Sweat
LEAD: A deeply held belief, usually acquired from childhood memories of castor oil, holds that no medicine can really be effective unless it tastes horrible.
It follows that no exercise can really be of benefit unless it brings aches, agony and sweat.

LEAD: The list of eminences now willing to consider legalization or decriminalization of drugs now includes Milton Friedman, the renowned economist; William F. Buckley, the journalist; Ira Glasser, head of the American Civil Liberties Union, and Kurt Schmoke, Mayor of Baltimore.

Resignation at Magazine
LEAD: The publisher of The Ladies' Home Journal, Robert D. Thomas, said yesterday that he was stepping down after 12 years to ''pursue other business and publishing interests.'' He is being replaced by Donna Galotti, advertising director of the magazine.
Mr.
Thomas was said to be unavailable to discuss his reasons for leaving the magazine, owned by the Meredith Corporation of Des Moines.

LEAD: DUCK and goose hunting can be a simple endeavor, or it can involve a considerable expenditure of time, effort and money.
The most casual approaches to waterfowling involve nothing more than positioning oneself in a likely spot and waiting for the birds to fly by within shotgun range, or poking along the edge of stream, river, lake or marsh, hoping to get close enough to birds resting or feeding on the water.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Becker Beats Edberg: Boris Becker, his leg muscles feeling tight after playing almost 14 hours in four days, handily defeated Stefan Edberg, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday to win the Paris Open.
But fatigue from three grueling matches earlier in the tournament forced Becker to bandage his thigh midway through the two-hour contest and take chances to end the match quickly.

No other runner has competed in as many.

LEAD: THE furor over program trading and index arbitrage has obscured a telling point: in the seven years since stock-index futures began trading, their overall effect has almost certainly raised, not lowered, stock prices.

Question Box
LEAD:  The Winning Pitcher  Q. In Game 2 of the National League playoff last month, the Cubs led San Francisco, 6-2, in Chicago, when the Giants put two runners on base with two out in the fifth inning.
With the dangerous Will Clark, a left-handed batter, coming up, Manager Don Zimmer removed his starter, Mike Bielecki, a right-hander, and replaced him with the left-handed Paul Assenmacher, who retired Clark to end the inning.

Pepsico-Perrier
LEAD: Pepsico Inc. said it had decided to end its franchise relationship with Source Perrier's subsidiary, Compagnie Francaise de Boissons Gazeuses S.A., at the end of next year because it failed to produce the desired results.
Source Perrier is the mineral-water giant based in France. ''We have taken this action to safeguard our market position, which has, in fact, shown consistent decline over the past 10 years and to protect the future of our brands given the enormous growth potential of the French soft drink market,'' Pepsico said.

Critic's Notebook; Romanticizing Hollywood's Dream Factory
LEAD: Hortense Powdermaker could be a screen name concocted by some mischievous junior press agent, giddy from a long day of inventing names to rival Rock Hudson or Tab Hunter.
But Miss Powdermaker was a real and serious anthropologist who spent 1947 doing fieldwork in Hollywood and emerged with a study that defined the central paradox of studio-controlled movie making.


Colgate-Palmolive To Acquire Vipont
LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company will acquire Vipont Pharmaceutical Inc. for about $94 million, enabling Colgate to strengthen its oral hygiene product line.
The merger agreement calls for Vipont, based in Fort Collins, to sell Colgate all of its outstanding common shares, at $14 a share.
Vipont will also spin off to its shareholders on Dec.


Chrysler Changes
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation is changing its corporate structure, disbanding its four-year-old holding company structure.
Under the change, the Chrysler Motors Corporation, the car-making arm of the company, will cease to exist on Jan. 1. ''We're merging Chrysler Motors into the Chrysler Corporation, and the legal entity of Chrysler Motors goes away,'' a company spokesman, Steve Harris, said.


Boeing Expected to Plead Guilty in Pentagon Case
LEAD: The Boeing Company, one of the nation's largest military contractors, has agreed to plead guilty to two felony charges of illegally obtaining Pentagon planning documents, Government officials said today.

Mighty German Banks Face Curb
LEAD: West Germany's commercial banks have long been accused of having too much power over the nation's industry and financial markets.
They sit on the boards of almost every major West German company, they own big stakes in many large corporations and they dominate trading on the nation's securities markets.


Schoenfeld Dismissed As Coach Of Devils
LEAD: The Devils dismissed Jim Schoenfeld as their head coach yesterday and replaced him with John Cunniff, who had joined the team as an assistant coach last May.

Total Health Sale To Equicor Is Set
LEAD: Total Health Systems Inc. agreed to be acquired by the Equicor Equitable HCA Corporation for $2.90 a share, or a total of about $19 million.
Total Health, based in Great Neck, L.I., owns and operates health maintenance organizations with about 115,000 members and had revenues for the first half of 1989 of $51.8 million.


Court Rejects Challenges to Dalkon Accord
LEAD: The Supreme Court, turning down two final challenges, cleared the way today for the reorganization of the A. H. Robins Company and the payment of up to $2.5 billion in damages to women injured by the Dalkon Shield, the company's defective contraceptive device.

LEAD: Columbia and Hartwick are back in the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament after a four-year absence, but Adelphi and Long Island University, who had legitimate hopes, were left out when the bids for the Division I tournament were announced yesterday.

LEAD: The departing American chief negotiator on conventional arms said today that to achieve an early agreement with the Soviet bloc, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization might need to drop its widely acclaimed proposal to include aircraft and troops in the Vienna talks.

Manila Stocks at High
LEAD: The main Philippine stock market reached a record high today after investors overcame weekend jitters caused by street demonstrations and President Corazon C. Aquino's departure for the United States.
The composite index rebounded 2.9 percent to close at 1,348.16 points.
The previous high was 1,337.47 on July 21, 1987.

Critic's Notebook; Day 3,650: Looking Back at the Hostages Crisis
LEAD: The seizure of the United States embassy in Teheran by Iranian revolutionaries on Nov. 4, 1979, and the capture of 65 staff members created a foreign policy emergency for Washington, a political disaster for President Jimmy Carter and an opportunity for television to demonstrate its power.
Now, 10 years later, the networks are replaying those strong pictures of blindfolded Americans and raging Iranians.


Bank Choice On Mexico
LEAD: Mexico has received replies from 42 percent of its foreign creditor banks on a debt renegotiation plan, and 90 percent of them are opting to reduce principal and interest rather than grant new loans, the official news agency Notimex said today.

From the Libretto of the Mayoral Campaign, Selected Verses
LEAD: If the New York City mayoral race has been filled with sour notes, it has also produced its share of sweet music.
Partisan poets of both camps have composed a veritable album of campaign songs - all of them unofficial, many of them unsolicited and most of them unheard.


Services for Horowitz
LEAD: The body of the pianist Vladimir Horowitz, who died of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan on Sunday afternoon, will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, tomorrow afternoon, with visiting hours from 4 to 7.
Mr.
Horowitz was 86 years old.
The pianist's wife, Wanda Toscanini Horowitz, will fly to Milan, Italy, with her husband's body on Thursday.


How to Love New York
LEAD: Maybe on Inauguration Day the next mayor will reveal to us a new plan for meeting the problems of New York, a whole set of fresh proposals for action that never occurred to Ed Koch during his 12 years in office.


BATTLE IN INDIANA LOOMS ON GAMBLING
LEAD: Voters in this economically depressed steel town endorsed casino gambling by a wide margin in a nonbinding referendum Saturday, clearing the way for a battle in the State Legislature over casino legislation.

Kumerow Is Arrested
LEAD: Eric Kumerow, a reserve defensive end for the Miami Dolphins, faces two felony counts of assaulting a police officer after reportedly punching a policeman Sunday night outside a sports bar in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that is operated by a former Dolphins safety, Mike Kozlowski.
Kumerow and his sister, Cheryl, were arrested after the police were called to the bar, Koz's, because of a fight inside the establishment.

30 Gramercy Apartments Ransacked
LEAD: More than 30 Gramercy Park residents - some of the 400 people forced to abandon their apartments after an asbestos-lined steam pipe exploded 11 weeks ago - have learned in recent days that their homes have been ransacked in their absence.


Lin and BellSouth
LEAD: The BellSouth Corporation and the Lin Broadcasting Corporation said that the waiting period under Federal law for their merger had expired.
Lin said it expected its proxy statement to be mailed to shareholders in the next few weeks for a meeting in December or early January.
The agreement calls for the merger of BellSouth's domestic cellular holdings with those of Lin.

LEAD: The Right to Life Party has withdrawn its endorsement of a candidate for State Supreme Court who serves as the lawyer for a Buffalo abortion clinic.

Most Hungarians Enjoy Freedom From Politics
LEAD: The vast majority of Hungarians are using their new political freedom to stay out of politics.


Reviews/Music; Najma Akhtar in U.S. Debut
LEAD: Najma Akhtar, a British singer of Indian descent, has made herself comfortable between two worlds.
In her United States debut, on Friday at Town Hall, she turned ancient poetry into cross-cultural songs, using Eastern and Western instruments to give the underpinnings of Western pop to Indian-inflected melodies.


International Paper
LEAD: The International Paper Company, the world's biggest paper manufacturer, will buy a majority stake in the West German paper maker Zanders Feinpapiere A.G.
The deal will proceed as soon as the Federal Cartel Office grants permission.
A representative of International Paper assured the supervisory board of Zanders, which employs about 4,000 workers, that it would win new markets in the United States.


Juergen Tonndorf, 75, Professor of Medicine
LEAD: Dr.
Juergen Tonndorf, a professor emeritus of otolaryngology at the Columbia University College of Physicians &amp; Surgeons, died of kidney failure on Friday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
He was 75 years old.


Tent Jail Closes in New Jersey
LEAD: Hudson County's tent jail closed today after a battle between state and county officials over the need to find more room for inmates.
The last 23 inmates were transferred to the county's new jail in Kearny, closing a chapter in New Jersey's struggle to reduce prison overcrowding.
Of the 12-tent jail, set up in an old quarry, a Corrections Department spokeswoman, Pat Mulcahy, said: ''It was very successful.


It's Premature for Pierce to Take the Fifth; Unseemly Assertion
LEAD: To the Editor:


Malaysian Tax Haven
LEAD: Malaysia will turn Labuan Island in Borneo into an international tax haven as part of efforts to attract multinational companies, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said today at an economic forum here.
He did not elaborate.
The 32-square-mile island in the Malaysian state of Sabah is a free port, which houses a shipyard and a gas complex.


Venezuela to Buy Rest of Citgo
LEAD: In what would be the first case of an OPEC member owning all of a large American oil refiner and marketer, Venezuela's state-owned oil company said today that it had agreed to acquire the remaining 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation.


Barry Sadler, 49, Balladeer, Dies
LEAD: Barry Sadler, a former combat medic with the United States Special Forces in Vietnam who recorded ''The Ballad of the Green Berets,'' died Sunday.
He was 49 years old.

A Draft Law Grants East Germans the Right to Travel or Emigrate
LEAD: East Germany today published the draft of a law that declared for the first time that every citizen has the right to travel abroad or to emigrate.
But against the weekend backdrop of yet another surge of emigration to West Germany, the measure seemed to attract little excitement.

LEAD: When Ronald Madson applied to the New York City Board of Education to have his live-in companion covered by his health insurance, the rejection arrived as a scribbled note across the top of the application, ''Only married spouses can obtain these benefits.''

Jacob M. Schein, 49, Head of Drug Concern
LEAD: Jacob M. Schein, who headed a manufacturer and distributor of generic drugs and supplies for the medical, dental and veterinary professions, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Pound Ridge, N.Y.
He was 49 years old.


Oldest Known Dinosaur Is Reconstructed
LEAD: SCIENTISTS have reconstructed the remains of the oldest known dinosaur, a flesh-eating creature with a jaw like an alligator that scampered around on its hind legs.


Greek Elections Leave Two Rivals in Deadlock
LEAD: Greeks awoke today to a sight that astonished even this land of cantankerous politics: the country's two most powerful men deadlocked, each claiming the right to govern but neither with enough seats in Parliament to take the reins of power.


Gasoline Prices Decline
LEAD: Retail gasoline prices fell almost one cent a gallon in the last two weeks, continuing a downward trend, an analyst said.
The average price for all grades of gasoline, including taxes, was $1.0816 a gallon, down 0.95 cent from the two-week survey that ended Oct. 20, according to the Lundberg Survey of 12,000 United States service stations.


P.L.O. Wants a Say on Negotiators
LEAD: After meetings over the weekend, the Palestine Liberation Organization has said that it reserves the right to decide on the makeup of a Palestinian delegation that would meet with Israeli officials on elections in the occupied territories.

LEAD: TWO large employers that were among the earliest to make vigorous attempts to control their medical costs are reporting some successes.
They are among a growing number of large companies that are keeping their medical inflation well below the 20 percent or more that is being absorbed by many other businesses.

Cowens Added to List Of Nominees for Hall
LEAD: Officials of the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., yesterday announced that Dave Cowens, a former star center with the Boston Celtics, had been added to the list of players renominated for election.
Jerry Healy, a Hall of Fame publicist, said that Cowens's name was inadvertently omitted from the list of nominees released last


New Polish Devaluation
LEAD: Poland devalued the zloty today by 14.3 percent.
It was the fourth devaluation since the Solidarity-led Government took office in September.
The devaluation is part of a program to narrow the large gap between the free market and official rates of the currency against the dollar.
The National Bank set the new rate at 2,800 zloties to the dollar, compared with 2,400 on Friday.

Cynthia Northrop, 39, A Nurse and a Lawyer
LEAD: Cynthia Ellen Northrop, a nurse, lawyer and educator, died of colon cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 39 years old.
Ms.
Northrop, who was in private practice in New York, was also an adjunct professor at Teachers College and at the Graduate School of Health Services at New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y.

4 Arrested at Supreme Court
LEAD: Four people were arrested today when they disrupted oral arguments at the Supreme Court to protest the Court's ruling last July that enhanced the states' power to restrict abortions.
In a brief outburst in the ornate courtroom, each of the protesters rose, denounced the ruling and was immediately taken into custody.


Education; Potential Donors Figure In Entry to Vermont U.
LEAD: Officials of the University of Vermont, which has benefited significantly in recent years from the enrollment of out-of-state students, have said they sometimes admit a few of these students partly because their families are wealthy and likely to give money to the university.

LEAD: The style and tone with which David N. Dinkins will confront some of the most serious problems New York City has ever faced will be more reminiscent of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner - slow and easy - than of Edward I. Koch - fast and frenetic, Dinkins associates agree.

C.
Anthony Wainwright, who last month resigned as chairman and chief executive of the Bloom Companies, was named corporate vice chairman of Esty, which is a unit of Saatchi &amp; Saatchi.

LEAD: L. Douglas Wilder appeared to have eked out a narrow victory for the governorship of Virginia today, on the basis of almost complete but unofficial returns.

LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $2.3 billion in three-year and 10-year debentures through various securities dealers.

Paging Plan in Europe
LEAD: The 12 European Community nations agreed today to start a European radio messaging system after 1992 to enable business executives and other users of beepers to page each other across national borders.
At present, each country operates its own national paging system and very few systems operate across borders.

LEAD: Negotiators for the New York City Opera and its orchestra, which has been on strike since Sept. 13, reached a tentative agreement for a new contract late last night.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:  QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS  Return of Assets to Iran  Q. Mr.
President, the United States is returning $567 million in frozen assets to Iran but says the action is not related to the plight of the eight Americans held hostage in Lebanon.

LEAD: Carlo Verri, the chairman of Italy's state-owned airline, was killed Monday when his car collided with a city bus, the authorities said.

A Welcome Inch in the Mideast
LEAD: The Arab-Israeli peace process has operated at two speeds - big leaps like the sudden flight to Jerusalem by President Sadat of Egypt in 1977, or microscopic steps that usually wind into circles.
This week Israel has offered a welcome new inch.
The Israeli Government now says the smallest possible yes to Secretary of State Baker's plan for initiating Palestinian-Israeli talks.

LEAD: A small potato chip company, whose product sells in expensive stores, is in talks aimed at setting up a joint venture to make chips in the Soviet Union.

60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: JUST because the leaves have fallen, there is no reason to forsake barbecues, even if they have to be simulated indoors with a kitchen broiler.
A good hot broiler can approximate the cooking technique of an outdoor grill.
Of course, you will not get any of the woody nuances possible with open flames and wood chips, but the results can be delicious nonetheless.

Why I Won't Run in the Marathon

LEAD: The Parking Violations Bureau comtions Bureau computer system has double-billed and collected fines from thousands of motorists who already had paid what they owed, state audits have found.


Supermarket as Theater, Service as Star
LEAD: AT the four-month-old Wegmans store in Greece, N.Y., shoppers are not greeted at the door by a row of checkout counters and aisle upon aisle of packaged goods.
Instead, their first impression is of a farmers' market, with enormous displays of fresh fruits and vegetables.

LEAD: Representative James J. Florio swept to a lopsided victory yesterday in the race for governor of New Jersey as voters rejected the campaign of his Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, who promised to fight crime, taxes and big government.


Ups and Downs of '89 New York Harvest
LEAD: Markus Riedlin, a wine maker, is excited.
Gene Pierce is pleased.
Cesar Baeza is glum.
And Ray Blum is grateful that his vineyards escaped destruction by Hurricane Hugo.
Their moods seem to reflect the variations in the 1989 New York harvest.


Commodore Reports Loss
LEAD: Commodore International Ltd. today reported a loss of $6.5 million in its first fiscal quarter, citing decreased demand for its computers.


AIDS Rulings Help the Falsely Accused
LEAD: Recent decisions in three cases charging AIDS-related discrimination are being hailed as important precedents that broaden protections in New York City and New York State.
The law is now said to cover people who are mistakenly believed to carry the virus that causes the disease and people who have the virus but are not yet ill.

LEAD: A former top Federal regulator testified today that four United States Senators had tried to persuade him to drop a tough regulation affecting a California savings institution whose owner gave the Senators more than $1 million in campaign funds.

LEAD: An article yesterday about Richard M. Nixon's visit to the White House, where he discussed his recent trip to China, misidentified the President who sent George Bush to Beijing as chief American diplomat.
It was Gerald R. Ford.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, articles yesterday and on Monday about the use of contractors by the Energy Department misstated the time of Energy Secretary James D. Watkins's appearance before a Congressional committee.
He testified in April this year, not in 1988.


Review/Pop; An NRBQ Retrospective
LEAD: It didn't take long for NRBQ to reach a state of euphoria at the Bottom Line on Friday night.
About halfway through the first tune, ''Rocket in My Pocket'' - pushed on by the fluid rhythm section and a crushing backbeat - Terry Adams, the group's pianist, delivered a solo full of cascading clusters and jarring upper register tinkles that had the crowd cheering loudly.

LEAD: For a while now, the Communist leaders of Czechoslovakia have regarded the political changes in Poland and Hungary as avoidable aberrations and looked instead to another neighbor, East Germany, for confirmation of their own policies of tight control.
Now, as East German protests mount and East German leaders resign, doubts here are rising.

The concert will not be rescheduled.

Amanda Blake Died of AIDS, Doctor Says
LEAD: Amanda Blake, the actress who played Miss Kitty on the long-running television series ''Gunsmoke,'' died of AIDS-related complications and not, as a hospital and her friends reported at the time, of cancer, her doctor says.


Nigerian Effort Praised
LEAD: Nigeria's efforts to turn around its economy, battered by declining oil prices, were praised by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund at a meeting of aid donors, a World Bank official said today.
At a meeting in Paris, Caio Koch-Weser, director of the World Bank's West African department, ''commended the Nigerian Government's determination in pursuing its structural adjustment program,'' the official said.


Richard C. Bond Is Dead at 80; Retired Wanamaker Chain Head
LEAD: Richard C. Bond, a Philadelphia civic leader and retired head of the John Wanamaker department store chain, died of pancreatic cancer and a cerebral hemmorhage Saturday at Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia.
He was 80 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

The Aruba Tourism Authority awarded its $3 million account to AC&amp;R yesterday.
The tourism board for Los Cabos, a Mexican resort community, awarded its $4 million account to HDM Los Angeles.

Coniston Meeting
LEAD: Coniston Partners, the New York investment group that is seeking to restructure the UAL Corporation, will meet in Washington tomorrow with officials from the airline machinists' union.
Coniston last week said it holds a large stake in Chicago-based UAL, the parent of United Airlines.
Last month, a $6.75 billion bid for UAL from management and pilots collapsed, in part because of opposition from the machinists.


Secord Reportedly Agrees To Enter Guilty Plea Today
LEAD: Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force general who brokered arms deals that figured in the Iran-contra affair, has agreed to enter a guilty plea as part of a deal with prosecutors to resolve the criminal charges against him, sources said tonight.

LEAD: While they say the consequences of the sudden and mounting demonstrations in East Germany defy precise prediction, American scholars specializing in German and European affairs generally agree that the mass marches have gone beyond the point where force could be used to quell them.

LEAD: Where the Department of Housing and Urban Development is concerned, Senator Alfonse D'Amato more and more resembles a child who, despite crumbs all over his face, reflexively denies he has been near the cookie jar.
When will the Senate Ethics Committee show some interest?

LEAD: Eastern Airlines has told the law firm for its creditors that it is short $200 million and will seek to amend its plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, a person involved in Eastern's bankruptcy case said yesterday.

The Mayor
LEAD: New York City, whether melting pot or mosaic, has now conferred its collective respect on another branch of the American family.
By electing David Dinkins as Mayor, New York has released a wave of pride in its citizens of African-American heritage and a sense of unity among the many white voters who rallied to his cause.


Guards' Lawyer Asks Counts Against Fans
LEAD: The lawyer for nine guards charged with beating fans at the Meadowlands Sports Complex last month says countercharges have been filed against five patrons ''to keep a proper perspective.''


Real Estate; Business Aid For Districts In 5 Boroughs
LEAD: EIGHTEEN New York City neighborhoods have formed Business Improvement Districts, in which assessments paid by commercial properties and businesses support a variety of services and programs.
Ten such districts, called BID's, are being developed and 18 others in all five boroughs are considering forming such local civic groups.


EAST GERMAN FLOW TO WEST CONTINUES
LEAD: The tide of East Germans flooding through Czechoslovakia into West Germany continued to rise today, and it showed no sign of ebbing, the border police said.


Jordan Gets 40 Points As Bulls Top Pistons
LEAD: Michael Jordan connected on a slam dunk after Scottie Pippin stole the ball from Isiah Thomas with 1 minute 5 seconds remaining in the game, breaking a tie and lifting the Bulls to a 117-114 victory over Detroit, their first victory over the Pistons here since Jan. 16, 1988.

LEAD: It has been a long and steady downward spiral for this onetime center of shoe factories and thriving shops 25 miles south of Boston.

LEAD: The NCR Corporation and Businessland Inc., the nation's largest personal computer retailer, said yesterday that Businessland would add NCR's personal computers to its product line.

A New Coating Thwarts Chip Pirates
LEAD: Several years ago, clever high-technology pirates removed a chip from a satellite-television descrambling device made by the General Instrument Corporation, electronically siphoned out hidden decryption software and studied it to figure out a way to receive clear TV signals.


Education: About Education
LEAD: ''Those in power want only to perpetuate it,'' Associate Justice William O. Douglas once said.
By now, those who contend that giving teachers greater power is the way to improve education know how difficult it is to persuade those in power - the principals, superintendents and school boards - to share that power.


Japan's Looking Glass
LEAD: The manuscript that is the rage of Washington, ''The Japan That Can Say 'No,' '' is beginning to cross the Atlantic.
Europeans who know of it are appalled, though it is not about Europe and a lot of the America-bashing points are endorsed by European businessmen.


Cutbacks at GTE
LEAD: The GTE Corporation said it would lay off 800 workers, close two Massachusetts plants and 17 warehouses nationwide in a restructuring of its distribution system.
The GTE light bulb plant operations in Salem will be moved to Pennsylvania.
The operations of GTE's Fall River fixtures plant will be moved to Toronto.


L.I. Killer Gets 33 Years to Life
LEAD: A marksman who shot and killed one man and wounded another, apparently because he thought they owed him money, was sentenced yesterday to 33 and one-third years to life in prison.


Sports People:HOCKEY; Richter Goes to Minors
LEAD: The Rangers yesterday sent the second-year goaltender Mike Richter, a former United States Olympian, to their minor league affiliate in Flint, Mich.
Richter had started just one of the team's 16 games this season, compiling a goals-against average of 2.12.
His National Hockey League debut was in the team's 4-3 loss to the Penguins in the Rangers' last playoff game last spring.


New Jersey Towns Face a Fall Compost Crisis
LEAD: The disposal of autumn leaves, usually not considered a problem for towns and cities, could become a costly one for 35 Bergen County communities that have been ordered by state environmental officials to shut down a composting operation.


Braniff Puts Itself Up for Sale
LEAD: Braniff Inc., which suspended all passenger flights on Monday night, has put itself up for sale.
But only small investors have shown an interest in buying the company.
And several analysts said yesterday that it appeared unlikely that Braniff's hub city, Kansas City, Mo., would soon find another large carrier to fill the void, although several airlines are adding flights there.


Losing Sleep
LEAD: To The Living Section:


The 1989 Elections; Houston Councilman Out
LEAD: Jim Westmoreland, a Houston City Council member who provoked widespread outrage here by making a racial slur, was defeated for re-election tonight by a political newcomer.


U.S. Silver Production
LEAD: The United States is expected to become the world's top silver producer as labor disputes keep Mexicans away from the mines while prospectors extract more metals in the United States, the Silver Institute said today.
United States output this year should rise to 65.80 million ounces from 54.50 million last year, according to the institute, a worldwide association of miners, refiners, fabricators and manufacturers.


Greek Conservative Gets Coalition Deadline
LEAD: Constantine Mitsotakis, leader of the conservative New Demacracy Party, received a presidential go-ahead today to try to form a new government, but party officials say he faces a difficult time.


Bush Nominates Watt II
LEAD: George Bush, who not so many years ago was justly critical of Ronald Reagan's ''voodoo economics,'' has become past master of an even more illusory art form: voodoo politics.


In Japan, It's Costly to Be a Consumer
LEAD: Japanese consumers are paying about twice as much as Americans for electric shavers, floppy disk drives and camera lenses and three and a half times as much for spark plugs, a survey conducted by Japanese and American Government agencies showed today.


Emmerling Is Picked
LEAD: The United Weight Control Corporation, an operator of weight-loss programs based in Englewood, N.J., has chosen John Emmerling Inc. for its agency.
The account, which industry reports have placed at $1 million in annual billings, had been at Tarlow Advertising since January.


N.F.L. Players Union Seeks Decertification
LEAD: The National Football League Players Association, acting in the aftermath of a court decision unfavorable to it, said today that it would surrender its collective-bargaining rights for the league's players.


Rise in Consumer Debt Slowed in September
LEAD: American consumers dramatically slowed their taking on of new debt in September, adding only $606 million in what analysts said was new caution about buying cars and other expensive items.


Results Plus
LEAD:  HORSE RACING  Trans Banner by a Neck: Casetta Farm's Trans Banner rallied into the stretch and won the $97,950 Knickerbocker Handicap yesterday for 3-year-old's and up at Aqueduct.
Soviet Lad, who contended throughout, lost by only a neck in the field of 12.
Impersonator was third by a half-length.

LEAD: Pennsylvania yesterday priced $177 million in general obligation bonds through competitive bidding, with the issue being awarded to underwriters led by Citicorp Securities Markets Inc.

LEAD: The Herald Center, the 10-story vertical mall that sits across 34th Street from Macy's, will be auctioned this morning in a court-approved foreclosure action by Security Pacific Mortgage and Real Estate Services, the property's mortgagor.

LEAD: Black candidates demonstrated in the elections yesterday that a deliberate approach, ample experience in office and a knack for turning minority status into a political asset could constitute a formula for electoral success.

LEAD: New Yorkers yesterday approved the most thorough overhaul of the municipal government since the Greater City of New York was created in 1898.

LEAD: An investment group led by Perry R. Bass of Fort Worth, raised its stake in Universal Health Services Inc. class B common stock to 8.8 percent from 6.9 percent.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said that it had acquired the shares as an investment.

Bronx Symphony Plans Free Opening Concert
LEAD: The Bronx Symphony Orchestra is to open its 10th season at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx with a free concert conducted by its new director, Michael Spierman, on Nov. 19 at 3 P.M.
Mr.
Spierman, the director of the Bronx Opera Company, was director of the orchestra from 1968 to 1980.


China Cracks Down on Private Work
LEAD: In a sweeping nationwide crackdown on nonstate enterprises, China has shut down more than a million rural industrial collectives and forced the demise of 2.2 million private enterprises, the Government announced today.

LEAD: D'Jaris Hinton Watson, an administrator for three New York City mayors, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 61 years old.
