LEAD: Yonkers voters, in a narrow but stunning upset, elected City Councilman Henry Spallone as mayor.
Mr.
Spallone had campaigned on a pledge to continue the city's resistance to a Federal desegregation order requiring it to build low-income housing in white neighborhoods.


Illinois Prosecutor Asks Role in Negotiations in Abortion Case
LEAD: Concerned that state officials are pushing to settle a major abortion case before it can be heard by the United States Supreme Court, a county prosecutor will ask a Federal judge on Wednesday for permission to intervene in the negotiations.


Stealth in the Stacks
LEAD: Truly clever deceptions in the Federal budget are the ones that never come to light, but now and then a lulu makes the news.
Example: Pentagon procurement officers laundering consultants' fees through the Library of Congress.


Senators Sought Deal, Savings Official Says
LEAD: A former top Federal regulator testified yesterday that four United States Senators who received more than $1 million in campaign funds from a California savings executive had tried to persuade the Government to drop a tough regulation.


Times, Citing an Ad Slump, Will Close a Printing Plant
LEAD: The New York Times announced yesterday that advertising volume had declined so much in the last two years that it would shut its northern New Jersey printing plant by the end of next year as part of its overall strategy to reduce costs.


Agreement On Raising Debt Ceiling
LEAD: After weeks of political maneuvering that brought the Government to the brink of financial default, Congress tonight approved legislation raising the national debt limit to $3.12 trillion through Sept. 30, 1990.

LEAD: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly off for the week that ended yesterday.

It was the University of California at Los Angeles.

LEAD: TO most American teen-agers, the symbolic value of a driver's license goes far beyond the legal right to drive.
It is a token of their power and independence, an opportunity for privacy and romance and a sign of increased status that can separate them from younger friends and siblings.

Doping Conceded
LEAD: East German officials, acknowledging drugging cases for the first time, said 14 athletes were caught taking banned substances last year, the East Berlin newspaper Junge Welt reported yesterday.
The newspaper, official organ of the nation's Communist youth organization, said that starting next year the country would publish the names of athletes who test positive for drugs.

PHELAN Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, suggests that a form of computer-assisted program trading used by some large pension funds has the potential to become as destabilizing to the market as ''portfolio insurance,'' or using stock index futures to hedge a position in the stock market.

Vermont Fence Ruling Sustains Poet
LEAD: The Vermont Supreme Court, following a poetic precedent by Robert Frost, says good neighbors need not help keep up good fences.
The five justices on Tuesday found unconstitutional a 1790 law making a livestock owner and neighbors equally responsible for maintaining the fences between their properties.


HEALTH: Radiation Safety; Childhood X-Rays Linked to Breast Cancer Risk
LEAD: New breast cancer studies show that exposure to radiation in infancy significantly increases a woman's risk of later developing the disease, but that chest X-rays after the age of 35 pose little risk.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Layers of Shingles  Q.The asphalt shingles on my gabled roof are 22 years old, and new shingles must be installed soon.
I had planned to cover the old shingles with new building paper and then lay the new asphalt shingles on top.
But I have been told that if I do so, the new shingles will last only half as long because of heat buildup; two layers of shingles, I was told, will not allow proper cooling between the attic and the top layer.


New Turner Book Unit
LEAD: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said today that it was creating a division, Turner Publishing Inc., that will develop book publishing possibilities related to the parent company's other interests.


Closing 'Window of Time' When Life Began
LEAD: In a new analysis of Earth's first billion years, scientists have defined what they believe is the ''window in time'' when existing life forms gained their initial foothold.


Court Ruling Sets Back Genetic Engineering in Germany
LEAD: A West German court ruled today that Hoechst A.G., one of the nation's leading chemical companies, must immediately curtail its plan to produce genetically engineered human insulin for the treatment of diabetes.

New York State Seeks $76 Million In Fines Over Fresh Kills Landfill
LEAD: New York State's top environmental official filed a civil complaint against New York City today accusing it of ignoring his orders to clean up its huge Fresh Kills Landfill on Staten Island.
He is seeking $76 million in fines.
The official, Thomas C. Jorling, the Environmental Conservation Commissioner, also threatened to obtain a court order to close the dump by the summer of 1991.

Personal Health
LEAD: A chronic illness or major disability in a child can turn a family's life upside down.
Parents often suffer emotional and physical exhaustion trying to cope with the child's medical needs and expenses.
They may also have illogical feelings of guilt over the child's fate or face new demands from their healthy children.

LEAD: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section yesterday about a tasting of Long Island wines at the New-York Historical Society next Thursday misstated the admission policy.

Pete Rose: Telling Lies Or Truth?
LEAD: rrIn other years, wherever Pete Rose went in Cincinnati he drew a crowd.
Now he scatters a crowd.
Not long ago the Reds' former manager was observed having lunch at a counter in Cincinnati with three empty stools on each side.
Such is life when you've been banned from baseball even when you're Pete Rose, perhaps especially when you're Pete Rose.

Ford Lifts Rebates And Sets Layoffs
LEAD: Responding to increased competition and slower sales, the Ford Motor Company increased buyer incentives on certain car and truck models and plans to lay off up to 350 workers at a truck plant.
The company said its 1990 and 1989 models of the Escort would now carry cash rebates of $700, up from $600, while buyers of the 1990 Probe GT will receive $1,000, a $200 increase.

THATCHER URGES PACT ON CLIMATE
LEAD: Warning that global warming could cause devastating floods and food shortages in wide areas, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain called on the United Nations today to complete by 1992 a treaty that would require action toward stabilizing the world's climate.


Panel Told Chip Effort May Falter
LEAD: The American effort to regain supremacy in manufacturing semiconductors is being jeopardized by serious deterioration of the industry's suppliers, the top official of Sematech, a federally aided industry research consortium, warned today.


Arts Endowment Withdraws Grant for AIDS Show
LEAD: The National Endowment for the Arts yesterday withdrew its sponsorship of a New York City art show about AIDS that includes images of homosexual acts and criticizes public figures.
It was the first such decision by the agency since a law was passed this fall that will curtail Government financing of artwork considered obscene.

LEAD: Stanford Olsen was to sing his first Count Almaviva at the Metropolitan Opera when the company's production of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' opened a few weeks ago, but he fell ill the morning of the performance.
He has rejoined the cast since then, and was heard on Monday evening.
There were newcomers in the other principal roles, too, all of whom have sung their parts in recent seasons.

Everglades Measure Advances
LEAD: The House has approved a bill that would expand the Everglades National Park in Florida by 110,000 acres, or 8 percent, to protect it from encroaching commercial development.
The bill was passed on a voice vote Tuesday and sent to the Senate.
It calls for land acquisition.
The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that it would require spending $79 million over the next five years.

Monteverdi's 'Ulisse,' Problematic and Rare, Is Newly Popular
LEAD: Claudio Monteverdi's first opera, ''L'Orfeo'' is performed frequently, and his last one, ''L'Incoronazione di Poppea,'' has its advocates too.
But ''Il Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria'' the only other surviving opera by the composer, who was one of the genre's founders, has posed so many problems for musicians and musicologists that until recently, productions have been few and far between.

LEAD: Workers conducting a secret experiment with a laser beam at a nuclear weapons laboratory near Dayton, Ohio, accidentally shattered a quartz window and released a radioactive gas yesterday morning, the Department of Energy said.

Castro Laments 'Sad' Events
LEAD: President Fidel Castro of Cuba, apparently referring to pressures for reform in the Soviet bloc, has warned that ''very sad things'' are happening in other Communist nations and that Cuba could face serious difficulties if those countries do not solve their problems.
He spoke at the inauguration of a factory near Havana on Tuesday.

LEAD: Soviet ballet is personified, for many American dancegoers, by Vladimir Vasiliev and Yekaterina Maksimova, two of the Bolshoi Ballet's longtime stars.
Miss Maksimova is now 50 years old and Mr.
Vasiliev is 49.
But they still dance with the kind of technique and emotional commitment that made them audience favorites at the company's American debut in 1959, when they were regarded as ''the babies of the Bolshoi.

Recycling Group's Winners and Sinners of Product Packaging
LEAD: THE average American generates approximately 3.5 pounds of garbage a day.
According to Garbage magazine, half of the volume, and about 30 percent of the weight of this collective trash, is packaging: all those containers and wrappers, often alluringly designed, that tend to be thrown away.


New President Named At the Prospect Group
LEAD: The Prospect Group, a publicly traded company that has gathered an eclectic portfolio through leveraged buyouts, has named Gilbert H. Lamphere as its president.

Hollywood Journal; Where a Minister Rubs Heels With Stars
LEAD: If the issue under debate was how quickly Billy Graham would pass through the Pearly Gates, no one in Hollywood would have paid attention, except perhaps to consider acquiring the screen rights.


Mesa-Air Midwest
LEAD: Mesa Airlines Inc. and Air Midwest Inc. called off negotiations on Mesa's possible takeover of Air Midwest, which has lost business because of the problems at Braniff Inc.
Gary Risley, Mesa's vice president for corporate affairs, said that the companies had decided to end the talks and that Mesa had withdrawn its cash and stock offer for Air Midwest's outstanding shares.


Chiron Agreement
LEAD: The Chiron Corporation reached agreement with the Dai-Ichi Pure Chemicals Company of Japan to develop diagnostic products for Japan and Taiwan using DNA probe technology developed by Chiron.
Chiron will receive up to $20 million in royalties over five years for licensing its technology and for research.


I.B.M. Chip Is Licensed To Micron
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation, in a further effort to bolster the American semiconductor industry, said today that it would license the technology for making its most powerful computer memory chip to Micron Technology Inc.


More Free-Agent Filers
LEAD: Fernando Valenzuela, the Los Angeles Dodger left-hander who was among the top National League pitchers in the 1980's until experiencing arm problems the last two seasons, filed for free agency yesterday.
Valenzuela, who has a 128-103 record, fell to 5-8 in 1988 and 10-13 last season.


Review/Dance; Mixing the Cerebral and the Bluntly Bodily
LEAD: Senta Driver named her dance company Harry, and like that name, her choreography defies conventional explanation.
Whatever you think of Miss Driver's dances, her performers move in ways that others do not.


Metro Datelines; Chlorine Fire Routs 300 Jersey Families
LEAD: A chlorine fire yesterday morning forced the evacuation of about 300 families and sent at least five police officers and three firefighters to the hospital to be treated for inhaling fumes, the police said.


Random House Gets New Chief
LEAD: After almost a week of speculation about who would be chosen to head Random House Inc., the nation's leading publisher of books of general interest.
Alberto Vitale was named yesterday as its chairman, president and chief executive.

Full Translation Is Required In Immigration Proceedings
LEAD: A Federal district judge has ruled that interpreters at immigration proceedings must translate all of those proceedings, and not just part of them, if the alien involved does not understand English.

Kissinger, in Beijing, Seeks to Mend Fences
LEAD: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met today with three Politburo members and China's Foreign Minister in the first of a series of talks that both sides hope will help ease the strains between China and the United States.


House Passes Amendment on Spill Liability
LEAD: The House of Representatives voted today to preserve the authority of states to determine how much companies must spend to clean up oil spills.
The vote, on an amendment offered by several members, set the stage for passage of comprehensive oil spill legislation that has been debated off and on for 14 years.


2 Design Innovations, Forging a New Metal Age in Furniture
LEAD: THEIR backgrounds could not be further apart, and their furniture designs have little in common except for their choice of material: metal.
One is a brooding showman whose exuberant overscale pieces reflect his own dense muscularity; the other is a spinner of fables whose fanciful constructions transform metal into a nearly ephemeral material.

LEAD: Each day, every assembly-line worker at the Xerox Corporation's copier manufacturing plant here, near Rochester, receives a report on all defects found in the previous day's production.

Bridge
LEAD: Thousands of players converging on Lancaster, Pa., for the Fall Nationals beginning tomorrow will have mixed feelings.

Richard J. Hayes, 57; Led Xerox Subsidiary
LEAD: Richard J. Hayes, president of Xerox Venture Capital, a subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation, died of a heart attack Tuesday while on a business trip in Raleigh, N.C.
He was 57 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.


ASHLAND ACCEPTS OIL SPILL ACCORD
LEAD: Ashland Oil Inc. agreed to pay $30 million to settle 20 class-action civil suits from a diesel fuel spill nearly two years ago that polluted two rivers and threatened drinking water supplies in three states.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the oil company Petroleos de Venezuela misstated aspects of the agreement to add the Southland Corporation's 50 percent stake in Citgo Petroleum to the 50 percent it already owned.
Petroleos paid $290 million, not $400 million, for the stake that it bought in 1986.


Georgia-Pacific
LEAD: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, which last week offered to buy the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation for $3.1 billion, said the Interstate Commerce Commission would allow it to proceed with the proposed acquisition.
The deal would create the nation's largest forest-products company.
Nekoosa, based in Norwalk, Conn., has not responded formally to the bid.

CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: THERE are twins in my building, little girls alike only in their amiability and their very red hair.
I seldom see them, so when I heard their chortles in the hall one night last week I opened my door for a chat.
They were side by side in a stroller, waiting with their mother for the elevator, and delighted to see the diversion that was me.

LEAD: Though written three decades apart, Harold Pinter's first full-length work, the 1958 ''Birthday Party,'' and his latest play, the 20-minute ''Mountain Language,'' build to the same grotesque conclusion: a defenseless man is reduced to a quivering, speechless wreck by properly dressed thugs serving an unnamed organization.

Morocco Trade Deficit
LEAD: Morocco's trade deficit grew more than 60 percent in the first half of this year, according to official figures published today.
Officials attributed the increase to costlier oil and wheat imports and the loss of a 500,000-ton phosphoric acid contract with India.
The cost of imports soared 16.6 percent for the first six months, to $2.6 billion, while exports fell 4.6 percent, to $1.5 billion.


A de Kooning Work Sets A Record at $20.7 Million
LEAD: The November art auctions began with spirited bidding Tuesday night at Christie's in a sale of contemporary art that established records for the works of 26 artists and unexpectedly high prices for those of many others.

Shuttle Launching Is Set
LEAD: NASA on Tuesday set Nov. 20 as the date for the next space shuttle flight, in which a secret military payload is to be launched.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the shuttle Discovery would be launched between 6:30 P.M. and 10:30 P.M.
This would be only the third shuttle to be launched at night.

Who gets the gag lines when the Great Negotiator meets the Great Conciliator?

New Jersey Chooses Continuity
LEAD: New Jersey voters, leaving no doubt about their choice for governor, elected Representative James Florio over Representative Jim Courter by a 24-point margin.
The outcome was a triumph of Democrat over Republican, of an activist philosophy of government over a minimalist view.
Mostly, though, it was an expression of a widespread desire for continuity and moderation.

New Politburo in East Germany
LEAD:  Egon Krenz, 52, Politburo member since 1983, was responsible for security matters until he became General Secretary on Oct. 18.
Son of a tailor, he joined the party in 1955 and attended a party school in Moscow between 1964 and 1967.
For many years led the Communist youth organization.
Retained seat.

Paul, voters elected their first new mayor in 13 years after the incumbent decided not to seek re-election.

'Junk Bonds' Advance For Third Day in a Row
LEAD: Prices of ''junk bonds'' extended their rally for a third day yesterday.

St. Louis Bank Sets 10% Prime
LEAD: The Southwest Bank of St.
Louis, often a bellwether on interest rate trends, said yesterday that it would lower its prime lending rate to 10 percent from 10 1/2 percent, effective Thursday.
The move followed signs that the Federal Reserve is pushing down short-term interest rates.

RJR Nabisco Sale
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. said it would sell its Nabisco food businesses in Spain and Portugal to a Spanish company for $77.5 million.
In the cash deal, Tabacalera S.A. will buy RJR Nabisco's 50.5 percent interest in three Spanish food companies - Galletas Artiach S.A., Marbu S.A. and Nabisco Brands Espana S.A.

Review/Music; Hogwood's Academy in All-Beethoven Concert
LEAD: The small pool of crack period-instrument performers in London that Americans keep hearing about has evidently become a sizable lake.
For Christopher Hogwood's Beethoven concert with his Academy of Ancient Music on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, the program listed 47 players.
Only 11 of them were among the London Classical Players, 65 strong, who performed here recently with Roger Norrington.

Review/Television; 'McCloud' Joins the Ranks Of Prime-Time Revivals
LEAD: On network prime time, hunks and teen-agers' idols are as common as commercials, from Ken Wahl in CBS's ''Wiseguy'' to Richard Grieco in Fox's ''Booker.'' There is no dearth of pretty faces, young and youngish, trying to attract the 18-to-39-year-old women coveted by advertisers.
But a different kind of television hero is quietly emerging.


Chamorro Meets Bush and Vows to Reduce Army
LEAD: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the opposition candidate for President of Nicaragua, met today with President Bush and said she would sharply reduce the size of the Nicaraguan Army if she wins the election scheduled for February.


Maud Russell, 96; Aided Chinese
LEAD: Maud Russell, who spent a quarter of a century in China as a welfare worker and teacher for the Young Women's Christian Association and lobbied for American recognition of the Chinese Communist Government after World War II, died of lung cancer Wednesday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 96 years old.

Unocal to Close Texas Refinery
LEAD: The Unocal Corporation said it would suspend operations at its refinery here next year because the plant, built in 1924, is no longer profitable.
The operation, 45 miles northeast of Houston, has 462 employees, including 337 represented by labor unions, according to a statement from the Los Angeles-based company.

Review/Film; Making The Best Of Being Terminal
LEAD: Bancroft (Timothy Dalton), the terminally ill lawyer who is the hero of ''Hawks,'' regards his own mortality as a bad joke and is determined to respond in kind.
Decker (Anthony Edwards), the terminally ill American football player who winds up as Bancroft's roommate in an English hospital, becomes the lawyer's willing protege.


Hindus Rally at Disputed Shrine in Show of Power
LEAD: Hundreds of thousands of Hindu militants gathered today near a shrine disputed by Hindus and Muslims to assert their growing power.


Wary of the 'Dramatic Situation,' Kohl May Curtail Visit to Poland
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl left open the possibility tonight that he might break off a visit to Poland to return to West Germany and deal with what he described as a ''dramatic situation'' after East Germany's decision to open its borders with the West.

News Summary
LEAD:  International A3-19  East Germany ended limits on travel and emigration yesterday, and thousands of East Germans swarmed across the Berlin wall in a mass celebration of freedom.
Page A1  East Berliners of all ages, and from every way of life, walked, biked and drove to crossing points in the wall last night, entering the western half of the city that they could previously only gaze at.


Behind Rockefeller Center's Allure
LEAD: Rockefeller Center is more than half a century old but office space there is still very hard to get and it rents for as much as that in brand new buildings just around the corner.
And the sale last week of a controlling interest to the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Japan suggests that Rockefeller Center will continue to be a very good business.

COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Cathay Pacific Airways, Hong Kong, said it would purchase two 747-400 freighters from Boeing Co., Seattle, and that it had secured options for two additional 747-400's.
The contract for the firm orders is $285 million.


Gas Pipeline Plan
LEAD: The Pacific Gas Transmission Company reached agreement with customers and natural gas producers to build a $1.2 billion pipeline between British Columbia and California.
The agreement, filed with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, will speed up the 864-mile project, scheduled to begin in 1993.

Sweeney Scores 3 Goals As Bruins Rout Oilers, 6-2
LEAD: Bob Sweeney had the first three-goal game of his National Hockey League career and Ken Linseman scored in his first game back from injury as the Boston Bruins beat the Edmonton Oilers, 6-2, tonight.


Topics of The Times; Bushlock in Greenwich
LEAD: President Bush went to Greenwich, Conn., last Sunday to visit his mother.
Thousands of people in two states were stopped dead on two highways and several streets to provide for his safety.
Is this really necessary?
Local police officials, following the Secret Service's instructions, stopped traffic for up to a half-hour on the Hutchinson River and Merritt Parkways, miles from Mr.


Knicks Legends Game
LEAD: A team of former Knick players, led by Walt Frazier, will oppose a team of former National Basketball Association players in the first Knicks Legends Game on Nov.21 at Madison Square Garden.
The game, at 6:45 P.M., will precede the Knicks-Houston Rockets contest.


Rules Are Eased In Ford Jaguar Bid
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission relaxed certain takeover rules in the Ford Motor Company's $2.5 billion bid for the British luxury car maker Jaguar P.L.C.
Ford sought exemption from a requirement that shares tendered in a takeover offer be purchased as soon as all bid conditions are met.

Trade Officials to Meet On U.S.-Soviet Accord
LEAD: Top commercial officials of the United States and the Soviet Union will meet next week in Washington to begin work on a new trade pact, Administration officials said today.
It is to be similar to an agreement nullified by Moscow in 1975, after Congress demanded freer Soviet emigration.

To Punch Is Not Quite To Kiss
LEAD: One night recently this reporter was watching an evening newscast when the sports came on with, of course, its routine footage of hockey players trying to simulate a car crash.
Some local sportscasters believe that unless they show a hockey fight on television every night, people won't be able to fall asleep.


Topics of The Times; The Answerers
LEAD: The New York Public Library has just published an imposing 836-page Desk Reference of miscellany that someone somewhere wants to know.
Based on the four million questions people ask the library's researchers each year, the work is a cross between an almanac and an encyclopedia, and then some.

2 Are Indicted in Landfill Case
LEAD: Two New York City men have been indicted on charges that they allowed pollutants to leak from an illegal landfill into the Neversink River, officials said today.
The men, Thomas Gambino, 45 years old, and Dominick Dercole, 59, will be arraigned in Sullivan County Court on Nov. 20, the officials said.

The Endowment vs. the Arts: Anger and Concern
LEAD: Prominent members of the arts community reacted with anger and concern yesterday to the decision by the National Endowment for the Arts to withdraw the agency's sponsorship of an exhibition about AIDS.
The criticism came as the agency's new chairman elaborated on why he had withdrawn the endowment's support on the ground that the exhibition was more political than artistic.

East Berliners Explore Land Long Forbidden
LEAD: The 28-year-old Berlin wall opened up Thursday and by midnight thousands of East Berliners - of all ages, from every way of life - were walking, biking and driving to crossing points in the wall and entering the western half of the city, a place they could only gaze at just hours before.

I.B.M. in Purchase
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation agreed to acquire the Lockheed Corporation's CADAM Inc. subsidiary, which makes software for computer-aided design and manufacturing applications.
I.B.M. did not disclose terms for the deal, which is expected to close within 60 days.


For Time, New Slogan And a Feat
LEAD: HAVING wrested Time magazine's advertising account from the agency that owned it for more than half a century, George Lois has ingratiated himself with the publisher by fulfilling every client's fondest dream: creating a slogan that names the product not once, but twice.


Kisio Hospitalized
LEAD: Kelly Kisio, the center and captain of the Rangers, was admitted to Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday for treatment of a badly bruised thigh muscle.
Kisio suffered the injury in Wednesday night's 3-2 loss to Montreal.
Kisio, who has already missed a handful of games this season because of a recurring back injury, was listed by the team as day to day.


Review/Art; Ferrer's Caribbean World Of Sensuality and Mystery
LEAD: Rafael Ferrer paints a Caribbean world in which immediacy and sensuality exist, mystery is everywhere and innocence is impossible.
His paintings at the Nancy Hoffman Gallery are both unfailingly romantic and relentlessly self-conscious.
Their conflict between bitter and sweet, north and south, pleasure and disorder, is miasmic and mesmerizing.

LEAD: The Dataproducts Corporation said it would not oppose an unsolicited $10-a-share tender by the DPC Acquisition Corporation if DPC can obtain financing.
But the chairman of Dataproducts, Jack C. Davis, said DPC has not yet begun discussions with financing sources and he therefore urged shareholders to reject DPC's offer.

LEAD: Chiat/Day/Mojo named Tom McElligott executive creative director yesterday, confirming rumors that the creative star would join the agency.
Mr.
McElligott, a founder of Fallon McElligott, the acclaimed Minneapolis agency, will oversee Chiat/Day's creative efforts in New York, Toronto and London.


Holiday Closings
LEAD: Because of Veterans Day tomorrow, New York City municipal offices will be closed today, as will state offices in New Jersey and Connecticut.

LEAD: The South-West Africa People's Organization, the front-runner in Namibia's pre-independence election, today accused its main rival of ''acts of desperation'' as the five-day voting period passed its halfway point.

Hammers Fall and Prices Soar
LEAD: IMPRESSIONIST and modern art -works by Pablo Picasso, Vincent van Gogh, Edouard Manet, Claude Monet and Edgar Degas - is in place at New York's major auction houses for Round 2 of the November sales.
The sessions began with contemporary art on Tuesday and will end on Nov. 18.


Curb on '900' Calls Offered in Connecticut
LEAD: State utility regulators today approved a plan by the Southern New England Telephone Company to put devices on phones to block expensive calls by children to so-called 900 numbers.


'Junk Bond' Rally Continues But New Issues Are Lacking
LEAD: Prices of ''junk bonds'' rose again yesterday, and even though the market's rally entered its fourth day, underwriters of high-yield bonds said the improvement was not great enough to reschedule the bond offerings that were postponed last month.

AIDS Panel Urges Support of Bleach Study
LEAD: The National Commission on AIDS has asked Congress to reverse its opposition to Federal financing of studies on whether giving drug addicts household bleach helps control the spread of AIDS.


Expansion Is Planned By Borden
LEAD: Borden Inc., putting muscle into its move away from the dairy business, said yesterday that it plans to spend $650 million over the next two years to expand and modernize its plants around the world.
It will also spend an additional $75 million to $100 million on advertising and marketing.


Wyse Bid Planned By Taiwan Group
LEAD: A Taiwan consortium said it would bid for the United States computer company Wyse Technology.
Wyse, based in San Jose, Calif., said Wednesday that it was discussing being acquired by an unidentified party at a proposed cash price of $10 a share.
Securities industry sources in Taipei said the consortium was prepared to pay up to $14 a share.


A Self-Doubting Monster Fights the Forces of Evil
In ''The Toxic Avenger Part III: The Last Temptation of Toxie,'' the newest installment in what its producers now call the ''Toxic Ring,'' the mutated title character is full of self-doubts. ''I was 25,'' he says on the sound track, ''but who was I?
What was I?''
Those questions can be answered by anyone who has chanced to see either of the first two films, produced with a good deal of comic nerve and very little money by the enterprising Troma Inc.


Berlin Border Guards Stunned by the News
LEAD: The East German border police at the Checkpoint Charlie crossing point in the Berlin wall were stunned today to learn that citizens could now travel through to the West freely.

LEAD: Further evidence of subdued inflation emerged today as the Government reported a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods in October and no increase at all for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production.

Nordiques End Slide While Islanders Sink
LEAD: In a sloppy but exciting game filled with poor checking, uncertain puck-handling, inconsistent goaltending, mental mistakes and lots of shots, the Quebec Nordiques beat the Islanders, 7-5, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.


Review/Theater; Winners and Losers in a Black 'Big Chill'
LEAD: ''The talented tenth,'' in W. E. B. Du Bois's memorable phrase, were those exceptional blacks who were destined to save their people from ''contamination and death.'' In Richard Wesley's ambitious, unwieldy new play, ''The Talented Tenth,'' his present-day equivalents of this leadership class are black urban professionals obsessively dedicated to their own self-interest.


Andrew E. Ullmann, Lawyer, Is Dead at 63
LEAD: Andrew E. Ullmann, a lawyer and retired chairman of the Stony Brook Council, a policy-making body of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, died of cancer Tuesday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital.
He was 63 years old and lived in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.


House Adopts Bill on Oil Spills
LEAD: After defeating a tough provision that it had approved only 24 hours earlier, the House of Representatives today passed a liability bill that provides extensive environmental protection in the event of oil spills.


Elegy Premiere
LEAD: Paul Zukofsky will conduct the Juilliard Symphony Orchestra in the world premiere of Kenneth Fuchs's ''Reconciliation Elegy,'' a work inspired by a Robert Motherwell painting, at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8.
The program also includes Igor Stravinsky's ''Apollon Musagete.'' Admission is free, but tickets are required.


Freeway That Failed Faces 'Slow-Motion' Quake
LEAD: Engineers of the University of California at Berkeley will use hydraulic jacks and other heavy equipment later this month to rock the Nimitz Freeway slowly back and forth as they try to determine why it collapsed in the earthquake.


Who's Playing And Where
LEAD: The New Music America '89 festival opens this weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section (718-636-4100), its nearby Majestic Theater, 651 Fulton Street, and other locations around New York City.
The festival ends on Nov. 18.
Schedule information: 669-7740.


Gap Reports A Record Net
LEAD: The Gap Inc. today reported record revenues and earnings for the third quarter, which ended Oct. 28.


Walt Disney Net at Peak
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company today reported record earnings and revenues for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year, based on the continued strength of the company's parks and film and video operations.


Milton Stern, 77, Retired Perfume Executive
LEAD: Milton Stern, a retired perfume marketing specialist, died of cancer Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.
He was 77 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla.

Argentine Composer
LEAD: John Daly Goodwin will conduct the New York Choral Society in music by the Argentine composer Ariel Ramirez at Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening at 8.
The works on the program include the ''Misa Criolla,'' ''Navidad Nuestra'' and excerpts from the ''Misa por la Paz y la Justicia.'' Mr.
Ramirez will also perform in the concert with his Solistas de Argentina ensemble.

Admission is $10; children under 16 years of age accompanied by an adult are admitted free.
Information: 535-9707.

3 Westbound Lanes to Open On Fire-Damaged Interstate
LEAD: Three westbound lanes of Interstate 78, damaged by a trash fire under an elevated portion of the road, will reopen Friday in time for the evening rush, officials said today.


H.U.D. Suspending Business Ties With Ex-Election Aide to Reagan
LEAD: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has barred the chief lawyer for Ronald Reagan's 1984 Presidential campaign from doing business with the department in eight Southern states because of allegations of ''irregularities'' in a federally assisted housing project in Georgia.


2 Landmark Utility Laws Stir Debate
LEAD: A law passed half a century ago to protect consumers and investors from utility company fraud is hurting consumers by barring big companies from the emerging business of competitive power generation, electric company officials told a Senate committee today.


Tumbleweeds Are Burying A Town in South Dakota
LEAD: Tumbleweeds tossed by 50-mile-an hour winds buried streets and houses in this Missouri River town.


It's Really the Gutenberg-Richter Scale
LEAD: To the Editor:


Economic Scene; Budget Woe Goes Beyond Gimmicks
LEAD: AS Washington's current battle of the budget demonstrates, more than a month into the new fiscal year, the effort to stay under the Gramm-Rudman deficit ceiling has worsened public confusion and increased the use of budget gimmicks.
For instance, Government payments are shifted to a different fiscal year or goods are paid for not in cash but through certificates or by pushing outlays ''off budget.


DENG IS RESIGNING LAST FORMAL POST WITH CHINA PARTY
LEAD: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, has resigned from his last formal post in the Communist Party leadership, marking another milestone in his 65-year party career.

LEAD: To the Editor:


How Small Firms Compete Amid Merging Giants
LEAD: In the increasingly competitive world of law firms, growing numbers of small and mid-size firms are forming loose networks to compete with the big firms created by mergers.


British Banks Lift Reserves
LEAD: Two major British banks put aside money yesterday to protect them against bad third world loans, together adding more than $2 billion to their reserves following similar moves by United States and Canadian banks.


Review/Theater; The City Is Sweet and Muggers Are Merry
LEAD: ''Prince of Central Park,'' the new musical at the Belasco, is a numbing evening of such guileless amateurism that it will probably have a future as a Harvard Business School case study, whatever its fate in the annals of drama.
Even modest Broadway shows like this cost more money than the gross national product of some third world nations.


Traffic Cases Can End if Police Miss Court
LEAD: Drivers in New York City and parts of western New York can have their traffic tickets dropped if the police officer who wrote them does not show up for court, the State Department of Motor Vehicles said today.


Control Data Sale
LEAD: The Control Data Corporation agreed to sell its Ticketron sports and entertainment ticketing division to the Carlyle Group, a private merchant banking firm in Washington, D.C.
Terms were not disclosed.
Control Data said it would retain Ticketron's automated wagering services and that the sale is expected to be completed in 30 days.

Finding a Home With the Raiders
LEAD: Imagine it is 1985.
Imagine then that you knew what you know now.
You are making the Kansas City Chiefs' first-round draft pick, which happens to be the 15th overall selection.
Do you pick Ethan Horton, a North Carolina running back, or, say . . .
Jerry Rice, who is still available?
Ethan who? ''Oh, yeah, I've heard all the jokes,'' said Ethan Horton, a quiet, unassuming player who exemplifies the Los Angeles Raiders' newfound spirit.

AT THE MOVIES
LEAD:  'A Normal Nice Girl'


Boston Bank Sued
LEAD: The Bank of Boston Corporation disclosed this week that shareholders had filed two class action lawsuits contending the bank's executives made fraudulent and negligent misrepresentations and omissions in releasing information before reserves against bad loans were increased on Oct. 2.
The bank lost $125 million in 1989's third quarter and added $370 million to reserves to cover souring real estate loans and an unidentified buyout loan that went bad.


Arthur Holland Mayor of Trenton For 26 Years, Dies of Cancer at 71
LEAD: Arthur J. Holland, the Mayor of Trenton for 26 years and a former president of the United States Conference of Mayors, died of cancer yesterday at the St.
Francis Medical Center in Trenton.
He was 71 years old.


Miami Bank, Prodded by State, Says It Has Sold Its Art
LEAD: In response to legal action taken by Florida bank regulators, the Centrust Savings Bank, a Miami savings and loan institution, announced yesterday that it had sold ''substantially all'' of a collection of Old Master paintings and sculptures that the regulators had cited as a ''nonearning asset'' and ''speculative.


Turkish President Sworn In And Appoints a New Premier
LEAD: Turgut Ozal, Prime Minister for the last six years, was sworn in as President today in a Parliament ceremony boycotted by opposition parties.
He named Yildirim Akbulut, Speaker of Parliament, as Prime Minister.

Magdeleine de Jesus, Founder of Nuns' Order, 91
LEAD: Sister Magdeleine de Jesus, author and founder of an order of Roman Catholic nuns, died Monday at the order's headquarters in Rome.
She was 91 years old.
Born Magdeleine Hutin at Montigny-les-Metz in eastern France on April 26, 1898, she founded the Fraternite des Petites Soeurs de Jesus - the Little Sisters of Jesus - in 1939, in the Saharan outpost of Touggourt, Algeria.

Viacom Buys 3 Stations
LEAD: Command Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell two radio stations in Denver and one in Los Angeles to Viacom Broadcasting Inc. for $101.5 million.
Viacom said the acquisitions were part of its strategy to pursue properties with high growth potential.
The stations are KJOI-FM in Los Angeles and KSYY-FM and KHOW-AM in Denver.

Man Is Given 22 Years In Girl's Beating Death
LEAD: A Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday to 22 years to life in prison in the death of Jessica Cortez, a 5-year-old girl who was found savagely beaten in a Brooklyn apartment last year.


Times Mirror Campaign
LEAD: Times Mirror Magazines, the publisher of Field &amp; Stream, Outdoor Life, Popular Science and five other magazines aimed at men, takes to the trades on Monday for the start of its first national corporate advertising campaign.
The $1 million campaign, created by FCB/Leber Katz Partners, promotes the company's group advertising plans enabling marketers to purchase ads at discounted rates in four or more of the publications.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 478 money market mutual funds increased by $3.92 billion, to $363.81 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 146 institutional funds increased by $2.27 billion, to $87.26 billion.
The assets of the 235 general-purpose funds were up by $1.49 billion, to $119.15 billion.

LEAD: Amgen Inc. said this week that it would give free supplies of genetically engineered erythropoietin to several thousand kidney dialysis patients who do not have Government or private health insurance.

It was 1954.
He was mayor.

Militant Muslims Gain in Jordan Voting
LEAD: Muslim fundamentalists have registered unexpected and sweeping parliamentary gains in Jordan's first general elections in 22 years, unofficial results showed today.
The victory brought consternation to Government officials alarmed by the display of Islamic fervor.

LEAD: While two young men quietly spackled and whitewashed the walls at Artists Space for an exhibition about AIDS that is to open on Thursday, Susan Wyatt, the director of the nonprofit gallery in TriBeCa, frantically fielded phone calls yesterday and tried to cope with an onslaught of attention.


Member of the Medellin Ring Gets Prison Term of 15 Years
LEAD: Five years after he was convicted here in absentia, a member of the Medellin cocaine trafficking ring who was extradited from Colombia last month was sentenced by a Federal court Tuesday to 15 years in prison and a $25,000 fine.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  McEnroe, Chang and Gilbert Gain: John McEnroe, Michael Chang and Brad Gilbert earned quarterfinal berths yesterday in the Wembley championship in England.
McEnroe beat an erratic Eric Jelen of West Germany, 6-4, 6-1.
Gilbert beat a fellow American, Leif Shiras, 7-5, 6-3.
Chang beat another American, Paul Annacone, 6-2, 1-6, 6-0.


Uncle Deadbeat Stiffs the U.N.
LEAD: If you're serious, a hard-boiled American maxim advises, put your money where your mouth is.
By this standard, the U.S. is profoundly unserious about the United Nations.
This country is not merely the host but the main architect of the U.N.
It is also the main deadbeat - a fact shamefully reconfirmed by a recent Senate decision to cut $123 million from President Bush's request for regular dues owed the U.N.


India's Low Castes Turn the Tables
LEAD: The caste system, always a major force in Indian society, may be growing in importance as disadvantaged groups use their numbers and solidarity to win a larger share of power.
It is likely to play a pivotal role in national elections this month, particularly if the contest is close, Indian politicians say.


Clamor in the East; The Upheaval in East Germany: a Singular Month Produces an Exodus
LEAD: Sept. 10: Hungary opens border with Austria to allow departure of East German refugees who had been gathering at the West German Embassy in Budapest.
More than 30,000 eventually reach the West in first big exodus of East Germans since Berlin Wall was built in 1961.


Mildred Bennett Dead; Cather Expert Was 80
LEAD: Mildred Bennett, an authority on the novelist Willa Cather, died of lung cancer on Tuesday.
She was 80 years old.

LEAD: Hungary has completed the dismantling of the electronic barrier along its westernmost border, an official said today.

Head of Bantam Doubleday To Emphasize Continuity
LEAD: Jack Hoeft, the new president of the Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group, said on Wednesday that he had wished his departing boss, Alberto Vitale, ''good luck, but not too good.''


Police Sued On Taping In Connecticut
LEAD: An association of 200 criminal-defense lawyers from across Connecticut charged in a Federal lawsuit today that the state police illegally recorded telephone conversations between lawyers and their clients for nine years in violation of the United States Constitution.


Infant Born to Slain Mother Dies Two Weeks After Attack
LEAD: The infant boy born to a pregnant shooting victim died today, two weeks after his mother was shot to death and his father wounded when they were held up outside a childbirth class.


Review/Film; Family Portrait From Small Town, U.S.A.
LEAD: Lee Grant's ''Staying Together'' is the kind of small-town comedy-drama that gives middle-class Middle Americans exactly the sort of idealized picture of themselves that many would like to believe is true.
It's about the loving marriage of Eileen (Melinda Dillon) and Jake McDermott (Jim Haynie), their three almost-grown sons, and the big and little problems with which they all cope to become better, more feelingful members of a society that never seems entirely plausible.

The Many Voices of New Music America '89
LEAD: It spreads across New York City like an invading army.
Shock troops take strategic points - the Knitting Factory, Performance Space 122, the Kitchen, the World, the Brooklyn Academy of Music - and settle in.
And for the next 16 days, music lovers, experimentalists and insomniacs can rejoice: New Music America '89, which is taking over 23 spaces for 120 shows, turns off for about 10 hours a night, just enough time to read the paper, pay a few bills and grab something to eat.

LEAD: Jermain Robinson, the 15-year-old who pleaded guilty in the rampage in Central Park last April and who has agreed to be a witness against the other suspects, has been arrested in connection with an attempted armed robbery of an East Harlem bakery, the police said yesterday.

Evolution Theory's Foes Win Textbook Battle in California
LEAD: In a concession to evangelical Christians that could affect the teaching of science nationwide, the California Board of Education adopted new textbook guidelines today that delete a reference to evolution as ''scientific fact.''


Setback for Yonkers
LEAD: More than anything, the city of Yonkers, N.Y., needs to put a divisive housing desegregation controversy behind it and deal with pressing issues of economic development, crime and drugs.
Yet on Tuesday, the city's voters elected a new Mayor and City Council that are likely to continue the housing distraction.


Denver Bans Assault Weapons
LEAD: The City Council voted 9 to 4 on Tuesday to ban semiautomatic assault weapons.
The legislation is to take effect as soon as it is signed by Mayor Federico Pena and then published, probably next week.
Residents who already own assault weapons will be able to keep them but will be required to register them within 60 days.


An American Story
LEAD: On the day New Yorkers chose a black Mayor and Virginians a black Governor, white and black citizens of Charleston were also asked to show their belief in a common bond.

LEAD: The Bush Administration has begun a quiet scouring of military bases in Colorado and across the country for a site to temporarily store radioactive wastes.


Sweden's Loan For Saab-Scania
LEAD: Sweden's Government made a substantial loan to Saab-Scania A.B. to make a new airliner, the Saab 2000 commuter plane.
But analysts said the cash advance, for up to 1.2 billion kronor, or $188 million, did not mean the company's troubles were over.


At P.S. 262, 2 Principals Now Occupy One Post
LEAD: The new principal reported for duty at Public School 262 in Brooklyn yesterday, but the acting principal he was sent there to replace refused to vacate the principal's office.
The acting principal even made the morning announcements on the public address system.


Stolen Picasso Artworks Recovered
LEAD: Investigators have recovered the $17 million in artworks stolen from the granddaughter of the artist Pablo Picasso.
The works were found today at the home of a restaurateur, who was then arrested, the police said.

LEAD: Four teen-agers were indicted yesterday for attempted murder in the May 30 shooting of a custodian and a student at East Orange High School.

LEAD: The Soviet Union today praised the sweeping changes affecting the Communist Party in East Germany and reiterated Moscow's intention to let its ally run its affairs ''on its own terms.''

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's long-running program to turn state-owned industries over to the private sector suffered another blow today when her Conservative Government decided it could not include nuclear plants in its planned sale of the power industry.

LEAD: Diplomacy is too important to become the exclusive preserve of Foreign Service officers, and far too important and complicated to be turned over increasingly to inexperienced political appointees.

LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins traveled to Washington yesterday and joined Democratic leaders there in proclaiming that his victory Tuesday was a sign of the party's renewed strength throughout the country.

LEAD: Securities dealers yesterday placed bids on $10 billion worth of new three-year Treasury notes as prices of most notes and bonds ended the day lower in fairly light trading.

LEAD: Signaling uncertainty about China's political stability, Moody's Investors Service Inc. today downgraded the country's long-term credit rating.

LEAD: When law firms need historical research for a trial, they usually call on their paralegals.

Exotic Sound of One-of-a-Kind Instruments
LEAD: Harry Partch lived either before his appointed time or else 2,000 years too late.
In his solitary art, music served a larger experience, one in which seeing, feeling and hearing joined together and erased the line between the sensual and the intellectual.
Partch believed that the music around him thought too much, or at least thought to the exclusion of the rest of the body.

LEAD: One of Britain's more prolific and popular playwrights, Alan Ayckbourn travels far better on television than in stage productions.

The BBC production of the same play was brilliant.
Quintessentially English, Mr.
Ayckbourn seems to require not just a British cast but a made-in-Britain production.

Despite Pledge, Homeless Still in Hotel
LEAD: There are only two single beds in the room at the Times Square Hotel where Kimberly Andrews, her husband and their 5-year-old son, who are homeless, have been living since September.
The paint is peeling so badly from the walls onto the stained carpeting that Ms.
Andrews routinely sweeps twice daily.

Crop Genetics
LEAD: Crop Genetics International, an agricultural biotechnology company in Hanover, Md., said plants inoculated with its genetically engineered corn vaccine had reduced corn borer damage by more than 80 percent in greenhouse tests.
The company said it was the first time that a plant had been able to grow its own pesticide in its vascular system.

Some Tips For a New Mayor
LEAD: David Dinkins's first job in New York is to restore civility.
Here are some ways to start: 1.
Tax limousine riders back onto the subway.
The town already levies staggering ''occupancy'' taxes on people renting hotel rooms.
Put a murderous ''occupancy'' tax on people who rent limousines.

Montedison Deal
LEAD: Montedison S.p.A., Italy's largest chemical company, signed an agreement to buy the 19 percent of Himont Inc. it does not already own in a deal valued at $627.3 million, the companies announced.
Montedison agreed to pay $51 cash for each of the 12.3 million Himont shares.
Himont's stock was unchanged at $48.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.


Harold A. Knapp, Nuclear Test Expert, Dies at 65
LEAD: Harold A. Knapp, a Defense Department analyst who uncovered risks from fallout in nuclear testing in the 1950's and initiated the reversal of a rape conviction of three black men in the 1960's, died of a form of cancer that attacks the spine on Wednesday at his home in Germantown, Md.
He was 65 years old.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1989
LEAD:  Companies


Holiday Today
LEAD: Because of the Veterans Day Parade, Fifth Avenue between 24th and 39th Streets will be closed today from 9 A.M. to noon.


The End of the War to End Wars
LEAD: Crowds of young Germans danced on top of the hated Berlin wall Thursday night.
They danced for joy, they danced for history.
They danced because the tragic cycle of catastrophes that first convulsed Europe 75 years ago, embracing two world wars, a Holocaust and a cold war, seems at long last to be nearing an end.


Robert Gerringer, 63, Stage and Film Actor
LEAD: Robert Gerringer, a stage, film and television actor, died of complications resulting from a series of strokes Wednesday in Cove's Edge Hospital, Damariscotta, Me.
He was 63 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Newcastle, Me.

Atari Is Selling 26 Federated Stores
LEAD: The Atari Corporation, the computer and video game maker, agreed to sell 26 of its struggling Federated Group consumer electronics stores to Silo Inc., a Philadelphia-based electronics retailer.
The tentative agreement Thursday calls for Silo to take over 21 Federated stores in Los Angeles and Orange counties and five in San Diego.

Review/Theater; Guilt and Retribution Overtake Nebraskans
LEAD: ''A Dance Lesson,'' by David Wiltse, begins as a gently amusing genre piece about an average Nebraska family in the mid-1950's.
As the work unfolds (at the Long Wharf Theater's Stage II), it is evident that the author has something more sobering in mind - a bitterly regretful play dealing with guilt and retribution.

Review/Television; Election Drama That Polls and Viewers Missed
LEAD: Remember the secret ballot?
The way it worked was you checked off your choices on a piece of paper or pulled the lever behind the curtain and nobody knew you were a closet Vegetarian.
And not only was the vote each citizen's private secret; it was also the nation's secret.
That made for a long evening of excitement sitting by the radio or before the tube and following the election results, sometimes into the small hours.

LEAD: A Manhattan appeals court yesterday upheld a State Supreme Court decision postponing enforcement of new rules that would limit the number of visits to doctors or hospitals that New York's Medicaid would cover.

Iowa's Sailors Looted After Blast, Paper Says
LEAD: A published report said today that sailors on the battleship Iowa were stealing possessions last April 19 after an explosion that killed 47 other sailors in a forward gun turret.


Sarwo Edhie, Indonesian General, 62
LEAD: Lieut.
Gen.
Sarwo Edhie, retired, who led army troops in suppressing a Communist coup attempt in 1965, died on Thursday of a stroke.
He was 62 years old.
He joined the army in 1943 when he was 16 to fight for independence from the Netherlands.
He also was a member of Parliament, from which he resigned in 1988.

Corrections
LEAD: A headline in Sports Pages on Nov. 3 misstated reasons for the resignations of two head coaches at the University of Florida.
Norm Sloan, the basketball coach, left after being accused of improperly paying a recruited player's air fare.
Galen Hall, the football coach, left after he admitted having improperly paid two assistant coaches in secret salary supplements.

LEAD: A week ago we mourned the death of daylight, and the refusal by those in charge of setting the world's clocks to extend daylight time for another month.

Review/Music; VibraphonistWith Pianist And Bassist
LEAD: Over the last half-century, the ranks of outstanding jazz vibraphonists have grown slowly.
One or two each decade seems to be the norm - Lionel Hampton and Red Norvo in the 1930's (although Mr. Norvo was playing xylophone at that time), Milt Jackson and Terry Gibbs in the 1940's, Gary Burton in the 1960's.


Yonkers Vote in Doubt; Machines Are Seized
LEAD: The voting machines used in Tuesday's election were impounded today after a partial recount of the mayoral race showed a 1,663-vote shift to the apparent loser, Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko.


Couple Found Dead in Park After Burglary at Their Home
LEAD: A General Motors executive and his wife were shot to death today and left in a park, apparently by intruders who robbed them and ransacked their house, the police and Federal agents said.


CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Critic's Notebook; A Sorry Chapter for Smiley's Kind: What's a Spy Story Without a Wall?
LEAD: ''They were almost at the wall when the beam darted to the north, leaving them momentarily in total darkness.
Still holding Liz's arm, Lemas guided them forward blindly, his left hand reaching ahead of him until suddenly he felt the coarse, sharp contact of the cinder brick.
Now he could discern the wall and, looking upward, the triple strand of wire and the cruel hooks which held it.


Winfield Stakes Claim On Yankee Right Field
LEAD: Even though he has not swung a bat in a game since the summer of 1988, Dave Winfield vowed yesterday that he would return to the Yankees next spring in top condition, ready to come back from back surgery and ready to win back his job in right field.

A.T.&amp;T. Changes Toll-Free Service
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is making it cheaper for businesses to offer international 800 service, which allows their customers to call them toll-free from 41 countries outside the United States.
A.T.&amp;T. subscribers now pay $266.50 to install a dedicated line, plus a one-time $99 fee for each country included and a monthly service charge of $36.70.


Nassau County Proposes to Cut Property Taxes
LEAD: Nassau County, under fierce pressure from homeowners to lower property taxes, proposed today a $1.62 billion budget for next year that would reduce county property taxes by almost 3 percent.


East German Events Seen Lifting Dollar
LEAD: The dollar rose yesterday against the West German mark and other European currencies in gains traders attributed to the opening of East Germany's borders.

'Powerless' In the Face Of Gambling
LEAD: A number of years ago there was a fellow I knew who was believed to have everything.
He was smart, good-looking, well liked, athletic, confident, ambitious and grew up in a comfortable home.
He became a lawyer, and married.
His father died and left a considerable amount of money to him and his mother.


Kitty Dukakis Recovering
LEAD: Kitty Dukakis remained hospitalized today, recovering from the effects of drinking rubbing alcohol, and there was no word on the date of her release.
Sue Kaplan, a spokeswoman for Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis, said only that Mrs.
Dukakis would not be released today from Brigham and Women's Hospital.
She was admitted Monday night after drinking what her doctor said was a small amount of rubbing alcohol.


Virginia Connolly Mitty, Pediatrician, 70
LEAD: Dr.
Virginia Connolly Mitty, a pediatrician in Manhattan for more than 40 years, died of a stroke on Thursday at St.
Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center.
She was 70 years old.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Pledge Sought On Oil Rights
LEAD: Oil companies should be guaranteed the right to produce oil they find in authorized offshore explorations, Ken T. Derr, the chairman of the Chevron Corporation, said Thursday.


First Victory for Wolves
LEAD: The Minnesota Timberwolves won their first game ever tonight, beating the Philadelphia 76ers, 125-118, in overtime as Tony Campbell capped a career-high 38-point performance with 4 points in the final minute and 57 seconds.


Atlantic Suit Is Dismissed
LEAD: A state court judge in Massachusetts has dismissed a lawsuit by a group of former stockholders of The Atlantic magazine who contended that Mortimer B. Zuckerman owed them additional payments from his acquisition of the publication in 1980.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Thursday about the results of mayoral elections and ballot propositions around the country referred incorrectly in some copies to the city where voters approved restrictions on smoking in public places.
It was Greensboro, N.C., not Charlotte.


Flach Out Also
LEAD: Two days after tearing ligaments in one of his feet in a first-round match, Ken Flach was forced to withdraw yesterday from the doubles competition at a tournament in Wembley, England.


Resorts Sees Bankruptcy
LEAD: Resorts International Inc., the big gaming concern owned by Merv Griffin, said yesterday that it expects a petition forcing the company into bankruptcy to be filed soon, regardless of the outcome of current negotiations with bondholders.


Houses That Trap Humidity May Unleash Health Problems
LEAD: A lesson about household air quality is unfolding at the Passamaquoddy Indian reservation on the rocky coast of northeastern Maine.
Dozens of children there suffer from respiratory problems, including asthma-like conditions.


Quietly, Giants' Collins Is Gaining Recognition
LEAD: For a cornerback, Mark Collins is comparatively flamboyant on the field, but cornerbacks seldom create a stir unless they give up a big pass completion.


PRICES OF TREASURY ISSUES UNCHANGED
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were essentially unchanged yesterday as the market marked time awaiting next week's auction's of nearly $46 billion of bills, notes and bonds.


Your Money
LEAD: People who pay for child care or who pay household workers like maids and gardeners face special tax reporting and withholding requirements.
And they should be sure they have complied with the requirements within 1989 - not wait until next spring when filing their tax returns.

U.S. ENTHUSIASTIC, BUT HAS CONCERNS
LEAD: Like the rest of the world, Washington is scrambling to keep pace with the changes unfolding by the hour in Eastern Europe.
But in contrast with the pivotal role the United States played 40 years ago in shaping the postwar European order that now seems to be coming apart, Washington finds itself more of a bystander - astonished, enthusiastic and concerned.


CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Ripples in Poland; KOHL DELIVERS AID AND RETURNS HOME
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany told Polish leaders today that he was interrupting a five-day visit to their country for 24 hours, but not until he had signed accords granting Poland the largest amount of economic aid it has yet obtained from a Western nation.

U.S., Mexico in Tax Pact
LEAD: Mexican and United States officials have agreed to share income and tax information in an effort to help each other find tax evaders, the Finance Ministry said Thursday.
The ministry and the United States Treasury have reached an agreement to provide each other with data about individuals' incomes and any evidence that they may be evading taxes, a ministry statement said.


Bush Offers Housing Plan to Aid Poor, Homeless and New Buyers
LEAD: President Bush today proposed a $7 billion, three-year package of housing programs and tax breaks to aid low-income families, first-time home buyers and the homeless ''who live a nightmare in the midst of the American dream.''


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Thursday about the sentencing of five men for an attack in Carl Schurz Park in Manhattan, on two men whom they believed to be homosexuals, misidentified a victim.


Little Gold in Coloring Old Films
LEAD: When color versions of such vintage black-and-white films as ''Yankee Doodle Dandy'' and ''Topper'' began appearing on television in 1986, executives in the color-converting business thought they saw a bright new industry emerging.


Baby's Death Makes Boston Case Double Homicide
LEAD: The death of the infant born prematurely to a fatally wounded mother has been ruled a homicide, a spokesman for the Suffolk District Attorney's office said today.
The baby died Thursday at the age of 17 days.

LEAD: Seeking to put a dispute over AIDS policy behind them, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops have issued a statement calling for reliance on sexual abstinence outside marriage to prevent the spread of the disease.

Armand Hammer in Hospital
LEAD: The industrialist Armand Hammer underwent surgery on Friday to have a heart pacemaker implanted and was later reported in good condition.
A spokesman for the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, where the 91-year-old Mr.
Hammer is chairman, said doctors expected him to be released from the U.C.L.A.
Medical Center in a few days and to return to normal activity.


I.B.M. Disk Drives
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to announce on Tuesday a new generation of data-storage devices that have been delayed for months by expensive technical problems.
The disk drives for mainframe computers account for about one-tenth of I.B.M.'s $60 billion in annual revenue.

LEAD: Three researchers who provoked anger and anxiety among women with a 1986 study that forecast a precipitous decline in the marriage prospects of well-educated women in their 30's are publishing a revised paper that omits those findings.

Suzanne Farrell to Give Her Last Performance
LEAD: Suzanne Farrell, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet who served as an inspiration for a number of Balanchine's ballets, has announced that she will dance her last performance with the company on the evening of Nov. 26 at the New York State Theater.
She will appear in the Rosenkavalier section of ''Vienna Waltzes,'' in a role created for her by Balanchine in 1977.

LEAD: Newspaper readers in China learned of the remarkable resignations of East German leaders this week, but they also picked up another bit of news: two East Germans who had fled more than a month ago to the West found the new society too disorderly and so returned home.

Review/Music; A Contrast Of Extremes From Mehta
LEAD: If there exist compositions more dissimilar than the two Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic are presenting this week at Avery Fisher Hall, they do not come to mind.
Franz Schubert's Symphony No. 5 (1816) and Gustav Holst's ''Planets'' (1916-17) may represent extremes of musical Romanticism, from the most chaste to the most grandiose, but this trivial historical observation gains nothing in the demonstration.

Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
LEAD: Yes, for two reasons.
Because everyone is chasing after Graf, the level of women's tennis will be raised.
Eventually someone will dethrone her.
Also, women's tennis benefits from having a star.
Because she is so easily recognized, more people are drawn toward the sport.
DENNIE BERNS  Bryn Mawr, Pa.

LEAD: The question of whether girls may wear Iranian-style veils to school has become a heated political controversy in this most secular of Western European countries.

LEAD: The Soviet Union embarks on a second revolution and reaches out for peace with the West; East Europeans demand freedom and democracy; East Germans tear down the Berlin Wall and flee their country.

Jeanne Moreau, Indestructible And in Demand
LEAD: ''Usually when a woman is 60, it's over,'' says Jeanne Moreau, sipping Evian in her dressing room at the Theatre National de l'Odeon here. ''But now it begins again.
During rehearsals I am confronted by things very mysterious.
I have terrific fights with inner demons, and it's more painful than it ever was.


Prospect of a Mall Stirs Colorful Debate
LEAD: PEOPLE heading into Watertown should consider the colors they wear.
A red baseball cap might indicate support for a proposed multimillion-dollar regional shopping mall, while the flutter of a bright orange kerchief would place someone in the opponents' camp.


Review/Theater; Infidelity And Love On Tape
LEAD: ''Your Handsome Captain,'' Simone Schwarz-Bart's drama at the Ubu Repertory Theater, is less a play than a poetic dialogue for two voices, one of which is only heard offstage in a simulation of a recording.
The play is the first by Ms.
Schwarz-Bart, a novelist from Guadeloupe.
It relies primarily on its incantatory language and repetitious imagery to create a dreamlike portrait of a couple struggling to maintain a long-distance relationship.


Swimming Duel
LEAD: The first showdown flopped when Tom Jager's dive beat everything, including the starter's gun, and so they will try it again on Dec. 2.
Jager, holder of the world record in the 50-meter freestyle, will meet Matt Biondi on that date as a special feature of a college invitational meet.


Paul Briggs, 76, Dies; Led Cleveland Schools
LEAD: Paul W. Briggs, who was Superintendent of Schools in Cleveland when a Federal judge ordered busing for desegregation 11 years ago, died of a brain hemorrhage Friday.
He was 76 years old.

LEAD: It would usually be considered quite an honor to be invited to City Hall to have breakfast with the Mayor.

SPEECHWRITERS AND POLITICIANS
LEAD: Clearly, a modern President hasn't time to craft speeches in the manner of Lincoln on the train to Gettysburg, so we should expect the White House to employ writers.
But that oratory can be ordered up as casually as lunch - devoid of a President's participation in the development of theme, tone and nuance - gives us not statesmanship, but artifice and public-relations hokum.

Robert Maxson, president, University of Nevada-Las Vegas.

LEAD: THE members of the most powerful Christian clan in Lebanon, the Maronite Catholics, were at each other's throats last week, barely a few weeks after their parliamentary representatives agreed with their Muslim counterparts on a formula for ending Lebanon's long civil war.


SPEECHWRITERS AND POLITICIANS
LEAD: One of my rules is never to buy a ''kiss and tell'' book.
I figure that when one is being paid to do a job, then loyalty and trust are part of the package.
However, I feel inclined to bend my rule after reading your excerpt from Peggy Noonan's book.
The lady can really write, and I found her honest, albeit irreverent, observations a delight.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  A MIND OF MY OWN: The Woman Who Was Known as Eve Tells the Story of Her Triumph Over Multiple Personality Disorder.
By Chris Costner Sizemore. (Morrow, $19.95.) Chris Costner Sizemore was the subject of ''The Three Faces of Eve,'' the gripping book and movie about multiple personality disorder.
In ''A Mind of My Own'' she recounts her events and tells how she met the challenge of living after the drama and spectacle of her mental illness were over.

A Life Afloat, Bound to the Tide
LEAD: IT is fall, the beginning of my 10th year afloat.
Six eager gray-brown cygnets are clacking their bills against my houseboat's catwalk, demanding their midday snack.
They are nearly as large as their graceful swan parents, but adolescent-gangly, lacking their parents' elegant ease.

Impossible Brew
LEAD: To the Editor:


Happy Trails: 13 Racers' Favorite Runs
LEAD: WHAT is your favorite ski trail?
Without hesitation, 13 top ski competitors from the past and present answered that question and described their favorite alpine run, slope or trail.
Although a few of these great skiers have returned to their selected trail, many remember the place for the moment, the feeling, the environment, the challenge of one run or one day.

LEAD: I WOULD be inclined, temperamentally, to say ''right on'' to Richard Elman, whose provocative article of Oct. 8  [ Opinion, ''Familiarity Breeds Mayhem'' ]  was like a whiff from the ammonia bottle, clearing the sinuses in its originality.
Yet I felt enormous pain to hear his analysis of how we must live, because of what he thinks we are.

Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
LEAD: Certainly, if Steffi Graf continues to dominate women's tennis it will be denied the excitement generated by a great rivalry like Evert-Navratilova.
But for tennis fans, Graf more than makes up for this with the beauty of her game.
She is an exceptional athlete whose renowned power game is complemented by graceful court movement and a first-rate volley.


Where Does Sports Fit In the Curriculum?
LEAD: In ''Should a School Athlete Pay to Play?'' (Opinion page, Oct. 15), Norman S. Winnerman raises the same old complaints: athletics are an important part of a school curriculum and therefore student athletes should not have to pay fees to play.
Actually athletics can only be defended in public schools as a way of promoting health and (a more tenuous point) teaching kids cooperation, sportsmanship and such values.


Tips for the Thwarted Consumer
LEAD: THE $68 WALKING SHOES were just six months old when the sole of the left one cracked across the ball of the foot.
A few days later, sales slip in hand, I returned to the shop where I bought them.
The same clerk who had sold me the shoes offered a store credit for the defective pair and said they would be returned to the manufacturer.

A 'Butterfly' Caught Up in a 'Tempest'
LEAD: ''Approach, my Ariel, come, '' commands Frank Langella as Prospero in a new production of ''The Tempest.'' Music plays.
From stage left, a creature in silky black pants and sandals flies in, chest bare, long hair in outlandish braids.
He lights on a rock.
Perched, eyes fixed on the distance, he offers raptly, ''To fly/ To swim, to dive into the fire, to ride/ On the curled clouds'' for his master Prospero.

Coping With Teen-Age Suicide Stanley Lependorf and Nancy McWilliams; Stanley Lependorf, Ph.D., is a psychologist at Princeton University. Nancy McWilliams, Ph.D., is a psychologist at Rutgers University and is vice president of the Flemington-Raritan Regional Board of Education.
LEAD: FACED with the alarming rise in suicides by high school and college students, New Jersey educational leaders have reacted with apt consternation and a flurry of efforts to cope.
By disseminating all available and appropriate information about the circumstances of the suicide, offering support groups and providing to distressed members of the community ready access to counselors, school officials are seeking both to ease the grieving process and to prevent suicides by other young people.

Two Tyrannies
LEAD: Historic.
Now there's a word journalists love.
But what other word is there for democracy's advances last week on German streets, and in the American elections?
The dominating demons of our lifetimes are Communism and racism; what is it but historic when the first tyranny shudders and the second continues, visibly, to soften?

LEAD: A day after thousands of angry citizens stormed the Interior Ministry building in the Soviet republic of Moldavia during six hours of clashes with the police, the authorities there have banned public meetings, ordered the confiscation of privately held weapons and stationed extra troops in Kishinev, the capital.


New York Pops Tour
LEAD: The first tour of the New York Pops will begin on Dec. 2 with a performance at the Mann Performing Arts Center in Fort Myers, Fla.
The tour, sponsored by the J. S. Karlton Company, will include three other stops in Florida, Melbourne, Sarasota and Miami Beach, and a stop in Columbia, S.C.
The orchestra, led by its founder and music director, Skitch Henderson, will play works by Grieg, Debussy, Smetana and Gliere, as well as a selection of songs from three Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals, with the soloists the soprano Patti Wilemon and the baritone Lothar Bergeest.

LEAD: The Abu Nidal terrorist organization has been ripped by a murderous internal power struggle in which more than 150 members of the group, including more than 20 of its leaders, have been killed, according to dissident senior leaders of the group, officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Arab diplomats.

Attack at Soviet Monument
LEAD: Two people were killed and two injured in an unsuccessful attempt to blow up a monument at the joint border of Armenia, Georgia and Azerbaijan, the Moscow radio said today.
A spokesman for the Azerbaijani Popular Front said the incident, involving a monument to friendship between the Soviet Union's Caucasian peoples, occurred Wednesday and involved Armenians.


The New Europe
LEAD: In the disorder of our stunned reactions to the drama playing out in East Germany, we can scarcely begin to see the consequences.
But one is clear.
Political stability in Europe is going to depend more than ever on the European Community.


Training Program For Waiters
LEAD: There is a training program for waiters on Long Island.
The adult program of the Great Neck Public Schools, in cooperation with the Greater Great Neck Restaurant Association, is offering a course on ''The Waiter as a Professional.'' In eight weekly sessions, Alan Reyburn, a Manhattan-based executive recruiter and consultant for the hospitality industry, is helping staff from several North Shore restaurants sharpen their professional skills.

LEAD: A FOND remembrance of childhood is the reward found under the pillow after the loss of a tooth.

Lost Lessons: Regard for Others...
LEAD: RECENTLY, I watched a man in a neatly pressed suit finish his newspaper and morning coffee just as the train pulled into Grand Central Terminal.
He placed the newspaper on the seat and deposited the stained coffee cup, now stuffed with a crumpled napkin, on the floor in the aisle.
As the train lurched to a stop, he got up to leave and never once looked badk at the clearly visible trash he had left behind.

Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
LEAD: You bet it is!
So accustomed are we to seeing Graf win that the rare victory by her opponent takes on mythic proportions.
Could any of us soon forget Aranxta Sanchez Vicario's victory over Graf in the French Open this year?
Or not love the game that makes possible so unlikely and gutsy a triumph?

LEAD: Gene Forrell, a conductor who has led several New York-based chamber orchestras, has formed a new band, which he is calling the Vivaldi Traveling Circus.

There was nothing circus-like or even indecorous in its stage demeanor.

Style Makers; Ritchie Jackson, Chair Designer
LEAD: Two years ago, Ritchie Jackson, an architectural technician from South Africa, took up chairmaking as a hobby.
