A 'Yellow Brick Road' Brightens a Museum
LEAD: What's the future of a fine museum in a faded urban setting on the wrong side of the Hudson?
Bright, predicts Samuel C. Miller, director of the Newark Museum and chief plotter of its just-completed $21 million renovation-expansion.
The revamping has not only tuned up the physical plant of this once-drab inner-city institution but - with gallery space nearly doubled, to 60,000 square feet - has also enabled it to reveal the depth and excellence of its hard-won holdings.

LEAD: Although world attention is focused on the drama of Communist reform, the statist systems of Latin America are undergoing an ideological restructuring that is no less radical than perestroika.
New leaders like Argentina's Carlos Saul Menem and Mexico's Carlos Salinas de Gortari are bent on privatizing their economies and opening them to the international market.

Tales of Success
LEAD: A SALESWOMAN hovers in the doorway of Volity Narayan Prakash's office in his jewelry store in Jackson Heights, Queens.
She has a problem.
A customer is buying a $2,400 gold chain for cash, but he is $100 short.
Mr.
Prakash strides out to the counter and speaks to his customer in the south Indian dialect he learned as a child in Bangalore.


Lasting Effect of Quake: Quality of Life Is Shaken
LEAD: The beguiling landscape here looks just as it did a month ago, the skyline is largely intact and the city is up and running.
But appearances are deceiving.
For millions of Bay Area residents, most of them far from the manifest ruin of Oct. 17, life after the earthquake is vastly different from what it was before: an unnerving sequence of annoyances, none of them traumas in themselves, but deeply unsettling when put together.

LEAD: Gertrude Honig Schweitzer, an artist whose works are in collections at several prominent museums, died Friday after a brief illness, at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J.
She was 79 years old and lived in Colts Neck, N.J., Palm Beach, Fla. and Santa Fe, N.M.

Intoxicated by My Illness
LEAD: SO MUCH OF A writer's life consists of assumed suffering, rhetorical suffering, that I felt something like relief, even elation, when the doctor told me that I had cancer of the prostate.
Suddenly there was in the air a rich sense of crisis, real crisis, yet one that also contained echoes of ideas like the crisis of language, the crisis of literature, or of personality.

After the Flood, Art
LEAD: There is a picturesque example of nature and art imitating each other in a lower corner of Central Park, where a sculptured zoo meanders along the paths between the real-life menagerie and the duck pond.
It is called Noah's Art, and it harbors beasts that the ark never took aboard - steel lions and stone birds, a bald eagle with an alabaster head, and a concrete tiger that looks like an animal cracker walking down a gangplank.

Global Warming Means New Global Politics
LEAD: UNTIL recently, politicians who wanted to avoid the issue of global warming could duck behind the scientific uncertainties.

The question is no longer whether the threat is real, but rather how fast it needs to be countered and at what expense.

Hopes Are Rising For Lower Rates By STEVE DODSON
LEAD: The credit market took hope from signs of an easing in Fed monetary policy.
On Tuesday the Fed added money to the banking system when the Federal funds rate was at 8 11/16, bringing the rate down to 8 1/2 percent.
But when the rate went below that, to 8 3/8, the Fed acted to drain money from the system, leading analysts to conclude that the easing would be limited.

No. 5: Strategies For an Anti-Shopper
LEAD: As a general rule, men shop but women go shopping.
That is to say, if a man requires a new shirt, he goes to the appropriate store with a clear idea of what he wants.
If his specific need cannot be met, he returns home and faces the world in an old shirt and a rage.
To men, money is something not to be spent but to be held and fondled; to men, checkbooks and safe deposit boxes are fetishes; they dream about these sacred objects, and their prayers are all in numerals.

LEAD: For the last 20 years Fairfield University juniors and seniors, at times as many as 800 of them, have enjoyed life on the beach.
They have rented privately owned houses two miles from campus on some of the most expensive real estate in the nation.


Basins and Bowls From the Palaces Of Imperial China
LEAD: Sir Percival David's 40-year pursuit of ceramics made from the Tang through Ching dynasties took him to Beijing several times in the 1920's and 30's.
There he acquired extraordinary 10th- to 18th-century treasures installed for centuries in the palaces of China, some of which are on view in ''Imperial Taste: Chinese Ceramics From the Percival David Collection'' at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts.


Tailgate Terrorists: Another Aspect
LEAD: I read with interest Lydia Rosenfeld's letter to the New Jersey editor (Oct. 15) concerning ''tailgate terrorists,'' but she failed to mention the primary cause for that problem, i.e., the driver who tries to ''control'' traffic by driving 55 M.P.H. in the left and center lanes, instead of staying to the right.

LEAD: Even as the nation's mayors and governors push President Bush to provide more resources for the war on drugs, they have been waging a civil war over whether the cities or the states ought to control the new Federal funds pledged to the battle.

LEAD: AT Auschwitz, it is inscribed in stone: four million people died in the Nazi camps.
But Yehuda Bauer, one of the foremost historians of the Holocaust and a sworn enemy of those who deny its reality, says that the number of victims was less than half that.

LEAD: One can offer only sympathy to Larry Josephs in his continuing battle against AIDS.

EUGENE W.  FELDMAN, D.M.D.
Lewistown, Pa.

Pastimes; Chess
LEAD: Some of what is interpreted to be stubbornness or excessive persistence may be made up of heavy doses of wishful thinking.
When we see a prominent grandmaster return to a favorite defense that has never given him anything but headaches - and do so on only the flimsiest pretext that his new move is really a valuable improvement that rescues his line of play from disaster - one must wonder what is going on in his head.

I had to buy that pot.''


College Coaches' Brief Encounters
LEAD: Outside the office window of the new basketball coach at Arizona State University, it was difficult to tell what point of the season Bill Frieder had reached.
At many places, a day like this, with the sun shining and the temperature high enough for students to wear shorts to class, would signal the end of winter and the middle of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

No. 4: Echt and Eclectic Source
LEAD: Fairway Fruits and Vegetables, the echt Upper West Side market a couple of blocks up Broadway from the Ansonia Hotel, says that 60,000 customers a week cruise through its packed aisles of produce, delicatessen, dairy goods and you-name-it (Kirbys, anyone?).
Of those 60,000, probably 40,000 are little old ladies who wield their shopping carts, dawn to midnight, the way a matador brandishes a cape.


Royal Couple Of the King Of Instruments
LEAD: In May of 1975, Maurice Durufle and his wife, Marie-Madeleine Durufle Chevalier, might have been one of the world's happiest couples.
They had shared 22 years together, and plenty of professional success: Each was renowned as a virtuoso organist, and their joint recitals on both sides of the Atlantic had drawn raves from critics and other organists.

Relief Group in Salvador Reports Repression
LEAD: At the headquarters of the National Union of Earthquake Victims here, the holes the soldiers made when they smashed in walls, ceilings and windows are still visible months later.

DAT Recorders For Home Use Finally Arrive
LEAD: After about four years of anticipatory tizzy, American audiophiles can now walk into a store and walk out with a DAT recorder.
DAT, as initiates know, stands for Digital Audio Tape; and the first digital tape recorder for home use is now officially on sale in this country.
This is unquestionably a milestone, and the price is correspondingly hefty: $11,000.


Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
LEAD: Athletes who dominate their sport raise the standards for others to follow, inspire younger players, and bring in fans.
The Celtics of the 60's, Steelers in the 70's, Edwin Moses for what seemed an eternity, were all dominant.
I don't recall people asking if they were ''good'' for their sport.

Tempos That Tell More Than Time
LEAD: Three recent albums of almost nonstop brilliance by the pianist Andrew Hill, 52 years old, the alto saxophonist Frank Morgan, 55, and the flugelhornist Art Farmer, 61, are good examples of how, for jazz musicians, age amplifies control.
The critic Hugh Kenner once wrote that art is the accumulation of detail; in jazz, detail derives from constant playing and the experience that comes with age.

2 Easy Winners
LEAD: Where is the best place to prepare to run the New York City Marathon?
Why, Colorado, of course.
That is where Juma Ikangaa of Tanzania, who broke the course record by 12 seconds last Sunday, and Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway, the winner of the women's division, trained for the race through the city's five boroughs.

Getting in Gear For the Slopes
LEAD: EVERY year ski resorts boast of the millions they spend sprucing up their lifts and trails for winter.
Less often, but still at considerable personal expense, skiers must undertake capital improvements of their own, replacing or upgrading their skis, boots, bindings or poles so that the equipment matches their skill and magnifies their pleasure.

In Splendid Isolation On the Tetons's Far Side
LEAD: WE skied in the west last winter, partly to check on a rumor.
Four of us - my wife, Holly, our 7-year-old daughter, Hilary, our friend Susan and I - began our mid-January holiday with three days at Jackson Hole, the great Wyoming resort that I'd skied before and wanted to introduce the others to.
But at home in Connecticut, we'd decided to take advantage of a combination deal that would also give us a taste of Grand Targhee, a resort a little over an hour away from Jackson Hole, on the other side of the Tetons.

LEAD: Fred J. Howard, executive vice president of Sterling National Bank and Trust Company, died of a heart attack Friday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx.
He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The School of American Ballet has announced that Robert Lindgren has been appointed its president.
He succeeds Lincoln Kirstein, co-founder of the school with George Balanchine.
Mr.
Kirstein retired in September as the school president and the general director of the New York City Ballet.

LEAD: THE FOOD DAY BEGINS shortly before midnight at the Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx.
It is a militaristic-looking complex in a wasteland of auto wreckers and junkyards.
Convoys of semi-trailers pass through a toll-booth opening in the barbed-wire and corregated-tin wall that surrounds the grocery compound.


The Census: How a Head Count Grew and Grew
LEAD: THE first United States census was taken almost two centuries ago.
It was designed as a simple head count to regularize the composition of the House of Representatives, with one seat for every 30,000 citizens. (Excluded were American Indians not paying taxes.) No one dreamed that by 1990 the tabulation would blossom into a vast statistical analysis, both reflecting and regulating much of our economic life.

Double Indemnity
LEAD: The United States Navy says the death of 47 sailors aboard the battleship Iowa last April was no accident, but the Amex Life Assurance Company apparently feels otherwise.
Navy investigators suspect that the explosion in one of the Iowa's huge gun turrets was intentionally set off by Clayton Hartwig, a sailor who carried a $50,000 life insurance policy that named his shipmate, Kendall Truitt (pictured with wife, Carole) as beneficiary.

5 Trials Down, 3 to Go
LEAD: As the court system disposes of indictment after indictment, the Iran-contra affair seems to be turning into a sort of crime without a perpetrator.
Of the four people sentenced so far in connection with the illegal sale of arms to Iran to raise money for illegal contributions to the contras, none has been found guilty of actually selling the weapons and none has gone to jail.

U.S.-German Pair Lead Bridge Tournament

Boston College Surprises Army
LEAD: Army's outside chance for an invitation to the Liberty Bowl was dealt a severe blow today when Boston College rallied from a 14-7 deficit to upset the Cadets, 24-17.


Finding Value in a Software Slowdown
LEAD: BY many measures, 1989 has been a rough year for computer software companies.
Several major vendors were late in shipping updates of key programs.
Distributors have been forced to take write-offs because of inventory surpluses and have not ordered as much new inventory as vendors expected.
What is more, sales of personal computers have flattened.


Fashion; Vivid Scarf Motifs Aren't Just for Scarfs Anymore
LEAD: Scarf prints have become a lot more than something to wrap around your neck.
The luxurious textures and vivid designs from Hermes and other companies now exert an influence on contemporary style that goes beyond the casually flung accessory.


Fashion; Flannel, for Counting Sheep Cozily
LEAD: Come winter, fashion sense selectively hibernates and function sense takes over, especially at bedtime.
Silky wisps and briefs may be banished in favor of comfortable grandmother-approved night clothes.


20 Hanged for Drugs in Iran
LEAD: Twenty drug smugglers were hanged in five Iranian provinces today as part of a campaign to curb addiction, the Teheran radio reported in a broadcast monitored in Cyprus.
More than 1,000 accused drug traffickers have been hanged in Iran in the last 10 months under a law requiring the death sentence for anyone caught possessing even small quantities of narcotics.

FICTION
LEAD:  OUTLAW.
By Warren Kiefer. (Donald I. Fine, $19.95.) Lee Garland, the narrator and title character in Warren Kiefer's fourth novel, has a cowboy drawl and his saga of some 90 years begins, circa 1894 in the New Mexico Territory, with tales of a hoof-pounding, hair-raising, cattle-rustling adolescence that's the stuff of boyhood dreams.


At the Front in the Battle Over Unix
LEAD: Even though the Unix operating system is 20 years old, it seems as if the battle over the one ''true'' Unix has been going on since the Crusades.
The war is far from over, but in recent weeks the field has narrowed to two major versions of the operating system.
One is controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and supported by an advisory group called Unix International; the other, scheduled for delivery next year, is being developed by a group called the Open Software Foundation, whose goal is to come up with something not controlled by A.T.&amp;T.


Review/Pop; Tension Through Irony From Eurythmics at Ritz
LEAD: In pop music, the distance between the implications of the music and a lyric is often where meaning lies.
An optimistic-sounding tune paired with a pessimistic lyric can often create a fascinating tension.


Healing Comes Slowly to Woods and Streams Where Hurricane Left Death
LEAD: From the Virgin Islands to Puerto Rico to South Carolina, Hurricane Hugo left a legacy of environmental destruction that is just now being catalogued and will take some areas years to overcome.


CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Goals of the Newcomers; A Search for Work and for Housing As the Emigres Get Their Bearings
LEAD: There were no speeches, champagne or applause at Bonn-Beuel station this morning, just cups of hot coffee handed out by Red Cross volunteers to revive the tired bodies of some 900 East Germans who traveled here overnight from Czecholovakia.


PERSPECTIVES: Town-House Rentals; East Side Project Back in Construction
LEAD: ''IT'S the biggest bargain in New York!'' said Monica Dalton, casting an admiring glance upwards toward the dazzling skylight in the one-family town house she is trying to rent out for the owner.
The skylight covers the entire room.
It swoops down from a height of 45 feet, halting 17 feet above the living room floor.


Uncertainty on Filling Florio's Seat in House
LEAD: THE vacancy created by Representative James J. Florio's victory in the gubernatorial election will most likely remain until next November, with rivals from the Democratic Party meeting in the regular June primary, officials say.

Style Makers; Gene Meyer: Fashion Designer
LEAD: When Gene Meyer opened his own fashion business in New York last week, he showed custom-made styles.
He decorated an aerie on 57th Street in robin's-egg blue and invited small groups of fashion followers and potential clients to seven fashion shows.
Among the visitors was the designer Geoffrey Beene.

LEAD: THE Kidz Kompany, a musical and theatrical company of 8- to 16-year-olds that evolved from the Westport presentation last year of the composer Paul Hindemith's musical play for children, ''Let's Build a Town,'' has set four shows for the Westport Arts Center at 2 and 4 P.M.
Saturday and next Sunday.

WHAT'S DOING IN: Geneva
LEAD: One of Europe's most cosmopolitan cities, Geneva has an upscale clientele all year: diplomats attending international conferences, oilmen, visitors to trade shows in the modern Exhibition Palace (PAL-EXPO) near the airport, conventioneers, collectors or dealers bidding at one of the frequent art or jewelry auctions, and unobtrusive guests who arrive to nurse their numbered accounts in some palatial bank near the lakefront.


'Another' Mascagni Work to Be Heard
LEAD: IN company with a number of composers whose fame essentially rests on a single work (for example, Humperdinck with ''Hansel and Gretel'' or Leoncavallo with ''Pagliacci''), Pietro Mascagni is today remembered exclusively for his 1890 prize winner, ''Cavalleria Rusticana.''


Ailing Mayor of Erie Resigns
LEAD: After nearly 24 years in office and more than a year of an incurable disease, Mayor Louis J. Tullio is stepping down.
In a letter delivered to the Erie city clerk Friday, the Mayor, who is 73 years old, said he had appointed Patricia Liebel, an assistant, as Acting Mayor.
Mr.
Tullio has suffered since May from amyloidosis, a rare terminal illness that produces proteins that destroy vital organs.

LEAD: Craig Spence, a lobbyist linked to a homosexual escort service under Federal investigation, was found dead in a hotel room here, the police said today.

Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
LEAD: Only to the extent that the myth of the unbeatable Graf becomes a script for tournaments and paralyzes other players is her dominance damaging.
The myth, created by the media and consumed by the public, is enacted by the players in a self-fulfilling prophecy.

Reports From a Broadway-Bound Gypsy
LEAD: The 30th-anniversary production of ''Gypsy,'' with its now-legendary music by Jule Styne, lyrics by Stephen Sondheim and book by Arthur Laurents, hit the road April 23, after a four-week rehearsal period in New York City, with Mr.
Laurents as director.
The 15,000-mile road tour would take the company of 34 performers, 24 musicians and 46 crew members to 14 cities over the next six months.

The Mixed Message Of Mother Goose
LEAD: FOR my daughter Kate's first birthday, I gave her an oversized baroquely illustrated collection of Mother Goose rhymes.
That evening, with Kate's tiny body enfolded in the crook of my arm, I opened the book to begin sharing the pulsing and playful rhymes.
Surely the nursery, awash with pale yellow light, would be transformed by the words and aglow with magic.

Australia
LEAD: To the Editor: In answer to the reader (Q &amp; A, Aug. 20) who wanted to see Australian wildlife in December, please note that one of the most delightful sights is the fairy penguins (none taller than 15 inches) coming ashore at dusk on Phillip Island (about a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Melbourne).

LEAD: ANGELO MARTINELLI, a Republican, lost the mayoralty here two years ago because his once firm opposition to a court-ordered housing desegregation plan had softened.
The winner was City Councilman Nicholas C. Wasicsko, a 28-year-old Democrat who had urged continued opposition to the plan.

Boys of Winter
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; Capturing Decades of Moving Images Video games take up the entire third floor of the American Museum of the Moving Image, in Astoria, Queens, for the year-old museum's exhibition ''Hot Circuits, a Video Arcade.''   ''We try to find things that are accessible to a large group of people,'' said Jo Ann Hanley, a curator at the museum, which opened in September 1988. ''The audience that comes here is much broader than, say, the audience that goes to the Museum of Modern Art.''   The three-story, 50,000-square-foot museum, which calls itself ''the first in the United States devoted to the art, history and technology of motion pictures, television and video,'' has exhibitions, film screenings, lectures and a gift shop. Unlike other institutions, like the Museum of Broadcasting in Manhattan, the museum is not concerned with the collection or preservation of film and video.   ''I think of the museum as a rose,'' said Rochelle Slovin, its founding director. ''It is revealing itself slowly as people begin to understand that the museum encompasses everything from the very early silent films to the very latest applications of video.''   The dimly lighted second floor is the heart of the museum, with its exhibits exposing the magic of special effects, a lavish re-creation of a 1920's movie palace and the ''TV Lounge.'' After walking up the winding staircase from the ground floor, a visitor encounters ''The Getaway Car,'' 63 color video monitors framed by bumpers, spinning tires and headlights and forming a Technicolor collage of flashing images.   A few feet away, a more prosaic bank of video screens show scenes from films and television shows. Each monitor is connected to a handset on which the visitor can listen to a running commentary. At one station, the 1950 production of ''All About Eve,'' starring Bette Davis, is analyzed by its director and screenwriter, Joseph L. Mankiewicz.   By viewing directors, production designers, actors and writers as artists and examining the creative process, the museum avoids becoming a repository for nostalgia, a place where flea-market gleanings are displayed. But the museum building itself had an important role in film history: it is part of a complex used by Paramount Pictures in the era of silent films and early talkies.   ''We are trying to present the historical and social considerations of these media so that people can better appreciate and enjoy the media with which they are confronted everyday of their lives,'' Ms. Slovin said.   Many exhibits underscore the intimate relationship between popular and consumer cultures. The visitor sees a white party frock worn by Joan Crawford in the 1932 movie ''Letty Lynton'' and reads that 500,000 copies of the dress were sold at Macy's alone that year. Part of a wall is filled with television-character lunch boxes like those that millions of children have carried to school for years.   The 47 video games, each with a text explaining its significance, have an obvious appeal for children, but other exhibits, like the hologram that projects costumes and the sound-effects machine, also invite adults to participate.   The overwhelmingly intricate and colorful ''Tut's Fever Movie Palace,'' a 20-foot-wide working re-creation of a 1920's movie theater created by Red Grooms and Lysiane Luong, is like a room made from a child's dream about ancient Egypt and movie stars. The walls are lined with murals of movie stars and Egyptian statues.   ''This place captures the fun of the old theaters,'' said Barbara Ehrlich, a 59-year-old school psychologist who was visiting the museum last week from Great Neck, L.I. ''The theater itself used to be one of the best things about going to the theater.''   Two theaters (more humble than ''Tut's Fever'') also have screenings. Next weekend, as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's New Music America Festival, the museum will present musical accompaniment to silent films. ''The Best of Everything: The New York Woman 1947-61,'' a film series about female New Yorkers on both sides of the camera, will begin on Nov. 24. Many of the museum's more than 700 annual screenings are accompanied by lectures.   Admission to the museum, at 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, in Astoria, is $5, $2.50 for students and children, and $4 for those over 65. Film and video screenings, along with five tokens for use in the ''Hot Circuits'' video games exhibit, which runs through Nov. 26, are included in the admission price. The museum is open Tuesday to Friday noon to 5 P.M. and Saturday and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. For program information, call 718-784-0077. Getting There   By subway: Take the R or the G train to Steinway Street. Walk down Steinway Street to 35th Avenue and right to 36th Street. Or take the N train to Broadway in Astoria; walk east on Broadway to 36th Street, turn right and proceed to 35th Avenue.   By car: Take the Grand Central Parkway to the Hoyt Avenue exit and turn left on 31st Street; turn left on 35th Avenue and proceed to 36th Street. A commercial parking lot is one block east of the museum on 35th Avenue.   For further travel information, call 718-784-4777.

LEAD: AFTER a fire destroyed Stonehenge, an old farmhouse turned inn in Ridgefield, it emerged from the ashes, completely rebuilt, and re-opened its doors last May.
A first-time visitor would never know that anything had ever been amiss.
But former patrons will miss the large, homey entrance lounge and note changes in the downstairs configuration and decor.

The World of Wearable Art
LEAD: BORDERS BETWEEN the arts tend to be vague in New York.
It's quite common to find the same artist moving from painting to sculpture and on to jewelry design.
That range suggests the parameters of today's jewelry artists, who are fabricating complex, one-of-a-kind objects that translate the concerns of mainstream art into the language of silver and gold.

LEAD: COMMERCE.
BUYING AND SELLING.
MONEY - IF you can make it here, you'll make it anywhere.
That's one of the most powerful images of New York City: this is the big time.

No. 1: That Unexpected Object of Desire
LEAD: I STOPPED TO SAY ''HI'' TO HIM every morning when I went to the corner for the paper.
He gave me the once-over, and I saw approval in his shiny black eyes. ''Hey, ol' buddy.
Hey, ol' buddy,'' I said.
He bobbed his head again and again.
I bobbed my head again and again.
As far as I was concerned, we were in love.

LEAD: When Vladimir Horowitz played, he generated electricity, thunder and lightning and displayed demonic technical control that always threatened to get out of hand but never did.

He was more than a pianist.


OUR MOST NOTORIOUS SCULPTOR
LEAD: Did the people and the press turn on Richard Serra because of government incitement?
Not really.
Government merely responded to citizen outrage.
And people, I think, simply sensed the contempt hammered into Mr.
Serra's sculpture and returned that contempt to its source.
STANLEY N. KURTZ


From Cash Cow To Cash Machine
LEAD: Romeo J. Ventres knows exactly what he wants Borden Inc. to be when he retires in December 1991.
He wants it to be the lowest-cost producer of all its products, from milk to pasta to plastics to glue.
He wants it to have a decent mix of national and regional brands.
He certainly wants it to be independent - a year ago, he and Borden's top 25 managers agreed to quit simultaneously in the event of a hostile takeover.

If Rules Aren't Broken, Don't Fix Them
LEAD: The question coaches always ask is, ''Am I responsible for every student that I bring to the campus?'' What about the youngster who decides to transfer to another school, or the youngster who comes to college and after a year or so decides this is not what he wants to do?
The important thing is that the graduation rates should be monitored on the basis of whether the youngster actually gets a degree, not whether it took four years, five years, or six years.

This afternoon they came back home.

Dolores Ibarruri, 'La Pasionaria' Of Spanish Civil War, Dies at 93
LEAD: Dolores Ibarruri, the president of the Spanish Communist Party and a fiery orator who came to be known in the Spanish Civil War as ''La Pasionaria,'' died in a hospital here tonight after a long illness.
She was 93 years old.
Party officials said after an emergency meeting that her body would be put on public display at party headquarters here beginning Tuesday and that burial would be Thursday.

Choreographer Awards
LEAD: The National Corporate Fund for Dance has announced five recipients of the third annual American Choreographer Awards.
They are David Dorfman, Miriam Mahdaviani, Sara Pearson and the choreographic team of Danial Shapiro and Joanie Smith, all of New York, and Liz Lerman of Washington.
The awards, underwritten by the General Electric Foundation, carry a cash prize of $5,000 for each winner and are given in recognition of talented emerging choreographers.

Fears of Neighbors Frustrate a Drug-Care Center
LEAD: Residents of Arverne, Queens, describe Daytop Village as a good neighbor.
In the five years that the residential drug-treatment program has been in their neighborhood, the residents say, no incidents of crime or vandalism have been linked to the center.
And, they concede, their fears that the center would lead to a drop in property values have proved unfounded.

Business and the Law; Uncertain Future For RICO Cases
LEAD: ALTHOUGH Federal prosecutors say reports of the demise of Wall Street racketeering prosecutions are highly exaggerated, defense lawyers relish the rulings last Monday by a Federal district judge who gave unexpectedly light sentences in the first Wall Street case to use the onerous racketeering law.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Family Media Rates
LEAD: Family Media Inc. announced a series of magazine advertising rate increases last week.
Discover magazine will increase its rates 6 percent while expanding its rate base by 10 percent, to 1.1 million.
There will also be rate increases of 7 percent at Savvy; 10 percent at Golf Illustrated; 10 percent at Taxi; 7 percent at World Tennis; 10 percent at Model and 5 percent at Health.

LEAD: Voters in Tuesday's elections confirmed a new and startling political truth about abortion: The issue, once seemingly a winner for right-to-life candidates, can now punish these candidates at the polls.
It can turn or swell the tide for pro-choice candidates like James Florio in New Jersey, Douglas Wilder in Virginia and David Dinkins in New York City.

Machines do things more quickly, powerfully and accurately and still comfort us with the belief that it is we who turn them on and off and tell them what to do.

This Weekend, Walk, Don't Run
LEAD: BOTH tourists and city-dwellers are finding that weekend walking is the best urban sport.
City walking, divided into five sports styles -strolling, hiking, climbing, brisk, and long-distance - offers a variety of places and ways to stay active.
And walking during a weekend means you'll have the extra time to enjoy your outing, whether within the city limits or in nearby wilderness.

Soviet Grain Figures Up
LEAD: The Agriculture Department said last week that the Soviet Union's 1989 grain harvest turned out larger than predicted but that Moscow must still import huge amounts of grain in the year ahead.
The department now expects the Soviet harvest to total 208 million metric tons, an increase of three million tons from the previous forecast.

LEAD: It was his determination to free poor Indian scavengers from a life of carrying away buckets of excrement on their heads that turned Bindeshwar Pathak, an academic social scientist, into a full-time crusader against the humiliations of untouchability.
It also made him a celebrity among the poor.


Jogger Well Enough To Visit Her Home
LEAD: The jogger who was gang-raped and beaten into a coma in Central Park in April has been making trips to her Manhattan apartment and has recovered enough to go to her family's home for Thanksgiving, a court source said yesterday.


Navratilova's Interests Go Beyond Racquet's Reach
LEAD: ALTHOUGH Martina Navratilova, once a tempestuous tennis machine on and off the court, has waited until the age of 33 to do it, she has finally, and gladly, branched out.

Elizabeth J. Hahn Wed in Scarsdale
LEAD: At the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y., Elizabeth Jane Hahn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
George A. Hahn of Scarsdale, was married yesterday to Dr.
Richard H. Dyckman, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Samuel A. Dyckman of Briarwood, Queens.
Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony.


Has O'Brien Lost Nerve?
LEAD: OVER his six seasons as the Jets' quarterback, Ken O'Brien has earned a reputation as one of the National Football League's toughest competitors.
He's been sacked as much as any truckload of Long Island potatoes, but he's always stood his ground against the assault of opposing pass rushers.
He's not nimble afoot, but when he's had to scramble he churned his legs for an extra yard.


Battered Redskins Set Back Eagles, 10-3
LEAD: Doug Williams's gamble on a fourth-down pass led to Earnest Byner's 1-yard touchdown in the second quarter today as the Washington Redskins beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 10-3.


Nevada Lands Are Searched for Stray Navy Bombs
LEAD: For years, Navy pilots accidentally dropped hundreds of bombs on public land outside a military bombing range in central Nevada, and now Gov.
Bob Miller is angry that he was never told about it.


No Hint of Change in Albania, Where Liberalization Has Long Been Suspect
LEAD: The political and economic changes sweeping through much of the rest of Eastern Europe are having no visible effect in this xenophobic, hard-line Communist nation, where for decades even the Soviet Union has been regarded as a renegade and apostate from true Communism.

Hammer Home After Surgery
LEAD: Armand Hammer went home today, two days after he received a heart pacemaker at U.C.L.A.
Medical Center.
The 91-year-old chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation ''feels great'' and expects to be back in the office on Tuesday, said an Occidental spokesman, Frank Ashley Mr.
Hammer, who has had heart trouble for more than 20 years, received the pacemaker on Friday.

LEAD: When they pass Jim Minx's driveway, some people scoff and roll their eyes.
Others lament the decline of standards.
One resident became so incensed that he took pictures of the awful sight to Village Hall, demanding action at once.


Review/Theater; Tune's Swirling Vision of a 'Grand Hotel'
LEAD: The director and choreographer Tommy Tune may have the most extravagant imagination in the American musical theater right now, and there isn't a moment, or a square inch of stage space, that escapes its reach in ''Grand Hotel.'' The musical at the Martin Beck Theater is an uninterrupted two hours of continuous movement, all dedicated to creating the tumultuous atmosphere of the setting: an opulent way station at a distant crossroads of history in Berlin - that of 1928.

LEAD: The Soviet Union appears to have adjusted its program for building long-range nuclear arms in anticipation of a strategic arms treaty, Bush Administration officials said today.

LEAD: WHEN a company needs more equity capital than it can generate internally from profits, it has two basic choices.
Either it can ask its shareholders to buy more stock, or it can hire a securities firm to find new investors.

Lawyer Says His Case Pits Ethics vs. Right to Dismiss
LEAD: With rare exceptions, employees in New York can be dismissed for just about anything and have no legal recourse.

LEAD: A leading trade official of the European Community said today that Western European nations were ''prepared to offer comprehensive agreements on commerce and economic cooperation'' to East Germany in the coming weeks.


Miami Officer Loses Appeal on Barring Juror
LEAD: Opening the way for the trial of a Miami police officer whose fatal shooting of a black motorcyclist set off rioting here in January, a Florida appeals court today rebuffed defense efforts to remove a juror in the case.


Instant Business Letters; Mix and Serve
LEAD: LAST May, we discussed a program with more than 400 business letters in 13 categories on disk.
You load the letter that best suits your needs, edit it as necessary with your word processor, and print it out, with no need to worry about dangling participles, split infinitives and the like.
The publisher supplies the literacy, the user supplies the particulars.


Review/Television; 'Midnight Caller' Continues Its AIDS Story
LEAD: NBC's ''Midnight Caller'' got stung last season with an episode about AIDS that triggered, and deserved, the strong protests of gay and other concerned groups.
The main character was a bisexual man with AIDS who knowingly continued his promiscuous ways with unsuspecting partners.
It was hardly the sort of depiction to calm existing public hysteria.


Slayings Block Traffic Around La Guardia
LEAD: The slaying of two detectives near La Guardia Airport forced police investigators to close Grand Central Parkway to westbound traffic for nearly two hours yesterday afternoon, and the spillback caused traffic jams throughout much of northwestern Queens.


New Technique Allows Study of Altered Genes in Offspring
LEAD: SCIENTISTS have developed a technique to introduce altered genes into mouse embryos so that, when the mice mature, some of them pass a functioning copy of the gene to their offspring.
The technique offers promise for research on new therapies for a wide range of human genetic diseases.

Ann H. Rothschild, 86, Interior Designer, Dies
LEAD: Ann Hatfield Rothschild, who helped design the interiors of several well-known New York City buildings, died Thursday at a nursing home in Newton, Mass.
She was 86 years old and had moved to North Easton, Mass., last year, from Piermont, N.Y., where she lived for many years.

Kitty Dukakis is a recovering alcoholic who has received treatment for chemical dependency. ''Slip'' is a term used by recovering alcoholics to describe a lapse back into drinking.

Meredith Adds a Title
LEAD: The Meredith Corporation, Des Moines, announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement to acquire the magazine Golf for Women from its founders, Debra and Woody Brumitt, who will continue to edit the magazine from its office in Oxford, Miss.
No terms were announced.
The year-old bimonthly publication will have a circulation rate base of 200,000 as of its April 1990 issue.

Mr.
Guida will replace Jack Cafferty, who announced last week that he would move to Channel 5 to become the anchor of a new late-night news program.

LEAD: Katharine Randall, a former secretary of the Tarrytown Women's Civic League, died of a heart attack Sunday at the home of her daughter Frances Wood in Mt.
Kisco, N.Y.
She was 97 years old and lived in Irvington.


O'Keeffe, Once an Icon, Is Now an Industry
LEAD: When Georgia O'Keeffe was young and obscure and teaching in Virginia, she wrote to a friend, ''If I went to New York I would be lucky if I could make a living.'' Yet at her death in 1986 at the age of 98, she was an American legend, known not only for her intense paintings of flowers and desertscapes, but also as a powerful, pioneering woman who had achieved fame, wealth and a life of enviable independence.

Seattle Voters Reject Busing
LEAD: A voter initiative asking the school board to stop busing students for racial balance was declared approved today after absentee ballots were counted.
The initiative promises that city sales tax money would be used for ''magnet'' programs aimed at achieving integration voluntarily.
It has no effect unless the school board adopts it.

Scientists Test Radical Accelerator Technology
LEAD: SCIENTISTS probing the mysteries of matter have reached a barrier almost as daunting as any created by nature: particle accelerators have grown so large that they are becoming too expensive to build.
But new research suggests that radically innovative technology could bring the size, and therefore the cost, of a future generation of ultrapowerful accelerators down to an acceptable level without sacrificing results.

When Violence and Terror Strike Outside the Schools
LEAD: ''I just walk straight home and I don't look at nobody or talk to nobody,'' said Jackie Peterson, a 15-year-old sophomore at Julia Richman High School on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, describing her afternoon routine. ''People are waiting for people after school to jump on them.''


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Stammering  Q. Why is it that people who stammer don't when they sing?
A. ''It is true that stutterers don't stutter when they sing,'' said Grace Privette, a speech pathologist who is director of the Atlanta Rehabilitation Institute, ''and the theory is that it is because speech is a left-brain-controlled function, especially the rate and rhythm, while singing is under the control of the right brain.


Don't Blame Program Trading
LEAD: After the 1929 stock market crash, Congress debated restricting the use of telephones to trade stock.
Following the Oct. 13 market plunge this year, Congress is debating similar curbs on the use of computers.
Phones did not cause the 1929 crash.
And program trading isn't the villain today.
The use of computer programs to trigger massive stock trades stabilizes financial markets and benefits investors.

Motorola Settles Lawsuits
LEAD: Motorola Inc. has agreed to settle patent-infringement lawsuits against the Tandy Corporation and a Finnish company.


Philadelphia Exchange
LEAD: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange plans to extend its trading day in foreign currency options by six and a half hours to coincide with trading in Far East and Pacific countries.
Under the plan, the exchange will remain open for foreign currency options from 10 P.M., its current close of evening trading, until 4:30 A.M., when it now begins its morning session.

Japan Surplus Plunges 39.4%
LEAD: Japan's trade surplus plunged 39.4 percent in October, to $4.66 billion, from $7.68 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today.
It was the largest fall ever.

LEAD: Beginning a buyer's revolt against sharply rising prescription drug prices, a growing number of state government and employer health plans are trying to force pharmaceutical companies to trim prices on brand-name products.


Bloodless Instant Replays
LEAD: There's something a little sinister about the instant replay in professional football: Halt the action, and wait for three men seated in a glass enclosure in the upper deck, half their faces hidden behind two television monitors, to determine the fate of the game.

Life-Style Shift Can Unclog Ailing Arteries, Study Finds
LEAD: STRICT changes in diet and life style - can not only prevent heart attacks but can actually reverse the clogging of the arteries, according to a small but pioneering study reported yesterday.
The study showed that a vegetarian diet, moderate exercise, and an hour a day of yoga and meditation could produce a reversal of atherosclerosis, a blockage of the arteries that can lead to a heart attack, in men and women who were strict in following the daily regimen.

LEAD: The Exxon Corporation chairman, Lawrence G. Rawl, said today that the company would have capital spending of about $7 billion in 1990, roughly equal to spending in 1989 excluding its acquisition of Texaco Canada from Texaco Inc.
Mr.
Rawl made the disclosure here at the annual convention of the American Petroleum Institute.

LEAD: *
Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., said its chemical unit would acquire the water services unit of Olin Corp., Stamford, Conn., a producer of specialty chemicals.
Terms were not disclosed.


Hagopian to Retire
LEAD: Louis T. Hagopian announced yesterday that he would retire as chairman of N.W.
Ayer in January, ending a 29-year career at the agency.
Mr.
Hagopian, who is 64 years old, stepped down as chief executive in April.
He was replaced by Jerry J. Siano, who will assume the title of chairman.
Mr.
Hagopian is not planning a sedentary retirement: he has been appointed vice chairman of the Media/Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America, the nonprofit industry coalition that sponsors anti-drug public service advertising.

LEAD: After holding discussions in August on ways to cooperate in the power generation business, Combustion Engineering Inc. and ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. agreed yesterday that ABB would buy Combustion Engineering for $1.6 billion in cash.

New Kodak Disk
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced an optical computer disk that it said is capable of storing 20 percent more information than the largest capacity disk now on the market.
The 14-inch optical disk will be capable of storing 8.2 gigabytes, equivalent to 8,200 megabytes, of information.
Kodak said the new disks would be fully compatible with hardware components of the Kodak Optical Disk System 6800.

LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins said yesterday that it would be useful but not essential for New York City's police commissioner to be a former police officer.

British Retail Sales Fall
LEAD: British retail sales fell a provisional seasonally adjusted seven-tenths of 1 percent in October, compared with rises of six-tenths of a percent in August and September, the Central Statistical Office reported.
This provided an annualized rate of increase of 1.3 percent in the three months to October, the lowest in seven years.

LEAD: Tony Kubek, the former Yankee star who since 1966 has served as an analyst on the NBC Sports ''Baseball Game of the Week,'' will have the same role on Madison Square Garden Network's cablecasts of Yankee games, which begin next season.
Kubek, who has also served as a broadcaster on Toronto Blue Jay telecasts during the last 13 seasons, will work with Dewayne Staats, the play-by-play announcer, and also will team with Al Trautwig on the network's pre-game program.(


Guilty Plea By Ex-Officer Of Beech-Nut
LEAD: The former president of the Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation admitted yesterday that he had knowingly sold sugar water to consumers who believed they were buying pure apple juice for their babies.


Disturbed Man Held; Mother's Body Is Found
LEAD: A man the police said was emotionally disturbed was arrested last night after hurling an ax at officers sent to his apartment in Brooklyn.
The police said that after subduing him, they found the body of his 60-year-old mother inside the apartment.

Book Notes
LEAD:  Off and Running


U.S. Sees 'No Threat' to Salvador Government
LEAD: Bush Administration officials said today that the latest offensive by Salvadoran guerrillas showed the rebels' ability to sow chaos in selected neighborhoods but was unlikely to overpower the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani.


Ex-Official's Sentence Cut Because of Illness
LEAD: A judge reduced the prison sentence of former City Transportation Administrator Michael J. Lazar yesterday.
Judge Whitman Knapp of Federal District Court in Manhattan, noting that the former official and developer had bladder cancer, vacated the three-year term for racketeering in the Parking Violations Bureau scandal.


Health Board Backs Move To Trace AIDS
LEAD: The New York City Board of Health reached a consensus yesterday to ask the state to require that the names of people infected with the AIDS virus be reported to the health authorities.
The purpose would be to trace the people they have had sex with or shared needles with.


An After-Dinner Jolt
LEAD: To The Living Section:


The Price Of Finding Role Models
LEAD: rrOf all the required tasks of a Little League season that can make Bonnie Fortney crazy, nothing compares with what's going on this week.
In this era of the memorabilia frenzy and high-priced baseball card shows, there is nothing to compare with the organization of the post-season celebration.
Not if you'd like a recognizable athlete to attend.


Navratilova Overwhelms An Out-of-Sync Fernandez
LEAD: She huffed and she puffed and she got the job done.
Martina Navratilova, a five-time winner of the Virginia Slims Championships, said her head cold left her looking pale and feeling disembodied but well enough to win.


Shots Fired at Paper on St. Regis Reservation
LEAD: Gunfire hit the office of a weekly newspaper on the St.
Regis Mohawk Reservation on Sunday night or Monday morning in what the state police called an outbreak of violence over gambling.


In Cyprus, the Dividing Line Seems Indelible
LEAD: From the door of the little shop where he sells eyeglasses in designer frames, Michael Theophanides can look about 100 yards down the street.
His view then stops at the barrier dividing this city.


Famous and Diverse Names Fill Dinkins Transition Team
LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins yesterday named a 21-member transition committee that is a ''Who's Who'' of permanently prominent and deliberately diverse New Yorkers to advise him on forming his administration.


Rematch Felled by Flu
LEAD: Steve McCarthy, the British boxer who in September lost a fight to the shoe-wielding mother of one of his opponents, withdrew yesterday from a rematch with the opponent in London, because of the flu.


Sugar Prices Reach Highs On Lagging Global Output
LEAD: World sugar prices resumed their advance yesterday and posted new contract highs in New York.
The yearlong rise in prices of free-market sugar also exerted upward pressure on the controlled domestic market.


Management Shifts Set By LaSalle Partners
LEAD: LaSalle Partners, a major real estate owner and manager, announced yesterday that its chairman and founder, William D. Sanders, will become chairman emeritus at age 47, while Stuart L. Scott and C. Gary Gerst will become co-chairmen, effective Jan. 1.


Selling of India: Tough Ads by Congress Party
LEAD: With a week to go until national elections in India, a series of unusual advertisements placed in Indian newspapers by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party seem to be generating more comment and controversy than the political campaign itself.


Bulgaria Offers to Readmit 11 Dissidents to Party
LEAD: Bulgaria's Communist leadership extended a rare olive branch today to its opponents by offering to reinstate 11 former party members who had been purged for anti-Government criticism.


CELLS SEEN AIDING PARKINSON'S FIGHT
LEAD: University of California scientists said today that they had injected genetically altered skin cells into the brains of rats suffering symptoms of Parkinson's disease and had reduced those symptoms.


Chairman Appointed By Stop &amp; Shop
LEAD: Lewis G. Schaeneman Jr., president and chief executive of the Stop &amp; Shop supermarkets since 1980, has been appointed chairman of the chain's parent company, the Stop &amp; Shop Companies, which also owns the Bradlees discount-store chain.

Reviews/Pop; Jeff Beck's Brand of Arena-Style Guitar
LEAD: In the 1960's, before rock bands routinely toured arenas, Jeff Beck was playing arena-rock guitar - every note a zinger.
He drew on the most penetrating blues guitar styles (especially that of Hubert Sumlin in Howlin' Wolf's band) to make notes slide and quiver and wail, trading linear melody for jabbing, snarling phrases that insistently buttonholed listeners.

LEAD: Disappointing city revenues force Mayor Koch to trim his budget proposals - including a depressing reduction in the Sanitation Department's street sweeping force by 188 more positions.

Therein lies a challenge to public discipline and pride.

LEAD: The Senate unanimously passed a bill today that would establish a Smithsonian Institution museum devoted to the culture and history of the American Indian.

LEAD: In an unexpected announcement, VMS Realty Partners, one of the nation's largest real estate firms, disclosed today that it is suffering cash-flow problems and would replace its top management and lay off some of its 500 employees.

Kohl Recalls Auschwitz And Agrees to Aid Poles
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany ended his visit to Poland today with a wreath-laying ceremony for the victims at Auschwitz and the signing of an agreement to provide Poland with $2.2 billion in economic assistance.


Bombing Attempt in London
LEAD: A bomb apparently intended for a British general was found under a car, and the police said today that it appeared to be the work of the Irish Republican Army.
The bomb was placed under the wrong car and fell off because it was not attached properly, the authorities said.


Bridge
LEAD: The winners had plenty to spare when two major board-a-match team championships were decided here Monday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.


Carter Says Sandinistas Are Trying to Smear Foes
LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the Sandinista Government was trying to smear opposition candidates in February's elections by tying the leading opposition coalition to military violence by contra forces still fighting in Nicaragua.


Egyptian Laborers Are Fleeing Iraq
LEAD: Thousands of Egyptian workers have fled Iraq in recent days after reports of abuse and unexplained deaths, Egyptian officials said today.
More than a million Egyptians work in Iraq, mostly as laborers, making up Cairo's biggest group of expatriates in the Arab world.


Violent Crime Up 4%, New York State Reports
LEAD: Violent crimes reported in the state increased 4.5 percent the first six months of the year, compared with the first half of 1988, officials announced today.

A Novice Reigns as Bridgeport Mayor
LEAD: Strange political twists seldom surprise anyone in this gritty city on Long Island Sound.
After all, P.T.
Barnum, the showman and circus master, was once mayor here.
So was Jasper McLevy, a Scrooge-like Socialist who reigned for 24 years until 1957.
So was John C. Mandanici, a target of death threats and car firebombings, who, during a failed 1981 re-election bid, often wore a bulletproof vest while campaigning.

LEAD: Joseph Markle, a lawyer and retired colonel in the Army, died of heart failure Monday at New York Hospital.
He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Space Shuttle Flight Delayed
LEAD: The launching of the space shuttle Discovery, which had been scheduled for next Monday, will be delayed at least two days because of potential short-circuits in the wiring assemblies of the two booster rockets.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said technicians today were removing four integrated electronics assemblies, two from each of the boosters, and taking them to the manufacturer for inspection.

Prague Loosens Restrictions on Travel
LEAD: Czechoslovakia's hard-line Government said today that it would markedly ease restrictions governing travel abroad early next year, probably on Jan. 1.

LEAD: In Congress's rush to adjourn before Thanksgiving, the list of important legislative initiatives that will be postponed until 1990 is growing fast.

Review/Television; 'Harold Lloyd: The Third Genius,' on PBS
LEAD: No, he was not Chaplin or Keaton, but ''Harold Lloyd: The Third Genius,'' leaves no doubt that he gave the silent screen many of its funniest moments.
The two-hour tribute to the daredevil in a necktie, beginning at 8 P.M. on Channel 13, is filled with laughs from Lloyd's hits of the 1920's.
There are car gags and horse gags and horsecar gags; football gags and mothball gags; girder gags, flagpole gags and, of course, the great clock-tower gag, with our hero dangling from a minute hand over the streets of Los Angeles.

Review/Opera; Soprano Makes Unexpected Met Debut in 'Frau'
LEAD: ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten,'' the seventh of Richard Strauss's 15 operas, did not arrive at the Metropolitan Opera until 1966, but it turned out to be one of the sensations of that first Lincoln Center season.
The Nathaniel Merrill-Robert O'Hearn production, the most lavish and mechanically intricate in the Metropolitan's history up to that moment, flabbergasted nearly everyone.


Three Inmates Escape From Nassau County Jail
LEAD: Three inmates, including two convicted murderers, escaped from the Nassau County Jail in East Meadow, L. I., yesterday morning, apparently by cutting through a grate and a metal door, the sheriff's office said.

LEAD: Edouard Manet's ''Rue Mosnier, Paris, Decorated with Flags on June 30, 1878,'' a poignant study of an aging veteran on crutches limping along a festive street, was bought last night for $26.4 million by the J. Paul Getty Museum of Malibu, Calif.

And the five dancers who moved into new roles in a performance of the ballet by the Joffrey on Saturday afternoon at City

LEAD: A count of absentee ballots showed Monday that the voters narrowly passed a measure opposing the busing of students for racial balance, but the head of the Seattle School Board says he is not sure whether the measure will be enacted.

LEAD: James Quinn, an assistant district attorney in Queens, said yesterday that in his 12-year career he had prosecuted several murder cases in which the victims were police officers.

He was 82 years old and lived in Towson, Md.

LEAD: The muffled drums were heard yesterday as the hearse carrying the body of Officer Gary C. Coe rolled slowly down Avenue R in Brooklyn and probably will be heard twice more this week.

LEAD: In the quest for clean air, the utility industry today introduced a high-technology entry to curb pollution from autos: an electric van that speeds along at up to 72 miles an hour, and can run for more than 100 miles without having to be recharged.

LEAD: According to votes of about a half-million baseball fans this summer, Hank Aaron's 715th career home run created the greatest moment in baseball history.


Knicks Defeated Despite 43 By Ewing
LEAD: Cliff Robinson scored 22 points and Terry Porter added 21 tonight as the Portland Trail Blazers defeated the Knicks, 118-117, despite a 43-point performance by Patrick Ewing.


Bush Sees More Change Across Czechoslovakia
LEAD: Calling the recent changes in Eastern Europe ''most exciting,'' President Bush today praised the decision by Czechoslovakia to abandon the use of permits for citizens seeking to travel abroad and said he expected a further relaxation of policies in that country.


Leagues Get Warning on Cable Deals
LEAD: Several senators and members of the House of Represenatatives said today that professional baseball and football risked losing their exemptions from antitrust laws if teams and leagues continued to reduce the number of games available on over-the-air network and local broadcasts in favor of lucrative contracts with cable networks.


Hungary to Return Vehicles
LEAD: East Germans who abandoned their cars and motorbikes in Hungary when they crossed illegally to the West must claim them within a week if they want the vehicles back, the official press agency said today.
Before Hungary opened its borders two months ago, East Germans crossing the Austrian border left behind 660 cars, 47 motorcycles, 36 mobile homes and 18 trailers.

U.S. Auto Sales Drop By 23.1%
LEAD: Early November sales of domestically produced cars plunged 23.1 percent, prompting gloomy predictions from industry analysts of more plant shutdowns and layoffs in the near future.


Real Estate; Plan to Ease The Transfer Of Air Rights
LEAD: THE New York City Planning Department has proposed to expand the area in mid-Manhattan to which unused development rights from Grand Central Terminal could be transferred for future building projects.


Brazilians Vote Today for President In a Free and Unpredictable Election
LEAD: After a gap of 29 years, Brazilians vote for president Wednesday in the first round of elections expected to set the direction for Latin America's largest nation in the 1990's.


Dollar Posts Sharp Decline; Mark's Advance Continues
LEAD: The dollar fell sharply against all major currencies, while the West German mark continued to take center stage in foreign exchange.

CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Petitions and Cantatas; A Leipzig Church Mirrors German Past and Present
LEAD: It is in places like old Thomas Church on the edge of the medieval Market Square here that the past nudges up against the future.

Namibia Rebel Group Wins Vote, But It Falls Short of Full Control
LEAD: The South-West Africa People's Organization, which waged a long guerrilla war against South African rule, was declared the winner today in the first elections in Namibia's transition to independence, but failed to achieve the two-thirds majority needed to impose its own constitution and policies.


Lebanese Holds Talks on Unity
LEAD: Selim al-Hoss, Lebanon's newly appointed Prime Minister, held extensive discussions today in an effort to bring the country's feuding factions together in a government of national reconciliation.


New I.B.M. Disk Drive Is Ready
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would begin shipping its newest disk drive storage system before most analysts' expectations, improving the company's financial prospects for 1990.

Not Satan Worship
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Thursday about the quality of voter surveys for the elections in New York and Virginia misstated the timing of a poll conducted by The New York Observer.
It was published in the Nov. 6 issue of The Observer, distributed to newsstands and subscribers on Nov. 1.


Dartmouth Divestment Announced
LEAD: Dartmouth College has said it will sell off $11.5 million in investments in companies doing business in South Africa by the end of the year.


Mets Grant Carter's Wish
LEAD: Gary Carter received a technical assist from the Mets yesterday when they acceded to his request and released him, as expected, so he could pursue talks with other teams at once.


Rangers Provide Penguins With a Bit of Relief
LEAD: For the Penguins, the speculation, as wide ranging as it was unrelenting, had come to a stop on Monday.
The jobs that were supposed to be in danger - Gene Ubriaco's as coach and Tony Esposito's as general manager -were temporarily secure.


Hastily Arranged European Community Summit to Discuss the Extraordinary Changes in East Bloc
LEAD: France has called for a meeting of the 12 leaders of the European Community ''to discuss the recent developments in the situation in Europe.''

Corrections
LEAD: Because of a computer entry error involving Brigham Young's football record, the College Computer Ranking in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the standing of the teams ranked 15th through 19th.
Brigham Young is 15th, Penn State 16th, Texas A&amp;M 17th, Texas Tech 18th and Clemson 19th.


One School Confronts A Killing
LEAD: Alfred E. Smith High School has a reputation as a quiet place: no guns, no knives, no nonsense.
But a student was shot to death in a hallway two days ago, a fellow student was charged in the death, and the Bronx school has been transformed.


Police Storm Brazil Prison
LEAD: State troopers stormed a prison in southern Brazil today and ended a siege by inmates, killing 8 prisoners and freeing 39 hostages, the police said.
Fifty troopers rushed into the Curitiba prison firing their guns after prisoners killed one hostage and wounded three others, said Sgt.
Ericu Gilberto Cassou Miller.


Reviews/Pop; Evolution of a Punky Spirit
LEAD: Deborah Harry was carrying a pink rose when she stepped onstage Sunday night at the World for her encore.
In the spotlight, she bit the flower off its stem and spat petals at the audience, showing off the punky spirit of her late-1970's band, Blondie.


Quake Gives an Impetus To Commuting by Phone
LEAD: Many people here go to work in San Francisco the old-fashioned way.
They drive or take mass transit, and since the Oct. 17 earthquake, they have been spending two, three, even four hours a day doing it.


Review/Film; 'Magnolias' Of the Stage Writ Large For Screen
LEAD: Herbert Ross's ''Steel Magnolias'' runs 118 minutes but seems even longer than ''Intolerance.''


Careercom Offer Is Terminated
LEAD: The Careercom Corporation, an operator of career-training institutes in the United States, said Maiden Lane Associates Ltd. had decided to terminate its agreement to acquire Careercom.
The acquisition by Maiden Lane, which was formerly known as the Home Group Investment Corporation, was to have been for $11.50 a share in cash, or a total of about $132 million.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''In this business people make mistakes, as these detectives did, and they paid a terrible price.''  - Police Commissioner Richard J. Condon of New York City.  [ A1:5. ]


Bush Meets G.O.P. Women on Abortion
LEAD: President Bush met today with four Republican Congresswomen who support abortion rights, and afterward they said the President did not rule out the possibility of signing legislation allowing Federal financing of abortions for poor women in the cases or rape and incest.


Scorers In Forefront For N.I.T.
LEAD: Last season, Loyola Marymount was No. 1 in the nation in scoring.
This season, Nevada-Las Vegas is No. 1 in the nation in the preseason polls.


In 2 Officers' Neighborhoods, A Day of Grief and Memories
LEAD: All day long, cars pulled up to the house where Detective Richard J. Guerzon had lived.
Some were driven by friends and neighbors; one was a sleek limousine bearing Richard J. Condon, the New York City Police Commissioner.
And for a brief visit in the middle of the day, there was an older car carrying the widow of Detective Keith L.


New-Music Festival; Organized Noisemaking By Percussion Ensemble
LEAD: Nexus, a Toronto-based percussion ensemble, played six contemporary works at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday afternoon in a concert that was part of the New Music America festival.
The players - Russell Hartenberger, Bob Becker, William Cahn, Robin Engelman and John Wyre - gave a musicianly demonstration of the art of organized, tightly choreographed noisemaking.


GORBACHEV URGES RESTRAINT BY WEST ON TURMOIL IN EAST
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appealed today for restraint in response to the tumultuous changes in Eastern Europe, warning the West against gloating about the defeat of Communism or trying to ''export capitalism.''


Economic Scene; Monetary Policy: A New Old Twist
LEAD: FOR nearly a century, monetary theorists have been searching for their Holy Grail: a way to figure just the right amount of money to keep the economy on an even keel.
Now two more pilgrim-scholars, David Glasner, an economist at the Federal Trade Commission, and Earl Thompson, a professor at the University of California at Los Angeles, are hot on the trail.


Garrett Family Era Is Coming to a Close
LEAD: Judd Garrett, the Princeton halfback, is so good at evading tacklers rather than running over them that he has been credited with special vision on the football field.


Rev. Donald MacLean, Educator, 59, Dies
LEAD: The Rev.
Donald I. MacLean, president of St.
Joseph's University in Philadelphia from 1976 to 1986, died of cancer Monday in Weston, Mass.
He was 59 years old.


Navy Accidents: What Has Gone Wrong
LEAD:  Incidents reported by the Navy in the last three weeks.
Oct. 29: Pilot making his first landing on an aircraft carrier slams into the Lexington in the Gulf of Mexico.
Four sailors and one civilian killed.
Oct. 30: Pilot of an FA-18 accidentally drops a 500-pound bomb on the guided missile cruiser Reeves in the Indian Ocean.


About New York; Using the Big Top To Put Normalcy In the Lives of 500
LEAD: rrTomorrow morning a group of 500 people have a special invitation to the Big Apple Circus, now playing at Lincoln Center.
They will be entertained by death-defying aerialists, stampeding Pekingese dogs, a dancing elephant and much, much more.
Most won't see a thing.
They're blind.
But they will taste the cotton candy, bounce to the rollicking circus music, smell the pachyderms, read a Braille program and feel wind from galloping horses.


When Drugs and Despair Vie With 3 R's
LEAD: At 8:30 A.M., Janet Short plants her feet on the uneven asphalt, scans the playground and rings an old-fashioned brass school bell.
She is beginning another day as principal of the Maurice J. Tobin School - and as surrogate parent, social worker and psychiatrist to children from one of Boston's toughest and most drug-infested housing projects.


Goal by Wells Sends Islanders to 6th Straight Loss
LEAD: Ron Hextall, playing his first full game since last spring's Stanley Cup playoffs, survived several mistakes off his own goalie stick tonight and helped the Philadelphia Flyers to a 5-4 victory over the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum.


Ford Recalls 1.5 Million Cars
LEAD: Ford Motor Company is recalling about 1.5 million 1985-87 Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx cars to fix problems with the driver's seat track.
The company said Monday a bracket attaching the front of the track to the floor could crack, causing the seat to rock.
Ford also said it would provide extended warranty protection for about 343,000 1986-88 Aerostar minivans with three-liter V-6 engines for a potential problem with a crankshaft pulley.


Metro Datelines;
LEAD: About $3 million was reported missing on Monday from a vault of Hercules Armored Car at 119 West Nyack Road.


Dykstra and Phillies Agree on 1990 Pact
LEAD: Lenny Dykstra and the Philadelphia Phillies have agreed to terms on a 1990 contract that will pay him $700,000 plus incentives.

LEAD: Liz Thompson, the executive director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., has been named director of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Ms.
Thompson will take over in January, succeeding Joseph V. Melillo, who was named president and artistic director of the New York International Festival of the Arts in

Pickens Rejects Changes in Mesa
LEAD: T. Boone Pickens has decided not to reorganize his Mesa Limited Partnership into a corporation, even though tax laws have made the limited partnership less attractive, the investor and oil man said.
Mr.
Pickens acknowledged in an interview that some Wall Street analysts had urged him to change the structure to push Mesa's market value above its current $8 per unit.


Oil Industry Calls for Opening Reserves
LEAD: The executive who will lead the oil industry's battle in Washington against tighter regulations said today that the United States could not remain an economic power if it prevented the energy industry's search and development of promising reserve fields.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about Resorts International reversed, in some editions, the payouts that two groups of bondholders would receive in a proposed reorganization.
The senior bondholders stand to collect 75 to 80 cents for each dollar of debt they are owed; the junior bondholders should recover 40 to 45 cents on the dollar.


Insurers vs. Doctors: A Software Battleground
LEAD: New computer software products using techniques developed by artificial intelligence researchers are helping a growing number of employers and insurers to audit some of the 1.5 billion doctor and hospital bills submitted each year for insurance payment.

At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence
LEAD: AS a jewelry designer who sells privately through friends, Elizabeth Locke goes to parties all over the country.
But in places like New York, Los Angeles and Washington, the parties are not what they used to be. ''You stand around eating broccoli and swilling water,'' she said.
Mostly, people talk about their work.


'Junk Bond' Staff Cut By Drexel
LEAD: In a move indicating financial difficulty at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the firm announced yesterday that it had trimmed the staff of its ''junk bond'' department in Beverly Hills, Calif., by about 11 percent.

LEAD: The 5-year-olds who watched the first ''Sesame Street'' show in 1969 are now old enough to have Cookie Monsters of their own, but the debate that began with the first show continues today: Is television a good teacher?

LEAD: Outside the fighter's dressing room, two West Orange, N.J., police officers stood guard.

Shakespeare Troupe Must Vacate Quarters
LEAD: The Riverside Shakespeare Company must vacate its 99-seat space at the West-Park Presbyterian Church on the Upper West Side by the end of the year.
Timothy Oman, Riverside's artistic director, said that a new lease had been in the process of negotiation and that the company had expected a six-month grace period.


Retail Sales Declined 1% In October
LEAD: Retail sales, held back by a sluggish automobile market, fell 1 percent in October, the first decline in eight months, the Government reported today.


Provision to Give Speaker Jet
LEAD: The Defense Department would be required to provide House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington with his own jet under an amendment added to the defense appropriations bill without hearings, debate or notice to members, it was learned tonight.


NEWS SUMMARY

Europe Joblessness Dips
LEAD: Unemployment in the 12 European Community countries dipped to 9.1 percent in September from 9.2 percent in August and from 9.8 percent a year earlier, the community said Monday.
According to Eurostat, the European Community's statistics agency, 14.2 million people were out of work in August.
A figure for September was unavailable because of a new method of counting unemployment in the Netherlands.


Davis, Reliever for Padres, Is Easy Winner of Cy Young Award
LEAD: The era of the relief pitcher reached new peaks of distinction yesterday when Mark Davis of the San Diego Padres scored a landslide victory to win the Cy Young Award as the best pitcher in the National League.

House Bill to Curb Program Trading Is Softened
LEAD: Congressional efforts to curb program trading were set back today.
A House subcommittee voted to remove a key section of a bill that would have granted regulators the power to suspend the computer-assisted trading during periods of high market volatility.

BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Gulfstream Aerospace Corp., Savannah, Ga., an aircraft manufacturing subsidiary of Chrysler Corp., offered employees in its Savannah division a voluntary termination incentive program.


McGill in Talks To Avoid SKF Bid
LEAD: The McGill Manufacturing Company said it was in talks with undisclosed third parties about possible alternatives to the hostile offer of $72 a share, or $104 million, from the Swedish concern SKF A.B.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, McGill, a maker of anti-friction bearings based in Valparaiso, Ind., said the third parties had agreed not to move to take control of the company without its permission until April 25.


Pennsylvania Passes Anti-Abortion Measure
LEAD: The Pennsylvania Senate overwhelmingly passed legislation tonight imposing the nation's toughest restrictions on abortion.
The bill, already passed by the State House of Representatives, is expected to be quickly signed into law by Gov.
Robert P. Casey, a Democrat who helped draft the legislation.


Raytheon Job Enlarged
LEAD: The Raytheon Company, based in Lexington, Mass., has received a $429.5 million addition to a fixed-price contract for production of Patriot antiaircraft missiles, the Army said today.
The original contract called for $3.94 billion for production of the missiles in the 1990 fiscal year.


Namibia Election Violence Targets Swapo
LEAD: To the Editor:


A Faintly Amused Answer to Fast Food
LEAD: YOU can't turn back the clock, but Carlo Petrini, an Italian intellectual and wine writer, favors unwinding, at least at the dinner table.
He is organizing an international movement called Slow Food, in response to the instant gratification of McDonald's, Pizza Hut, Kentucky Fried Chicken and perhaps even the minute steak.

Community Shrinks From Crack's Embrace
LEAD: With its handsomely restored brownstones, well-organized block clubs and political activism, the southern part of Bedford-Stuyvesant contradicts the popular view of it as a crumbling and dangerous ghetto.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Political Memo article yesterday about assessments of the abortion issue at the Republican Governors Association meeting characterized remarks by Linda Divall, a Republican poll taker, incorrectly.
She said that the elections last week did not mean candidates who oppose abortion cannot be elected; they can.


Decaffeinated Coffee Tied to Cholesterol Rise
LEAD: Middle-aged coffee drinkers who switched to decaffeinated coffee increased their blood levels of a form of cholesterol that contributes to heart attacks, a study has found.
