Foreign Air Takeovers Benefit U.S. Travelers; British Restrictions
LEAD: To the Editor:


Philadelphia to Pay Damages to Detainees
LEAD: The City of Philadelphia has agreed to pay at least 336 black men a total of $50,000 because they were stopped, frisked, questioned or arrested in a police hunt last year.


Italians Taking Sides Over Ghostwriting For a Nobel Winner
LEAD: Is it possible?
Can it be true?
Eugenio Montale, one of the great poets of the century, the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1975 and a noted literary and music critic, used a ghostwriter?


Southmark Backs Sale of Integon
LEAD: The Southmark Corporation said its board had approved the previously announced agreement to sell its 89 percent interest in the Integon Corporation, an insurance company in Winston-Salem, N.C., to an investor group formed by Jupiter Industries and Head Insurance Investors L.P. for $109 million in cash and $40 million in debt to be issued by the purchaser.


Review/Theater; 'Tempest' With Langella as a Detached Prospero
LEAD: The British director Jude Kelly might have a vibrant ''Tempest'' in her, but the production that opened last night at the Roundabout Theater isn't it.


Reviews/Music; Kenneth Fuchs Premiere By the Juilliard Symphony
LEAD: For the second concert in its regular series, on Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall, the Juilliard Symphony originally announced an ambitious program: Stravinsky's ''Apollo,'' Xenakis's ''Pithoprakta'' and the premiere of Kenneth Fuchs's ''Reconciliation Elegy.'' However, because of the heavy recent schedules of some players, including participation in the telecast of the New York Marathon, the conductor, Paul Zukofsky, dropped the Xenakis to allow more rehearsal time for the other pieces.


Telephone Workers and Nynex Face Local Issues
LEAD: Striking telephone company workers were ''popping corks all over the state,'' celebrating Monday's tentative settlement of a bitter three-month strike against the Nynex Corporation, Jan Pierce, a vice president of a local district of the Communications Workers of America, said in Manhattan yesterday, but negotiations on a series of local issues were continuing.


Review/Film; Andersen's 'Mermaid,' by Way of Disney
LEAD: The heroine of Hans Christian Andersen's story ''The Mermaid'' failed in her bid to become human, and became a disembodied spirit relegated to spending centuries in limbo. ''The Little Mermaid,'' a glorious Walt Disney version of this tale and the best animated Disney film in at least 30 years, is due for immortality of a happier kind.


Thoughts of Chairman Krenz
LEAD: Whew!
I've been the head man in East Germany for a truly tumultuous few weeks and I'm still here.
Bulldozing more holes in the wall worked.
Two million people went across; all but 1 in 100 came back to work Monday.
And others will come home when they see that life in the West won't be easy.

Franz Josef of Liechtenstein, 83, A Head of State for 51 Years, Dies
LEAD: Prince Franz Josef II of Liechtenstein, head of state of the tiny principality in a half century that saw it become one of the world's richest nations, died Monday, the Government said today.
He was 83 years old.
The ruler's death after a long, undisclosed illness came less than a month after his wife, Princess Gina, died at 67.

Review/Film; Japan's Comedy Legend Comes to the United States
LEAD: In Japan, the character of Tora-san is as familiar and popular as Mickey Mouse is in America, as bumbling and endearing as Ralph Kramden, as durable as James Bond.
Since 1969, 41 films have centered on this cheerful, middle-aged street vendor who embodies traditional values of family and home life while remaining an unambitious, unattached drifter in an increasingly buttoned-down, economically driven society.

Alaska Reports Earthquake
LEAD: A moderate earthquake felt in Juneau was recorded early Monday west of Haines, but no damages or injuries were reported.
The Tsunami Warning Center here recorded the temblor at 4.2 on the Richter scale.
The quake, which struck at 5:07 A.M., was centered about 140 miles northwest of Juneau and 70 miles west of Haines, said George Carte, a seismologist at the center.

Stuffing As You Like It: Tried or Trendy
LEAD: A GROUP of grinches initiated a campaign several years ago to undermine turkey.
In full hearing of well-known taste makers, they whispered that the Thanksgiving bird of choice was, in fact, overbred, overrated and dry.
Glossy food magazines began proposing capon and pheasant, duck and squab as tasteful alternatives.

Police Are Permitted To Disable Car Alarms
LEAD: To the Editor:


A Common House, a Common Home
LEAD: My address marks the fourth time that I have had the opportunity to speak publicly in what you call the socialist camp and we call the Soviet bloc.
Each time there was an historical coincidence to the timing.
The first was in July 1968 in Prague, during the Czechoslovak ''spring.'' The second was two years ago in Budapest, at the beginning of the end of the Kadar era.


Delta Order For Boeing, McDonnell
LEAD: Delta Air Lines, announcing plans to expand what is already one of the most modern fleets in the industry, said yesterday that it was ordering or placing options on 260 aircraft worth about $10 billion with the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
The total is one of the largest orders in the history of the industry.

LEAD: ''Shirley Valentine,'' a one-woman comedy by Willy Russell, will close after the evening performance on Nov. 25 at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street.
The play, directed by Simon Callow and starring Ellen Burstyn, will have run for 8 previews and 324 regular performances.


UAL Seeks Ways To Repel Coniston
LEAD: Directors of the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, acting to repel an investor group that wants to sell or restructure the airline, told its financial advisers to explore options, but stopped short of putting the airline up for sale.
After a long directors' meeting Monday, UAL's board said it had authorized its investment banker, the First Boston Corporation, to explore transactions for UAL, including employee stock ownership or a recapitalization.


Singapore Stock Shift
LEAD: Singapore said today that it would introduce trading in foreign shares to offset the impact of an impending split between the local bourse and the stock exchange in neighboring Malaysia.
The Stock Exchange of Singapore plans to establish an over-the-counter trading system to deal in foreign stocks by next January, Richard Hu, Singapore's Finance Minister, told an investment conference.

Europe '92: Wary View
LEAD: Australia is wary about the proposed establishment of a single European market by the end of 1992 because of fears that it may create a ''Fortress Europe,'' the Foreign and Trade Minister, Gareth Evans, said today, addressing the Sydney Institute of Public Affairs.
He said Australia's worry stemmed from the European Community's subsidies for farm and mineral exports.


A Heist, A Handshake And a Hall
LEAD: Long overdue, the concept of a New York Sports Museum and Hall of Fame is finally off the ground, flapping its wings to attract corporate contributions.
As yet, there is no hall for this fame but according to its president, Bill Shannon, a Manhattan site will be announced soon.
Early next year, 100 charter members will be selected from some 400 nominees in 30 sports within a rr75-mile radius of the Big Apple.

Home Improvements
LEAD: USING extension cords or multiple-outlet plugs to supplement an insufficient number of wall receptacles can be a fire hazard.
A safer solution is to extend a circuit's wiring and install additional electrical outlets.
Before beginning, consult a local building inspector to learn whether amateurs are allowed to do the work and whether any methods other than those described here must be used.

Dow, in a Rebound, Advances 22.33 Points
LEAD: Stocks rose moderately yesterday, buoyed by a modest increase in bond prices and strength in some takeover-related issues.


Corrections
LEAD:  Because of an editing error, the Advertising column of Business Day on Tuesday misstated the relationship between the Ogilvy &amp; Mather agency and the Ogilvy Group.
The group is the agency's parent company.


Swapo Chief Vows to Allow Democracy
LEAD: The leader of the South-West Africa People's Organization pledged today that it would observe a bill of rights and would practice multiparty democracy unless Namibians chose otherwise.


First Bank System Cuts Dividend 50%
LEAD: In the midst of a reorganization that includes layoffs, the First Bank System board voted to cut the Minneapolis bank holding company's dividend by half, to 20.5 cents quarterly.
The move was not mandated by banking regulators, First Bank management said.


Clamor in the East: Gratitude and a Request; In Talk to Congress, Walesa Urges A Marshall Plan to Revive Poland
LEAD: Lech Walesa, the founder of Poland's Solidarity movement, called for a second Marshall Plan today as he addressed a joint meeting of Congress.
He warned that without the sort of commitment that helped rebuild Western Europe after World War II, the situation in his country could become dangerous.


Reagan Warmly Received in Return to Capital
LEAD: In his first visit here since leaving the White House, Ronald Reagan today unveiled his official Presidential portrait and dedicated a $6 million Republican campaign building named in his honor.


Journal of Commerce by Fax
LEAD: The Journal of Commerce on Monday began facsimile transmission of a summary of the next day's paper that reaches subscribers in midafternoon.


Cable Giant Hungry for Programs
LEAD: With 11 million subscribers and interests in more than a dozen program distribution services, Tele-Communications Inc. is already the nation's largest cable television operator, a behemoth in its business.
But for its president, John C. Malone, that is no longer enough.
Like other cable operators, his company is stepping up expansion with an eye on becoming a program producer as well.


Preservation of New York Adirondack Park Wins Wide Support
LEAD: To the Editor:


G.A.O. Sees Losses in Loan Efforts
LEAD: The myriad of rapidly expanding Federal insurance and credit-assistance programs exposes the Government to losses of $5 trillion, equal to the value of the economy's total annual output, the General Accounting Office reported today.


Braves Waive Sutter Because of Injury
LEAD: Bruce Sutter, the 36-year-old relief pitcher who is third on major league baseball's career save list with 300, was waived by the Atlanta Braves yesterday as chronic shoulder injuries ended his chances of becoming No. 1 in his specialty.
Sutter unofficially announced his retirement last March after a complete rotator cuff tear was found in his right shoulder and did not pitch in 1989.


Metro Matters; After the Tally, Political Puzzles Hang in the Air
LEAD: Who won?
The official canvass of New York City's mayoral election, which started yesterday, is unlikely to change last week's unofficial answer.

Clamor in the East: Speaking Out; KISSINGER EXPECTS A UNITED GERMANY
LEAD: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has told a foreign policy group that German reunification is inevitable and that NATO's plan for upgrading nuclear weapons in West Germany is now ''out of the question.''


Clamor in the Easst: Bleak Fiscal Picture; Grim State of East Germany's Economy Is Disclosed to Parliament
LEAD: East Germany's economy, battered by the flight to the West of more than 100,000 workers, many of them highly skilled, is in much worse shape than almost anyone knew, high-ranking Communist officials disclosed this week.


Bolivia Declares a State of Siege After Breakdown in Strike Talks
LEAD: The Government declared a three-month state of siege today and rounded up at least 700 teachers and labor leaders a day after negotiations with striking teachers broke down.


Moondog Returns From the Hippie Years
LEAD: Anyone who spent time in midtown Manhattan between the late 1940's and the early 1970's is likely to have seen and perhaps puzzled over Louis T. Hardin, better known as Moondog.
For nearly 30 years, the gaunt blind musician with a flowing beard haunted the Avenue of the Americas around 54th Street, dressed in a homemade robe and a horned Viking helmet with a long spear at his side.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about the 50th anniversary of Congregation Habonim, a temple on the Upper West Side of Manhattan founded by Reform Jewish emigres from Germany, referred imprecisely to the founding of another Reform congregation, Temple Emanu-El, on Fifth Avenue.
It was established in 1845.


Saab-Scania Aircraft
LEAD: Saab-Scania A.B. of Sweden said Tuesday that the United States carrier Business Express had placed an order worth 1.7 billion kronor, or about $263 million, for 18 of its commuter aircraft, with an option on a further 10 planes.
It said Business Express, a privately owned regional company feeding Delta Air Lines hubs in New York, Philadelphia, Boston and Washington, had already bought 15 Saab 340 B's and was ordering 18 more.


Clamor in the East; Soviets Protest About the Wall
LEAD: The Soviet Government has issued a sharp protest to the East German Government about the opening of the Berlin wall, a high-ranking East German Communist Party official said today.


Laidlaw to Get Disposal Company
LEAD: Laidlaw Transportation Ltd. of Ontario won a court battle to take over Canada's largest chemical waste disposal company.
Laidlaw, a garbage disposal company and North America's largest school bus operator, won control of Tricil Ltd. in an out-of-court settlement after a three-year legal battle.

Riney Denies Rumors That It Will Be Sold
LEAD: James D. Travis, the president of Hal Riney &amp; Partners, moved yesterday to quash spreading rumors that the agency is on the verge of selling itself to another advertising company. ''I got a call that said we were sold, and I said, not that I know of,'' Mr.

Death and Diplomacy in El Salvador
LEAD: By infiltrating 1,500 guerrillas into the capital, El Salvador's leftist rebels have shown their continuing strength, at a terrible cost in lives.
But they have little realistic chance of defeating the right-wing Government.
The battlers in this unending war continue to stagger against each other, neither strong enough to deliver a knockout blow, each unwilling to end the contest.


Many Restaurants Evade Taxes, Koch Says
LEAD: Dozens of Manhattan restaurants, including some of the world's most famous, have been skimming profits and will be billed for about $6 million in back taxes, New York City officials said yesterday.

LEAD: One of Canada's top three junior hockey leagues this week changed an important rule to lure a 16-year-old prodigy away from other options, including college hockey in the United States.

LEAD: Police officers searched warehouses, lots and vacant buildings today for three inmates, two of them murderers, who escaped from the Nassau County Jail on Tuesday.

LEAD: The Bush Administration urged Congress yesterday to ratify a treaty amendment that would increase airline but bar award of additional damages based on an airline's fault or misconduct.

LEAD: JEWELRY and porcelain may seem an odd marriage, especially when the combination is displayed at a gallery that specializes in French and Continental furniture and decorative objects.
But for Anthony G. Victoria, the president of Frederick P. Victoria &amp; Son, the pairing works well.


What Bush Could Say
LEAD: My fellow Americans, You and I share a rare moment in the lives of any people.
A new chapter is opening in human history, and we are privileged to see it.
I come to you tonight to speak of the great change that is taking place, and of the part I believe our country can play in it.


Currents; Creating the Colefax &amp; Fowler Look
LEAD: FOR 50 years, Colefax &amp; Fowler, the London design partnership of John Fowler, Sibyl Colefax and Nancy Lancaster, has been creating cozy, chintz-filled interiors that have come to epitomize English style. ''Our influence on both sides of the Atlantic has been so enormous, and so many people have interpreted our style the wrong way, we thought it was time to set the record straight,'' said Chester Jones, a joint managing director of Colefax &amp; Fowler.

LEAD: More than 200 miniature Japanese art objects valued at $300,000 were stolen before dawn Monday from the Japanese Art Museum in Haifa, the museum's director said.

Read All About It
LEAD: In an effort to speed up pedestrian movement in midtown Manhattan, a group of city officials will soon announce new regulations for newsstands.
Their first effort, two years ago, would have closed down most existing stands and practically prohibited new ones.
Ideally, the new rules would protect public access to the newsstands as well as sidewalk traffic.

LEAD: A brief article in Business Day on Tuesday about a new publication called TimesFax, which is to summarize The New York Times for businesses and travelers in the Far East by facsimile transmission beginning in January, misstated the planned number of pages.
It is four to six (not six to eight).

Market Place; Tighter Money And Stock Prices
LEAD: A TIGHT money supply has traditionally been a harbinger of coming contractions in the financial markets.
When there is less monetary growth or liquidity is low, it is generally believed, there will be less money around to push up the prices of assets, including stocks.

Dr. Joseph and AIDS Testing
LEAD: The New York City Board of Health favors the idea of contact tracing in cases of AIDS.
That would mean, if New York State approves, that people infected with the AIDS virus would have their names reported to health authorities.
They, in turn, would try to trace and alert the patients' sexual and needle-sharing partners.

LEAD: Since its inception in 1969, the Cleveland Quartet has been one of this country's leading exponents of the quartet repertory.
Throughout those 20 years, three members have remained constant: Donald Weilerstein, the first violinist; Peter Salaff, the second violinist, and Paul Katz, the cellist.
The viola has been the unstable spot, although it was always well filled - now, by James Dunham.

Mexican Debt Status

LEAD: Interest rates are likely to decline as the economy slows, but the beneficial effects of lower rates may not be enough to forestall a recession in the United States, Henry Kaufman, the economist, said yesterday.


Giants Sign Bass For $5.25 Million
LEAD: Kevin Bass became the first of baseball's 90 free agents to be signed as he agreed yesterday to a three-year contract with the San Francisco Giants for $5.25 million.


LaFontaine Helps Islanders End Drought
LEAD: The Islanders ended a bleak string of defeats tonight by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-2, at Nassau Coliseum.

Walesa And Shamir
LEAD: Lech Walesa brought such pleasure, shared such a sense of pride in a nation's achievement, that it was almost impossible to find room in the mind or heart for anything else -even another piece of history being acted out in the city.


The Two Countries Are Likely to Join Their Industries Before Their Politics
LEAD: Foreigners who worry about ''reunification'' as an immediate and ominous consequence of the end of the Berlin wall overlook two things.
One is that East and West Germany together only constitute about two-thirds of the pre-war territory of the German Reich.
Another is that East and West Germany have gradually been extending and broadening ties of all kinds ever since they established diplomatic relations with each other in 1972.

LEAD: If ever a game figured to have one team as the perfect foil to snap an opponent out of its misery, it is Sunday night's Jets-Colts affair.

LEAD: The Bush Administration today condemned the killing of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador and said it had asked President Alfredo Cristiani to order a full inquiry.


Falcons' Quarterback Getting High Marks
LEAD: The Atlanta Falcons have a cornerback, Deion Sanders, whose loose lips are infuriating some of his teammates, a head coach, Marion Campbell, who heard screams for his dismissal this week, and a 3-7 record.
There is little hope among the Falcons that they can finish any place but last, once again, in the National Conference West Division.

Hard Times Overtake the Roosevelt Tram
LEAD: In the 14 years since the Roosevelt Island tramway began operating, its admirers say, the twin red cabs have become as much a symbol of New York City as the Brooklyn Bridge and the Staten Island Ferry.
And like the ferry, these admirers say, the tram is a bargain; a dollar and a quarter not only gets you from here to there, but also provides a spectacular view.


New York City Employees To Be Subject to Drug Tests
LEAD: New York City employees in 53 safety-related job categories - from lifeguard to crane operator to juvenile counselor - will be subject to random drug testing under an executive order issued yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch.
The order follows a two-year study of the issue by a special mayoral task force.


Reviews/Film; 'Times to Come,' Argentine Political Tale
LEAD: ''Times to Come'' is an example of that risky hybrid the avant-garde political thriller.
The first feature by an Argentine director, Gustavo Mosquera, it delivers far more atmosphere and promise than accomplishment.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Bucks 132, Magic 113: Milwaukee tied a National Basketball Association record last night with 50 points in one quarter and, led by Ricky Pierce's 28 points, routed Orlando in Milwaukee.
The 50 points came in the first quarter.
Milwaukee made 21 of its 24 field-goal attempts, including 3 for 3 from 3-point range.


Hotels Seized in Savings Case
LEAD: More than 60 Federal agents and Phoenix police officers seized control of two luxury hotels that had been crown jewels in the empire of Charles H. Keating Jr., the deposed head of Lincoln Savings and Loan.
Page B5.


Play Based on the Life Of a Literary Agent
LEAD: A reading of a two-character play based on the autobiography of Audrey Wood, the literary agent, will be presented at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, at 8 P.M.
Nov. 27.
The work, arranged by Max Wilk and performed by Tandy Cronyn and Jeffrey De Munn, is called ''Mr.
Williams and Miss Wood'' and deals with the 30-year relationship between the playwright Tennessee Williams and his agent.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary by The Associated Press on Nov. 7 about Vivian Mercier, an Irish literary critic and teacher, misidentified an American institution where he taught.
It was the City University of New York, not New York University.


Prague Denies Being Warned By Moscow to Speed Change
LEAD: Communist Czechoslovakia disputed a report today that Moscow had formally warned the Prague leadership to speed up change.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shuffle at Foote, Cone
LEAD: Foote, Cone &amp; Belding Communications shuffled the executive lineup in its international division yesterday.
Craig R. Wiggins, vice chairman of Publicis-FCB Communications, Foote, Cone's joint venture with the French agency Publicis, was named chairman of FCB International.
Antonio S. Beja, chairman of FCB Latin America-Pacific, will become president of the international division and vice chairman of Publicis-FCB.

LEAD: Allegheny International Inc., which had indicated it would not seriously consider a $683.8 million takeover offer from Japonica Partners L.P., has decided to let the New York investment group review its records. ''We're pleased that the board is now apparently cooperating, and we are looking forward to completing a transaction that is in the best interests of creditors and shareholders,'' said Fredric Spar, a Japonica spokesman.

Tarpley Is Suspended
LEAD: Roy Tarpley, the Dallas Mavericks forward with two strikes against him in the eyes of the National Basketball Association for alcohol and drug problems, was suspended from the league indefinitely yesterday by counselors in his after-care program.
The ban came one day after he was arrested in Dallas on charges of driving while intoxicated and resisting arrest.

LEAD: A California State Assemblywoman has been barred from receiving communion in the Roman Catholic Church because of her support for abortion rights in her campaign for the State Senate.

Bridge

Luxury Hotels Seized in Predawn Raid in Arizona
LEAD: In the early-morning hours today, more than 60 Federal agents and plainclothes Phoenix police officers descended on two luxury hotels that had been crown jewels in the financial empire of Charles H. Keating Jr.
They seized control of the hotels, sealed off Mr.
Keating's office and announced that he was being discharged as president of the hotel company.

LEAD: The police said today that they were banning local distribution of The Asian Wall Street Journal because of an article that they said had insulted the leader of Thailand's predominant Buddhist faith.


J. Emerson Thors, 87, an Investment Banker
LEAD: J. Emerson Thors, a retired investment banker, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Water Mill, L.I.
He was 87 years old.

LEAD: One of three inmates who escaped from the Nassau County jail Tuesday morning was recaptured last night in North Bellmore, L.I., the police said.

LEAD: Three men with ties to the Genovese crime family were sentenced to 20-year prison terms yesterday on Federal racketeering convictions that included the 1986 murder of a police detective in Queens.


Annual Christmas Fair At St. Luke's School
LEAD: A Christmas fair - complete with a festive dinner - is to be offered today at St.
Luke's School, 487 Hudson Street.
The fair, which continues through tomorrow, features a variety of crafts, workshops, entertainment and foods.
Hours for the fair alone are 5 to 10 P.M. today, and noon to 5 P.M. tomorrow.

LEAD: The CBS/Fox Company has sued the MGM/UA Communications Company for $50 million in damages, charging that MGM/UA reneged on an agreement that gives CBS/Fox rights to distribute MGM/UA movies on videotape.


Kohl Says Bonn Will Not Press East Germany on Reunification
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl presented today what has evolved into a broad West German consensus on how to approach the new developments in East Germany, declaring that Bonn would not try to influence the East Germans on reunification and would respect whatever path they chose.


Vermont Journal; The Fire For Wood As Fuel Is Cooling
LEAD: There is a closet in John Illick's house where a wood stove used to be.
For seven years, he and his wife, Beth, burned wood for primary heat in the long winters here, for economic and esthetic reasons.
But the appeal began to wear thin. ''Wood is dirty and it's a lot of work,'' said Mr.
Illick, who is a vice president at the Bread Loaf Construction Company.

LEAD: Although it will have no representative at a meeting of the Western European allies this weekend, the Bush Administration plans to follow the talks through diplomatic channels and direct contacts with European leaders, American officials said today.


New-Music Festival; Farafina in the Sounds and Rhythms of African Tradition
LEAD: Bare-bones melodies, layered repetition and propulsive cross-rhythm -the stuff of Minimalist music - have a long history in African tradition.
So it was perfectly appropriate for the New Music America festival, founded 10 years ago by Minimalist and other composers, to book Farafina.
The eight-man group from Burkina Faso would humble any Minimalist ensemble in a battle of the bands, even without its flamboyant dancing.

Review/Art; Old Masters on a Visit From Fort Worth
LEAD: When Kay Kimbell died 25 years ago, he left his family's collection of European and American paintings, jades and ivories to the city of Fort Worth, where he had settled in 1924 and presided over some 70 corporations.
Like the archetypal self-made Texas millionaire, Kimbell only thought big.
He said his desire was to create a museum ''of the first class,'' filled with great works of art and housed in a great building.

LEAD: Playing down its traditional role as a military alliance, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has begun arguing that it is the instrument through which the United States and Western Europe can best manage the political transition of Eastern Europe.

Review/Art; At Whitney, a Look Back At Thomas Hart Benton
LEAD: Thomas Hart Benton (1889-1975) is one of the more formidable personalities in American art.
He was born in Neosho, Mo., near the Oklahoma and Arkansas borders, and named after his great-uncle, the first Senator from Missouri.
His father, Maecenas Eason Benton, originally from Tennessee, was a highly successful lawyer and a populist politician who served four terms in Congress and, according to his son, had ''something like a puritan aversion to images.

Counting on Vulnerability in 'High Stakes'
Amos Kollek's ''High Stakes'' is a romantic comedy about Bambi (Sally Kirkland), whose real name is Melanie Rose, a stripper and whore, and John (Robert LuPone), an Upper East Side-type who makes his fortunes as a Wall Street speculator.
They meet cute.
Bambi, half-dressed, has just been tossed out of a car by a client, who says she's too old.
On the steps outside her bohemian walk-up apartment on West 42d Street, she meets John.
He has just been mugged.
Bambi takes John up to her apartment for a glass of water and they fall in love.
She is vulnerable.
He is vulnerable.
The apartment door is vulnerable.
Her pimp bursts in.
One thing leads to another.
Bambi and John bop the pimp over the head, then take his gun and roll of cash.

New Ford Plants
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would spend $300 million to build three large electronics plants to keep pace with worldwide demand for its advanced automotive components.
The company said sales of its electronics division had doubled since 1985 and were expected to do so again by 1997. the first new plant, in Worcester Township, Pa., will be started early next year.


Reserves Up At AmSouth
LEAD: The AmSouth Bancorporation, the largest banking company in Alabama, announced yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would be sharply reduced by a special $21 million increase in its reserves to cover possible loan losses on Florida real estate loans.


Dresser in Merger
LEAD: Dresser Industries said its board had approved a merger agreement with Smith International Inc. of Houston.
The company said that Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., which owns about a third of Smith's stock, had also approved the offer.
The acquisition, which must be approved by the Justice Department, would give Dresser more than 30 percent of the American drilling tool and service market.

Dukakis, 52 years old, was hospitalized last week after drinking rubbing alcohol.

U.N. Backs Measure on Cambodia That Allows Khmer Rouge a Role
LEAD: The United Nations General Assembly overwhelmingly approved a resolution today calling for a comprehensive political settlement in Cambodia.

Black Driver Aiming for Indy 500
LEAD: The Raynor racing team, which competes on the Championship Auto Racing Teams Indy-car circuit, announced in Manhattan yesterday that it had hired Willy T. Ribbs as its driver in a three-year deal that includes Bill Cosby as a backer.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 252 to 174 by which the House of Representatives today approved a bill to increase by more than 35 percent the pay of its members and other top Government officials, while also revising ethics rules.
A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill.
Voting yes were 168 Democrats and 84 Republicans.

At Budget Hotels, Growing Pains
LEAD: Judging by the jammed parking lot at the Fairfield Inn here, one might think that the budget hotel business is flourishing.

Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 478 money market mutual funds decreased by $200.80 million, to $363.61 billion, for the week ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 146 institutional funds increased by $166.60 million, to $87.43 billion.
The assets of the 235 general-purpose funds were down by $354.30 million, to $118.79 billion.

Paddling The Lords Of Baseball

Review/Film; Of Good Dogs, Heaven And, Naturally, Death
LEAD: One reason all dogs go to heaven, a character in the film by that name says, is that ''unlike people, dogs are naturally good and loyal and kind.'' That's nice.
Another reason, as children watching Don Bluth's new full-length animated feature are sure to surmise, is that all dogs die.
Anyone not wishing to discuss this idea and its greater implications on the way home from the theater would be well advised to think twice before taking a small child.


Restaurants
LEAD: Just when everyone thought the Cajun craze had been interred in that gastronomic Woodlawn where all such fads return to dust, here comes Paul Prudhomme, bounding out of the bayou with his magic spices and magnetic personality.
Suddenly, New Yorkers by the score were lined up outside his Broadway restaurant in punishing midsummer heat waiting to be made even hotter by gumbo and jambalaya.

LEAD: Lower refining and marketing profits for the fourth quarter will cut the Sun Company's earnings for the period to below the 72 cents a share reported for the comparable period in 1988. Review/Theater; 'A Whistle in the Dark'
LEAD: The furies are unleashed in ''A Whistle in the Dark.'' Tom Murphy's drama, which is being revived at the South Street Theater, centers on the Carneys of County Mayo, a brawling, brutish pack of street fighters who have been brought up to respect their father and their family honor.
The fact that both father and family honor are severely tarnished does not lessen the conviction or the ferocity of the characters.


Glaxo in Singapore
LEAD: Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. said it would invest up to $250 million (Singapore) to build a pharmaceutical plant in the country.
The plant, to be completed by the end of 1991, is expected to begin producing three new drugs in 1992, said Sir Paul Girolami, Glaxo's chairman.
Those drugs are sumatriptan, for treating migraine headaches; salmeterol, an asthma drug, and ondansetron, for reducing nausea during cancer treatments.

Outdoors; Federal Support Awaited for Bluefish Limit Plan
LEAD: If it is approved by the United States Department of Commerce, the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council's bluefish plan will go into effect next year.
The plan, already adopted by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, which embraces the coastal states from Maine through Florida, establishes a 10-fish possession limit for recreational anglers.


Race for 2d Narrows in Brazil
LEAD: Brazilians waited anxiously today as the margin between two leftist presidential candidates narrowed to 1 percent of the votes cast.
With 53 percent of the votes officially counted, Luis Inacio da Silva led his rival, Leonel Brizola, by 760,000 votes.
Authorities said the winner would not be known until Sunday.

Ferranti Charges Fraud in U.S. Deal
LEAD: Ferranti International Signal P.L.C., the British military contractor, said it lost more than $157 million in cash because of fraud in its acquisition of the United States company International Signal and Control.
In total, Ferranti said its loss was the equivalent of $338 million as a result of what it called ''a serious fraud'' involving bogus contracts that it unwittingly inherited when it bought the American company in November 1987.


Frunze Journal; Off the List, Into a Lean-To: A Hammer Beckons
LEAD: Amid the deepening gloom about national resurgence, thousands of ordinary Soviet citizens desperate for state housing have begun taking the solution into their own hands.
They are seizing Government land and creating vast new urban squatter settlements, building everything from clay hovels to brick houses for their young families.

The Suspects in El Salvador
LEAD: Once again the abominable occurs in El Salvador, this time the execution-style murder of six Jesuit priests, their cook and her daughter.
Once again a Salvadoran President denounces the crime and promises an investigation.
And once again, the barbarous killers are likely to escape.
What's different this time is America's horrified impatience.


A Cloud Seven Senators Wide
LEAD: The Senate Ethics Committee has finally hired an outside lawyer to look into the suspicious behavior of six more Senators, in addition to one whose case is already in the works.
The fact that seven Senators are challenged at once challenges the credibility of the institution itself.
That puts a heavy burden on the committee and its counsel to be thorough, honest and open.


Martin Marietta
LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation has been awarded a $156.6 million contract by NASA to launch the first United States spacecraft to Mars since 1976.
The contract, awarded Thursday to the company's Denver Astronautics Group, is seen as an important victory in the competitive commercial space market.

LEAD: Dunkin' Donuts Inc., which fought off a hostile takeover attempt earlier this year, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the British food and beverage group Allied-Lyons P.L.C. for $325 million in cash.


Clamor in the East; Miners Trapped in Yugoslavia
LEAD: A gas explosion and fire in a coal mine today trapped workers nearly a half-mile underground and about 90 miners were feared dead, the official press agency reported.
It reported 73 miners had escaped unharmed.
The methane gas explosion and fire started at noon at the Aleksinacki Rudnici mine, 120 miles south of Belgrade, the mine director, Branislav Mandusic, said.


This Year, Service Plus Bargains
LEAD: When the holiday shopping season begins at Thanksgiving, people can expect to see still more of the heavy markdowns they have seen the last few holiday seasons.


Offer for New Hampshire Utility Increased
LEAD: Northeast Utilities sweetened its bid for the assets of the bankrupt Public Service Company of New Hampshire yesterday and said that it had won the endorsement of some secured creditors.


Fight by Nekoosa, Georgia-Pacific
LEAD: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation said it had filed a motion with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to require the Georgia-Pacific Corporation to obtain the commission's approval for the transfer of Nekoosa's hydroelectric projects and licenses in Maine and Wisconsin.
In a related action, Nekoosa said it had filed a motion and complaint with the commission to intervene in Georgia-Pacific''s pending hydroelectric license proceedings for its Gilman, Vt., mill.

LEAD: Charles Lane, writer, producer, director, actor and fan of early Chaplin movies, sums up his approach to film-making with a maxim of the boxing ring: ''Stick and move.'' LEAD: The National Basketball Association has begun its attack on a move to add pro basketball to a state betting game in Oregon, and there were indications yesterday that the vehement, high-profile objections were being heard.

SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING
LEAD: Alex Stewart, a heavyweight, underwent surgery Thursday to repair the tendons in his left hand that he injured in his eight-round loss to Evander Holyfield on Nov. 4 at Atlantic City.
Stewart, who lost for the first time in 25 fights, tore tendons over the knuckles of the middle and little fingers of his hand.


Lithuanians Resist Pressure From Moscow on New Party
LEAD: Lithuanian Communist officials summoned to the Kremlin for an unusual 10-hour meeting with the Soviet Politburo indicated today they would not alter their plan to form a new Lithuanian party more independent of the leadership in Moscow.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Falling Mortgage Rates
LEAD:  The slowing economy has created opportunities in real estate, as a generally depressed housing market has reduced the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage by more than 1.25 percentage points since March.
It is now 9.66 percent, a five-year low.
Continued soft spots in the economy, including housing, could push that rate down another half-point by spring, many analysts say.

LEAD: If Steffi Graf ever tired of being the finest female tennis player in the world and chose instead to become a dancer, the hustle would surely be her forte.

Nightmares and Counselors Descend on Stunned Town
LEAD: Nightmares haunted little Robert Hayes all Thursday night.
He dreamed mostly of a friend, C.J.
Scotto, one of the seven children who were killed Thursday when a tornado swirled into the cafeteria at East Coldenham Elementary School during lunchtime.


Transit Leader Asks $1.25 Fare With a Discount
LEAD: The president of the New York City Transit Authority proposed yesterday that subway and bus fares rise to $1.25 in January and that the increase include a discount offer of 18 tokens for $20, reducing the cost of a ride to $1.11.
The fare has been $1 since 1986.
The president, David L. Gunn, said the 18-pack discount could ''avoid some pretty controversial stuff'' at the turnstiles, such as more people hopping over them to avoid paying.

Starts in Housing Show 12% Rebound for October WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -Housing starts bounced back by 12 percent in October from September's seven-year low, the Commerce Department reported today.   Analysts said they expected the construction rate to remain stable through the first quarter of 1990.   ''The housing market seems to have bottomed out,'' said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. But he and other analysts said they did not expect any surge in building.   The Commerce Department reported that new homes and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.42 million units last month.  Drops in Previous Two Months     The 12 percent rebound from September was the sharpest gain since a 13 percent advance in December 1986. Starts had fallen 4.6 percent in September and 6.4 percent in August.   Although September's pace was revised upward from the 1.26 million reported earlier, it was still the most sluggish since new homes and apartments were built at an annual rate of 1.17 million units in October 1982 during the depths of a recession.   Many analysts attributed the September construction drop to a rise in mortgage rates and said the October gain followed a subsequent decline.   The housing industry has been among the hardest hit as the Federal Reserve drove up interest rates to slow economic growth and lower inflation. But the Fed has slowly eased rates over the summer and, except for the blip in September, rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages have fallen from March's 11.22 percent peak to 9.82 percent by the end of October, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.  Decline in Inventories     The higher rates stifled sales and bolstered inventories of single-family homes to an 8.1-month supply by last March, said Richard Peach, an economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association. As rates have fallen, he added, inventories have dropped to a six-month supply, which, he said, ''by historical standards'' puts the industry ''in good shape.''   But even though many analysts expect mortgage rates to drop another half of a percentage point in coming months, Mr. Peach said he did not expect a sharp rise in building.   Construction of single-family homes in October rose 6.9 percent, to an annual rate of 1.03 million units. Single-family starts had fallen 3 percent in September and 3.5 percent in August.   Apartment construction rose 28 percent in October, to an annual rate of 393,000 units. It had fallen 9.4 percent in September after dropping 14 percent in August.   Total housing starts during the first 10 months of the year were down 6 percent from the corresponding period of 1988.   The South, which posted a 14.7 drop for the steepest regional decline in September, turned in the sharpest increase in October, up by 17.1 percent, to 562,000 units. It was followed by the Midwest with a 16.5 percent gain, to 289,000 units.   Construction rose 6 percent in the Northeast, to 176,000 units, and 5.1 percent in the West, to 393,000 units.


New York State to Challenge Disposal Law
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo said today that New York State will challenge the Federal law that requires the state to dispose of its own low-level radioactive waste.

LEAD: Carbon monoxide sickened 68 workers yesterday at an office in the Bronx, the authorities said.
An obstructed flue from a natural gas heater sent the fumes into the building at Zerega and Newbold Avenues in the Unionport area, a Fire Department spokesman, John Mulligan, said.

Your Money
LEAD: Full of the holiday spirit, millions of Americans will start gift shopping next weekend, but for many the bills run up between Thanksgiving and Christmas will be a year-round burden, particularly to those who make only the minimum monthly payments on their credit-card bills.

Review/Jazz; Strings Make the Most of It
LEAD: A crucial problem for a jazz group made up predominantly of strings is its ability to engender a swinging attack.
Any group led by Ron Carter, one of the major jazz bassists for the past 30 years, has the basis for just such an attack.
So it is not surprising that his string-laden Nonet, which will be at Fat Tuesday's through Sunday, plays with a robust, surging rhythm.


Review/Philharmonic; A Cellis Carrying On The Work Of a Master
LEAD: Thanks to notation and, to some extent, recordings, music does not depend entirely on uninterrupted tradition, as folk song and poetry did in primitive times when a pupil's ear was art's only conservator.
Still, the value of one-on-one transmission from teacher to student - from one Bach to the next, from Haydn to Beethoven, from Liszt to his phalanx of epigones - can hardly be overestimated.

How to Do Justice to the Native Cranberry
LEAD: FOR many Americans, cranberries are thought of only once a year, as a sauce or condiment to serve alongside turkey.
If turkey happens to make it to the dinner table more than once a year, then the cranberries will accompany it on those occasions as well.
That does not do justice to the native cranberry.

Reviews/Music; Speculum Musicae in Takemitsu Finale
LEAD: There are three explanations for Toru Takemitsu's unquestioned status as Japan's best-known composer.
First, his music is pretty good, the sonic tip of a deep-probing esthetic and philosophical exploration of the intersections between East and West.
Second, he is adept at international composer careerism, which is not so much a cynical dismissal as a dispassionate observation.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. The cold-water faucet in my bathroom sink gives off a loud whistling or humming noise whenever it is turned on.
The noise stops when the faucet is turned on all the way.
I tried tightening the screw on top of the faucet handle, but this did not help.
Can you tell me how to eliminate this noise?

On this vote, a yes vote was a vote to approve the pay package.

Woman Dies in Bus Accident
LEAD: A tourist bus on a foggy Golan Heights highway swerved, apparently to avoid a car, and overturned into a ravine today, killing a West German woman and injuring the bus driver, a guide and 48 West German passengers, the police said.
Druse villagers, Jewish settlers, military doctors and emergency medical service workers from the nearby town of Qiryat Shemona helped in the rescue operations.

LEAD: HARRY Streep has been teaching contemporary dance classes for nearly 10 years.
He has taught the young, the old, the fit and the unfit, and until the New Rochelle High School hockey team entered his class a couple of months ago he thought he had seen it all.


Style Makers; Teddy and Arthur Edelman, Leather Designers
LEAD: Ten years ago, Arthur and Teddy Edelman sold their fashion leather business in Manhattan to Mitsubishi, the Japanese company, and focused exclusively on home furnishings, providing interior designers and architects with high-quality and unusually textured leathers. ''We liked fashion,'' said Teddy Edelman, who is 61 years old.


New-Music Festival; Brooklyn Ensemble And Moondog's Return
LEAD: From either inclination or a lack of opportunity, composers who frequent New Music America festivals do not normally write for symphonic forces.
Not all the festivals have even offered such extravaganzas.
But this year's 10th-anniversary festival gathered itself together Thursday night for a Brooklyn Philharmonic program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Majestic Theater - which has already proven itself a fine acoustical venue for such events.

Singles' Plight
LEAD: To the Editor: I recall a letter by a single traveler who complained about exorbitant rates.
I concur and think it is high time the travel industry recognized that there are many singles out there, and by charging this ridiculous single supplement they discourage us from traveling.
For example, I would like to go to Cancun - the double rate is $475, the single rate $865.

Making Industrial Policy at the Pentagon
LEAD: IN the 1960's and 1970's, a small Pentagon office called the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency helped create an explosion of innovation in computer research that has had an immense impact on the American economy.
Acting independently and without the bureaucratic strings that often shackle Government organizations, the agency served as a de facto venture capitalist for the American computer industry.

Recently, though, the guest shows signs of moving in for good.
Today's concertgoers pick up programs to find Ellington and Monk in spots previously reserved for Mozart and Brahms.

He writes that ''to Americans she may always be a chambermaid.'' Why would anyone, besides the stepchildren and their lawyers, consider such a highly educated woman always to be a chambermaid, merely because that was the first job she held in the United States?

There are about 4,000 students at the university.

She is coming.

Garden Party Whatsit
LEAD: ONE OF THE GREAT word-pictures in the American language is &gt;the skunk at the garden party.
Think about it: There is the garden party, an elegant institution peopled with perfumed ladies in large hats and gentlemen in blazers and green pants who are holding gin fizzes.
An expensive tent called a ''marquee'' is in place in case of showers; a few of the fellows slip off for a slow game of croquet, and into this strawberry-and-cream world meanders a small black animal with a white streak down its back and a bushy tail, with the potential, if it is frightened, of causing such a stink as to rende

FICTION
LEAD:  ULTIMATE PRIZES.
By Susan Howatch. (Knopf, $18.95.) This third novel in Susan Howatch's ecclesiastical series (the first two were ''Glittering Images'' and ''Glamorous Powers'') demands so insistently to be taken seriously that - though it flies in the face of good sense - one is left with no choice but to do so.


Hey, Dude, Like NEH-oh Way!
LEAD: I HAVE NEVER MUCH LIKED THE WAY I TALK.
IN UPSTATE New York, where I was raised, people said things like ''Lemme have a HEE-am SEEN-wich'' and ''You scared the BEE-JEES-us outa me.'' It had no grace.
Nowhere in our local speech was there the hint of a drawl, or any majestic New England tones, or even a trace of downstate Brooklynese - which can sound almost poetic if you are in the right mood.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Off the Record
LEAD: In his post-Beatles career, Ringo Starr has blazed no trails of musical glory, but he maintains that things would look even more bleak if an album he recorded in 1987 ever reached the listening public.
Testifying in an Atlanta courtroom last week, Mr.
Starr said he and other musicians were under the influence of drink and drugs when they recorded the album, and contended that his musical reputation would be injured if the album's producer, Chips Moman, were allowed to release it.

New-Music Festival; Negativland's Message
LEAD: ''Media about media about media,'' said a voice on tape, summing up the tactics of Negativland, a California group that performed Thursday night at the Knitting Factory as part of New Music America.
Negativland dips into the torrent of broadcast words from the likes of preachers, bureaucrats and advertisers, then turns the found messages into collages with noises and occasional songs.

The season will not really fill up again until the end of the month.

High School, near Lincoln Center in Manhattan, is so designed.

Plant Conversion: Technical Pitfalls
LEAD: ENGINEERS are forever telling visitors to places like Shoreham that nuclear plants make electricity the same way that oil- or gas-fired plants do: by making steam, which is converted into mechanical energy in a turbine, which then turns a generator.
Much of this is true.
But even the non-nuclear side of a plant like Shoreham has substantial differences from a conventional plant, and those differences may become extremely clear in the next two months or so.


FOOTBALL
LEAD:  LOOKING DEEP.
By Terry Bradshaw with Buddy Martin. (Contemporary, $17.95.) As Susan Sontag once remarked, writing well is the best revenge.
Revenge is probably not what Terry Bradshaw had in mind when he wrote ''Looking Deep'' with the Denver Post sports columnist Buddy Martin, but that is what he has got: revenge over the scores of sportswriters who called him dumb during his career as a quarterback with the Pittsburg Steelers and who will never write a book about football as good as this one.

LEAD: Q. The cold-water faucet in my bathroom sink gives off a loud whistling or humming noise whenever it is turned on.
The noise stops when the faucet is turned on all the way.
I tried tightening the screw on top of the faucet handle, but this did not help.
Can you tell me how to eliminate this noise?

Son Killed in Father's Home
LEAD: A 36-year-old man was fatally shot Friday night by his father's roommate five weeks after the son moved to the city to be reunited with his father, the police said.
The father had not seen the son since shortly after he was born.
The son, Alonzo Colbert Jr., had been arguing with his father when the roommate, Lawyer Meadows, 55, became alarmed and shot him in the chest, the police said.

Reviews/Dance; Disparate Motions By Fagan
LEAD: Garth Fagan, the founder and director of the Bucket Dance company, has long been praised as a choreographer of great originality.
Mr.
Fagan has also been seen as a visionary dance director who molded a group of untrained young dancers into a sleek and eloquent company over the last 20 years.
But one of the great pleasures in his work, less frequently celebrated, is its bracing and expressive physicality.

How to Do Justice to the Native Cranberry
LEAD: FOR many Americans, cranberries are thought of only once a year, as a sauce or condiment to serve alongside turkey.
If turkey happens to make it to the dinner table more than once a year, then the cranberries will accompany it on those occasions as well.
That does not do justice to the native cranberry.

8 Youths Charged With Rape
LEAD: Seven high school students have been arrested and an eighth is being sought in the gang rape of a 19-year-old woman here.

LEAD: Government troops said today that they had defeated a new Tamil militia accused of killing 38 Muslim police officers in the eastern Ampara district.


London Embraces the Thames Again
LEAD: LONDON has at last decided to face the River Thames, after centuries of turning its back on it.
The Docklands, an area of eight-and-a-half square miles covering both sides of the river and once a wasteland of industrial dereliction, is being transformed into a city within a city.
All along the Thames, old buildings are being gutted and restored, with Georgian warehouses becoming sumptuous apartments, smart offices and shopping malls.

The Floating Dollar Needs an Anchor
LEAD: The United States has paid a high price for the instability of the dollar.
A dollar that floats in value against other world currencies confuses markets, distorts supply and demand, and makes it harder for the economy to operate.
Long-range investment decisions are clouded by unnecessary short-range uncertainties.

LEAD: The Franklin D. Roosevelt Library here, the nation's first official Presidential library, will celebrate its 50th anniversary on Sunday with special exhibits, a birthday cake and showings of newsreels of the Roosevelt era.

'Stand-Up Tragedy'At Hartford Stage LBy ALVIN KLEIN
LEAD: IN its pursuit of eclecticism, Hartford Stage has been a study in extremes of late.
Having opened the season with ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' Oscar Wilde's perfectly escapist Victorian comedy of gentility and absurdity, the theater is now shaking up its subscribers with ''Stand-Up Tragedy,'' a tough and loud dose of contemporary urban reality, replete with street talk, rap music and break dancing.


Getting Even
LEAD: Leonard Bernstein apparently felt that if the people in Washington were going to rescind a $10,000 grant to an art show on AIDS, they could keep their National Medal of Arts too.
Mr.
Bernstein at first refused to comment on why he turned down the chance to be one of 12 recipients of the arts medal this year, but it was generally accepted that he did so in protest of a decision by the National Endowment for the Arts to withdraw support for the AIDS exhibition at the Artists Space gallery in Manhattan.

LEAD: LITCHFIELD COUNTY is one of Connecticut's choicest environs, and it has also been a magnet for New Yorkers looking for weekend houses to which to escape their city pressures.

When Motion Pictures Found Their Tongue
LEAD: A current series of film presentations at the Museum of Modern Art, titled ''The Dawn of Sound'' and running through Dec. 4, focuses on what was probably the most decisive period in the development of the movies.
During the late l920's, the addition of sound transformed film from a mute mime show into a form of theater with an unequaled range of expressive options.

'Behold Ye Living Passing By': The Ultimate in Booking Ahead
LEAD: OAKLAND CEMETERY in Sag Harbor is in a felicitous location, 27 acres of rolling high ground in what was once a forest lush with whispering oaks older than any inhabitants in the place.
The rhododendrons and azaleas run riot in the spring, cedars and pines stand straight as sentries.
George Balanchine, master of the ballet, although not a resident of Sag Harbor, picked Oakland Cemetery because he ''liked the look of it.


A Melee at Washington
LEAD: While trying to tear down a goal post and throw it in Lake Washington, celebrating students battled Mace-spraying police today after Washington's 20-9 victory over Washington State.
The melee lasted more than 30 minutes after the end of the game at Husky Stadium.
Police also were seen hitting students with nightsticks.

POSTINGS: Shops, Apartments, Offices; At a Project's Core, an 1840 House and a Barn
LEAD: Five buildings including an 1840 Greek Revival house and its barn are being developed into shops, apartments and offices in the Kings Highway Historic District in Westport, Conn.

Corrections
LEAD: A pie chart last Sunday about foreign ownership of commercial property in New York City was labeled incorrectly.
The numbers represented square feet, not percentages.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  EDUCATION OF A WANDERING MAN.
By Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $16.95.) A few days before his class in Jamestown, N.D., graduated from high school, Louis L'Amour (then Louis LaMoore) sat in a Singapore bar with his shipmates.
He had decided that ''school was interfering with my education.'' This intellectual autobiography details the path that L'Amour traveled to become admirably, refreshingly self-educated.

HOW FAR WILL DE KLERK GO?
LEAD: EVEN BEFORE FREDERIK WILLEM DE KLERK BECAME leader of his party and his country, he laid out four options for South Africa's whites: they could surrender to the black majority, which de Klerk contended the liberals were advocating; they could retain minority control at all costs, which the conservatives wanted; they could find a more acceptable way to hold onto power; or, as he proposed, they could make up their minds to share power with the blacks.

Jenkins said was modeled after Alex Hawkins of the Baltimore Colts.

Correction
LEAD: A photograph on Oct. 22 of a sculpture, ''Grenada,'' by Melvin Edwards was positioned incorrectly.
What appeared to be the floor, on which the work rested, was actually a wall at the right, to which it was affixed.

Most American wine buffs are no different: they may think of red Bordeaux as the king of wines but of white Bordeaux they rarely think at all.

General Electric's Hungarian Deal
LEAD: G.E. is moving into Hungary, taking advantage of liberalization in Eastern Europe.
General Electric will pay $150 million for control of the Tungsram Company, a light-bulb maker.
The deal is the largest American investment in Hungary since World War II.
John F. Welch, G.E.'s chairman, said the purchase would help bolster G.E.

LEAD: JULIE D. BELAGA of Westport, a Republican who lost her bid for governor in 1986, has been appointed Region 1 administrator for the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the Government's top environmental post in New England with a staff of 575 people and offices in Boston.


Colorado Romps to Finish 11-0
LEAD: Colorado completed its first unbeaten regular season since 1937 and won its first Big Eight Conference championship in 28 years, routing Kansas State, 59-11, today as Darian Hagan became the fifth player ever to run and pass for more than 1,000 yards in a season.


Yale Deprived Of Outright Title
LEAD: A Harvard team that could do no wrong upset a Yale team doing little that was right today before a crowd of 59,263 in the Yale Bowl.
The loss, by a 37-20 score in the 106th contest of the 109-year-old rivalry, deprived the Bulldogs of the outright Ivy League championship.
They had to share the title with Princeton, both finishing with 6-1 records in the league.

On the Lam in Chicago
LEAD: NO historical marker, no plaque, tells what once happened at the corner of Western and 63d Streets, on Chicago's South Side.
But there are the bullet holes, small craters in the brick and chips in the terra cotta, that mark the spot where a hood named Frank McErlane opened fire one sunny September morning in 1925 with a submachine gun.

Vicenza
LEAD: To the Editor: A ''Palladian Journey in Vicenza'' (Travel, Aug. 13) would be incomplete without a tour of the city's Olympic Theater.
Palladio's evocation of classical Greco-Roman design was commissioned by fellow members of the Olympic Academy, a civic organization founded in 1556 to promote humanistic thought and cultural activities in Renaissance Vicenza.

Horses and Over-Riders
LEAD: Last month, Ed Koch lost his chance to go down in history as the Mayor who rescued New York's carriage horses from heat exhaustion, chill, long hours and terrifying traffic.
He vetoed a bill that would protect them from having to work when it is very hot, very cold, very humid or for more than eight hours at a stretch.

MAKING LIKE A RAJAH
LEAD: IN THE GOOD OLD DAYS, IT WAS THE MEN WHO GOT to wear the gorgeous stuff.
During the heyday of the Mogul era in India, it was the maharajahs who were laden with ropes of pearls and strands of diamonds.
Their rings, brooches, belts and sabers dazzled with emeralds and other gems, while thick tassels of pearls and rubies swung against their brocaded robes.

LEAD:  NORTH DALLAS AFTER FORTY.
By Peter Gent. (Villard, $19.95.) Talk to a football fan about ''North Dallas Forty'' and the fan smiles.
It was a novel about the ribald life of a legendary (and fictitious) Dallas football team.
Now the football team has grown up.
It is 20 years later and Peter Gent, himself a former Dallas Cowboys flanker and tight end, has given us a sequel, this time concerning the team's reunion.

LEAD: Most homeless families who seek emergency shelter in New York City have either never had their own apartments or have lost their housing through eviction, and almost all are on public assistance, according to a study released by the city's Human Resources Administration.

New Ppularity as Markets Become More Global
LEAD: As an organized industry, the language translation business is an infant on the verge of growing up.

The Age of Now Hear This!
LEAD: What will they say about 20th-century music when it's dead and gone?
By ''they,'' I mean the historians whose duty it will be to shuffle the evidence, weigh tendencies, compute the pluses and minuses and play categories.
What plausible description could be applied to a period inhabited by such stylistically variegated composers as Elgar and Webern, Stockhausen and Iggy Pop?

How to Do Justice to the Native Cranberry
LEAD: FOR many Americans, cranberries are thought of only once a year, as a sauce or condiment to serve alongside turkey.

That does not do justice to the native cranberry.

India's Monumental Reliquary
LEAD: INDIA, in the majestic sweep of its long history, has known glory and famine, empire and invasion.

Road Trips Making Teams Homesick
LEAD: A week ago the Indiana Pacers, winners of their first four games, were the only undefeated team in the National Basketball Association.
Now they are 4-3.
Why?
A West Coast road trip.
With the exception of the Los Angeles Lakers and the Utah Jazz, who have played mostly at home, each of the other 25 teams have at least three losses.

LEAD: The Foreign Ministry summoned the American Ambassador today to protest as ''brazen and unwarranted'' a resolution passed last week by a Senate panel that focuses on Armenian-Azerbaijani tensions in the Soviet Union.
The Soviet officials, who are upset that the resolution criticizes the Kremlin's handling of the ethnic clashes, called the panel's move a ''relapse into the cold war'' and chided the panel for ''interfering'' in a delicate ethnic problem.

Hot Hands
LEAD: Kombi Ltd., a company based in Naugatuck, Conn., uses heating circuitry in its 1990 line of heated gloves and footwear.
The system includes a rechargeable battery, measuring three inches by two inches, to produce heat.
The warmth passes into the glove through hairlike conductors that are much finer than wire.

Peshawar Journal; In Skulduggery's City, Afghan Feuds Find Home
LEAD: In the capital of the Northwest Frontier Province, winter is the season for polo.
On fields where officers of the British garrison once sharpened their skills, pilots of the Pakistan Air Force thunder back and forth, as skilled on horseback as they are practicing dogfights at the Khyber Pass in American-made F-16's.

Question Box
LEAD:  Rookie to Legend  Q. Among all the players voted rookie of the year in the major leagues, how many have gone on to be voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame?
A.
A total of 86 players have won rookie-of-the-year honors since the award was instituted in 1947, and so far only 7 have fulfilled their promise enough to be enshrined in Cooperstown.

Merc Expels Franc Trader
LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange today expelled a Swiss franc futures trader whose illegal trading was unmasked by an elaborate undercover operation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation earlier this year.


Tax Break for Fuel Additive
LEAD: To bolster the nation's corn farmers, the Treasury Department said today that it planned to give a tax break to a new ethanol-based fuel additive that President Bush brought to public attention last summer.


Bridge
LEAD: An exciting finish to the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship here Sunday night concluded the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.
A strong finish gave the title to a cosmopolitan group consisting of Zia Mahmood, Michael Rosenberg, both of Manhattan; Sam Lev of Israel; Mark Molson of Montreal, and Chris Compton of Houston.


Hunts Avoid a Liquidation By Settling With Creditors
LEAD: After two weeks of tense negotiations, attorneys handling the personal bankruptcy lawsuits of William Herbert Hunt and Nelson Bunker Hunt and their creditors today averted the scheduled liquidation of one of the former billionaire's estates and paved the way for both to be reorganized.


William Haines, 81, Author and Playwright
LEAD: William Wister Haines, a novelist, playwright and screenwriter whose best-known work was the play ''Command Decision,'' died on Saturday, three days after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage.
He was 81 years old and lived in Laguna Niguel, Calif.

Drugs Sought to Halt Damage to Brain Cells After Head Injuries
LEAD: IN experiments that could lead to a dramatic shift in treatment, researchers say they are developing drugs to stave off the irreversible brain damage that typically accompanies strokes and other head injuries.

Kohl Aide Meets East Berlin Leaders
LEAD: East Germany's new leaders held their first talks today with a senior aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl, while hundreds or thousands of East Germans took to the streets again in Leipzig and several other East German cities to maintain the pressure for change.

Plan to Buy New Buses Is Faulted
LEAD: State Senator Franz S. Leichter attacked the New York City Transit Authority yesterday for the proposed purchase of 400 buses, saying they are virtually identical to 1987 models that ''work worse than almost any other buses in the fleet.''


MOYNIHAN ASSAILS INDIA-C.I.A. CHARGE
LEAD: Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, Democrat of New York, today denounced charges printed in an Indian newspaper that the leader of the opposition to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi had accepted support from the Central Intelligence Agency and a private American foundation.

Msgr. John Heneghan, 80, Diocesan Aide
LEAD: Msgr.
John J. Heneghan, a former chancellor of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and pastor emeritus of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Astoria, Queens, died of cardiac arrest Friday at the home of a cousin.
He was 80 years old and lived in Queens.


Book Publishers Now Look to the Numbers
LEAD: Book publishing, faced with a combination of increasing competition, declining profits and slumping unit sales, is beginning to undergo changes that are likely to alter the shape of the industry in the 1990's, although it may not seem all that different to casual book buyers.

Robert Pace, 85, Dies; Ex-Chief of University
LEAD: Robert S. Pace, president of Pace University from 1942 to 1960, died of respiratory failure Sunday at King's Row Adult Residence in Middletown, N.J.
He was 85 years old and had lived in Monmouth County since 1968.


Corrections
LEAD: An article and a caption on Nov. 14 about the Pelham Bay landfill in the Bronx misidentified a woman who has campaigned for its cleanup.
She is Patricia Nonnon.

LEAD: The outlook for military contractors has grown steadily dimmer since the Reagan Administration's arms buildup peaked in 1985.

Tapes Show Jet Crew Made Proper Checks Before Crash
LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board today released cockpit recordings showing that the crew of USAir Flight 5050 properly performed all the usual preflight checks before the plane crashed into the East River in New York City after an aborted takeoff on Sept. 20.

Our Towns; Why One Man Delivers Pizzas For His Living
LEAD: Two years ago in October, Harold O'Garra Jr. of Huntington Station, then 29 years old, saw a newspaper advertisement seeking a real estate salesman, and since he had a real estate license and some experience, he decided to apply for the job.


Reynolds Joins In Soviet Venture
LEAD: The Reynolds Metals Company said it had entered a joint venture to build a $200 million plant in the Soviet Union to make aluminum foil.
It said the plant, in south-central Siberia, is expected to produce 47,000 tons of foil and converted products each year and employ 650 people beginning in 1992.


Action at Ford in Britain
LEAD: Union leaders at the Ford Motor Company in Britain today called for a strike vote for 32,000 workers after rejecting a 9.5 percent pay increase.
Union officials set no date for the vote.
British Ford has offered a 9.5 percent pay rise to workers at its 22 plants for next year, with a rise of 2.5 percent above inflation for the year after.


More Chrysler Cuts Seen by Iacocca
LEAD: The chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca, said sluggish car and truck sales might force the company to increase budget cuts beyond a planned $1 billion by the end of 1990.
Mr.
Iacocca also said additional closings of assembly plants were possible for the nation's third-largest auto maker.


China Limits Money Moves
LEAD: China has issued new regulations limiting the amount of Chinese money foreigners may change back into hard currency, officials said today.
For every $100 a foreigner changes into Chinese currency upon entering, he can leave China with no more than $50.


Ascent From the Heights
LEAD: They have met only seven times - once as collegians with a national championship at stake, the six other times as pros.
But theirs is still one of basketball's pre-eminent matchups: Patrick Ewing of the Knicks versus Akeem Olajuwon of the Houston Rockets, unquestionably the dominant big men in the game today.


U.S. Is Reportedly Speeding Talks For Accord on Global Warming
LEAD: The United States is prepared to quicken the tempo of negotiations for an international agreement on how to deal with global warming, the nation's chief environmental official said today.


Perils Seen In Warnings About Abuse
LEAD: A SHARP dispute is emerging over whether nationwide efforts to educate young children about the dangers of sexual abuse are instilling fears and confusion more often than they prevent such abuse.


Britain's Delay Called Costly
LEAD: Britain's European Competition Commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, told employers today that Britain's delay in becoming a full member of the European Monetary System is harming the nation's industry.


NOMINEE ASKS BUSH TO REMOVE NAME
LEAD: President Bush's nominee to the Agriculture Department's leading environmental post asked the White House today to withdraw his name from consideration after it became clear that he faced insurmountable opposition in the Senate.


South African Draft Resister Fights to Stay in U.S.
LEAD: Craig Demmer, 25 years old, a white South African, is about to spend his fourth winter in New York, far from friends, family and the warm, sparkling beaches of his native Durban.
What makes him bitter is not just homesickness but the possibility that he will be forced to return home.


Dispatches From the Bus Wars
LEAD: ONE of the major issues at the annual Comdex computer exposition here last week was the rival ''bus architectures,'' or internal data pathways, of personal computers.
Until recently the debate has been theoretical.


Notebook; Taunts From a Packer Put 49ers in 'Smoke'
LEAD: ''Hey Harris,'' yelled Eric Wright, a San Francisco 49er cornerback. ''How many sacks do you have?''


Rigid Ethics Code Is Urged In Los Angeles Government
LEAD: In a move that supporters hope will be a national model for cleaning up corruption, a special commission proposed a new ethics code today for Los Angeles's city government, calling it the toughest and clearest such measure in the country.


Older Women Lag On Taking Pap Tests
LEAD: Older women were less likely than younger women to have had a Pap test for cervical cancer in the last year, even though the risk of the disease increases with age, the Federal Centers for Disease Control has reported.

Choctaw Has 6.2% of Justin
LEAD: Choctaw Securities L.P., a Kansas City-based investment partnership, has acquired a 6.2 percent stake in Justin Industries and said it believed the shares of the building materials and leather-goods manufacturer based in Fort Worth are undervalued.


RUMANIAN LEADER REFUSES CHANGES
LEAD: Using the occasion of a major Communist Party congress, President Nicolae Ceausescu made it clear today that as long as he is in charge, Rumania will not follow other East European countries along the paths toward democracy or capitalism.

ABORTION AT ISSUE IN PRESIDENT'S TRIP
LEAD: Acting after a day of campaigning for two prominent Republicans who advocate abortion rights, President Bush vetoed a budget bill for the District of Columbia tonight because it would permit the use of locally raised money to pay for abortions.

LEAD: The Senate Armed Services Committee today ended the Bush Administration's hopes for obtaining confirmation this year of its nominee to head the Energy Department's nuclear weapons program.

200,000 March in Prague as Calls for Change Mount
LEAD: More than 200,000 marchers called today for freedom and a change in government in the largest and most vociferous public demonstration since the euphoric Prague Spring that preceded the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: Carl D. Chambers, a former research director for the New York State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission, died of complications of a heart attack on Friday at West Pennsylvania Hospital in Pittburgh.
He was 55 years old and lived in Athens, Ohio.

Soviet Autonomy Plan Rejected as Too Weak
LEAD: The Soviet Parliament demanded far greater decentralization of economic power today as it firmly voted down a Kremlin proposal to extend only limited economic autonomy to the nation's republics.

LEAD: Roger F. Nelson, retired vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died of lung cancer Saturday at his home in Stuart, Fla..

LEAD: NEARLY a decade after the first X-ray laser was triggered by the explosion of a nuclear bomb, a gentler version has been harnessed in a revolutionary new type of microscope capable of revealing the smallest details ever seen inside living cells.

NBC-TV to End Dramatizations of News
LEAD: NBC News said yesterday that it would discontinue the use of the widely criticized technique of dramatic re-creations because they confuse viewers about where reality ends and the re-creations begin.


Nekoosa Stock Is Most Active

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Fingernails  Q.What causes white spots on the fingernails?
And does the half moon at the base of the nail have any function?
A.These questions are related, said Dr.
Phoebe Rich, a Seattle dermatologist.
The commonest cause of the white spots, called punctate leukononychia, is probably mild trauma, such as pushing back the cuticle too hard.


American Medical
LEAD: The private hospital group American Medical International Inc. said it was seeking a buyer for its 65 percent stake in the British concern AMI Healthcare Group P.L.C.
Under British rules, any buyer of the stake would be required to make a full offer for AMI Healthcare on the same terms as those offered to American Medical.


Fur Vault Plans Shift in Assets
LEAD: Fur Vault Inc. said its board is seeking purchasers for the company's retail fur operations and its Andrew Marc division as part of a plan to redeploy assets.
The company said no buyer had been identified and no acquisitions were being pursued, but that it would use proceeds of any sale to invest in other retail businesses.

Working Rigs Decline
LEAD: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs declined by five last week, to a total of 1,040, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today, It was only the second decline in the last 12 weeks.
Nevertheless, there were still 117 more rigs actively exploring for oil as of last Friday than there were a year earlier.

LEAD: United Airlines pilots have abandoned their threat to stop flying 747-400's, a move that gives some hope to renewed efforts toward an employee buyout of the airline, United's parent company said today.
