Guerrillas Attack in Cambodia
LEAD: About 5,000 non-Communist guerrillas mounted major attacks today to reinforce gains in northwestern Cambodia but met strong resistance from Government troops, a guerrilla official said.
The official, from the Khmer People's National Liberation Front led by Son Sann, said 36 Government soldiers had been killed and 26 wounded.

A Trackball for Places Mice Have Roamed
LEAD: A TRACKBALL is an upside-down mouse, with the ball on the top, to be moved with the fingers, rather than on the bottom, to be moved with the whole hand.
In either case, the movement of the ball is echoed on the screen, moving a pointer to make selections, draw lines, etc.

A Ruling On Phone 'Dumping'
LEAD: The International Trade Commission ruled yesterday that American manufacturers of telecommunications equipment have experienced substantial damage because small-business telephone systems from Japan and Taiwan are being sold in this country at unfairly low prices.
The ruling paves the way for countervailing duties to be imposed on the imports.

Review/Television; Finding Out What Music Is And How It Really Works
LEAD: ''What Is Music?'' asks tonight's offering of ''Nova.'' Although no conclusive answer is forthcoming, the hour, at 8 P.M. on Channels 13 and 49 and at 9 P.M. on Channel 21, touches many strings.
It moves from the synthesizing of sound, to the reproduction of violins that are said to approach the quality of the renowned 17th- and 18th-century instruments, to how performers bring their personalities to bear on musical scores, to what happens when the sounds of music creep in our ears.

LEAD: Former Senator Margaret Chase Smith, the first woman to serve in both houses of Congress, was listed in good condition today in a Chicago hospital's intensive care unit after undergoing treatment for chest pains.
The 91-year-old Maine Republican, who left the Senate in 1972, was taken to Resurrection Medical Center last week from O'Hare Airport after she became ill on a flight.

A state agency, Pennvest, offers grants of up to $500,000 a community and loans of up to $10 million or in some cases more.

Review/Music; Contrast of War and Strauss's Forgiveness
LEAD: Given Richard Strauss's easy relationship with the warlords of modern Germany, one approaches the idea of ''Friedenstag'' with some suspicion.
This ''Day of Peace'' had its Munich premiere in 1938 and was played for Berlin audiences a year later.
One could hardly blame many among those first listeners if their minds occasionally wandered from Strauss's message of forgiveness and reconciliation.

LEAD: A truck driver who was fired Monday by the printing company for which he had worked for several years returned this afternoon and shot two former co-workers with a shotgun, critically wounding both, officials said.

James S. Donnelly, 73, Ex-Dean and Editor
LEAD: Dr.
James S. Donnelly, dean of the Fordham University School of Education from 1955 to 1962 and later an editor and writer of textbooks and technical publications, died of hepatic cancer Monday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital.
He was 73 years old and lived in Convent Station, N.J.


Top Magazine Award
LEAD: John Mack Carter, editor in chief of Good Housekeeping magazine, has been awarded the Henry Johnson Fisher Award by the Magazine Publishers of America.
The industry group will present the award, its highest honor, in a ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in January.
Good Housekeeping, which Mr.
Carter has edited since 1975, won a National Magazine Award this year in the special interest category.


Indians Sign Guante
LEAD: The Cleveland Indians yesterday signed Cecilio Guante, a free-agent pitcher, to a one-year contract.
Guante, a 29-year-old right-hander, appeared in 50 games in relief for the Texas Rangers last season.
He was 6-6 with two saves and a 3.91 earned run average.(AP)

Miami Coach to Leave
LEAD: Bill Foster, the coach who resurrected basketball at the University of Miami in 1985, yesterday announced plans to step down as coach of the Hurricanes at the end of the season.
In his four years at Miami, he had a combined record of 65-56, but the Hurricanes have not played a post-season game since 1963 and attendance has been stalled at 3,000 a game in recent years.

Phobic?
Frenzied?
Faltering?
Help is a phone call, a meeting, a best-selling paperback book away.

But what about the host with a bad case of nerves?

Review/Opera; Haunting and Boisterous 'Contes d'Hoffmann'
LEAD: It is a wonder that Offenbach's ''Contes d'Hoffmann,'' with its history of textual confusions, ever makes sense on the stage.
Despite claims made for competing editions of the score, there still is not - never can be - one unchallengeable version.
But come together ''Hoffmann'' generally does, owing to its string of haunting melodies and boisterous ensemble numbers, but also for the possibilities it offers singing actors to portray different characters under one skin.

Citicorp Rates Up
LEAD: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.
It was the fourth increase in the last five weeks.
The bank holding company sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.2181 percent, up from 8.1896 percent last week.
Citicorp also sold $50 million in 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.8822 percent, up from 7.8587 percent.

LEAD: Nearly 500 million voters in 24 Indian states and 7 federal districts will be eligible to cast ballots from Wednesday to Sunday to choose a new People's Assembly, the lower house of the Indian Parliament.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on the Media Business page on Monday about the coming of advertising to Congressional Quarterly reversed the identifications of two men.
Wayne P. Kelley, publisher, was at the right and Robert W. Merry, managing editor, at the left.


Renault Shutdown
LEAD: The French state-owned car company Renault said it would close its oldest factory.
The company said the 64-year-old plant at Billancourt, an island near central Paris, is considered obsolete and would be closed by 1992.
Employment at the factory has dropped from 22,000 in 1969, to its current level of 4,000.


Antoinette Quilleret, Executive, 85
LEAD: Antoinette Quilleret, a a co-founder and former president of David Webb Inc., the jewelry concern, died of complications of cancer on Thursday at her home in Marbella, Spain.
She was 85 years old.


Hakim Pleads Guilty to One Misdemeanor
LEAD: Albert Hakim, the financial organizer in the Iran-contra affair, today pleaded guilty to a single misdemeanor charge of helping to supplement the salary of Oliver L. North by providing a $13,800 security system for home.


Rose Murphy, 76, Dies; Jazz Pianist and Singer
LEAD: Rose (Chee Chee) Murphy, a jazz pianist and singer whose birdlike high-pitched voice brought her fame, died on Thursday in St.
John's Hospital in Queens.
She was 76 years old and lived in St.
Albans, Queens.


About New York; A Doctor's Hand For the Old, Poor And Terrified
LEAD: Andrea Fox, M.D., makes house calls to sick old people who cannot leave their homes.
The other day she called on Martha in a tattered South Bronx neighborhood.


Episcopal Head Asks U.S. to Rethink Latin Policy
LEAD: The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church has called for a complete reassessment of United States policy in Latin America - ''from top to bottom'' - in the wake of killings and arrests of church workers in El Salvador.


Administration Picks 4 Areas to Receive More Funds in Drug War
LEAD: The Bush Administration plans to designate New York, Miami, Los Angeles and the Southwestern border as having particularly serious drug trafficking problems.
It expects to spend up to $40 million in the current fiscal year and up to $100 million next year to speed up Federal law enforcement efforts,

Consumer Borrowing Could Avert Recession
LEAD: American consumers are laden with debt, but instead of staggering under the burden, they have plenty of borrowing power in reserve -enough, some economists suggest, to help ward off a recession.

After January, It'll Be 'How'm I Suing?'
LEAD: Already committed to lecturing, broadcasting and writing after he leaves City Hall - endeavors in which he is much practiced - Mayor Edward I. Koch will also practice something he hasn't in two decades: the law.


Friendly Advice to a Shrinking Military
LEAD: In these last days, the newspapers and television screens have dealt fully and with wonderment with what is happening in Europe and its meaning for Europeans.
Let no one doubt that there will also be great and enduring effects on us, especially on our military establishment.
This is a word of sympathy, counsel and guidance for that establishment in what promises to be a difficult time.


Bush Nominee for F.C.C.
LEAD: President Bush will nominate Ervin S. Duggan, a former aide to President Lyndon B. Johnson, as a member of the Federal Communications Commission, the White House announced Tuesday.
Mr.
Duggan, 50 years old, was national editor of Washingtonian magazine from 1981 to 1986.
A published novelist, he has run a communications consulting business in Washington since 1981.


Treasuries Rise in Light Trading
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved modestly higher in light pre-holiday trading yesterday.


Congress Rescinds Long-Term Care Act Before Adjourning
LEAD: Congress voted early this morning to repeal the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, including the politically unpopular surtax that helped finance the 16-month-old program.

Nureyev Resigns at Paris Opera, Ending Feud
LEAD: A 14-month feud at the Paris Opera ended today when Rudolph Nureyev resigned as director of the opera's ballet company.


Lured by Bonuses, Workers Vote to End Strike at Boeing
LEAD: The second-longest strike in the Boeing Company's history ended today as 57,800 machinists, attracted by holiday cash bonuses, agreed to go back to work at the world's foremost airplane manufacturer.

Steam-Blast Evacuees Allowed Back
LEAD: Residents from a Gramercy Park building that was coated with asbestos when a steampipe exploded last summer were told yesterday by Consolidated Edison that they can begin to return to their apartments today.


Paper Recycling Plan
LEAD: Noranda Forest Inc. said Monday that it had created a recycling unit to develop paper products because of growing concern about the environment.
Noranda Forest Recycled Papers Ltd. will initially produce 42,000 tons of recycled paper a year, the company's chairman, Adam H. Zimmerman, said.
The unit will begin with the company's Thorold, Ontario, pulp mill, but Mr.


Former U.S. Judge Is Paroled
LEAD: Walter L. Nixon Jr. left a halfway house on parole today after serving 20 months of a five-year prison term for perjury.
The Senate removed him as a Federal district judge on Nov. 3.
In 1986, a jury convicted Mr.
Nixon of lying to a grand jury when he denied discussing a marijuana case with a district attorney.


Soviet Musical
LEAD: A Soviet rock musical called ''Junon and Avos: The Hope,'' the story of a Russian explorer who visits California in the early 1800's, is heading for City Center, courtesy of Pierre Cardin.
It comes from the Lenin Komsomol theater in Moscow and has a cast of 60, a libretto by Andrei Vosnesensky, music by Aleksei Ribnikov and choreography by Vladimir Vasiliev of the Bolshoi.


Gunmen Kill Basque Politician in an Attack at a Madrid Restaurant
LEAD: Gunmen killed a Basque politician and critically wounded another here late Monday night, the eve of their swearing-in as members of the Spanish Parliament.


Rachel B. Wischnitzer, An Art Historian, 104
LEAD: Rachel Bernstein Wischnitzer, a professor and art historian who specialized in synagogue architecture, died Monday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 104 years old.


Civics Lesson in Namibia
LEAD: After decades of domination by white-ruled South Africa, Namibia may now have a chance at lively pluralistic politics.
The Namibian people did their part to assure that earlier this month by electing a constituent assembly in which no party has a majority big enough to impose its will.

LEAD: Helen Lehman Buttenwieser, among the first women admitted to the City Bar Association in New York and a civic leader, died of heart failure yesterday at New York Hospital.

Katharine Butler, Internist, 91
LEAD: Dr.
Katharine Butler, a retired attending physician at New York Hospital and clinical associate professor of medicine at Cornell Medical College, died Saturday at Crosslands, a Quaker life-care community near Kennett Square, Pa.
She was 91 years old.


Nets' Losing Streak Now 5 Games
LEAD: Charles Smith scored 26 points and Ken Norman added 25 tonight as the Los Angeles Clippers dealt the Nets their fifth straight loss, 106-97.


2 Sentenced in Rape
LEAD: Nigel Clay and Bernard Hall, former members of the University of Oklahoma team, were sentenced yesterday in Norman, Okla., to 10 years in prison for rape.
District Judge Preston Trimble also fined the men $10,000 each.
Glen Bell, another former Sooner football player, was acquitted of the same charge.


Relief but No Remedy in El Salvador
LEAD: Americans will share President Bush's ''delight and relief'' at the freeing of 12 U.S. military people trapped in a San Salvador hotel.
This averts what could have been a confrontation with the Salvadoran guerrillas who escaped unharmed from the same hotel.


Lawmakers Tell the Elderly: 'Next Year' on Health Care
LEAD: Hours after Congress voted to repeal the Medicare act covering the high costs of extended illness, House and Senate leaders pledged today to address health care for the elderly next year.
But they acknowledged that many political obstacles remained.

LEAD: Onkal (Duke) Guzey used to have to ask his small children if he could borrow their Lego toys to build his model homes.
Now, five years and half a million Lego pieces later, he has built his own city.


Clamor in the East; East Germany's Free Travel Overloads Rails and Phones
LEAD: East Germany's transportation systems and telephone lines have come under enormous stress as a result of the Communist Government's decision 13 days ago to allow 16.5 million citizens to travel freely to the West.


Stone Container Facility
LEAD: The Stone Container Corporation said Tuesday that it would open a new recycling plant at its mill in Missoula, Mont., that will handle about 144,000 tons of used corrugated boxes in the coming year.
The $16 million recycling plant is part of a $42 million capital investment Stone is making to increase its recycling capacity in 1989.


250,000 Czechs, Hailing Dubcek, Urge Ouster of Hard-Line Leaders
LEAD: More than 250,000 Czechoslovaks who gathered in Wenceslas Square for a sixth consecutive day of protest shouted ''Resign!
Resign!'' today when speakers called for the country's hard-line Communist leaders to step down.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today barred the disclosure of classified information in the Iran-contra trial of a former Central Intelligence Agency official in a move that could lead to the dismissal of charges.


The Ordeal for Lebanon: 14 Years and 7 Months
LEAD: April 13, 1975 Decades of simmering political and sectarian rivalry are brought to a boil by Christian resentment of the Palestianian state-within-a-state that has sprung up in Lebanon after the expulsion of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Jordan in 1970.
Civil war breaks out between the Phalangists, a right-wing Maronite Christian group, and Palestinians after Maronites are killed at a church.


Markets Closed
LEAD: All financial markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving.
Banks, government offices and most businesses will also be closed.
Most stock and futures exchanges will be open tomorrow, but the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the Frozen Concentrate Orange Juice Futures and Options Exchange in New York will remain closed.


Rodman &amp; Renshaw Picks Chief Executive
LEAD: Rodman &amp; Renshaw Capital Group Inc., a regional securities firm based in Chicago, has promoted Kurt B. Karmin to chief execuive, 18 months after he joined it as president.
He will succeed Ira J. Kaufman, who will continue as chairman.
Both men are 61 years old.

BUSH CLAIMS ROLE IN HOSTAGE RESCUE IN SALVADOR HOTEL
LEAD: President Bush said today that he had dispatched commandos to San Salvador after rebel forces seized a hotel where American military advisers were staying.
He boasted of helping to rescue the hostages in an operation that was launched without seeking approval from the President of El Salvador.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Bush Affirms Commitment to NATO
LEAD: In a Thanksgiving address to the nation from Camp David, President Bush tonight hailed the emergence of a ''new Europe'' but affirmed that the American commitment to the Atlantic alliance would remain strong and stable ''as long as our friends want and need us.''

Time to Sell Scott, Foresman for $455 Million
LEAD: Time Warner Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell Scott, Foresman &amp; Company to Harper &amp; Row for $455 million.


Durable-Goods Orders Dropped 0.6% in October
LEAD: Orders to factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods fell in October for the fourth time in six months, and economists said the decline was further evidence that American industry was facing a sharp downturn.


Crown Cork Deal For Unit of CCL
LEAD: The Crown Cork and Seal Company agreed to buy the Continental Can Canada Inc. unit of CCL Industries for about $330 million.
The agreement also calls for CCL to buy 2.5 million Crown Cork shares, or 8.8 percent, after the purchase for $128 million, or $50.50 a share.
The company, based in Philadelphia, said the transaction must be approved by

Lafleur's Next Goal a Historical One
LEAD: Guy Lafleur's next goal will be his 545th and will move him past Maurice (the Rocket) Richard into sole possession of eighth place on the National Hockey League's career goal-scoring list.
It could take place in an appropriate place against an appropriate team.

LEAD: SURE, it is hard work, this daylong ritual of basting and stuffing and slicing and dicing.
But look at it from another perspective.

Bank of Japan's Leader Leaving
LEAD: The governor of the Bank of Japan, Satoshi Sumita, will step down on Dec. 16 at the end of his present term, the country's Minister of Finance, Ryutaro Hashimoto, announced today.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 478 money market mutual funds increased by $4.65 billion, to $368.27 billion, for the week ended Tuesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 146 institutional funds increased by $2.19 billion, to $89.62 billion.
The assets of the 235 general-purpose funds were up by $737.4 million, to $119.53 billion.


Mexican Oil for Japan
LEAD: Japanese oil companies have agreed to buy 150,000 barrels a day of Mexican crude oil for the next five years, executives said Tuesday.
The contract, which takes effect in January, was agreed to last week by Pemex, the Mexican state oil company, and 20 Japanese oil refiners that have formed the Association of Japanese Importers of Mexican Crude Oil.

Propp Has Surgery
LEAD: Brian Propp, the Philadelphia Flyers' right wing, had surgery yesterday to remove a blood clot in his left hand and will be out of action four to eight weeks, the team announced.
Propp, 30 years old, is the Flyers' second-leading career goal scorer with 361 in 11 seasons with the club.
He also has 471 career assists.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: LAST week's column described how to plan the extension of a household electrical circuit to supplement existing outlets and how to begin installing an extension using surface wiring.
Household electrical projects are subject to local building code regulations in nearly every community.
Before beginning this or any electrical project, consult your local building inspector.

British Water Share Price Cut
LEAD: In an attempt to attract investors, the Government has reduced the price for shares in Britain's water industry.


Jordanian Senate Appointed
LEAD: King Hussein appointed a new 40-member upper house of Parliament today.
The King retained former Prime Minister Ahmed al-Lawzi as speaker along with 15 members of the previous 30-member Senate.
Leila Sharaf, a former Information Minister who resigned in 1984 over press restrictions, became the first woman Senator.


Girl in Baby Swap Case Is Told of Test Results
LEAD: When Robert Mays told his daughter, Kimberly, she was not his biological child, ''she cried and cried,'' he told a news conference here today.


Clement Haynsworth Dies at 77; Lost Struggle for High Court Seat
LEAD: Clement F. Haynsworth Jr., the Federal judge whose nomination to the Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate in 1969 after a tense battle between the Nixon Administration and a coalition of labor and civil rights groups, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Greenville, S.C.
He was 77 years old.


CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: IT is time to speak again of ''Days of Our Lives.'' But then I am always speaking of ''Days of Our Lives.'' ''Did you tape the show?'' my daughter asks on the days she's forgotten to set her VCR. ''What happened?'' I ask on the days when I've done the same.

LEAD: Victor Bumbalo's ''Adam and the Experts'' may be the most important play to deal with the AIDS crisis in gay society since William Hoffman's ''As Is'' and Larry Kramer's ''Normal Heart'' sounded their anguished alarms four and a half years ago.


Sale by Hanson
LEAD: Hanson P.L.C. said it had sold its remaining 8 percent stake in Gold Fields of South Africa Ltd., its interest in the Kloof Gold Mining Company and other South African gold mining interests that had been affiliated with Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C.
The sale raised $:240 million, or about $376 million.


Bronx Hospice, Facing a Chronic Deficit, to Close
LEAD: The budget passed by Congress yesterday includes a long-awaited increase in Medicare reimbursement rates for hospices.
But for one hospice in the Bronx, the Federal help is too little and too late.

Clamor in the East; Soviet Novelist Apologizes to Prague
LEAD: A Soviet newspaper today published a prominent novelist's passionate apology to the Czechoslovak people for the Soviet-led invasion of Prague in 1968, calling the intervention a ''collective murder'' that introduced a Stalinist regime.


Eastern's Pilot Union Ends Strike
LEAD: Leaders of the pilots' union at Eastern Airlines voted yesterday to end the union's nearly nine-month-long walkout, but the machinists' union vowed to continue its strike.


Therapy Groups Yield Surprising Benefits for Cancer Patients
LEAD: In a new study of women with breast cancer that has spread, researchers were surprised to find that the women who belonged to a psychotherapy group lived almost twice as long on average as those who did not participate in a support group.

Nynex Agrees With Strikers On a Contract
LEAD: The Nynex Corporation and telephone workers tentatively agreed on a contract yesterday that would end a bitter 16-week strike.
The workers were scheduled to return to their jobs on Dec. 4.


Chemical Banking
LEAD: The Chemical Banking Corporation began a hiring freeze and cutting expenses last Friday, a bank spokesman said.
The company did not disclose the amount of money it expected to save from the actions.
Analysts said banks were bracing for lower revenues because of a slowing economy and a low demand for new loans.


4-Plane Boeing Order
LEAD: Southwest Air Lines of Okinawa, Japan, has ordered four Boeing 737-400's and taken options on four others in a deal worth about $160 million, the Boeing Company said Tuesday.
Southwest would become the first Japanese carrier to operate the 737-400, a twin-engine jetliner that can seat 145 to 170 people.

No Headline
LEAD: Merrill Lynch &amp; Company, the nation's largest brokerage, has undertaken an overhaul that is expected to involve the abandonment of several business lines and the dismissal of as many as 1,000 employees, Wall Street executives said yesterday Merrill announced its plans this week in a letter to more than 40,000 employees.


Pioneer-Discovision Tie
LEAD: Two American units of the Pioneer Electronic Corporation of Japan have completed the purchase of Discovision Associates for $200 million, Pioneer said on Monday.
The main business of Discovision, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., is licensing a worldwide patent portfolio for optical disk recording and reproducing technology.





Bribery Link To Nomura
LEAD: The police on Tuesday arrested an employee of Japan's largest securities firm, the Nomura Securities Company, and a Kawasaki municipal worker on suspicion of bribery in Japan's latest stock scandal.

Allied-Lyons Plan
LEAD: Allied-Lyons P.L.C., the British food and beverage concern, said it would explore the sale of Dunkin' Donuts Inc.'s restaurant division after it completes its $325 million offer.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Allied-Lyons said it had not begun negotiations about a possible sale of the division, which holds the right to develop Chili's Grill and Bar restaurants in New England, New York State outside the New York City area and certain Canadian provinces.


Talking Deals; Time-Warner Tie: Focus on Closing
LEAD: WALL STREET is keeping a close eye on the closing of the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc., which now seems likely not to be completed by the end of 1989.
And so, apparently, is the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is treating the deal as what it calls a ''going private transaction'' and is now reviewing the documents to make sure they comply with disclosure standards.

Arnold Herstand, Art Gallery Owner And Educator, 64
LEAD: Arnold Herstand, a painter, art dealer and former president of the Minneapolis College of Art and Design and the San Francisco Art Institute, died of brain cancer on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Squanto's Luck
LEAD: Late on a raw November day, Plimoth Plantation is a forbidding place; bare trees groan in the wind rushing off the ocean.
As darkness deepens the pervasive chill, the Pilgrims huddle indoors.
They draw their layers of English wool tighter as cold steals in through chinks in the walls.
Logs glowing in a fireplace warm only a corner of the small room.


Review/Dance; Exploring the Art of the Solo In 2 Forms From Japan
LEAD: Suzushi Hanayagi and Suzusetsu Hanayagi are noted interpreters of Jiuta-mai and Kabuki dance.
So the program they presented on Friday at the Asia Society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium offered an informed look at those two classical dance forms of Japan.
But a program of solos also necessarily becomes a commentary on the art of solo dancing, and that was the greatest pleasure and fascination of the evening, which also included dancing by Suzusetsumi Hanayagi.


Ashland Oil to Pay $4.6 Million to Pennsylvania
LEAD: Continuing its financial mop-up of one of the nation's largest inland fuel spills, Ashland Oil Inc. has agreed to pay Pennsylvania $4.6 million in costs and civil penalties.


Barkley Fined $5,000
LEAD: Charles Barkley, the Philadelphia 76ers' All-Star forward, has been fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association for his conduct during a game against the Magic at Orlando, Fla., on Saturday night.

Gray Is Showing in SoHo's Punk Look
LEAD: Every weekend, thousands of people stroll down West Broadway into SoHo, a former industrial district that is a magnet for the chic and the would-be chic.
They pass famous art galleries like Mary Boone and Leo Castelli; they pass bustling restaurants like I Tre Merli, where black-clad women grasp their focaccia with red-painted fingernails.

It was a typically exciting moment at Monday night's Salsa Meets Jazz at the Village Gate.

LEAD: The Senate early today unanimously confirmed Vaughn R. Walker of San Francisco as a Federal District Court judge, ending a two-year controversy over his membership in a club with a record of discrimination.
Mr.
Walker's nomination was delayed because of his 15-year membership in the Olympic Club of San Francisco, which had no black members until last year and still excludes women.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Hot Water Circulation  Q.Our master bathroom is about 80 feet from the hot water tank.
Would a closed loop on a hot water line that goes from this tank to the bathroom keep the water in the line hot all the time because of natural circulation, or would the water fail to circulate by itself?


Sales Start Early At Altman Stores
LEAD: The six B. Altman stores in the New York metropolitan area started their going-out-of-business sales yesterday, advancing the scheduled start from Friday.
John Schultz, the chairman and chief executive of B. Altman &amp; Company, said the turnout was excellent despite no advertising.
The price reductions were 20 percent.

It is an angry work, filled with bitterness about the impossibility of amelioration.

LEAD: The powerful bomb that killed Lebanon's President, Rene Moawad, also shattered that country's best hope of peace.

LEAD: Set two people dancing together on stage and after only a few moments they can seem to be either loving or hating each other - or doing both simultaneously.

So it is no wonder that choreographers are fond of creating ballets on themes of love.

He was 93 years old and was active in the Sidney Janis Gallery until his 90th birthday.

Australia Trade Deficit
LEAD: The Australian Government reported today that the current account deficit had jumped 33 percent in October, to $2.24 billion (about $1.68 billion in United States dollars).
But economists said the underlying figures in the trade data suggested a healthier trend.
When the data were adjusted to exclude seasonal factors like a flood of imports before Christmas, the shortfall was $1.66 billion (Australian), down 14 percent from September's seasonally adjusted $1.93 billion, they said.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, facing a strong threat to his leadership in general elections this week, received another setback today with the resignation of his cultural adviser, Pupul Jayakar, who is also one of the oldest friends of his family and held the rank of Cabinet minister.

LEAD: Engineers using a helicopter will photograph cracks and other rocky wrinkles in the aging 60-foot-tall Presidential faces on Mount Rushmore next week to determine whether the national memorial needs a face lift.


Soviet Computer Deal
LEAD: Electronique Serge Dassault said today that it had signed a contract worth one billion francs, or about $160 million, with the Soviet Union's largest bank to computerize banks and businesses in the Baltic states.
It agreed with Sberbank to computerize its operations in Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia, and to provide staff training and install a maintenance program, the French company said.


Cambodia Rebels Offer Gold
LEAD: A Cambodian guerrilla leader is offering $1,000 to $40,000 in gold to Cambodian soldiers who defect with Soviet fighter jets or other military hardware or deliver a Vietnamese soldier wearing a Cambodian Army uniform.
The rebel leader, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who commands one of three guerrilla groups fighting the Vietnamese-installed Government, announced the reward offers in a broadcast over the resistance radio Wednesday.

LEAD: Ethiopian and Eritrean peace negotiators settled two more procedural issues today.
A spokeswoman for former President Jimmy Carter, who is mediating the talks, said the two sides agreed on a chairman and co-chairman and a secretariate for further talks aimed at ending their civil war.
Mr.
Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, treated both seven-member negotiating teams to a traditional American Thanksgiving dinner at a Nairobi hotel after three and a half hours of talks today.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Moore Back With Spurs
LEAD: Johnny Moore, a former guard for the San Antonio Spurs, has returned to the team, declaring his bout with Desert Fever to be over and pledging to make the most of any playing time he gets.


High Court Modified Malice Requirement
LEAD: To the Editor:


Lebanese Lawmakers Meet to Plan Election of Slain President's Successor
LEAD: Members of Parliament gathered in a town on the main road to Syria today to prepare for the election of a successor to President Rene Moawad, who was assassinated Wednesday when a bomb blew up his car in Beirut.


Letter Aids Soviet Boy Requiring Operation
LEAD: Zoya Zdanovskaya was alone in her cramped Moscow apartment on the night of Dec. 7, 1988, and desperate about her year-old grandson, Kirill.
Believing she had ''nothing to lose,'' she wrote a letter to the Voice of America and sent it to Washington.


Review/Music; Durufle's Wife Is Organist in His Works
LEAD: Donald Keene, the organist and choirmaster of the Church of the Ascension, put together a three-concert tribute to the French composer and organist Maurice Durufle in which virtually all of the composer's works were performed.
The first two concerts took place at Mr.
Keene's church and at the Manhattan School of


2 Killed in Helicopter Crash
LEAD: A Marine helicopter operating from an aircraft carrier crashed and sank Wednesday in the Mediterranean Sea, killing both crew members.
The search for the AH-IT Cobra helicopter and its pilot and co-pilot was called off this morning, said Capt.
Elizabeth Kerstens, a Marine Corps spokeswoman.
The helicopter was operating from the carrier Iwo Jima off the coast of Spain when the crash occurred.


Fourth Woman's Body Found in River Gorge
LEAD: The body of a woman was found today in the Genesee River Gorge, where the bodies of three other women who were slain have been found in the last month, the police said.


Review/Art; 'The Winds of Revolution': French, That Is
LEAD: Is there room for yet another exhibition about the French Revolution?
Is the subject not worn out, squeezed out, talked out and argued out?
Where are the paintings, the drawings, the prints and the documents that could justify so belated an adventure?


Injury Sidelines Moyer
LEAD: Paul Moyer, a Seattle Seahawks safety, has a ruptured disk in his neck that will sideline him for the rest of the season and could end his football career, a published report says.


Sports News Briefs; Lady Volunteers In Season Opener
LEAD: The women's basketball season opens tonight with the defending N.C.A.A. champion Tennessee playing a soft touch, Stetson, at home.


Metro Datelines; Man Is Arrested In Teacher's Slaying
LEAD: A Manhattan man was arrested and charged with the stabbing of a high school science teacher killed last month on Long Island, Nassau County police said yesterday.


Rachel Wischnitzer, Professor, 104
LEAD: Rachel Wischnitzer, an authority on synagogue architecture and a professor emeritus at Yeshiva University, died Monday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 104 years old.


EX-H.U.D. OFFICIAL MAY NOT TESTIFY
LEAD: Another former senior official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development has indicated he may refuse to answer questions from a House panel investigating fraud and mismanagement at the department, Congressional officials say.


OPEC Expects Demand to Fall Short
LEAD: Officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries predicted today that demand for the organization's oil would average 21.5 million barrels a day next year, well under its current level of production.


Tim Wengerd Service
LEAD: A service for Tim Wengerd, a choreographer who was formerly a leading dancer in the Martha Graham Dance Company, will be held at 7 P.M. next Friday in the Actor's Chapel at St.
Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, 239 West 49th Street.
Mr.
Wengerd died on Sept. 12 in Albuquerque, N.M.


Canada Invites Bids for Oil Rights in Arctic
LEAD: For the first time in nearly two decades, the Canadian Government is inviting petroleum companies that had not previously explored for oil in the Arctic Ocean to do so.


Power Failure Stalls 3 Rail Lines
LEAD: Thousands of travelers in New York and New Jersey were delayed several hours yesterday afternoon when a power failure temporarily shut down service on Amtrak, New Jersey Transit and PATH trains between Manhattan and Newark.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Regional Star Risks New York
LEAD: QUICK: Name an advertising agency that opened out of town, built a reputation as an award winner in creative competitions and transformed that reputation into a growing base of national accounts.


NEW DRUG FOUND TO FIGHT CANCER
LEAD: A drug derived from a Chinese tree has proved to be a potent agent against colon cancer in experiments on animals, scientists are reporting in a journal today.


Eagles Shut Down Cowboys
LEAD: Cris Carter made two acrobatic touchdown catches and Philadelphia's defense forced five turnovers today as the Eagles beat the Cowboys, 27-0, handing Dallas its worst loss in 22 Thanksgiving Day games, all at home.


Computer Graphics Aiding Jurors' Recall
LEAD: Jurors hearing a lawsuit over the supposed merits of a new dog food were recently taken, via three-dimensional computer animation, on a journey inside a Labrador retriever's leg to see how its muscles, bones and joints function.

Lesson From San Salvador: Rebels Come and Go at Will
LEAD: Even as they celebrated the peaceful ending of the hostage crisis at the Hotel Salvador, military experts said the incident reinforced the most striking lesson of the recent rebel offensive here: That large numbers of leftist insurgents can enter and leave the capital at will, even under intense Government scrutiny and bombardment.


When Price Is Out, Cavs Are Not Right
LEAD: His size, barely 6 feet and close to 170 pounds, raises doubt about whether he belongs in the National Basketball Association earning more than $1 million a year.
His heavy-lidded eyes make it appear as if he just woke up and is not too keen about what is going on.
But his peripheral vison and almost inexplicable sense of the game make Mark Price an All-Star playmaker, and the Cleveland Cavaliers would not be the same without him.


East German Change Owes No Thanks to Us; Europe Is Hopeful
LEAD: To the Editor:


Richard Goode and Piano Warm Up for a Good Cause
LEAD: ''This past decade has been partly a matter of restoring the balance,'' the pianist Richard Goode said the other day, looking back on his 1978 decision to leave the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and devote himself more fully to solo performance. ''I had done a great deal of chamber music, but I was probably the only pianist on my block who had not performed the Beethoven 'Appassionata' in public.


Mohawk Police Cost Millions
LEAD: The state spent more than $3 million to keep police officers at the St.
Regis Mohawk Reservation for four months after a gambling raid last summer, officials said.


A Capital Idea for Eastern Europe
LEAD: Westerners are exhilarated by the drama of Eastern Europe but puzzled about how to help.
The West cannot alter the fact that it's Eastern Europe's job to break the chains of centralized control and to wean consumers from subsidized prices and producers from guaranteed sales.
But the West can ease this painful process and modestly improve the chances for success.

TV Weekend; A Victoria Principal Vehicle As Blind Witness to Murder
LEAD: Starring Victoria Principal, ''Blind Witness,'' the television movie on ABC this Sunday at 9 P.M., was produced by King-Phoenix Entertainment in association with Victoria Principal Productions.
In other words, it is a star vehicle, the kind of showcase contraption that once used to be constructed for a Katherine Cornell or a Helen Hayes.


Hearing for Williams
LEAD: Carl (the Truth) Williams will defend his United States Boxing Association heavyweight title against Tyrell Biggs, an Olympic gold medalist, on Jan. 11 at Atlantic City.
Ira Leibowitz, Williams's manager, said the fighter would appear at a hearing at the World Boxing Association Convention in Philadelphia today to ask that his loss July 21 to Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, be ruled no contest.

LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums


Poles Burn Lenin Statue
LEAD: A monument to Lenin in the town of Nova Huta was splashed with paint and set afire on the eve of the visit to Moscow by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a newspaper reported today.
The act was carried out by members of the anti-Communist Federation of Fighting Youth, the newspaper Zycie Warszawy quoted an official as saying.


Thinking Long Term Is Costly to Caterpillar
LEAD: Caterpillar Inc., the nation's largest producer of earthmoving machinery, is learning that the costs of international competitiveness are high: $1.5 billion, ill will on Wall Street and a few dollars off its stock price.


A 'Job' In Salvador
LEAD: Suppose a secret cabal of United States military men routed six priests out of their beds, murdered them, then faded back into clandestine silence.
Suppose, say, President Mitterrand of France called up the White House and asked President Bush if he had ordered the killings, or knew anything about them.


Court Upholds '88 Increase in Thruway Tolls
LEAD: A citizens group lost another round today in its fight to have last year's toll increase on the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway ruled illegal.


Salvador Chief, Claiming Victory, Rejects Rebels' Cease-Fire Offer
LEAD: President Alfredo Cristiani rejected a rebel cease-fire offer today as little more than a trick and asserted that the military had dealt the insurgents a decisive defeat.


Results Plus
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Bruins 6, Maple Leafs 0: Andy Moog stopped 32 shots in Boston last night for his second shutout.
Boston pulled away early with three goals in the first period.
Toronto's John Kordic and Boston's Michael Thelven started fighting at 12 minutes 36 seconds of the third period.
Before the fight was over, Referee Terry Gregson called 124 minutes in penalties and 10 players were ejected from the game.


A White Thanksgiving Sets a Record
LEAD: A Thanksgiving snowstorm, the first in New York City in 51 years, cloaked the metropolitan region in wintry white yesterday, preventing high school football games from being played, horses from running at Aqueduct and Snoopy and Bugs Bunny from making it to the big parade in Manhattan.

LEAD: Hank Kuhlmann, who replaced Gene Stallings as coach of the Phoenix Cardinals on Monday, wasted little time making a major change.
He said yesterday that Tom Tupa, a second-year quarterback who has started one game and played in several others, would start in place of Gary Hogeboom for the Cardinals (5-6) in their game Sunday against Tampa


7 Protesters Join Parade
LEAD: Seven people received summonses for disorderly conduct yesterday after they briefly joined the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade with a black balloon shaped like a bomb that read, ''Stop U.S.
Bombing of El Salvador'' on one side and ''No Vietnam War in El Salvador'' on the other.

LEAD:  Politician Wounded in India  An opposition politician was near death after he was shot in a violent first day of voting in the three-day election in India.
Page A15.
Lebanese Leaders Meet  The members of the Lebanese Parliament, meeting in northern Lebanon, are expected to choose a new President today.


Rail Worker Is Killed by Train
LEAD: A Long Island Rail Road track worker was killed, apparently when he was struck by a train, as he worked on the tracks in Queens Village, the L.I.R.R. reported yesterday.
The worker, Roger Sander, 29, a three-year employee, died between 8 P.M. and 11:30 P.M.
Wednesday, said a L.I.R.R. spokesman Mike Charles.


China's Frontier: The Search for Development
LEAD: This is the ''other China,'' a land of poor peasants and occasional smokestacks, where for some households upward mobility means nothing more grand than moving out of their cave and into a house.

LEAD: The crumbling of the Berlin wall was also the end of innocence for untold numbers of rabbits.


B.A.T. Buys More Shares
LEAD: B.A.T.
Industries, the British conglomerate fighting a hostile $21 billion bid from Sir James Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments Ltd., said today that it had acquired more shares under a plan to buy back up to 10 percent of its stock.


Harris Sets a Record As Mountaineers Win
LEAD: The fullback Rico Tyler scored the winning touchdown on a 1-yard run in the third quarter as 17th-ranked West Virginia capitalized on a turnover and beat Syracuse, 24-17, tonight in a game between bowl-bound teams.

LEAD: International A3-17  Factions in Prague vied for support from the nation's security forces on the eve of a Central Committee meeting expected to make changes in the Communist leadership.
Policemen supporting hard-liners secured a television station.
Page A1  Czechoslovak students ask workers at farms and factories to support their reformist aims.


2-9 No Laughing Matter
LEAD: Because of their 2-9 record, the Jets have eschewed their traditional Thanksgiving turkey scam, at least officially.


Florida Escape Spurs Study of Work Release
LEAD: A crime spree by an inmate who walked away from a Florida center where he was living while completing a prison term has led officials to question parts of the state's work-release program.


Metro Datelines; One Man Is Linked To Three Sex Attacks
LEAD: New York City police believe the same man was responsible for the rapes this month of two women and the attempted rape of a third in Fort Tryon and Inwood parks in upper Manhattan.


Greece Installs Government of 3 Major Parties
LEAD: An all-party Government of politicians and technocrats was sworn in here today, putting a formal if temporary end to the political crisis plaguing Greece since its two inconclusive general elections.


Krone Accepts Ban
LEAD: Julie Krone has dropped her appeal of a 15-day suspension and will sit out the final month of racing in this year's thoroughbred meeting at Meadowlands Race Track.

Two days after his dismissal, he taped a new commercial.

Clamor in the East; For East Germans, Nice Place to Visit
LEAD: More than eight million East Germans, equal to about half the East German population, have visited West Germany and West Berlin since the East German leaders lifted restrictions on travels to the West on Nov. 9.


Sugar Quota Is Increased
LEAD: The United States Agriculture Department increased the nation's sugar quota today by 13.5 percent, the second time in three months that the Government has increased imports to combat tight supplies and high domestic prices.


Europe Nears Mergers Pact
LEAD: The European Community moved closer today to setting a common policy for investigating the big company mergers that are transforming Europe's business landscape.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.


Holiday Movie Audiences Create Box-Office Windfall
LEAD: Smashing records at nearly every showing, Universal's ''Back to the Future II'' is expected to sell between $37 million and $45 million worth of tickets over the Thanksgiving holiday period beginning Wednesday.
A Universal spokesman said that snow conditions in the East might reduce box office receipts by as much as $5 million.

LEAD: MICHAEL A. MINOVITCH is the first person to admit that his idea for launching space vehicles by magnetic propulsion from a thousand-mile vacuum-pressure tunnel seems a little surreal.


Imasco Predicts Earnings Increase
LEAD: The continued slowing in Canada's economic growth, which is expected next year, will not prevent Imasco Ltd. from increasing net earnings 10 percent to 20 percent, its chairman and president, Purdy Crawford, said in an interview.
He said the improvement should come in all divisions, including the underperforming United States operations: the fast-food chain Hardee's and Peoples Drug Stores.

LEAD: The broom that swept out the leadership of East Germany's Communist Party earlier this month also pushed away an essential political component - its living embodiment of unswerving opposition to Nazism and total devotion to Stalin, senior officials here say.

Stifling a Late Rally, Kansas Wins N.I.T.
LEAD: Kansas began the Dodge National Invitation Tournament as an unheralded and unranked team, expected to lose in the early rounds.


Adirondack Park Panel Seeks Balanced Future
LEAD: The Adirondack Park, six million acres of forests, mountains and lakes in the heart of New York State, is many things to many people: a slice of wilderness, a livelihood, a home.
Members of New York State's Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century have traveled around the state to hear residents discuss their visions of the park.

LEAD: Federal health officials investigating a nationwide outbreak of a serious illness linked to a dietary supplement, L-tryptophan, said yesterday that they were focusing on the way it was manufactured in Japan.

South Africa Opens 4 Areas to All Races
LEAD: The Government today declared four residential areas in South Africa open to all races.
But the step was soon assailed by critics of apartheid, who said that it did not go far enough.


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1989
LEAD:  Companies


Attwoods to Add Mindis Industrial
LEAD: Attwoods P.L.C., a mineral extracting and waste disposal company, agreed to acquire the Mindis Industrial Corporation, an Atlanta-based recycling company, for up to $65 million in cash and shares.
An initial $18 million will be paid in the form of $15 million in 2.21 million new Attwoods shares and $3 million in cash,


Stocks Post Broad Gain; Trading Off
LEAD: Stocks gained strongly yesterday in exceptionally slow post-Thanksgiving trading.


Abuses Seen on 2 Sides in Salvador
LEAD: Rebels who seized working-class neighborhoods killed at least four civilians suspected of being informers for the army or members of death squads, residents of the areas and human rights monitors said today.
The monitors also criticized the Government and military for bombing crowded residential areas where the rebels were holed up, leading to the deaths of an undetermined number civilians.


Plumtree Journal; Uncertain Lies the Land of Zimbabwe's Farmers
LEAD: For the first time in 20 years, Max Rosenfels, whose family has toughed it out for almost a century in this arid, wind-swept region of southern Africa, is enjoying a productive season.
The rain has been unusually promising and the end of the civil war in Matabeleland, this region of the country, has meant farming without danger.


U.S. Delays Decision on Agent Orange Pay
LEAD: The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, Edward J. Derwinski, announced today that he was delaying a decision on whether any Vietnam veterans could receive disability pay for exposure to the defoliant Agent Orange.


Maxwell Seeks Stake In Clal, Israeli Concern
LEAD: Robert Maxwell, the British entrepreneur, is offering $250 million for a substantial stake in Israel's second-biggest company, the Clal conglomerate, a Maxwell spokesman said Thursday.


Bridge
LEAD: Very few women have headed the standings in the New York City and Long Island final of the North American Open Pairs, formerly the Grand National Pairs.
Joining that group last month was Gladys Collier of East Hampton, L.I., who qualified with Win Allegaert of Manhattan for the national playoffs in Fort Worth in March.


The Winds of Change
LEAD:  POLAND  June 4, 1989: Solidarity candidates achieve what the Communist Party calls a decisive majority of the popular vote in a parliamentary election, the first free election in almost a half century.
Aug. 19: Gen.
Wojciech Jaruzelski designates Tadeuz Mazowiecki, a senior Solidarity official and prominent Roman Catholic layman, to be the first non-Communist Prime Minister of Poland since the early postwar years.


Orchestra's Debut
LEAD: The full orchestral version of Aaron Copland's ''Appalachian Suite'' and Charles Wuorinen's ''Bamboula Beach'' will be given their New York premieres on Dec. 14 by the New World Symphony, in a concert at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall.
The ensemble, which is believed to be the only full-time training orchestra in the United States, will be making its New York debut under the direction of the founding conductor and artistic advisor, Michael Tilson Thomas.


What Did Columbus Know, When Did He Know It?; Civilizing Mission
LEAD: To the Editor:


Batco Closing Factories
LEAD: The British American Tobacco Company, a unit of B.A.T.
Industries P.L.C., said today that it would close cigarette factories in Liverpool in northwest England and in Amsterdam.
A total of 599 jobs will be lost.


Rural Intrigue Is Unearthed With 5 Bodies
LEAD: Ray and Faye Copeland lived in self-imposed rural isolation near here for decades, a quiet farm couple scratching out a living on 40 acres of hard soil in northwest Missouri.


Clamor in the East; Hungary Opposition Splits, Threatening Ballot on Vote
LEAD: A national referendum on Sunday to decide on the sequence of the first free Hungarian elections in 42 years has deeply split the opposition and put the largest of the new parties in the same camp as the governing Socialist Party.

LEAD: A television set started a fire that swept through a row house early today, killing two children, their aunt and their grandmother, fire officials said.

Salvador Moves Toward Broad Curbs on Dissent
LEAD: The Legislative Assembly in El Salvador moved today toward final approval of sweeping new restrictions on individual freedoms, including virtually unhindered Government power to ban dissent and peaceful protest.


An Acquisitive Utility Spreads in the West
LEAD: Pacificorp, the company bidding $2.08 billion for the Arizona Public Service Company, has grown through acquisitions from a little-known Oregon company into the third-largest utility in the West.
In the process, it is becoming known as a leader in the trends toward distributing power across many states and diversifying into non-utility businesses.


No. 7 Train's Extra Car Leaves Riders No Exit
LEAD: A No. 7 train began operating yesterday morning with an extra car, its doors opening at elevated stops where the last car did not reach the platform, the Transit Authority said.


Bush Weighing Citizenship for 10,000 Nurses
LEAD: A bill that would allow about 10,000 foreign nurses with temporary work visas to become United States citizens has been passed by Congress.
President Bush is expected to sign the bill despite reservations in the Labor Department, said Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, the House sponsor.


Held in Protest Against Abortions
LEAD: Forty-three anti-abortion protesters were arrested for trespassing yesterday morning after they blocked entrances to several physicians' offices where abortions are performed, the police said.


Taping Puts Connecticut in a Legal Thicket
LEAD: Three weeks after the top command of the Connecticut State Police was rocked by revelations about the force's tape-recording of telephone conversations between suspects and their lawyers, the implications of the controversy are spreading downward to affect local courthouses and police departments around the state.


Canada Fight on Fund Loss
LEAD: Canadian provinces are squabbling about who should pay compensation to 67,000 investors who lost about $450 million (Canadian) when two Alberta investment companies collapsed.


OPEC Seeks Kuwait and Emirate Oil Cut
LEAD: An OPEC majority tried today to persuade two Persian Gulf Arab states, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, to agree to cut oil output, for fear that their excess production could weaken prices early in 1990.

LEAD: Gary Pettis, the only major league outfielder with more than 300 putouts in fewer than 120 games last season, agreed yesterday to a three-year contract with the Texas Rangers.

LEAD:  Rebels Accused of Killings In San Salvador Offensive


Eastern Talks With Pilots Set
LEAD: Eastern Airlines said today that it set a special meeting with its pilots' union for Tuesday to eliminate any uncertainties about employee status.


About New York; Listen, We've Got Another Homer Story
LEAD: Homer Bigart looked out the window of the New Hampshire country house that has been his home for nearly two decades.
Trees he planted himself bended in the wind coming down off the Pawtuckaway Mountains.


Senate Dispute Delays Naming of Arts Group
LEAD: A dispute in the Senate is holding up the appointment of members of a Presidential commission that will review the grant-making procedures of the National Endowment for the Arts.


Clamor in the East; No Israeli Ties Yet, Poles Say
LEAD: Poland today denied an Israeli report that it had decided to restore full diplomatic relations with the Government in Jerusalem. ''The information is not true,'' Deputy Foreign Minister Jan Majewski said. ''The Polish Government is considering the possibility of restoring diplomatic relations with Israel in the not-too-distant future, but it has not taken any decision yet.


What Did Columbus Know, When Did He Know It?; Didn't Bring Slavery
LEAD: To the Editor:


Shots Miss India's Opposition Leader
LEAD: Unidentified gunmen fired three shots today moments after the Indian opposition leader, Vishwanath Pratap Singh, made a campaign stop at a polling place.
Mr.
Singh was not wounded in the incident, which took place in a village in his home constituency in Uttar Pradesh.


Human Rights Panel Restores 2 Officials To Anti-Bias Posts
LEAD: New York City's Commission on Human Rights yesterday announced the reinstatement of the director of its AIDS discrimination division and his deputy, who had been dismissed from their jobs last month, touching off protests from AIDS and homosexual-rights groups when the two asserted they had been removed because of their homosexuality.


A School's Pride Is Home for the Holiday
LEAD: Javier's back!
As the tall young man with the small gold earring and the megawatt smile bounded through the corridors of Murry Bergtraum High School for Business Careers, the news spread: Javier Eduardo Mateu, last year's valedictorian, was home for the holiday from college, and not just any college.


China Report On Ventures
LEAD: Most joint ventures involving foreign investment are reporting profits despite a cloudy business climate after the crackdown on political dissent in June, a Government news report said today.

LEAD:  * JOSEPH F. FERNANDEZ


The Worlds Of Puckett And Selvie
LEAD: On the front page of The New York Times's sports section on Thanksgiving Day, the two leading stories seemed worlds apart, and were, but they were also ironically linked.


Crane Seeking Milton Roy
LEAD: The Crane Company said today that it would like to acquire the Milton Roy Company, a maker of analytic instruments and pumps, for $21 a share in cash, prompting a sharp rise in the St.
Petersburg, Fla.. company's shares on the New York Stock Exchange.


MAN IN THE NEWS: Elias Hrawi; An Earthy Politician Who Makes Both Ends Meet
LEAD: The newly elected President of Lebanon, Elias Hrawi, comes from a wealthy family of landlords in Zahle, a Christian town in the Bekaa, where the bulk of Syria's 40,000 troops in Lebanon are deployed.


Telerate Suitor
LEAD: Dow Jones &amp; Company, which produces The Wall Street Journal and other publications, said that it had been tendered about 24.4 million shares of Telerate Inc. in response to its $21-a-share offer.
The shares raise Dow Jones's stake in Telerate, a computerized financial data company, to about 92 percent from 67 percent.


Liquor Consumption in U.S. Reported at a 3-Decade Low
LEAD: The average consumption of hard liquor by Americans has fallen to its lowest level in three decades, Federal health researchers reported today.


Sensibility of New York Offended As a Nuisance Becomes Common
LEAD: On weeknights, between 8 and 9 o'clock, Maria Emilia Dalmeida is likely to be sitting at the dinner table in her apartment at Greenwich and Murray Streets in Manhattan, eating or writing.
Most nights, she'll look out the window and spot a taxi driver standing against the open door of his car, relieving himself.

In Wenceslas Square, a Shout: Freedom!
LEAD: Word surged through the crowd like a current, and it seemed that within seconds every one of the hundreds of thousands of people in Wenceslas Square learned that the entire Czechoslovak Communist Party leadership had resigned.


Case Dismissed In Contra Affair, Clearing Agent
LEAD: A Federal judge dismissed all criminal charges today against a former Central Intelligence Agency official indicted in the Iran-contra affair, citing Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's decision to block disclosure of classified information at trial.


Barry's Jewelers
LEAD: Barry's Jewelers Inc. said it had made a competing bid to buy the assets of Merksamer Jewelers Inc., a subsidiary of the L. J. Hooker Corporation.
Hooker, which is in Chapter 11 proceedings, agreed last month to sell its 80 percent stake back to Merksamer management for an undisclosed amount.
Barry's said it had offered an undisclosed amount ''substantially in excess'' of the $55 million it said Merksamer had bid.


Richard C. Gallop, 51, a Lawyer Who Headed Columbia Pictures
LEAD: Richard C. Gallop, former president and chief operating officer of Columbia Pictures Industries, died of a brain tumor Thursday at New York Hospital.
He was 51 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Gilford, N.H.

LEAD: Last week's opening round of Brazil's first direct presidential election in 29 years produced two runoff candidates of integrity and conviction.
Either is likely to provide more inspiring leadership than the outgoing Jose Sarney.

LEAD: The nation's exports of farm products in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30 came close to the $40 billion forecast by Agriculture Department experts three months ago.

LEAD: Many owners of small businesses and professional practices need to act promptly to avoid losing the deductibility of their retirement plans, warns Philip M. Herr, a tax manager with Spicer &amp; Oppenheim, an international public accounting firm.


Danish-French Insurance Talks
LEAD: Denmark's biggest insurance company, the Baltica Group, said it was negotiating an alliance with the French insurance and finance company Groupe Victoire and Suez.


Drug Abuse Counselor Held on Crack Charge
LEAD: A drug abuse counselor at a New York City intermediate school was arrested yesterday and charged with possession of four vials of crack, the police said.


Dinkins Moves To Find Names For Chief Posts
LEAD: David N. Dinkins appointed five committees yesterday to look for candidates to head major agencies in New York City, but his transition aides noted that all the jobs will not be filled by the time the Mayor-elect takes office on Jan. 1.


G.M. Reduces Isuzu Stake, But Is Still Main Shareholder
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had sold 20 million shares of Isuzu Motors Ltd., the Japanese auto maker and a longtime G.M. affiliate.
The sale reduced G.M's stake percentage to 38.2 percent from 40.2 percent, but G.M. remains Isuzu's largest shareholder.


Swiss Bank Adds
LEAD: BSI-Banca della Svizzera Italiana, a leading Swiss bank, said it was taking a 20 percent stake in Cassa Lombarda S.p.A. of Milan, Italy, which specializes in commercial and industrial lending.
BSI said the move would develop a contact with Compagnie de l'Occident pour la Finance et l'Industrie S.A.


State Plans Ads for New York City
LEAD: The state will try to help New York City bring in tourist dollars with a $3 million advertising campaign using network television, national magazines and direct-mail advertising, Vincent Tese, the state's Director of Economic Development, announced Thursday.

LEAD: He says he still believes the Philadelphia Eagles offered a bounty on two of his leading offensive players, but Coach Jimmy Johnson of the Dallas Cowboys is content to leave matters up to the officials of the National Football League.


North Stars Move Up By Beating Devils, 7-6
LEAD: Neal Broten's goal 4 minutes 13 seconds into the third period broke a 5-5 tie tonight as the Minnesota North Stars moved atop the overall National Hockey League standing with a 7-6 victory over the Devils.

Clamor in the East; Hopes Sink To Bottom In Belgrade
LEAD: There is a fountain here where, as with the Trevi in Rome, people once threw coins to wish their heart's desire.
But these days the coins are so devalued that they do not even buy a dream.
So the fountain is layered with sodden bank notes in four-figure denominations, destined too for worthlessness.

Credit Markets Shrug Off Fed Move
LEAD: The Federal Reserve made an unexpected move yesterday to arrest the decline in interest rates by draining some of the reserves that it had added to the banking system before the Thanksgiving holiday.
The infusion of reserves on Wednesday was taken as a strong signal that the central bank was easing rates.

LEAD: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the Polish leader who took office on the strength of popular resistance to Communism, was warmly welcomed today at the Kremlin, with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declaring, ''Our relations have changed for the better.''


Police Are Searching For Mother of Infant
LEAD: New Haven police are looking for the mother of a baby girl who was found alone inside a cold apartment on Thanksgiving morning.

Blockbuster Sale By United Artists
LEAD: The United Artists Entertainment Company said it intends to sell the 7.6 million shares of stock it holds in the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, a video store operator.
United Artists Entertainment, a cable television and movie theater company based in Denver, obtained the Blockbuster shares earlier this year through the merger of the predecessor company, United Artists Communications, and the United Cable Television Corporation.

LEAD: Midway Airlines today announced additional flights to Florida from Chicago and from Philadelphia, beginning Jan. 8.

From Philadelphia, round-trip flights will be added with Sarasota, Fort Myers and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

Too Many Dammed Rivers
LEAD: Of the 3.5 million miles of river that once laced this continent, an estimated 15 percent now lie dead behind 60,000 dams of all kinds.
For every river mile preserved under the national Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, 65 have been extinguished.

Clamor in the East; Guards Whitewash Berlin Wall
LEAD: Four days after artists painted colorful scenes onto the Eastern side of the Berlin wall, border guards have painted over them with whitewash.
East German newspapers said the guards produced paint cans and brushes on Thursday after officers decided that the artists' spontaneous action was illegal despite the relaxed regime at the border.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''This is the first time in my life that I have been able to say the word freedom and to feel that I am indeed a free man.
For 40 years I have lived under the Communist dictatorship.
We could not talk freely, we could not think freely, but we became fed up, all of us here.
And now, we will never stop saying this word: freedom!

Correction
LEAD: A brief article by The Associated Press on Sunday about expanded inspections being ordered for some Boeing 747's misidentified the aircraft model on which 28 cracks were found.
It was a 747-100, an older model of the jumbo jet, not a 747-400, the newest.

France's Credit Lyonnais bank is about to close a deal to sell nearly a third of the shopping center for 420 million francs, about $68 million, to the Nippon Life Insurance Company, bank sources said.

Santa Fe's Spicy Cultural Mix
LEAD: Out here in the West where old means almost anything that happened before World War II, Santa Fe is the exception.
It was established in 1610 by settlers from New Spain to the south.
And although residents like to talk about ''descendants of the conquistadors,'' the folks who came up the Camino Real from Mexico City in the train of Juan de Onate were already two or three generations removed from their Spanish antecedents and their blood was thoroughly mixed with that of the Mexican natives their fathers and grandfathers had conquered.

Four economists assess inflation and the Federal Reserve's next move.

FICTION
LEAD:  EARTHLY REMAINS.
By Peter Hernon. (Birch Lane/Carol Publishing, $18.95.) In 1947, the British were pulling out of Palestine, leaving the region's Jews, in their struggle to create an independent state of Israel, to fight the Arabs.
At the same time, a startling discovery of a group of ancient scrolls was made by a band of Bedouin tribesmen in a cave located in Trans-Jordan, little more than a stone's throw from the Dead Sea.

Review/Music; Don Pullen's Pianism
LEAD: It wasn't until the end of the pianist Don Pullen's last tune of his first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night that it became clear how unusual his compositional ideas are.
Launching into a conventional blues piece, he made the previous hour of music seem carefully premeditated.
Every tune had its own rhythm from which to work; one piece functioned as a suite, another had a pop-gospel sunniness, while another was essentially a ballad played as piano solo.

INSIDE THE INTIFADA
LEAD: Joel Brinkley portrays the Intifada as the shebab - as masked young men - who throw stones at Israeli soldiers and settlers (''Inside the Intifada,'' Oct. 29).

The Intifada is, indeed, stone throwers, but, more significantly, it is the resistance to Israeli occupation.

LEAD: Q. Soon after we moved into our new home, a wood toilet paper roller was accidentally flushed down the toilet.

THIS IS NOT REAL
LEAD: Smoke issued from vents, as a kaleidoscope of lights flashed wildly.
Two hulking figures brimming with human meanness, with painted faces and Mohawk haircuts and encased in black vests decorated with metal studs, commenced an ominous walk down a black ramp toward the ring.

Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
LEAD: Yes.
Not all sports can be judged popular according to a professional standard.
Soccer is a game played by millions of youngsters and adults across America.
The United States doesn't need a professional soccer league to make the game popular.
All we need are the youths to play the game, a few experienced coaches and a baseball outfield on which to play.

LEAD: APPLYING wallpaper is no longer the tricky, messy task it once was.
Although stronger paper and slower-drying adhesives have eased the job considerably, achieving smooth-surfaced results still depends on preparing the wall carefully before applying the paper.

A Yankee Upstart Sprouts in Thatcher's London
LEAD: The scale of Canary Wharf is immense: 24 buildings on 71 acres, its centerpiece a 50-story, 800-foot-high skyscraper by Cesar Pelli that when finished will be the tallest building in Britain.
This is most assuredly not the London of Christopher Wren or of John Nash.
Nor is it the London of Prince Charles, who has made it clear that he expects this huge tower to be a desecration of the city's skyline.

LEAD: LIVING IN THE MIDDLE of the woods in upstate New York, I am sometimes reminded that a gun can be a useful tool in the normal course of country life.

A View of Warhol Surfaces From The Old Underground
LEAD: ''Andy was a person.
Just like we are.
Just like you are.'' Perhaps.

And he generally delighted in whatever myths about him might be in circulation.

LEAD: More and more airlines are assessing penalties, known as prepay charges, for travelers who book an advance-purchase seat through a travel agent but get the ticket issued at the airport.

ENVY, THE WRITER'S DISEASE
LEAD: It used to be like a fever with me, a compulsion, a madness: to go into a bookstore, head straight for the brand-new books, flip right to the back of the jacket and see if the author was young or old, my age or even - rats! - younger.
Envy is a vocational hazard for most writers.
It festers in one's mind, distracting one from one's own work, at its most virulent even capable of rousing the sufferer from sleep to brood over another's triumph.


The High Price of Smiling
LEAD: ALMOST everyone I know has a driver's license, yet none of my friends have ever shown theirs to me.
Perhaps they are as ashamed of the photograph on it as I am of mine.
People usually don't show them around, proudly, like baby pictures.
Instead, they are carefully hidden in billfolds or handbags, retrieved only when identification is required.

Now I'm afraid it's too late.''


Psychoanalyzing Vienna and Its Oedipus Complex
LEAD: FIFTY years after Freud died in London, Vienna is dutifully paying respect to its famous son.
This fall a stream of exhibits and other commemorations has reminded the Viennese of their association with the founder of psychoanalysis, who lived in this city for 78 years.
But psychoanalysts here say that behind Vienna's public acknowledgments is a deep ambivalence toward Freud and his ideas.

LEAD: WITH the approach of winter, New York City's hospitals are bracing for what is fast becoming a sorry seasonal ritual: huge numbers of patients, many with preventable illnesses, packed double to a berth or spilling into emergency room hallways, waiting hours for treatment and, when needed, admission to scarce beds.

LEAD: Chita Rivera, at age 56, personifies the tough-as-nails show-business trouper determined to stay on the boards as long as she can kick up her heels and play the raucous life of the party.


Hearing at Hand for Captain In Oil Spill in Alaskan Sound
LEAD: Lawyers for the tanker captain accused of allowing the nation's worst oil spill to occur will seek to have his case thrown out of court on claims of immunity, a flawed sobriety test and other grounds, in a hearing that begins Monday.


PLANE IN SALVADOR WITH SOVIET ARMS CRASHES AND 4 DIE
LEAD: A light plane carrying two dozen Soviet-made antiaircraft missiles crashed in eastern El Salvador today on what Government officials said was a mission to resupply leftist guerrillas here with weapons from Nicaragua.


SHOWDOWN AT WINDOW ROCK
LEAD: UNDER THE BRILLIANT BLUE ARIZONA SKY, AN air-conditioned GMC Sierra bumps along a weed-choked wagon track near the main road to Kaibito, just south of Many Waters Lake, at the foot of the Peak Where the Wildcats Stretch.
In the back seat, Peter MacDonald, the embattled leader of the Navajo nation, peers through the tinted glass window at a distant figure on horseback.

PARENTS AND CHILDREN
LEAD:  WHY KIDS LIE: How Parents Can Encourage Truthfulness.
By Paul Ekman with Mary Ann Mason Ekman and Tom Ekman. (Scribners, $17.95.) This thoughtful and provocative book is much better than its title suggests.
Mr.
Ekman, a research psychologist, has spent years studying the phenomenon of truth and its distortion, and he's taken all that he's learned and applied it to young people learning to be adults and to the parents struggling to help them.


Michigan Gains Rose Bowl Slot
LEAD: The evidence was clear: Michigan had the better team today against Ohio State.
But it took the Wolverines almost forever to prove that and to confirm their reservations for the Tournament of Roses.


Are Many Salespeople Stumped?
LEAD: In the beginning of the personal computer age, many executives were appalled at the low quality of sales help.
Some salespeople could not answer basic questions.
Worse, some passed off their wild guesses as expertise.
As years went by, salespeople climbed the learning curve along with users, and it became fairly rare to find a dunce selling equipment in the major stores.


A Stellar Quartet Offers Brahms
LEAD: ISAAC STERN, Jaime Laredo, Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax are scheduled to record the two Brahms Piano Quartets, but before that they have decided to play the towering masterworks in concert.
One of the concerts will be at 8 P.M.
Friday in Woolsey Hall in New Haven (432-4159).
The other will be at 3 P.M.


BERN
LEAD: The Bernese may have a reputation for staidness, but they did noticeably rejoice when a female among the brown Alpine bears that are kept in a pit near the Nydegg Bridge whelped early this year.
There had been no cubs in 1988, and the happy event was felt to augur well for Switzerland's capital.
The bear is Bern's emblem; the city's name is believed to be derived from the German word for bear.

A Century's Worth Of Decoys Alight At the Peabody
LEAD: The most memorable carved and painted ducks, geese and shorebirds exhibited in ''Tollers and Tattlers: Massachusetts Waterfowl Decoys 1840-1940,'' at the Peabody Museum here, are rarely the prettiest or most realistic renderings.
Of the 193 decoys shown, the most compelling are the working varieties made for hunters, to pull birds from the sky.

Can Movies Teach History?
LEAD: Something strange - not new, but ever more conspicuous - haunts the cultural landscape.
Movie makers and television producers have become our most powerful, though perhaps not our most careful, historians.
It seems fair to say that more people are getting their history, or what they think is history, from the movies these days than from the standard history books.

LEAD: On the very first page of THE TITAN GAME by Niven Busch (Random House, $17.95), it is clear that we are in the presence of a real writer.
The topic is weapons. ''Never before in history had there been such a glut of weapons of all kinds: weapons lurking with eyes agleam in the black holes of outer space; weapons that could pop out of the void and kill at ten times the speed of sound; weapons as small as pinheads and as big as cathedrals; .


Fashion; Glamorous Comfort in Party Shoes
LEAD: Holiday shoes for men and women are ornate yet practical this season.
Women's shoes are lavishly embellished, but designed with low heels and high vamps.
For men, the fussy dance pump with its round toe and grosgrain bow is supplemented with daytime styles - lace-up or slip-on - made in elegant materials like faille, satin or gleaming patent leather.

Fright Mail
LEAD: More than a fib but less than a fraud - that's how one member of Congress describes a postal phenomenon known as ''fright mail.'' These are solicitations sent out by organizations with names like the ''Social Security Protection Bureau'' or the ''Internal Review Service,'' often in official-looking envelopes bearing the notice: ''Official Business.
