All 54 Aboard Survive Crash of a Jet in Seoul
LEAD: Twenty-one people were injured when a Korean Air Lines jet with 54 people on board crashed and caught fire on takeoff today from Kimpo Airport in Seoul, a spokesman said.


A Town Where the Mayor Oversees Crime
LEAD: The real crime capital of the world may be a small town nestled in a rural Virginia forest where bank robberies, kidnappings and deadly extortion plots are running rampant.
The town's mayor shrugs it off with a serene smile.


Andrew Young Going Afield to Run for Governor
LEAD: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta is aggressively traveling the state these days, buttonholing all who will listen to his plans for a run at the Governor's mansion in 1990.


Four 'Liaisons,' But Only One Is Dangereuse
At a cocktail party full of jazzy music, tinkling ice cubes and an aura of boozy flirtation, a French diplomat named Valmont stalks the room, making eyes at women wearing little black dresses.
His wife, Juliette, has plotted this event as part of her ambitious campaign to further her husband's career, but her sultry eyes are also on the lookout for desirable men.
They are cold-blooded opportunists with a notorious open marriage, these Valmonts, played by Jeanne Moreau and Gerard Philipe in a world-weary manner.
But, directed by the less-than-artistic Roger Vadim, this first screen version of ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' was hardly a timeless triumph.
In 1959, having earned a bad-boy reputation with ''And God Created Woman,'' Mr.
Vadim took up Choderlos de Laclos's classic 1782 novel of sexual manipulation and romantic war games and sent it skittering toward the 60's.
Here, when Valmont falls desperately in love with an apparently unattainable woman, she is a ski bunny with hair teased up like Brigitte Bardot's.


A Correction
LEAD: The name of one of the writers of a letter published Nov. 19 under the subheading ''Northern Bigotry'' did not appear correctly.
He is Michael J. Graetz, Justus S. Hotchkiss Professor of Law at Yale University.


The Bishop and the Truce of Tolerance
LEAD: The Roman Catholic Bishop of San Diego has denied communion to Lucy Killea, a state Assemblywoman, because as a candidate for California's Senate she strongly advocates the pro-choice position in the abortion debate.


Plan for a Community Of Laotians Stirs Debate
LEAD: A LAOTIAN immigrant, hoping to preserve Laotian heritage in his new country, wants to build a community of 25 homes for Laotian refugees in the small Tolland County town of Willington, but some residents see it as a shunning of American ways and plan to fight the proposal.


POSTINGS: TriBeCa Warehouse; From 4 Buildings, One
LEAD: Four 100-year-old buildings that had stood vacant for a decade on the eastern end of the block bounded by Laight, Vestry, Varick and Hudson Streets in TriBeCa have been renovated into a warehouse intended primarily for household goods.
Called the New York Security Mini Storage, the six-story facility near the Manhattan end of the Holland Tunnel that incorporates the adjacent buildings will have 28 Laight Street as its address.


Feeding Raccoons: Other Viewpoints
LEAD: I'd like to point out to Janet Pollak (''My 7 Visitors and How They Really Love to Eat,'' Opinion Page, Oct. 22) that one person's raccoon food is another person's decaying garbage.
I don't want to be labeled a curmudgeon, so I won't write about the human need for the unconditional love given by pets.

POSTINGS: West of Broadway; Rialto Rehabs
LEAD: Cleaning and dressing up the exteriors of two theaters just west of Broadway in Manhattan's rialto is costing their owner about $900,000.
The facade of the Ritz Theater, at 219 West 48th Street, has just been cleaned and renovated for $400,000 and the Virginia Theater, at 245 West 52d Street, is undergoing a more extensive facelift that will also replace the marquee and doors at a total cost of $500,000.

Will Cuts Help the Deficit?
LEAD: REDUCTIONS in military spending will not produce a pot of money for domestic programs any time soon.
Nor will the cuts make it easier for President Bush and Congress to lower the budget deficit next year.
The deficit problem is simply too daunting and potential Pentagon cuts too gradual to make much short-term difference.


The Nuclear Industry Tries Again
LEAD: Right now, the American nuclear power industry appears headed for extinction.
Every plant of the more than 100 ordered since 1973 has been canceled, and many others are approaching retirement.
But reactor manufacturers say that fears of global warming - the greenhouse effect - are giving them a second chance.

LEAD: Like Ken Russell, John Schlesinger and John Boorman, Tony Palmer is a graduate of the British Broadcasting Corporation in the 1960's: what has come to be seen, in retrospect, as the Golden Age of British television.
But where many of his former colleagues have become movie directors, Mr.
Palmer is best known as a maker of musical documentaries (including studies of Maria Callas, Benjamin Britten and William Walton) and feature-length portraits of composers (most recently Shostakovich in ''Testimony'').


Class Consciousness: The Pros and Cons
LEAD: The scrapbook-ready 1980's moment in ''Immediate Family,'' the film about a comfortable middle-class couple seeking to adopt the baby of an unwed lower-class teen-ager, is the one in which the prospective parents look at snapshots of the pregnant girl's family.
Her late mother, a lank-haired hippie, is seen standing beside a clothesline; her stepfather, a truck driver, is positioned in front of a small house with a factory in the background.

Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
LEAD: Frankly, I find soccer as exciting as watching ice melt.
The sport has evolved into a series of 0-0, 1-0, and 2-1 games.
Unless the rules and strategy open up to the point where a single goal is not something to riot over, I doubt the sport will ever capture the hearts and imagination of the American sports fan.

Pastimes; Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: If the Thanksgiving Day snow has melted, plant bulbs; they are better in the ground at this late date rather than tossed and forgotten in the back of a garage or toolshed.
Be sure the compost pile is securely piled so it does not blow down or away in winter storms.
Lightly prune rambler and climbing roses, if their canes are subject to wind damage.

Review/Theater; The Varieties of Life's Illumination, in 'Brightness'
LEAD: For Ping Chong, ''Brightness'' is an experiment in light and sound, a surrealistic canvas of nonserial images.
This new work (at La Mama Annex) is a small play of sensory but not intellectual stimulation.
As such, it should be considered a sidelight to Mr.
Chong's venturesome career as an author and director of conceptual theater.


Where the Brokers Are Still Smiling
LEAD: It's business as usual at A. G. Edwards &amp; Sons Inc. and, considering the cutbacks on Wall Street these days, that is pretty remarkable.
Take the branch near here in suburban Frontenac.
One recent day, as the markets remained lackluster, there was the hum of business in the air.
Phones were ringing, brokers were chatting up clients and plans were being made to find desks for people who had just been hired.

Collecting Objectivty
LEAD: FREUD DESCRIBED COLLECTORS AS MISERLY, PEDANTIC, STUBBORN and compulsively tidy.
And indeed, most do confess their boundless penchant for objects is, well, a little eccentric. ''Anybody who collects is obsessed,'' says Sue Railey, an international representative for Christie's who has spent most of her life scouring flea markets and junk shops around the world.

LEAD: Scott Barrie, who was known for designing sexy matte jersey dresses in the 1960's and 70's, has a new line and a whole new look.
After five years in Milan, working for Krizia, the Italian high-fashion house, he is now doing a collection of sportswear, knits and leather clothes under his own name.

LEAD: THE FOLLOWING IS THE RECORD OF a recent visit to East Berlin, at a time when the burst of freedom that greeted the opening of the borders to the West on Nov. 9 was still an anxiously held breath; when even the most optimistic could not imagine such a swift and fortunate denouement.

A second is filled with floor-to-ceiling shelves laden with files.

The Steel Band Goes Mainstream
LEAD: Conrad Jordan has a proprietary interest in the steel drum, which he describes as ''the only musical instrument invented in this century and the only musical instrument invented in the Western Hemisphere.'' For more than 25 years Mr.
Jordan has been tuning steel drums and has made a life's work out of studying how the drum - also known as a pan or steel piano - is made.

INSIDE THE INTIFADA
LEAD: The reference to Arabs lining up to find day work in '' 'slave markets' in Jerusalem'' is beneath contempt.
When longshoremen are picked out to unload ships in the United States, is this a ''slave market''?
If Arab contractors pick up laborers, is this a ''slave market''?
And at what hour would one expect laborers to line up if they expect to do a full days' work, if not before 8 A.M.?

A-Hunting They Will Go
LEAD: AT 5 A.M. on the William Floyd Parkway in Suffolk, no creatures are stirring, not even a raccoon.
It is so dark, so still, you don't know if it's morning or evening, and your body begs not to find out.

LEAD: Karel Urbanek, a Communist Party functionary unknown abroad and little known in his own nation before he was surprisingly chosen as Communist Party chief, found himself in his first day in office at the center of swelling criticism.
He was forced to go on television to appeal to the Czechoslovak nation for understanding.


Soaking in the Pashas' Pools
LEAD: Budapest is a bather's dream city.
Nowhere else in the world will you find this combination of a rich cultural life, magnificent architecture and good restaurants with endless possibilities for bathing and swimming in pools fed by thermal springs.


Correction

Leonid Kishkovsky, an Orthodox priest, described the National Council of Churches incorrectly.
It links 32 Christian denominations, not just Protestants.

Wallpaper Without Tears
LEAD: APPLYING wallpaper is no longer the tricky, messy task it once was.
Although stronger paper and slower-drying adhesives have eased the job considerably, achieving smooth-surfaced results still depends on preparing the wall carefully before applying the paper.

LEAD: Michael Harwood, an author and naturalist, died of an embolism Friday at the University of California at San Diego Medical Center, where he had undergone arterial surgery.
He was 55 years old and a resident of Washington, Conn.

Union Square: Gritty Past, Bright Future
LEAD: The people who live in the vicinity of Union Square are engaged in heated debate about the future of real estate development in their neighborhood.
Some equate development with progress, saying that until the last few years the area was regarded by many as having no future at all; others worry that too much development will ruin its social and architectural diversity.

Maybe the plan to issue a Deutsche Grammophon recording (427 686; CD and cassette) made it special; maybe the participation of James Levine (appearing for the first time in Japan) added a sense of occasion and pride.

INSIDE THE INTIFADA
LEAD: I looked carefully at the pictures that accompanied your article, and saw young men, their faces covered, armed with stones and firebombs.
They seemed well-dressed, in blue jeans and sweat shirts.
I did not see torn clothing; indeed, the general impression was one of strength and good health.


APPLE POLISHING
LEAD: I don't understand how Marcia Adams can say that the Apple Cake With Hot Caramel Sauce ''will keep for a week'' (Food: ''Apple Polishing,'' Oct. 8).
Only part of mine ever made it into the fridge, and that lasted only until the next day.
Thank you for a delicious recipe.
JOLA JAKIMIK  Evanston, Ill.

Foul-Ball Damages
LEAD: Few legal principles are as established as the one that holds that when you go to a baseball game you accept the risk of being hit by a foul ball.
Courts have held so over and over.
But that particular judicial word has not gotten through to a court in Chicago.
Last week, a Cook County Circuit Court jury awarded a 16-year-old boy, Delbert Yates Jr., $67,500 of Cubs money for damages suffered when he was hit by a foul ball at Wrigley

Talking: For Sale Signs; Imposing Viable Controls
LEAD: Until recently, few people made a fuss when a neighbor posted a ''For Sale'' sign on his front lawn, since it usually remained there for a just few weeks.
Moreover, the right to do so seemed - like the right to decorate a front yard at Christmas - indisputable.
It was, after all, a personal act on private property.

Government officials and Soviet diplomats, however, say the situations are not comparable.

L. A. Hyland, Radar Pioneer, 92; Howard Hughes's Top Executive
LEAD: Lawrence A. (Pat) Hyland, a pioneer in radar technology and aircraft communications who made the Hughes Aircraft Company an industrial giant, died at Antelope Valley Hospital here Friday after suffering a heart attack earlier in the week.
He was 92 years old and lived in this Los Angeles suburb.

LEAD: Much of Lebanon shut down today as President Rene Moawad was buried in his hometown in the country's north.

New York City Faulted on Slow Construction
LEAD: Less than one-tenth of New York City's municipal construction projects are completed on schedule, and more than half are not even under construction when they should be finished, according to a report by a private civic group.


POSTINGS: 21 Upscale Houses; Banker's Estate
LEAD: Part of the estate of Percy H. Johnston, a millionaire banker who died in 1957, is being developed into 21 upscale homes in Montclair, N.J.
Mr.
Johnston's five-bedroom home, which was built in 1940, was sold earlier this year for $400,000 and the 21 houses are to be built on eight surrounding acres.

LEAD: Eastern Airlines blamed striking machinists for bomb threats against a flight today, claiming that their union was trying to frighten travelers.

Another Side
LEAD: To the Editor:


Family Ties
LEAD: A dispute over who gave birth to 11-year-old Kimberly Michelle Mays has ended.
A point was proved, but nobody won.
Genetic tests showed 10 days ago that Kimberly was not the biological daughter of Robert and Barbara Mays, the Sarasota, Fla., couple who raised her from birth.
Mr.
Mays, whose wife died of cancer in 1981, broke his silence on the issue last week, saying that when he told Kimberly of the test results, ''She said, 'Daddy, daddy, what does this mean?


Review/Dance; It's 'Nutcracker' Season, And the Joffrey Is First
LEAD: ''The Nutcracker'' is back.
This year's first production of the winter holiday classic was that of the Joffrey Ballet, which danced it Friday afternoon and evening at the City Center Theater.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  WISDOM AND STRENGTH: The Biography of a Renaissance Masterpiece.
By Peter Watson. (Doubleday, $21.95.) ''An Allegory of Wisdom and Strength'' was painted by Paolo Veronese in 1576 near Venice and now hangs in the Frick Collection in New York City.
In this richly detailed book, Peter Watson traces the painting's remarkable existence through four turbulent centuries and illustrates the major developments in the collecting of old masters since the Renaissance.

Leonard Boudin, Civil Liberties Lawyer, Dies at 77
LEAD: Leonard B. Boudin, a civil liberties lawyer who in more than 50 years of practice defended a number of controversial clients, including Julian Bond, Paul Robeson, Benjamin Spock and Daniel Ellsberg, died at St.
Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan late Friday after a heart attack.
He was 77 years old.

Neo-Nebuchadnezzar
LEAD: THE RESTORATION OF THE CITY of Babylon is likely the most long overdue project in history.
It is the desire of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to restore from 2,000-year-old rubble (above, lower right) the glory of the city at its most glorious.
The was during the reign of Nebuchadnezzar, Babylonia's ruler from 605 to 562 B


A New Breed of Dieter Watches Weight at the Workpalce
LEAD: Men are more likely to join weight-control programs held at their workplace than those that meet in their community.
That is what the Diet Workshop branch in Dayton, Ohio, which is considered the fattest state, has discovered.
Males account for 33 percent of the 400 people enrolled in its workplace programs, but make up only 9 percent of the 3,200 dieters in its standard program.


State's Elderly Gain Influence As Lobby Group
LEAD: WHEN the House of Representatives approved a measure to expand the Medicare program to protect older Americans from the high cost of acute extended illness, all 14 members of the New Jersey delegation voted for it.
But when the House voted to repeal or curtail the Catastrophic Coverage Act last month, all 14 largely abandoned it.


Parents Debate Roles in AIDS Education
LEAD: A NEW state law that requires AIDS education in public schools is getting mixed reviews from parents.
Some say that such lessons should be taught at home and that the classes should stress abstinence rather than safe sex.
Other parents say they are relieved that the schools are offering AIDS classes.


Japan Will Help Poland and Hungary
LEAD: Responding to appeals from the Bush Administration and European nations, Japan has announced that it would provide $150 million in loans to Poland as an initial step to help both Poland and eventually Hungary deal with their financial crises and break loose from the Soviet bloc.


Wallpaper Without Tears
LEAD: APPLYING wallpaper is no longer the tricky, messy task it once was.
Although stronger paper and slower-drying adhesives have eased the job considerably, achieving smooth-surfaced results still depends on preparing the wall carefully before applying the paper.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing  Schneider Captures Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, the defending World Cup champion, who fell on her first run of the season Friday, turned in two flawless runs to win the women's slalom yesterday at Park City, Utah.
Schneider, who won 14 times last year, negotiated the 427-meter course at the Park City Ski Area in 47.77 seconds on her first run and in 46.88 on her second for a total of 1:34.65.


Thatcher Says She'll Lead Tories Two More Times
LEAD: Only weeks after she indicated that she was likely to step down in a few years as leader of the Conservative Party, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has announced that she is willing to lead the party into two more general elections.

U.S. May Cut Dues to U.N. Over Arab Resolution
LEAD: The United States will drastically cut funds to the Rome-based United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization if the agency agrees next week to cooperate with the Palestine Liberation Organization on agricultural development in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Administration officials say.


CONDUCT UNBECOMING?
LEAD: Representative John Dingell's singular ambition has been to expand his power base by grabbing any issue that is related to energy and commerce and letting loose his army of investigators.
Issues that do not interest the news media are discarded.
Mr.
Dingell needs to be taken down a peg, but none of the Democratic leadership has had the courage to rein in this modern day McCarthyite.


Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
LEAD: No.
The American sports mentality simply does not have the patience or attention span for a continuous-play game.
Half the fun of football, baseball, basketball, etc., is the time when there is no action.
During these breaks we argue over the pros and cons of our team's performance, go to the refrigerator, mull our ineptitude in this week's pool picks, and on and on.

LEAD: Carol M. Bassok, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Nathan Bassok of West Hartford, Conn., was married last evening to Michael B. Lowenstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Richard Lowenstein of Rye, N.Y.
Rabbi Daniel Wolk officiated at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.
Mrs.
Lowenstein, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, is a vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York.


Georgia Southern Subdues Villanova
LEAD: Joe Ross rushed for 190 yards and two touchdowns as Georgia Southern defeated Villanova, 52-36, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA playoffs.


In Italy, a Brooder Takes a Break
LEAD: Traveling alone has its pluses: you can go where you want when you want, and you are spared that runaway irritation that comes of suddenly spotting all the little flaws in your companion (who alone seems to be detaining you from perfect enjoyment) and the tension of having to keep that knowledge secret.


Rather Than Pork, Seafood and Beans
LEAD: PORK and beans is one thing, but fish with beans?
Now that people are trying to cut down on fat (even in winter, when we crave sustaining food), there is no reason not to serve seafood instead of the usual pork, duck or ham with dried beans and peas.

Liquid Protein: The Diet of the Stars
LEAD: Baby boomers may prefer the concept of weight control to the diet, but they still love a good fad.
Among the fastest-growing crazes to fight fat is the liquid protein diet, or very-low-calorie diet, as it is also known.
Sales of these liquid proteins have grown to $5 billion a year since the late 1970's.

Why Groovy Isn't Groovy Anymore
LEAD: By the end of 1990, record companies are saying, the vinyl LP will be mostly a memory.
Statistics are piling up: According to the Recording Industry Association of America, which monitors the larger companies, in the first half of 1989 LP's accounted for only 4 percent of the value of recordings shipped; in units, LP's were outnumbered 12 to 1 by cassettes and nearly 6 to 1 by CD's.

PARENTS AND CHILDREN
LEAD:  GROWING UP WRITING By Arlene Silberman. (Times Books, $18.95.) I wish this book had been available when my son came home from kindergarten last year, eagerly starting stories with the invented spelling he had learned through his school's ''Writing to Read'' program.
Despite my professional writing credentials and parental desire to see him enjoy writing as much as I do, in my compulsion to ''correct'' spelling and grammar I reacted like the benighted parents and educators Arlene Silberman indicts in her provocative and important new book.

Norrington's remarkable sensitivity to timbral niceties and to the composer's imagination as shaped by the actual instruments of his day.

All four of the works on the program were by living composers, but only one of the pieces was written this year - or, for that matter, in the 1980's.

After 30 Years, Japan Patents Chips
LEAD: Japan granted a patent that Texas Instruments Inc. had been seeking since 1960.
The patent covers the basic semiconductor chip, which the company's researchers invented in 1958.
The Tokyo decision requires all Japanese chip makers to pay royalties to Texas Instruments.
Japanese chip makers have about 90 percent of the Japanese chip market and 80 percent of the United States market.

Israel Plan to Sell Banks
LEAD: An Israeli Cabinet committee has approved a plan to equalize the voting rights of shares in all major Israeli banks, a crucial step toward selling them, a Finance Ministry spokesman said today.
There are currently two kinds of bank shares: normal shares with no control rights and special voting shares that have little financial value but give the owners control over the banks.

Domestic Car Sales Show Drop
LEAD: The nation's Big Three auto makers suffered serious sales declines in mid-November, while the so-called Japanese transplants posted sharp gains on far fewer sales.
Over all, sales of domestically produced cars slumped 6.1 percent, and light-truck sales dropped 1.7 percent, not quite so dismal a trend as during the early part of the month.

LEAD: he orbit of Solar Max, a 5,000-pound satellite that collected information on solar flares for nine years, has deteriorated to the point that the spacecraft should crash back to earth late this week, the space agency said today.

Southland Decides Not to Sell Division
LEAD: The Southland Corporation, the owner of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, said it had decided not to sell its distribution and food processing group, which had been put up for sale in March.
A spokeswoman said the company believed it would better maximize the value of these assets by owning them and profiting from their growth.


Award Urged for Gorbachev
LEAD: A group of Italian politicians, scientists and writers said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union should be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for inspiring a new concept in international relations.
Among those signing the appeal, made through an Italian-Soviet friendship association, were the novelist Alberto Moravia and Rita Levi-Montalcini, a neuroscientist who won the Nobel Prize for medicine in 1986.


How a British Ford Plant Became Productive Again
LEAD: In the early 1980's, the sprawling Ford Motor Company factory here was a microcosm of Britain's industrial ills.
There was so much turmoil at the inefficient and strife-ridden plant that the local newspaper, The Liverpool Echo, made daily calls to check for trouble.
When nothing happened, it was front-page news.

French Conduct Nuclear Test
LEAD: France today set off its largest underground nuclear blast this year, at Fangataufa in French Polynesia, New Zealand Government scientists said.
The 90-kiloton explosion was the fourth since testing resumed on Oct. 24.
It brings to 111 the number of underground tests at sites near Tahiti.

LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company will announce on Tuesday a set of computer programs to allow people to work together electronically even if they use different types of computers and different brands of software.

Blue Jays Sign Wilson To Two-Year Contract
LEAD: The Toronto Blue Jays announced yesterday they had signed Mookie Wilson to a two-year contract worth $2.95 million that includes an option year.
The deal calls for a $450,000 signing bonus and salaries of $900,000 in 1990 and $1.4 million in 1991.
The option year calls for a salary of $1.45 million or a $200,000 buyout.


City Opera Announces Some Changes of Plan
LEAD: Christopher Keene, the general director of the New York City Opera, announced his plans yesterday for 1990 and beyond, which include fewer, better-prepared productions with more cohesive casts and an emphasis on innovative repertory and direction.

Fed Signals No Easing; Bonds Sag
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board sent an extraordinary signal to credit market participants yesterday that it had not eased monetary policy last week, as had been commonly thought.
As a result, prices of Treasury securities sagged and short-term interest rates rose sharply.


Witness Links Killers of 6 Priests to Salvador's Armed Forces
LEAD: A woman described as a witness to the slayings of six Jesuit priests this month has provided the first sworn evidence linking the killers to the Salvadoran armed forces.
The judge investigating the slayings said today that he also thought that they had been committed by members of the armed forces.


Cezanne Sells for $17.3 Million, a Record
LEAD: Paul Cezanne's ''Apples and Tablecloth,'' a still life from 1879-80, was sold last night in London for $17.3 million to a collector who was not identified.
The price was a record for a work by the artist.


Prehistoric Pottery
LEAD: Anthropologists have concluded that the Stone Age people who invented ceramic technology about 26,000 years ago probably designed clay figurines to explode when fired rather than intending the statuettes to be artistic works.

Mitterrand Cites Drug Threat
LEAD: President Francois Mitterrand opened a new Interpol headquarters today with a warning on the peril generated by the international drug traffic. ''Every state must fight back if we do not want to collectively record a failure for civilization,'' the French President said.
The annual General Assembly of Interpol, the International Criminal Police Organization, starts on Tuesday in Lyons, where Interpol moved its headquarters from its Paris base.


Carl C. Dauterman, Art Curator
LEAD: Carl C. Dauterman, curator emeritus of Western European art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died of lymphoma on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Democracy Speaks in India
LEAD: What most distinguishes a democracy is the people's right to reject those in power.
In India, the world's largest democracy and the third world's most durable, voters have done just that, denying a majority to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party.
They gave no clear mandate to any single political force but everywhere vented their anger at incumbents for corruption, inequality, religious discord and a variety of local failures.

LEAD: Suddenly the sound of machine-gun fire is heard on the edges of Wenceslas Square in Prague.
The huge crowd of peaceful demonstrators packed into the great open space begins pushing and screaming.

LEAD: Oil ministers of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries continued today to seek a production quota they can all abide by.

Surgery for Treasury Secretary
LEAD: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady will undergo elective surgery to replace his hip on Dec. 14 and will be out of the office for three to six weeks, the Department of the Treasury said today.
While he is recuperating, Deputy Secretary John E. Robson will be in charge of the department.
Mr.
Brady, 59 years old, has suffered from arthritis in his right hip for years, and has recently walked with a pronounced limp.


Panel Replaces Senate Counsel In H.U.D. Case
LEAD: The Senate Ethics Committee said today that it had appointed a new outside counsel to investigate accusations that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato may have improperly lobbied Federal housing officials on behalf of campaign contributors.


Correction
LEAD: An article in The Connecticut Weekly on Sunday about AIDS education misstated the response of a New Canaan public school official to a parent's charge that condoms had been distributed in a pilot program at New Canaan High School.
The official, James Comer, district health education coordinator, said students had never been given condoms.


First Lady Scheduled For Eye Exam Today
LEAD: Barbara Bush will be examined on Tuesday by eye specialists at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., for a thyroid disorder that continues to give her vision problems, her office said today.

LEAD: A leader of the Russian Orthodox Church met with Pope John Paul II today, asserting that extremists in the Ukrainian Catholic Church have been causing violence and endangering reconciliation talks between the two faiths.

LEAD: The Canadian financier James A. Pattison and a group of companies that he controls have acquired a 9.37 percent stake in the IPCO Corporation, which operates the Sterling Optical eyewear chain.

LEAD: Jerry R. Curry took office today as Administrator of the National Highway TrafSafety Administration, the nation's top highway safety official.
He said he would seek to reduce highway deaths by emphasizing seat belt use and curbing drunken driving.

Curry, 57 years old, a retired Army major general, was nominated by President Bush for the post and the Senate confirmed him this month.

LEAD: A 10-year-old boy who was struck in the head by a golf ball has died of his injuries.

Thomas Garrick of the Fairhope police said.
The boy died Saturday at University of South Alabama Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said today.

Martha Wallace, 61; Business Consultant Led Big Foundation
LEAD: Martha Redfield Wallace, a management consultant who was a director of many corporations, died of a heart attack Friday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 61 years old.
She was the founder in 1983 of a consulting business, Redfield Associates, which helped to raise money for many causes.
Its headquarters were in River House at 435 East 52d Street.


Uruguay's Mixed Election Result May Lead to Conflict
LEAD: After national elections on Sunday in which a centrist, Luis Alberto Lacalle, was elected President while a Marxist coalition gained control of the Montevideo city government, Uruguayans now say the stage is set for a sharp conflict.


Paribas Lifts Bid
LEAD: The merchant bank Compagnie Financiere de Paribas said it had raised its formal offer price for Compagnie de Navigation Mixte, a holding company with interests in insurance and banking, to 1,887 francs a share from the initial 1,850.
Francois Morin, Paribas's vice chairman, said the 2 percent increase was automatically initiated under French takeover rules after the financial group bought Mixte shares on the open market for more than its formal bid price this morning.

LEAD: The Jets had a problem Sunday: The Atlanta Falcons had the National Football League's worst rushing offense and worst rushing defense and the Jets didn't want to do anything to change that.

Oil Rig Count Dips by 3
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped last week by 3, to 1,037, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
It was the second weekly decline after a string of gains.
But the total number of working rigs still reflects 126 more than for the corresponding week a year ago.

LEAD: The Oakland Athletics traded Rickey Henderson to the Yankees five years ago because he was approaching free agency and they did not want to pay what it would have taken to keep him.
They got him back earlier this year, and they are not going to let him get away again.


Koch to Join Ethics Panel
LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch, whose re-election quest was hurt by corruption scandals in his administration, was named today to a special panel that will advise local governments on ethics.

LEAD: The Soviet Union and the 12-nation European Community reached agreement today on a 10-year trade pact that would ease European quotas for Soviet goods and increase technical cooperation.

LEAD: Jim Fassel, whose teams compiled a 25-33 record in his five years as head coach at the University of Utah, was dismissed yesterday, three days after the Utes completed a 4-8 season. Louis, which three weeks ago was the first to announce a cut in its prime lending rate to 10 percent, said yesterday that it was raising the rate back to 10 1/2 percent ''at least on a temporary basis.''

LEAD: A chronology on Saturday about developments in Eastern Europe dated several political events in Hungary incorrectly.
Janos Kadar, the Communist leader, stepped down on May 22, 1988, not 1989; the Communist Party was formally disbanded on Oct. 7, 1989, not 1988, and the constitution was amended to allow a multiparty system on Oct.

When he left, he was escorted to jail.

Economic Scene; Shifting Spending To Public Works
LEAD: THE upheaval in Eastern Europe, with its greater openness to the West, means to many Americans that the United States no longer needs a huge military establishment.
The Bush Administration, in fact, is beginning to shrink the $300 billion military budget.
But if billions of dollars are diverted from military spending over the next decade, how should the money be spent?


Parkway Honors Clara Barton
LEAD: President Bush today signed legislation renaming the Maryland and Washington parts of the George Washington Memorial Parkway the Clara Barton Parkway.
The name change is intended both to honor the Civil War nurse who organized the American Red Cross in 1881 and to help motorists who confused the Maryland-District stretch of the parkway with the longer, better known portion of the George Washington Memorial Parkway on the Virginia side of the Potomac River.

LEAD: Priscilla Robertson, an author, a historian and a teacher, died of a stroke on Sunday at Humana Hospital-Suburban in Louisville, Ky.
She was 79 years old.

LEAD: At least five people were killed here this morning when a construction crane collapsed in the financial district, slamming into two nearby buildings, crushing several cars and two buses and leaving the area strewn with twisted metal, crushed concrete and shattered glass.

LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. said it had filed a revised reorganization plan with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Western Pennsylvania.


EATING WELL
LEAD: DR.
JEAN MAYER has been the president of Tufts University for 13 years, but he is still well known as a nutritionist.
He secured his place in the nutrition hall of fame when he was chairman of the first White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health in 1969.
At the time, the French-born, much-decorated World War II artillery officer with the Free French forces was a professor of nutrition at Harvard University.

Trident 2 Test Threatened
LEAD: Members of the anti-nuclear protest group Greenpeace will try to halt the launching of a Trident 2 missile from a submarine off the Florida coast, a spokeswoman said today.
The spokeswoman, Shannon Fagan, said the launching was set for Friday, but the Navy declined to confirm or deny it.
Greenpeace was successful in stopping a Trident 2 test from a submarine last July, maneuvering small rafts close enough to the vessel to attach protest banners to its hull and mast.

LEAD: President Bush declared today that he does not intend to strike a deal that would sharply reduce troop levels in Europe when he meets this weekend with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President.

LEAD: A state judicial panel today censured a Dallas judge who said he had given a lighter sentence to a killer because the victims were ''queers'' looking for teen-age boys.

LEAD: The Cuomo administration is planning a major push to expand New York State's drug treatment network to treat 10,000 more addicts, state officials said today.

LEAD: The ceiling on the size of single-family home loans purchased by the nation's largest secondary mortgage-market agency is declining by $150, to $187,450 next year, the first drop in at least a decade, the agency said today.

Mary the Virgin, 139 West 46th Street.
There will be two performances each night, at 7 and 9:15.
The work is based on medieval manuscripts from Spain, France, Italy and England, with music composed over a period of 400 years.

An Outline of German History
LEAD:  1815 After the Congress of Vienna redrew the map of Europe with the defeat of Napoleon, the main German states grouped themselves into a loose association of 39 kingdoms, duchies, principalities and free cities known as the German Confederation.
It was dominated by Prussia and Austria.  1834 The states formed a German Customs Union with free trade, which brought economic growth.

Gen.

At his death Soane left a rich array of buildings, including two unquestioned masterworks: the headquarters of the Bank of England, which was altered beyond recognition by Sir Herbert Baker in 1925, and his own house and office at 13 Lincoln's Inn Fields, which remains essentially as he left it, open to the public as Sir John

Hungarian Says Trade Will Double
LEAD: Hungary's Minister of Trade predicted today that the United States' recent decision to grant most-favored-nation tariff treatment to Hungary would contribute to a doubling of two-way trade, to $1 billion a year, by the early 1990's.

Wherein Balloons Teach the Learning Process
LEAD: Try this: Place a tiny mirror flat against a wall and guess where two people must stand so each can see the other's reflection.
Then explain why.

LEAD: Joseph T. Nall, a member of the National Transportation Safety Board, was killed Monday in the crash of a small plane in Caracas, Venezuela, board officials said today.

LEAD: Nearly 600 arts institutions throughout the United States plan to observe ''A Day Without Art'' on Friday to draw attention to the effects of AIDS on the arts community.


OPEC Sets New Policy On Quotas
LEAD: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided tonight to revise its quota system in a fundamental way that would give Persian Gulf oil producers a firm grip on prices and production in the next decade.

LEAD: The Aristech Chemical Corporation said its board had voted to reject a proposal by Huntsman Holdings Inc. of Salt Lake City to acquire Aristech for $25 a share.

Polaroid Venture
LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation said it was developing electronic medical imaging equipment for hospitals.
The company said the products, which are to be available in 1991, would record images from electronic diagnostic tools, quickly giving doctors pictures of internal organs and other body parts.


Medieval Book of Kells Printed in Switzerland
LEAD: The Book of Kells, a medieval masterpiece that ranks as one of the world's most beautiful illuminated manuscripts, has been printed almost 12 centuries after it was created.


Knicks Back Out West
LEAD: The Knicks yesterday flew to the West Coast, where they will open a four-game trip tonight against the Golden State Warriors in Oakland, Calif.
Going into their game with the Nuggets in Denver last night, the Warriors, who posted a 43-39 record last season, a 23-game improvement over the year before, were off to a 3-8 start.


Oil, a Foundation of Alaska, Works to Rebuild Its Image
LEAD: For four days last month, the State of Alaska refused to allow an oil tanker to discharge her cargo at a refinery 100 miles south of here in Kenai.
In a state that owes its prosperity and indeed its existence in large part to oil, the event was a jarring one.


Dow Rises 7.04 as Light Trading Continues
LEAD: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing above 2,700, after languishing in a slightly higher range throughout most of the session.

LEAD: One-ring circuses from the United States, France, Switzerland and Canada are the subject of a photography show that will be on view through Jan. 27 at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center.

Easing Seen In Food Costs
LEAD: Consumer food prices will rise at a much slower pace in 1990 as farmers continue to expand their crop production, a senior Agriculture Department economist predicted today.


Victorian Era: Holiday Images For All Times
LEAD: HOLIDAYS reinforce links to the past, and not necessarily one's own.
As December rolls around, the bygone era most often dusted off is the 19th century, especially as it unfolded in Victorian England.
This season the image seems more pervasive than ever.


'General Winter'
LEAD: Quite literally, the weather this winter can change history.
That has happened twice in Europe since World War II, once for the worse and once for the better.

Edith S. Stevens, 90, Volunteer for Agency
LEAD: Edith S. Stevens, a volunteer for Planned Parenthood of Union County, N.J., died of a stroke on Nov. 22 at her home in Plainfield, N.J.
She was 90 years old.


New Jersey Sets Guidelines on Video Terminals
LEAD: With almost half of the 500,000 public employees in New Jersey spending time in front of video-display terminals, the State Health Department today issued guidelines intended to eliminate hazards that can cause injury and stress.

LEAD: When Col.
Lansana Conte seized power in Guinea five years ago, he vowed to restore law and order to a nation that had endured nearly three decades of nightmarish repression, purges and bloodshed.


Treasury Issues Little Changed
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday as dealers placed bids at an auction of $10 billion worth of two-year notes.


After Eastern Europe's Spring
LEAD: The end of history?
The remarkable uprisings in Eastern Europe are more like a resumption of history.
As Hungarians plan their first free elections since World War II, demonstrators in Czechoslovakia quote Thomas Jefferson and chant the name of Alexander Dubcek, who failed heroically in 1968 to bring reform.


Justices Uphold U.S. Right to Fee for Deciding Claims Against Iran
LEAD: In a legal footnote to the Iran hostage crisis, the Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the Federal Government's authority to keep for itself a small part of the compensation won by American companies in a special court set up to handle claims against Iran.


Change in S.&amp;P. Index
LEAD: The Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation said this week that it would remove the Noxell Corporation from its 500-stock index at the close of trading tomorrow.
Noxell is being acquired by the Procter &amp; Gamble Company.
St Jude Medical Inc. will be added to the index.


Official's Trips Home Cost T.V.A. $172,700
LEAD: The Tennessee Valley Authority paid $172,700 to fly a top manager between his home in Virginia and his office in Tennessee over a one-year period, a Congressional report says.


Long Term in Gay Man's Death
LEAD: A high school football star was sentenced today to 40 years in prison for his part in the beating death of a gay man from Wethersfield.


Delta Raising Some Fares
LEAD: Delta Air Lines Inc. joined other leading airlines yesterday in raising domestic fares by $5 to $8 a trip.
Analysts said the ticket increases were aimed mostly at business travelers.

Tests on First Lady Find Eye Condition Remains Unchanged
LEAD: Barbara Bush learned today after two hours of tests at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., that her thyroid disease is not improving, although it has not worsened, her spokeswoman said.


IMMUNITY AN ISSUE IN ALASKAN SPILL
LEAD: Capt.
Joseph J. Hazelwood's contention that he is immune from prosecution for sailing the Exxon Valdez onto the rocks of Prince William Sound last March is being fought out in a state court here, two months before his trial is to start.


High Court in Maine Outlaws Riverblocks
LEAD: The State Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that armed state officials who were trying to stop illegal and rowdy conduct on the popular Saco River in southern Maine had no right to set up a ''riverblock'' last year to stop and search canoeists there.


2 U.S. Towers At Foley Sq. Will Avoid Review Steps
LEAD: Worried that full public review might seriously delay or even derail their plan to build two large civic buildings in lower Manhattan, the Federal Government and New York City have agreed to sidestep that process.


Baseball Talks Begin Cordially
LEAD: On the same day they officially announced the departure of their longtime chief labor lawyer, representatives of baseball's club owners opened talks with the players' bargaining team yesterday calling for an end to the hostility that has raged between them.


Water Club's Ex-Manager Guilty of Embezzlement
LEAD: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a former manager of the Water Club restaurant in Manhattan embezzled at least $485,000 while he ran the restaurant from 1983 to 1986.


McCaw Offers to Sweeten Its Bid for Lin
LEAD: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said today that it would make its offer for the Lin Broadcasting Corporation more attractive, if the New York-based cellular telephone company would accept a friendly transaction.
Lin, trying to fight off McCaw's advances, has agreed to merge with the BellSouth Corporation.

LEAD: Hundreds of philosophy students crammed into the second floor at Charles University today to discuss with their deans and professors how the department's curriculum could be changed to make it less doctrinaire.

Which Is Cheaper, $1.11 or $1.15?
LEAD: In a kinder world, New York's present $1 bus and subway fare would stay right there.
But that's neither realistic nor prudent.
The cost of living has gone up 22 percent since the last fare increase, in 1986, and so has the cost of operating the transit system.
That means fares or government transit subsidies must go up.

Topics of the Times; The I.R.A., You Say?
LEAD: For several months rumors have circulated in Britain and the U.S. that McDonald's, the fast-food chain, has given financial support to the Irish Republican Army through Noraid, the I.R.A.'s North American fund-raising group.
McDonald's itself couldn't figure where the implausible charge came from, and denied it flatly at every opportunity.


Bridge
LEAD: Earlier this week this column fell victim to an ambiguity and understated the role of women in the last three decades in the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship.
The Official Encyclopedia record lists John Solodar, who went on to become a world champion, as a runner-up in 1974, but it was actually his wife at the time, Judi Solodar, who as Judi Radin has since won three world titles.

John's University for 39 years until he retired in 1973, died on Tuesday at his home in Largo, Fla., after a long illness.

Corrections
LEAD: The Market Place column in Business Day on Tuesday, about stock custody services for investors, referred incorrectly in some editions to the fee typically charged by a bank for this service.
It is generally 2.5 basis points of the portfolio value. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)

LEAD: Business and labor advisers to the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, called on the White House today to give the ''highest priority'' to streamlining its export controls.

Frederick Kingsbury, Banker, Is Dead at 82
LEAD: Frederick Hutchinson Kingsbury Jr., a general partner in the private banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman &amp; Company, died Monday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 82 years old.


Books of The Times; The Best Picture Books Of the Year for Children
LEAD: The challenge of picking the year's best children's picture books is daunting.
As Ralph Waldo Emerson once observed, ''St.
Peter's cannot have the magical power over us that the red-and-gold covers of our first picture book possessed.'' None of the following 11 books have an exclusively red-and-gold cover, nor can I swear that any of them will surpass the power of a work of Renaissance architecture in the eye the young beholder.


U.S. Staff Told To Take Refuge In San Salvador
LEAD: In the face of a new rebel attack here in the capital, the United States Embassy today urged its officers, contract employees and dependent families to leave their homes for safer quarters on embassy property.
It also offered to grant special leaves to diplomatic personnel who wished to leave the country.

Market Place; Flight From 'Junk Bonds' Appears to Be Losing Steam
LEAD: The flight from ''junk bond'' funds seems to be slowing, some mutual fund managers said yesterday as industry figures showed that about 9 percent of the assets in those funds was withdrawn in the four months through October.
Indeed, October was the worst month ever for junk bond funds as $1.2 billion poured out of the funds.


A-PLANT IS CLOSING FOR SAFETY REVIEW
LEAD: The Energy Department announced today that it was temporarily shutting down the buildings at the Rocky Flats Plant in Colorado that are the nation's only source of purified plutonium for nuclear weapons.
The department said it would use the time to take an inventory of plutonium and to resolve safety, management and environmental problems.


California Water Negotiations Will Consider Environment
LEAD: Under strong political pressure, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. announced today that environmental factors would be taken into account when the Federal Government negotiates the renewal of water supply contracts with farmers in California's Central Valley.


Topics of The Times; Floating Anchors
LEAD: What's an anchorman?
The term, also rendered as the gender-neutral anchor, has won dictionary recognition; it refers to a television personality who coordinates all the reports on a news broadcast.
But even as the word wins formal acceptance, events are draining away its meaning.
This has become the era of floating anchors.


A Moment of Decision At the Kennedy Center
LEAD: The announcement last month by the board of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts that it would not renew the contract of Ralph P. Davidson, the center's chairman and president, underlines the special problems of that gleaming culture palace on the banks of the Potomac.


Finally a Tenant for Governor's Mansion
LEAD: Eight years after it was designated the official residence of New Jersey's governors, the 19th-century Greek Revival mansion called Drumthwacket will soon have its first tenants.


Banks Are Upheld on Insurance Business
LEAD: Efforts by independent insurance agents to keep commercial banks out of the insurance business were set back yesterday in a decision by the United States Court of Appeals in New York.


3 Linemen Are Finalists
LEAD: Moe Gardner, a nose tackle from Illinois; Mohammed Elewonibi, an offensive guard from Brigham Young, and Michael Tanks, a center from Florida State, were named finalists yesterday for the Outland Trophy as the country's top lineman.
The winner will be announced Dec. 6.
The voting is by the Football Writers Association of America.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The economy grew at a moderate rate of 2.7 percent in the July-September quarter, slightly higher than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said.
Most private analysts predicted a sharply weaker performance in the final three months of the year and the first quarter of 1990.


Topics of The Times; Where Do Men Come From?
LEAD: To some it is a redundancy, to others a logical necessity and to still others an excrescence on higher education.
It is called ''men's studies,'' and it is said to be enjoying growing popularity on the campus.


Review/Television; Inventing Las Vegas In 'The Neon Empire'
LEAD: Showtime's two-part, four-hour movie ''The Neon Empire,'' which will have its premiere on the pay-cable service at 9 P.M. on Sunday and Monday, is an ambitious package with a promising subject: the creation in the 1940's of glittering Las Vegas out of a dusty Nevada town on the road to Los Angeles.


Clamor in the East; Party Orthodoxy Falters In a Yugoslav Republic
LEAD: Milan Kucan and Joze Pucnik share the sense that something basic needs to change in Yugoslavia.
And though they came to this view from divergent poles of power and oppression, they have drawn conclusions that evoke one of Eastern Europe's most tantalizing dilemmas: can Communist rulers instill reform without reforming themselves into oblivion?


McEnroe Whines, Baits, Stalks And Wins
LEAD: The Masters was treated last night to its first dose in three years of its favorite - if irreverent - son, John McEnroe, and the great gesticulator did not disappoint.

Review/Theater; Father and Son's Sentimental Bluegrass Musical
LEAD: ''Feast Here Tonight'' is a Kentucky blend of bluegrass music and tales about stranded turtles, lazy dogs, pumpkin pies and angels that speak to mules.
The atmosphere is congenial, almost everyone plays a fiddle or a guitar and the sentiment is as thick as the elderberry jam that figures so prominently in the text.


Government of Laws?
LEAD: In the tumult of our joy at what is happening in Czechoslovakia, a small cold irony is passing almost unnoticed.
Just as the Czechs move toward democracy, we have taken a step toward arbitrary, unaccountable government power.

LEAD: The Erick Hawkins Dance Company opened its weeklong season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) on Tuesday night with an exhilaratingly upbeat program of new and recent dance.
The lives of artists may be all too brief, but their particular art can grow and change in remarkable ways during those life spans.

Europe 'Dumping' Move
LEAD: The European Community's Executive Commission said today that it was investigating a complaint of ''dumping'' by China of silk used to make typewriter ribbons.
The community's only producer of the silk, Spinnhuette G.m.b.H. of West Germany, contended that the China National Silk Import and Export Corporation sold the material at artificially low prices.

Review/Television; Profiles of Burton and Gary Cooper
LEAD: Having rerun most old movies, whether classic or trash, to the point of exhaustion, television is exploring new ways to market or repackage the same material.
There is, for instance, coloring black-and-white movies.
And increasingly there are the biographical essays that focus on one personality.
Mixing film clips with fact, interviews with speculation, these collections offer the subjects and their lives as metaphors for our times, indeed our century.

Next Inc. Outlook
LEAD: Steven P. Jobs, the president of Next Inc., said that his company was shipping thousands of its work stations this year and that it expected to ship tens of thousands of them next year.
He told industry officials that half of the 100 largest American companies had been testing the new machines and that a half-dozen new applications programs were expected by next spring at $600 to $700 each.

Close to Home
LEAD: SUDDENLY, it seemed to me that I needed a change of scene, if only for a few days.
That I couldn't bear to look any longer on dirt and disorder, that I wanted to bathe in some sea of tranquillity.
So I went to a little island and wandered along beaches and boardwalks lined with deer so tame they all but asked for a pat on the nose.

Warming of Earth Is Slowed, Scientist Says
LEAD: The major climate changes that may result from the warming of the earth's atmosphere are being delayed by 20 years because the use of the gases thought to cause the warming has been reduced, a space agency scientist says.

LEAD: The Ethiopian Government and one of the rebel groups opposing it said today that they had agreed on procedures for substantive peace talks to begin early next year.

Toyota Plant Starts
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation said its automobile plant in Georgetown, Ky., began producing engines for its Camry models, which in the future would be exported to Japan.
Toyota, Japan's largest auto maker, said annual production at the plant would rise to 300,000 vehicles in 1992.
The plant has 3,000 employees and produces 200,000 Camry sedans a year.

50 MX Missiles Are to Be Shifted to Trains in 7 States
LEAD: The Air Force announced today that seven states had been selected as sites for the 50 MX nuclear missiles that will be removed from silos and placed on trains to make them less vulnerable to a surprise enemy attack.

LEAD: On the eve of the Malta summit meeting, Administration officials have concluded that the Soviet leader, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has in essence written off Eastern Europe and no longer feels that direct control there is essential for Soviet security.

LEAD: At least seven parties have expressed interest in buying a large part of the American Express Company's stake in Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. as part of a deal to inject capital into the investment house, Wall Street sources said yesterday.


Aer Lingus Switch
LEAD: Aer Lingus, the Irish national airline, yesterday switched its advertising account from Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos to the New York office of Campbell-Mithun-Esty.
Bernie Lynch, the passenger marketing manager of Aer Lingus, would not disclose the budget of the account or say why it had been moved.

LEAD: As Governor Mario M. Cuomo proved by hinting and hedging his way through New York City's Democratic mayoral primary, even the subtlest suggestion of favor from the Governor's mansion can send a booming echo through City Hall.

LEAD: Posey Quest Genova, a small Connecticut agency, said yesterday that it had dissolved, with TBWA Advertising buying a share of the agency to merge into its New York office.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that unauthorized disclosures to reporters had prompted him to order a complete review of Justice Department press guidelines to tighten the release of information.

John F. Grady, Surgeon, 87
LEAD: Dr.
John F. Grady, a retired surgeon, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn.
He was 87 years old.
He practiced in Manhattan from 1933 to 1974, when he retired.
He had been an attending surgeon at the French Hospital in Manhattan and a director of the French Polyclinic Hospital.

LEAD: A New York City public school gym teacher with a criminal record, including a conviction for public indecency involving a minor, was arrested yesterday in the Bronx, prompting an investigation into how he was hired for a system that is supposed to run extensive background checks on new teachers.

Importance of Test-Driving Skis
LEAD: Test-driving a pair of skis before laying out $300 to $500 would seem to be a sensible idea, but most skiers base their buying decisions on such superficial things as color, price or a friend's recommendation.
Equipment manufacturers have for several years been trying to counter this method by providing skis for free tests.

LEAD: Explosives experts at Los Angeles International Airport today blew up a suitcase bound for Bogota, Colombia, that was suspected of containing a bomb.

Club's Limit on Women Upheld, Grudgingly
LEAD: A judge said today that a golf club's policy to restrict women's tee-off times was repugnant and offensive but legal.
The judge, Edward McCarty of Nassau County Court, said he was powerless to order a change because the club, Cedar Brook in Old Brookville, is private.

LEAD: The Comptroller General told Congress today that the Federal Government, riddled with serious management problems at every large agency, faced more than $100 billion in losses.

LEAD: Argentina, Belgium, Brazil, Italy, Spain and West Germany will be the seeded teams for the 1990 World Cup, the president of soccer's world governing body said in an interview published today.

Clamor in the East; On Course for Malta: Three Decades of Statecraft
LEAD:  September 1959: President Eisenhower and Nikita S. Khrushchev meet at Camp David, Md.
The talks result in the ''Spirit of Camp Daivd,'' an effort to press for scientific and cultural exchanges and disarmament.
May 1960: Eisenhower and Khrushchev go to Paris.
But the Soviet leader, angry after his country sights and downs an American U-2 spy plane over the Soviet Union, cancels the meeting.


Clamor in the East; Malta, Speck Among Nations, Ends Military Links to Libya
LEAD: After being bartered, seized or bullied by almost every power in the Mediterranean, Malta has turned another page, this one peaceful, in its history.

The Lavoro Scandal
LEAD: A parade of F.B.I., I.R.S. and Customs agents, accompanied by Justice Department lawyers and the Inspector General of the Department of Agriculture, have been descending on the office of the U.S.
Attorney in Atlanta to help with what Federal lawmen say is a ''long-term investigation'' into what international bankers call ''the Lavoro affair.

Clamor in the East; Spirit of 1968 Is Still Alive, Still Distinct
LEAD: ''You remember the spirit of 1968,'' said a science writer who left her country that year for exile in West Germany.
She came back last weekend for three days, bringing her young daughter, so that she, too, could see ''our second revolution.''


Arab Foreign Ministers Meet On P.L.O.'s Call for Support
LEAD: Arab foreign ministers met in Tunis tonight at the request of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which wants them to renew the broad Arab commitment to the P.L.O. as a central player in Middle East diplomacy.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  SKIING  Italian Wins Slalom: Alberto Tomba of Italy won the second slalom of the World Cup season yesterday by 1.73 seconds in Waterville Valley, N.H.
Tomba easily won both heats in times of 57.96 and 58.28 for a total of 1 minute 56.24 seconds.
His closest challenger in each test was Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, who was more than one second behind after a first run of 59.15 seconds.(AP)

Lottery Ads to Dailey
LEAD: After a review that included three other agencies, Dailey &amp; Associates retained the $50 million advertising account of the California State Lottery.
The Los Angeles agency, a unit of the Interpublic Group, edged out Chiat/Day/Mojo and the Los Angeles offices of BBDO and J. Walter Thompson after a review process mandated by state law, said Phillip Joanou, the agency's chairman.


DEALS
LEAD:  BASKETBALL  LOS ANGELES CLIPPERS (NBA) -Activated Danny Manning, forward, from the injured list.
Waived Carlton McKinney, guard.
FOOTBALL  NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Waived Undra Johnson, running back.
Signed Bobby Morris, running back.


Doubts on Japanese Deal for Bloomingdale's
LEAD: Several new twists have been added to the attempts to organize a buyout of Bloomingdale's with Japanese investors.
The American retail store's chairman said all was going well, but two potential buyers expressed misgivings about the price being asked.


97 by Sooners Set Mark (for a Half!)
LEAD: Oklahoma missed four chances at college basketball's first 100-point half before settling for a record 97 tonight on the way to crushing U.S.
International, 173-101.


Makela Goes to Kings
LEAD: Mikko Makela, the right wing who scored 95 goals and was credited with 124 assists in 307 National Hockey League games for the Islanders since he was a fifth-round draft choice in 1983, was traded to the Los Angeles Kings yesterday for Ken Baumgartner, a defenseman, and Hubie McDonough, a rookie center.


Ewing and Knicks Pound Warriors
LEAD: Patrick Ewing scored a season-high 44 points and grabbed a career-high 24 rebounds as the Knicks started a four-game Western trip with a 129-111 victory over the Golden State Warriors tonight.


Dow Drops By 13.23, To 2,688.78
LEAD: Stock prices fell across a broad front yesterday as traders concluded there was no possibility of an imminent cut in interest rates.


Survey Finds Split on Abortion Persisting
LEAD: Americans remain sharply divided over the abortion issue, with 41 percent saying abortion should be ''generally available'' and 42 percent supporting stricter limits than currently exist, according to a New York Times/CBS News survey.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''We don't want the monopoly of one party to continue.''  - Vasil Mohorita, a new member of the Czechoslovak Communist Politburo.  [ A1:6. ]


Just What Does Congress Do to Merit a Raise?
LEAD: To the Editor:


Court Blocks Execution of Slayer With I.Q. of 76 Who Killed at 17
LEAD: The Supreme Court today blocked the execution of Dalton Prejean, who was due to die early Thursday in Louisiana for killing a state trooper when Mr.
Prejean was 17 years old.


Dorothy Bowles, Social Worker, 86
LEAD: Dorothy Stebbins Bowles, a social worker and former chairwoman of the Board of Education in Essex, Conn., died yesterday at her home in Essex.
She was 86 years old.
A 1928 graduate of Smith College, Mrs.
Bowles was the widow of Chester B. Bowles, who served as Ambassador to India and Governor of Connecticut.


U.S. Plane Aiding Guerrillas In Angola Reported to Crash
LEAD: A C.I.A. plane carrying military and other equipment from Zaire to American-backed rebels in Angola crashed this week, killing at least five Americans and an undetermined number of insurgents, Government officials said today.


Fiat Called Set For Bid to Saab
LEAD: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian car maker, is prepared to offer more than five billion kronor, or about $780 million, for 51 percent of the car division of Sweden's Saab-Scania A.B., Swedish Radio reported today.
Quoting unnamed sources, Swedish Radio said the Wallenberg family, which is Saab's largest single shareholder, was willing to let Saab sell a majority stake in the division.
